author: aniruddhabonny
title: A blood-crawling, gut wrenching, exhilarating movie!
text: This is how I want to see a spy/espionage movie in Indian cinema. Excellent world and character building, with outstanding set pieces. Every single actor played their roles to perfection! Askhay Khanna stands out the most. However, as others mentioned, the role of Ranveer was not to stand out in the first place, and the director and actor executed that perfectly!

author: gk303007
title: After a long time, a good espionage movie
text:
Well, well, well... Pathan, War 2, Singham, and so on and so forth. Pathan was Shahrukh's comeback and we all know his nuances: he drives a movie on his shoulders. Yet, when it came to spy thriller, it was frankly so-so. Then we all know star studded movies like the lastest Singham and War 2... There's only masala with heavy star cast and a very, very little storyline or nothing on the spy topic. I can definitely say, they were mass movies relying on starcast and some CGI.

So then comes Dhurandhar. Not to say again but a heavy star studded movie with spy and espionage elements. But the difference, the stars gave phenomenal performances, including the young lady Saira and our own Rakesh Bedi. While everyone applaused Akshaye Khanna, Sanjay Dutt, Arjun Rampal and ofcourse Ranveer Singh, I felt these two side characters were equally good in whatever roles they were offered.

Now coming to spy world. The movie showcases what's there, is there. How it works, how things topple upside down due to a slight mistake, or how you may have to take chances, heavy chances to get something done. When you have one and only aim, your chances heavily rely on your guts and brain. Because be it or not, a rotten apple in a crate may leave its rottenness in other apples.

Moreover, the movie is shown with the point of view of Indian forces, and some actual incidents, that blend with the overall sentiments and anger of a viewer.

Again, there is some gore, but not so much and elaborated like movie Animal. But not so less that you can watch with kids.

I did feel little glitches here and there but overall, a wonderful movie. And yes, I am waiting for the next part.

On a side note. The movie is long, but you won't yawn anytime during its running time.

author: Premgupta1048
title: The Best Film Of 2025 In Bollywood
text:
Since the beginning Movie pace and Story hook you that much, you'll forget about popcorn on your lap.

Background music 10/10, Highly Impressive. I was complimenting while watching itself.

Direction 10/10, every single shot is too notch. So impressive

Please watch this film in theatre for better experience in terms of music most. I'm filled with compliments for this film.

author: skmenon1993
title: DHURANDHAR EXPERIENCE üî•üî•üî•üî•
text:
A spy action movie with a runtime of 3 hrs 34 minutes approx, it's engrossing without a single moment of boredom, thanks to the robust screenplay and casting of talented performers. Director Aditya Dhar has been successful in ensuring that each character leaves an indelible mark on the viewers.

It's not solely a Ranveer Singh show, as the director has ensured each character has a memorable presence. R Madhavan, Arjun Rampal, Akshay Khanna, Sanjay Dutt, and Ranveer Singh deliver performances akin to a north Indian person savoring an authentic south Indian meal, with each bite providing satisfaction. Akshay Khanna, who won hearts with Aurangzeb in Chaava, has again impressed as Rehman Dakait in Dhurandhar. His swag, look, and dialogue delivery are mind-blowing. As the movie progresses, Sanjay Dutt brings a new gear, accelerating the pace with his enjoyable screen presence. R Madhavan and Arjun Rampal have limited screen time but make their presence felt. Sara Arjun delivers a decent performance as the lady love. Ranveer Singh's character development is amazing to watch, and his mass performance will be eagerly anticipated in the second part.

From a technical standpoint, Aditya Dhar's direction is astounding, perfectly capturing the essence of Dhurandhar. Sashwat Sachdev's score and music blend seamlessly with the movie's tone. The placement of old Bollywood classics in certain situations is entertaining and thrilling. Vikash Nowlakha's cinematography is commendable, and Shivkumar V Panicker's editing is sharp.

author: jonny78
title: this will change indian cinema
text:
Intelligent writing, peak performances, gritty and realistic action. After such a long time, mainstream bollywood finally has a movie which is truly cinema.

It's no simple task to construct a nearly 4 hour long movie without losing your audience, yet dhurandhar manages to do exactly that. In fact, the runtime serves as a strength, allowing you to fully immerse yourself in such a dense, complicated, and dark world.

I say this will change indian cinema because the film is just so thoughtfully built and so different at the same time. It feels like an experimental take on commercial cinema. There's so much aura farming, but dhar's clever script adds a classy weight to them that just isn't present in other bwood flicks.

There are some truly disturbing scenes here, in particular the scene for the 26/11 attack. The shock, the disgust, the sadness. I don't think a film has made me feel so angry in such a long time. Another scene involving arjun rampal's character is straight out of a horror movie. The 18 rating is definitely justified.

Don't miss this masterpiece.

author: itzimraan
title: Emotion that lingers, action that erupts
text: The world of Dhurandhar is as mesmerizing as it is dangerous, with every corner of Karachi rendered in cinematic precision. Ranveer Singh delivers a layered performance that anchors the audience amid escalating threats and moral dilemmas. Director Dhar crafts sequences where strategic planning meets brutal action, keeping viewers perpetually on edge. The supporting cast contributes significantly, fleshing out a realistic criminal ecosystem. Cinematography and editing combine to maintain tension, while the score punctuates key moments. The narrative's blend of action, politics, and human drama makes the film a truly immersive experience.

author: DevanshD-14
title: Reasons you should watch it in cinemas
text: The movie absolutely stands on top of other Bollywood movies in the year 2025 , the movie has it all , great acting, great story, a unique storytelling. The movie is undoubtedly long, but it doesn't feel stretched, the movie has been targeted for violence, but in my opinion , the violence is natural and necessary, we don't have unwanted violence like movies like animal or gangs of Wasseypur . The movie can be criticised only if you have a personal bias against it already , overall I'll suggest you to give the film a try and watch it without any bias , I am sure you'll like it.

author: HitYaFlop_MovieWorld
title: A Grand, Ambitious Spectacle Powered by Stellar Performances
text:
Aditya Dhar's Dhurandhar arrives as a bold, painstakingly mounted espionage thriller that thrives on scale, ambition, and sheer cinematic craft. It is a film that demands patience for its towering 214-minute runtime, but richly rewards those who stay with it. With top-notch production values, memorable set pieces, and some of the finest performances of the year, Dhurandhar stands tall as a big-screen experience meant to be felt as much as watched.

Inspired by true events, Dhar's story is inherently gripping. The screenplay is layered and compelling, especially in how it maps the journey of an ordinary Indian man who infiltrates the heart of Pakistan's political machinery. The tension is relentless, yet the storytelling never becomes loud or preachy. However, the writing does stretch thin in the first half. Aditya Dhar dialogues are passionate, often theatrical, and suit the film's soaring tone.

Dhurandhar is packed with sequences that are crafted for maximum impact. The infiltration episodes are particularly thrilling sharp, suspenseful, and rooted in strategy rather than convenient heroism. The intermission arrives at a nail-biting turning point, leaving audiences gasping. Post-interval, Hamza's descent into madness is exceptionally staged. The finale, a brutal and emotionally charged fight sequence, serves as a fitting crescendo. The only major drawback: the length. At nearly 3 hours and 34 minutes, the film demands more endurance than necessary. A tighter edit could have easily elevated its impact.

Ranveer Singh delivers one of the most outstanding performances of his career. He inhabits the character with remarkable intensity and vulnerability. Akshaye Khanna is phenomenal, expressing oceans through the subtlest shifts in his eyes. Sanjay Dutt is electrifying, commanding, and immensely watchable. Arjun Rampal, though limited in screen time, makes every moment count. R. Madhavan is terrific, leaving a lasting impact with his portrayal. Sara Arjun makes a decent debut, though her chemistry with Ranveer feels oddly underdeveloped. Rakesh Bedi, Gaurav Gera, Naveen Kaushik, and Danish Pandor round out the supporting cast with assured performances.

Music is a mixed bag but effective. The title track is already a sensation. "Ishq Jalakar - Karvaan" emerges as the standout. "Gehra Hua" is soothing and well-placed. Cinematography is spectacular, the frames are rich, atmospheric, and visually arresting, making the film feel even larger than its scale. The action Choreography is gritty, dynamic, and rooted in physical realism. A gripping spectacle that could have been a masterpiece with tighter editing.

Direction 3.5/5 Acting 4/5 Editing 2.5/5 Story 3.5/5 Screenplay 3.5/5.

author: raghav-75870
title: Best of all time
text:
Dhurandhar" packs a powerful punch - a gritty, high-stakes spy thriller that drags you deep into the murky underworld of Karachi with style, tension and spectacle. Directed by Aditya Dhar, it follows Indian agent Hamza (Ranveer Singh) as he embeds himself deep within the mafia network of Karachi's notorious Lyari gang, attempting to dismantle terror operations from within.

From the outset, the film builds a potent atmosphere - dank alleys, ominous conspiracies, and a mounting sense of danger that never quite lets go. The cinematography, drenched in shadow and sharp contrasts, and the stirring background score - sometimes throbbing with urgency, sometimes hauntingly minimal - elevate ordinary frames into moments of nail-biting suspense.

Ranveer Singh's performance is perhaps the greatest strength of the film: he plays Hamza with restraint and intensity, letting silence and subtle gestures speak louder than grand dialogues. Supporting cast members - from villains to allies - also deliver convincingly, making the world of "Dhurandhar" immersive and convincingly dangerous.

That said, the film does have its flaws. At three and a half hours, the runtime occasionally drags, and certain sequences - especially in the second half - feel overdrawn or repetitive. The gritty violence sometimes feels gratuitous, and a few plot threads seem more like setup for a sequel than satisfying arcs in themselves.

Despite those drawbacks, "Dhurandhar" works when it matters - for its ambition, its mood, and its commitment to telling a volatile story with conviction. It may not be perfect, but it's bold, intense, and rarely dull. For viewers who appreciate raw, uncompromising thrillers with emotional weight and real-world resonance, this is a ride worth taking. Amazing.

author: amansingh-05354
title: A breathtaking journey through gangster politics
text:
First of all I would like to salute the direction and storytelling of this movie. This type of story telling has not been seen before in bollywood. The music mashup, bgm and intro of every character was top notch. First half had all the cuisines for perfect build up for all the characters and story. In Second half all that build up explodes and gives great fight sequence, music, and goosebumps moment. After interval the story just flows and you won't feel like it's been 3:30 hours.

Final conclusion: Just don't miss this masterpiece if you are cinema lover, you can't afford to miss this type of storytelling.

author: imrajneesh
title: A gritty masterpiece that redefines the Indian spy genre
text:
If Uri: The Surgical Strike was the roar, Dhurandhar is the bite. Aditya Dhar has returned with a spy thriller that does not just rely on loud patriotism but backs it up with grit, intelligence, and a scale that Indian cinema rarely attempts. Clocking in at over three hours, it is a marathon of a film, but one that leaves you breathless rather than exhausted.

This is the Ranveer Singh we have been waiting for. As the covert operative Hamza Ali Mazari, Singh strips away his usual high-energy flamboyance to deliver a performance of simmering intensity. He is quiet, lethal, and emotionally vulnerable. Whether he is navigating the treacherous lanes of Karachi or breaking down in a rare moment of solitude, he anchors the film with a maturity that defines the second act of his career.

While Ranveer is the soul, Akshaye Khanna is the electrifying current running through the narrative. As the antagonist Rehman Dakait, Khanna is terrifyingly calm and intellectual, proving once again why he is one of the most underutilized actors in the industry. The face-off scenes between Singh and Khanna are masterclasses in tension, relying on psychological warfare rather than just explosions.

What stands out most is the technical brilliance. The film respects the intelligence of the audience, weaving a complex web of espionage involving historical stakes without feeling like a history lesson. The hand-to-hand combat is visceral and realistic, avoiding the gravity-defying stunts often seen in the genre. Shashwat Sachdev's background score is a character in itself - pounding and relentless during the action, yet haunting during the emotional beats.

Is it long? Yes. But the runtime is justified by the depth of the world-building. Dhurandhar is a mass entertainer with class sensibilities - a rare beast that satisfies the action junkies and the cinephiles alike. It is a high-octane saga that cements Aditya Dhar as a master of the war-spy genre. A must-watch for anyone who loves grounded, intense cinema.

author: rashidhusain
title: High octane spy thriller
text:
A must watch movie if you are a fan of intense spy thrillers. You're going to love it.

Ranveer Singh delivers a powerhouse performance and is absolutely on fire.

His performance alone is enough to watch movie.

The film dives deep into espionage, underworld infiltration, and raw patriotism with tremendous intensity and swagger. Although the runtime feels a bit long at times, the gripping narrative and high-voltage execution keep you engaged throughout.

author: milanjolly
title: Blockbuster movie. Must watch.
text:
I initially thought the movie would have unrealistic action scenes to glorify the spy. But I was taken aback by the meticulously well done world building of Pakistan and Lyari. It showed the mindset of mafia, terrorists and pakistan's intelligence agency very well and which is reality grounded. Pakistan is historically known to attack India and torture the captured military personnel brutally and in an inhumane way. The movie doesn't shy away to show that brutal side of Pakistan. The actors gave a fabulous performance, particularly Akshay Khanna and Ranveer Singh.

This movie was a treat to watch. I would recommend every Indian who isn't delulu left wing but actually cares for the nation regardless of whether they are left or right wing to watch this movie.

author: ranjitclimb
title: Impact full
text:
Dhurandhar is a strong and engaging film that leaves a lasting impression through its powerful performances and well crafted story. The movie keeps you connected from start to finish without unnecessary complications, and the emotional weight of each character adds depth to the overall experience.

Akshaye Khanna stands out instantly. His calm yet intense way of acting gives the film a very solid foundation. He doesn't need loud moments to create impact his expressions, timing, and controlled performance speak for themselves. Every time he appears on screen, the scene feels more serious and meaningful.

Sanjay Dutt brings his natural authority and experience to the film. His presence adds a sense of strength and maturity to the storyline. He plays his role with a balanced mix of power and emotion, making the character believable and memorable without overacting.

Arjun Rampal contributes strongly with a very composed and focused performance. He adds a sense of mystery and depth, and his character holds the audience's attention throughout. Rampal's acting feels effortless yet very effective, helping maintain the film's intense tone.

The biggest highlight, however, is Ranveer Singh as the spy. Ranveer fits the role perfectly. His energy, expressions, and emotional range show how much thought he has put into understanding the character. He plays a spy who carries both responsibility and inner conflict, and he brings this out in a very natural way. His action scenes look real, and his emotional moments feel honest. Ranveer's performance is strong enough to uplift the film on many levels.

The direction and storytelling are simple but impactful, keeping the focus on characters rather than unnecessary twists. The pacing is smooth, and the background music supports the tension in the right moments.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a well made, engaging, and powerful film. With strong acting from Akshaye Khanna, Sanjay Dutt, Arjun Rampal, and an excellent performance by Ranveer Singh, it becomes a movie worth watching for anyone who enjoys intense and meaningful cinema.

author: vinay-93622
title: Awesomely thought and scripted movie
text:
Amazed to see a brilliant movie coming from Aditya Dhar, which is well scripted and offers you a cinematic experience.

It showcase the journey of weak Indian government in early 2000 against terrorism ; and how RAW launches a brilliant plan to infiltrate Pakistani mafia.

Akshya Khanna will blow your mind with subtle act. You will find him heroic

A must watch in theatres only !

author: pranayjalvi
title: Started strongly, but falters at places
text:
Dhurandhar opens with a jolt. The film throws you straight into the brutality of its historical backdrop, staging the violence with a kind of cold intensity that doesn't letup. The story dives into the world of undercover operations, betrayal, and the constant tension of living behind enemy lines.

The performances are easily the strongest pillar here. Ranveer Singh handles the lead role with solid control, especially in the heavier moments, though the film never lets us truly get under his skin. The real standout is Akshaye Khanna as Rehman Dakait. He barely speaks, yet his eyes carry entire paragraphs. Every expression lands like a threat, and he steals the frame without even trying. I personally felt Sanjay Dutt as SP Aslam as the weaker character, with no impactful dialogue or presence on the screen.

Technically, Dhurandhar is an impressive film. The background score keeps tightening the rope around the audience, although I didn't feel it synced every time with the scene. The cinematography was good, however the direction and editing could have been better. A lot of choppy editing was noticeable throughout the movie. The camera movement while decent throughout the movie, was awkward on certain occasions. The use of real footage of 26/11 conversation was something surprising as well as heavily convincing.

But the film collapses under its own weight. There are too many characters, too many arcs, and too many threads fighting for attention. With the narrative jumping around so much, there's little emotional connection with the protagonist or his mission. It's hard to care whether he succeeds or fails when the film doesn't slow down enough to let us live with him.

The romance between Ranveer Singh and Sara Arjun is easily the weakest part of the film. The chemistry felt both awkward as well as forced. Everytime there scene appeared, it kinda pulled me out of the real narrative.

The violence, while impressive in execution, sometimes crosses into excess. There are moments that feel gruesome just for the sake of being gruesome, adding shock but not substance. The pacing was another concern. The film was long by atleast 30 minutes due to various unnecessary subplots and I felt it could have been wrapped in 3 hrs with a tighter grip on the story.

Overall, Dhurandhar is an ambitious and technically strong movie, that works mostly due to it's premise and great performances, however is bloated by uneven storytelling that loses it's grip on the way.

My Rating : 3.5/5.

author: imdbfan-6010566564
title: Trauma in the name of Cinema
text:
Text: Went to watch Dhurandar and honestly... I regret it. What an unbearable stretch of a movie. Two words: Senseless. Pathetic. A spy agent enters Pakistan, instantly becomes famous, convinces a politician to marry his daughter. Like seriously??? Is being a spy this easy now? Where's the realism? Where's the logic? Who approved this script? The story writing, editing, and screenplay feel like torture - long, dragged, and nowhere engaging. The plot tries to be "mass patriotic thriller" but ends up looking like WhatsApp-forward level fiction. Only one saving grace: Akshaye Khanna - the only actor who even tries to keep this disaster alive. Without him, the movie would collapse in the first 30 minutes.

Final Verdict If you love your time, your money, and your mental peace - skip this film. It's not entertainment, it's cinematic trauma.

author: aman_tewathia
title: Blood in Shadows
text: It's brutal, uncompromising, and unapologetically hard-edged. Perfectly assembled cast. Each actor embodies their role with precision. Powerhouse performance from each character. Together, they elevate the films from mere action into a character driven saga. Strong background score becomes part of the story.

author: khannadir-83584
title: A Milestone in Indian Spy Cinema
text:
Dhurandhar is nothing short of a landmark in Indian espionage filmmaking. Bold, sharp, and unapologetically intense, the film elevates the spy genre in ways Bollywood has rarely attempted. What sets it apart is its commitment to gritty realism, its depiction of covert operations, high-stakes intelligence work, and the psychological toll on field agents feels far more grounded than the glossy, larger-than-life approach seen in many mainstream spy franchises.

The film's portrayal of a hostile intelligence adversary, modeled through its fictionalized spy agency antagonists, is brutal, raw, and narratively effective. Where some commercial films opt for sanitization or melodrama, Dhurandhar leans fully into the darker shades of espionage, using tension and moral ambiguity to drive the story forward.

The screenplay is exceptional. Real-world inspired incidents are woven seamlessly into the narrative, creating a sense of authenticity that never feels forced. Every subplot, every twist, and every backstory merges into a cohesive whole without a single jarring bump. It's rare to see such meticulous structuring in Bollywood thrillers.

The background score deserves special recognition. It heightens the suspense without overwhelming the scenes, striking the perfect balance between cinematic flair and subtle atmospheric tension. The action sequences, too, are a standout-brutal, tightly choreographed, and refreshingly devoid of unnecessary slow motion or over-the-top heroics.

In a genre often dominated by style over substance, "Dhurandhar" proves that Indian cinema can deliver espionage storytelling that is both artistically rich and thrillingly raw. It's a must-watch for fans of realistic spy dramas and a benchmark future Indian films in this genre will be measured against.

author: bajajgaurav
title: The best espionage film in Indian cinema.
text:
I do not even know where to start but I will try my best to give it a shot.

The thing is that we have abused words like greatest, masterpiece, generational and blockbuster to an extent where they mean nothing anymore and we have thrown them at so many empty mediocre films that when something real arrives we do not have the vocabulary left to honour it. Because of that inflation of praise I do not know how to give justice through words to something that actually deserves reverence.

All I can honestly say is that every Indian should watch this film because Dhurandhar is not just any film, it is one of the greatest cinematic experiences of recent times and unquestionably the best espionage film in Indian cinema.

The performances are frighteningly brilliant because these people are not acting. They are breathing the consequences of history. Akshaye Khanna does not perform, he embodies Rehman Dakait, one of the finest actors this country has ever seen. Ranveer Singh reminds you that regardless of how loud, messy or chaotic he is as a public figure he is a generational actor. Arjun Rampal, Sanjay Dutt, R Madhavan, Rakesh Bedi and Sara Arjun every single one of them delivers with terrifying precision.

Aditya Dhar, easily one of the best directors right now, deserves to be celebrated because he has created something that deserves cultural recognition. We celebrate average films with loud voices but this is the kind of work that should be remembered. I am genuinely glad that this story is being told in two parts because one film could never have carried the weight of this narrative or the tension of this experience.

There is a moment in this film where they play the real recordings from 26/11 attacks, the real conversations between the handlers and the terrorists and in that moment everything becomes frightening, enraging and unbearably real. It does not sensationalise tragedy and it does not treat terror like entertainment. It confronts you with history and demands that you feel something instead of just consuming it.

Dhurandhar is special because it is not scared to show the truth even when the truth is ugly.

Oh man, I could go on and on about how I am in absolute awe but anything I say right now will probably sound like hyperbole to y'all, so it is better that you go watch the film and live the experience I just lived.

The post credit scene that teases Dhurandhar 2 gave me chills.

19 March 2026. I'll be there.

I don't know if these words do justice to what I just experienced, but if you're reading this -

Go watch Dhurandhar. Not later. Now.

author: kspvg
title: Aditya Dhar !! You beauty
text:
What a movie !!!! Shows how actually a spy operates.

Dhurandhar is a film that stays with you long after the credits roll. It is not merely a spy thriller; it is an emotional reminder of the men and women who walk unknown streets, carry hidden identities, and fight unacknowledged battles so that the rest of us can live in peace. Rarely does a film manage to blend intensity, patriotism, and raw human emotion with such precision.

The narrative hits with force. Every frame feels purposeful, every scene carries weight. The director crafts a world of shadows where loyalty is tested, sacrifice is constant, and courage is not loud - it is silent, disciplined, and deeply personal. What touches the heart is the film's honesty. It does not glorify heroism; it reveals the emotional cost behind it.

The lead actor delivers a performance that is both powerful and heartbreakingly vulnerable. You see the steadiness of a soldier, the burden of duty, and the quiet tremors of a human being who cannot afford to break. The supporting cast mirrors this emotional depth, giving the story a lived-in realism that draws you in completely.

The writing is sharp yet sensitive, capturing the spirit of service without theatrics. The background score elevates this emotional journey beautifully - stirring, soft at the right moments, and rising with a patriotic pulse when needed. The cinematography matches the tone perfectly, pulling you into the tension, the loneliness, and the unspoken bravery that defines an intelligence operative's life.

What makes Dhurandhar unforgettable is its heart. It honours those who protect India without applause, without visibility, without rest. It is a tribute to sacrifice that ordinary people will never fully understand - and that is exactly why it must be seen.

A gripping, emotional, deeply heartfelt film.

author: shobhansingh-243-918368
title: Enjoyed watching it...
text: The movie was gripping enough to keep me hooked for three plus hours... We watched in IMAX and found the bgm was done well... There were some good action sequences and gore scenes that kept my eyebrows raised... Very Indian and full of patriotic masala so one should take the story with the grain of salt... Had fun with the hooting and laughs in the theatre...

author: kulincoolkkp
title: Dhurandhar: A Bold, Immersive Thriller Elevated by Powerful Performances and Technical Mastery
text:
Dhurandhar opens with striking intensity, pulling the audience straight into the unforgiving world of covert operations and the psychological weight carried by those who live behind enemy lines. Rumoured to be inspired by the life of Major Mohit Sharma, the film blends tension, atmosphere, and high-stakes drama with impressive control. Ranveer Singh delivers a steady, compelling performance, while Akshaye Khanna's near-silent portrayal of Rehman Dakait is magnetic-every look feels loaded with meaning. Technically, the film is exceptional: the score heightens the suspense, the cinematography and production design achieve an eerie authenticity, and the VFX integrates seamlessly with practical work. Smart use of real footage and audio elevates key moments into genuinely chilling territory, and the action sequences are raw, grounded, and executed with remarkable precision.

Where Dhurandhar stumbles slightly is in its narrative density. With a large cast and multiple threads, the emotional core doesn't always receive the breathing room it deserves, and a few subplots-particularly the romantic track-feel less essential to the film's overall impact. A handful of violent moments edge toward excess, and the pacing occasionally stretches under the weight of its ambitions. Still, the film's strengths far outweigh its flaws. Dhurandhar stands as a bold, immersive, and technically outstanding thriller-one that leaves a strong impression and sets the stage confidently for its next chapter.

author: kunalmshah
title: So...it's good...but...
text: Let's talk about the positives first. Great acting all around, very well cast. I think this was one of Rakesh bedi's best performances. I don't get the hype around Akshaye Khanna in this movie. He is always stellar and did well in this movie but this is no where close to his best acting performance. I felt his performance was as good as Sanjay dutt or Arjun Rampal without being that much better. Ranveer definitely stood out and carried the movie well. I'm not a huge ranveer fan but he always performs really well. This was ranveer's "Animal". The story line was compelling especially considering it was based on true events. The movie was very long though and did drag in certain parts. I also don't get the need for hard core gore when it comes to showing the violence. I thought they could've done a better job of speaking more Urdu and less Hindi throughout the film to add to the authenticity of being in Pakistan. The music was average. Not a huge fan of the underlying Hindu nationalist subtext throughout the movie. This is not a movie I would want to watch again. That being said, I will be seeing the sequel for sure. I do feel it is way better than any yash raj spy universe movie but doesn't compare to movies like raazi and URI which shine in this "spy/armed forces jai hind" genre. Overall I would say this movie was towards the upper end of average but not above average in any metric.

author: abbydash
title: Not worth the hype
text: Dhurandhar arrives wrapped in loud promotions and sky-high expectations, but sadly, the film struggles to live up to the buzz. What promises to be a gripping, high-energy entertainer ends up feeling oddly hollow and uneven. The background score and cinematography are serviceable, but they feel more like noise and visual gloss than meaningful storytelling tools. Even the action sequences, which were heavily marketed, lack originality and fail to leave a lasting impression.

author: nitishsahsah
title: Worth watching
text: It's been a long time since Bollywood pulled together a cast this big and truly made it count. Great chemistry, sharp pacing and strong performances kept me hooked. I'm still replaying scenes in my head. A film that's absolutely worth your time and deserves all the praise coming its way and definitely a movie I'd recommend without hesitation.

author: satyajeetdash-60955
title: Best Spy movei of 2025 since after baby
text: Best movie to watch i have watched this in theatre for 2 times still want to watch this again....not a single moment you feel bore in this movie the songs, the cinematography is so goated that I feel so amazed to see.you need to watch the movie in theatres for the best sound effect and the use of music in movie was so nice.

author: harshzaveriz
title: Constant thrill for 3+ hr, intricately detailed in all aspects
text:
A once in a decade spy thriller, and coming from the director of Uri, the movie is such an upgrade on revealing Pakistan's reality, the other spy-universes don't even come close to the unabashed portrayal of reality and the constant sense of danger our Indian spies must be going through each moment behind the enemy lines.

More than a one-time watch as I am sure one could pick out more details in subsequent viewings and connect them with the real life characters the movie alludes to.

author: manishagarwal-67679
title: Best
text: Best movies till date. Dhurandhar is one of those rare films that pulls you straight into its world from the very first frame. It is intense, gripping, emotional, and crafted on a massive scale. What stands out most is the powerhouse performance by Ranveer Singh, who disappears completely into the character. His raw intensity, vulnerability, and unpredictable energy make the film unforgettable.

author: abhisheksingh-72561
title: GAME CHANGER!!
text:
Aditya Dhar's Dhurandhar is a long, intense, and ambitious film that has earned strong but divided reactions from both critics and audiences.

A Gritty, Geopolitical Thriller

Set against the backdrop of real historical events like the 1999 hijacking and the 2001 Parliament attack, the story follows a RAW agent who goes deep undercover into Karachi's Lyari underworld to dismantle a gangster-ISI terror nexus. The film is structured into distinct chapters and builds a gritty, complex world of espionage and geopolitical maneuvering.

The Major Strengths

¬∑ Powerhouse Performances: The cast is consistently praised as a major highlight. Ranveer Singh delivers a controlled, intense performance, often described as career-best. Akshaye Khanna is frequently called the scene-stealer, bringing a chilling, charismatic menace to his role.

¬∑ Technical Craftsmanship: The film is noted for its high production values, visceral action choreography, and a pulsating background score that significantly elevates the tension.

¬∑ Immersive World-Building: Director Aditya Dhar is commended for creating a detailed, believable, and ruthless world of Karachi's underworld and intelligence operations.

Key Points of Criticism

¬∑ Demanding Runtime: This is the film's most debated aspect. With a runtime between 212 to 214 minutes (over 3.5 hours), many reviews note that the narrative feels overstretched, particularly in the first half.

¬∑ Uneven Pacing: The slow-burn, deliberate pace of the first hour, dedicated to character and plot setup, tests the patience of some viewers expecting a faster thriller.

¬∑ Contested Romantic Subplot: The romantic track between Ranveer Singh's character and the politician's daughter (played by Sara Arjun) is seen by some critics as an underwritten element that could have been trimmed.

Final Verdict & Audience

Dhurandhar is not a light, breezy watch. It is a dense, serious-minded spy saga that requires and rewards patience. Most reviews conclude that if you can commit to its epic length and appreciate grounded, performance-driven geopolitical thrillers, it offers a compelling big-screen experience.

However, if you prefer fast-paced, straightforward action or have limited tolerance for very long films, you might find it challenging. The film also ends with a clear setup for a sequel.

I hope this non-spoiler review helps you decide. Are you generally a fan of long-form, detailed storytelling in films, or do you tend to prefer tighter narratives? Knowing this could help me provide more tailored insights.

author: rajyashjainbm
title: Brilliant Movie - Must Watch
text:
Dhurandhar honestly shocked me in the best way possible. It's been a long time since a Hindi movie pulled me in this deep. The film is raw, intense and hits you straight in the gut. The scale is massive, the performances are crazy good (Ranveer and Akshaye Khanna absolutely killed it), and the whole world-building is so real that for a moment you feel like you're actually standing right inside the chaos.

What I loved the most is that the movie doesn't shy away from showing the dark truth behind terrorism, politics and how our soldiers and officers actually risk everything. Some scenes are brutal, yes, but they are meant to be brutal. That's the point - it's not fake heroism, it's the real cost of violence.

The cinematography, background score, the long but gripping storyline - everything comes together like a proper cinematic experience we rarely get nowadays. This is not a "timepass movie," this is one of those films that stays in your head hours after you walk out of the theatre.

India honestly needs more movies like this - fearless, strong and unfiltered. Dhurandhar isn't perfect, but it is powerful. And in today's times, that's more important.

Highly recommended.

author: AtimaN-5
title: Cringefest at best!
text:
The rule of thumb, never, to never go with high expectations! Let down is harder. For all its grandilosque statements, gut wrenching action, torture scenes bordering on savagery, the uniqueness of the plot (?) An impressive cast is not enough.

After a while, the characters were interchangeable. The mannerisms, abuses, dangling cigarettes ( lol), the sneers, were visible. For many Shades and face fuzz acted as a cloak for histrionics!

The vote swayed between bulging biceps, swaying locks, sneery snarl, filthy mouths, beastly mannerisms!

The person who stood out is Rakesh Bedi. He stole the show with his performance. A small but much needed human, comic relief came from him. As for the deeper insight into the politics of the two nations. It is lost in all the unnecessary violence. On a serious note, topics of national security, real threats to our country, need for more, more & much, much more were touched upon in graphic details. How can an average cinegoer, out for entertainment, munching on warm popcorn in the dark help in matters our government fails at is baffling? A documentary would have sufficed. They are planning a sequel; beware!

author: HasanQ-71
title: Nothing really made sense
text:
Dhurandhar mistakes length, noise, and seriousness for intelligence. What it actually delivers is a convoluted spy drama that collapses the moment you stop admiring the background score and ask the most basic question: what was the mission?

The film opens with a hijacking by Jaish, after which Indian intelligence decides the best response is to send a criminal-turned-agent to Karachi to infiltrate a Lyari gang that has nothing to do with Jaish, terrorism, or the hijacking. Why Karachi? Why Lyari? Why this gang? The movie never bothers to explain.

From here, the agent inexplicably helps Rehman Dakait rise in the underworld. This rise then attracts two conveniently placed intermediaries who introduce Rehman to the ISI chief, a chain of events so dependent on blind luck that it accidentally turns espionage into a lottery. Neither the agent, Rehman, nor R&AW plans this. It just... happens. Twice.

Ironically, terrorism only escalates because of the agent's involvement. Rehman starts supplying weapons to the ISI after the agent embeds himself in the gang. If the goal was to prevent attacks on India, the mission is not just a failure it is actively counterproductive.

At one point, the agent declares his ambition to become the "King of Karachi," a line that sounds dramatic but leads absolutely nowhere. He neither becomes king, nor dismantles any terror network, nor prevents any attack. Instead, the plot gets distracted by a half-baked romance and ends with the agent assassinating the very man he helped empower.

The film then abruptly ends, as if it suddenly remembered it had been running for over three hours and needed to stop.

Dhurandhar wants to be gritty, intelligent, and epic. It is actually a bloated, poorly thought-out narrative where cause and effect don't exist, stakes are retroactively invented, and the protagonist's mission remains unclear even in the final act.

This isn't slow-burn storytelling.

This isn't complex espionage.

This is just noise masquerading as depth.

If you remove the performances, the score, and the scale, you're left with a spy thriller where the spy shouldn't have been sent in the first place and where the story only works if you don't think about it at all.

author: ShambhaviG-9
title: A Power-Packed Thriller That Hits Every Nerve
text:
I walked into Dhurandhar without even watching the trailer -only drawn by the song "Jogi" - and I walked out stunned. This film is a masterclass in how to blend action, politics, intelligence operations and raw human conflict into one explosive narrative.

Akshaye Khanna delivers one of his most charming yet chilling performances. His character makes you hate him for what he does, yet somehow you never want to see him fall - that's how compelling he is. Ranveer Singh, Sanjay Dutt and Arjun Rampal match that energy with equal intensity, giving the story a solid ensemble base where every character matters.

What really sets the movie apart is how deeply it dives into the silent suffering of a spy - the years spent undercover, the lost identity, the isolation. The plot doesn't shy away from the ugly truths: gore, betrayal, political manipulation, and the weight of patriotism. Every scene feels earned, every twist hits hard.

Dhurandhar proves that a commercial thriller can still have a beating heart and heavy emotional stakes. If you're looking for a film that keeps you conflicted - rooting for monsters yet understanding their pain - this is one you shouldn't miss.

A gripping and unexpectedly impactful watch. Highly recommended.

author: harishnj
title: A Stunning Star Showcase Driven by Terrific Performances
text:
"Dhurandhar" (2025) is a truly stunning cinematic experience, succeeding on the strength of its ambitious vision and the phenomenal acting of its leading men. The film is elevated by the presence of Ranveer Singh, who delivers a great performance, and the sheer excellence of Akshaye Khanna, who is simply terrific in his role.

The film's stunning quality is evident in its production design and execution, suggesting a visually rich and high-energy production that pulls the viewer into its world. The dual star power of the leads is a major asset, with Akshaye Khanna's terrific presence providing the perfect counterpoint to Ranveer Singh's great energy.

However, the film's high quality is tempered slightly by a "little bit of uneven pacing." This suggests that while individual scenes and performances are brilliant, the flow of the narrative occasionally falters, perhaps slowing down during exposition or rushing through necessary developments. This minor flaw, though present, is ultimately overshadowed by the spectacle and the powerful acting.

Overall, "Dhurandhar" is a cinematic triumph anchored by two powerhouse performances. It's a visually stunning and thoroughly engaging film that is a must-watch for its stars and high production values.

author: shriram-karpur
title: A Shallow Attempt at Patriotism That Misses the Mark
text:
While Indian cinema has recently seen a surge in high-quality, impactful patriotic films, every successful trend eventually produces imitators. This latest release is a prime example of a film attempting to capitalize on the "patriotic mindset" of the audience without putting in the necessary work on script, logic, or direction.

The Plot: Familiar Territory The core premise is one we've seen before: internal power struggles between rival Pakistani gangs serving as a front for the ISI. The narrative suggests that the Pakistani government uses these criminal skirmishes as a "deniable" way to funnel arms and ammunition into India to fuel terrorism. While the geo-political concept had potential, the execution turns it into a messy, confusing gang war rather than a taut political thriller.

The "Faltu" Factor The film fails significantly in three major areas:

Dialogue Writing: The lines are uninspired and "faltu," lacking the gravitas or sharp wit found in the modern classics it tries to emulate.

The Music: The songs feel forced, breaking the momentum of a story that was already struggling to stay afloat.

The Action: This is perhaps the film's greatest sin. In an era where audiences appreciate the grounded realism of movies like Sam Bahadur, this film opts for ridiculous, gravity-defying stunts that feel decades out of date.

The Final Verdict: Save Your Head The biggest disappointment lies in the final act. After a build-up of "hoo-haa" and hype, the movie culminates in a 25-minute fight sequence that is so unrealistic and loud it becomes physically draining. It lacks the emotional weight of Bajirao Mastani or the raw honesty of The Kerala Story.

Conclusion: If you decide to watch this for the plot, do yourself a favor and turn it off for the last 25 minutes. You'll save yourself a headache and some valuable time. Compared to the high-quality patriotic films of recent years, this one is a hollow imitation that prioritizes noise over nuance.

author: ankitqu
title: Emotional Depth with electrifying Action
text: This is a film that thrives on contrasts-quiet moments of introspection juxtaposed with explosive action and high-stakes tension. author: arkshing
title: The Perfect Blend of Thrill and Heart
text: The film grips you from the very first scene, immersing you into a world of tension and intrigue. Ranveer Singh delivers a powerhouse performance, balancing intensity with subtle vulnerability that makes his character feel profoundly human. The supporting cast adds layers to the narrative, each scene enriched by their nuanced portrayals. Director Dhar weaves together action, suspense, and political undertones seamlessly, creating a cinematic rhythm that never falters. The action sequences are meticulously choreographed, combining adrenaline-pumping fights with strategic tension, while the cinematography captures both the grit and grandeur of the setting. The editing maintains perfect pace, ensuring that even the quieter, character-driven moments hold immense weight. The film's score complements the visuals masterfully, heightening suspense without overwhelming the story. By the end, you are left both exhilarated and contemplative, a testament to the director's vision and the cast's dedication.

author: jaswalaman
title: Drama That Keeps You on the Edge
text: From start to finish, the film expertly balances suspense, strategy, and action. Ranveer Singh commands every scene with intensity and nuance, while Sanjay Dutt provides authority and menace. Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan enhance the ensemble with subtle performances that elevate the narrative. Arjun Rampal's controlled menace creates tension that persists throughout, while Sara Arjun's emotional authenticity raises stakes. Aditya Dhar orchestrates narrative threads and action sequences with precision. Cinematography captures both the chaotic underworld and intimate character moments. The score heightens suspense, and the finale delivers both adrenaline-fueled action and emotional payoff.

author: mazon-3

author: RyderAviCR7
title: M Aditya Dhar Did What Bollywood Was Too Afraid To Do
text:
This movie is what happens when a director actually has the spine to tell the truth instead of playing it safe for multiplex audiences and foreign markets.

Dhurandar doesn't apologize. It doesn't soften the edges. It shows you exactly what happens when a spy operates in the shadows - the guilt, the isolation, the impossible choices. Aditya Dhar built this film on real incidents, real audio recordings, real photographs. That's not cinematic liberty - that's documentation dressed as cinema.

The violence? Absolutely necessary. People cry about "graphic scenes," but it's literally nothing - a car accident on the road is more brutal than 80% of what's shown here. That's barely 3-4% of what actually happens in real life. The brutality in this film has purpose - it's reflective, not mindless. It's there to shake people up, not glorify gore.

And here's the uncomfortable truth: people want to cry "too graphic" because they've been fed sugar their whole lives by Bollywood directors too afraid to upset Pakistan or their own conscience. This is a spy movie. Spies don't solve problems with dialogue and philosophy - they solve them with action, and sometimes that action is ugly. That's the reality. If you can't handle that, you're simply not mature enough for this film, and that's fine - no one's forcing you to watch. Go watch Kapil Sharma if you just want a laugh. This film is for those who have the spine to face reality.

.

What killed me about this movie is how human it is. The lead doesn't become invincible. He doesn't single-handedly destroy an entire system while cracking jokes. He suffers. He carries the weight. He waits. He makes calculated moves. That's the actual craft of espionage, and no Bollywood film has ever shown it this way.

The performances are something else entirely. Every actor understands the assignment - this isn't about being likeable. It's about being real. You can feel the exhaustion, the purpose, the cost. That's masterclass acting right there.

And here's the thing people won't say out loud - this film is necessary. Not because it's anti-Pakistan or pro-India propaganda. It's necessary because it shows our young generation that there ARE people willing to bleed for this country, and their stories deserve to be told without apology or filter. That's not nationalism - that's truth.

YRF and the "progressive" brigade will never make this film. They're too busy worrying about what Twitter thinks and whether their next release will play in Gulf markets. Aditya Dhar didn't care about any of that. He made a film for Indians, about Indians, showing the reality of what Indians face.

This is the most honest spy film Indian cinema has ever produced. Period.

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê - Raw. Uncompromising. Absolutely necessary.

author: abhinabapal
title: Dhurandhar is not just a movie, it's a hard slap of truth.
text:
It hits hard because it doesn't rely on "cinematic exaggeration." Instead, it builds its story on real incidents - from the Kandahar hijack, to the 2001 Parliament attack, the fake currency network, and even the Lyari gang war links to 26/11.

What makes it truly intense is the use of real footage, real images, and real audio of terrorists, that detail alone changes the whole experience. You don't just watch the film, you feel the weight of what actually happened.

If you want a thriller that's not just entertaining but also shocking, informative, and unforgettable. Dhurandhar deserves your time.

author: rockstarankit
title: Once in a Generation movie.
text: Went to watch Dhurandhar in imax 6 am show . Who wakes up at 4:30 am on a sunday in Delhi winters to watch a movie !! I did & it was all worth it ! The movie is 3 and half hours long but it won't feel like. You won't take your eyes off the screen. What a performance by entire cast and hats off to Aditya Dhar for the vision and putting such a cinematic experience on the screen. Akshaye Khanna finally getting the roles and credits he deserves for his work, he completely stole the show. What an aura ! Ignore the negative reviews and just watch it you won't regret it. Dhurandhar restores your faith in Bollywood. Don't miss the ending there is a high chance that things are going to get crazy in the next part.

author: omkarjoshi1989
title: Perfect example of how covert spy movie should be made
text:
Director is the character of the movie. With Uri as his first directorial movie, he gave what NEW BHARAT represents, jo dushman ke ghar me ghusta bhi hai aur marata bhi hai.

Some original and some originally inspired government officials characters makes it realistic. Covert spy doesn't provided all setup , all spoon feed mission intel on land, otherwise this time the wait is longer and spy has to make his way up in gangsters of Lyari town of Pakistan. Infaltrating enemy within is the motto here. Its not usual bollywood-ish spy thriller with high octane one sided action scenes, and heroine in bikini sequences. Here we get to see 3 hours and 32 minutes long saga of a man conspiring on his each step with calm mind and clear intentions to reveal enemy plans informing back to India.

Special mention for Akshay Khanna as villain manages to hit the impact on viewers even if hes not the hero of the film. Ranveercs character Hamza Ali Mazari, takes back foot in screenplay which feels correct since he has to implement his mission in most intelligent manner.

R Madhavan as Ajit Doval's inspired character Ajay Sanyal impacts you whenever he's on screen. Rage inside his eyes during annopening scene when he's been mocked by terrorist on plane, was top notch. With Mission Dhurandhar, he is in fact going to show enemy that "Indians ke gude me kitna jor hai"

Movie at one point shows 26/11 incidents first hand by using RED ACREEN EFFECT, which I don't think been implemented so great in any of the past films.

Kudos to Jio Studios and Director Ditya Dhar and all casting for giving such a wonderful wonderful film to root for!

author: chand-suhas
title: Ghayal hun, isiliye Ghatak hun!
text:
Narrated in 10 chapters, Aditya Dhar's highly ambitious magnum opus is that rare espionage thriller that enjoys proper research, aided by superb casting. The Director's confidence in his narrative, can be seen in the nearly 2 hours long first half with both halves getting 5 chapters each for a period of 10 years. Hamza infiltrates Pakistan's notorious gang run by Rehman Dacait and rises through the rank as his confidante. The way he gathers the information about how ISI uses these gangsters for their weapons is quite intriguing. The extreme violence is in sync with the current demand and I wasn't bothered by it. Despite the lengthy runtime, the film remains engaging though exhausting. The second half does get predictable and doesn't match the first half.

Ofcourse the other need of the hour, the whole politics of it is what leaves a bitter taste considering the original story was potent enough and the good performances carried the story forward. The jingoistic nationalism with Pakistan as the target was pretty much given and that is definitely not the issue. Yet, the opening disclaimer reads out loud and clear, that the film is inspired by true events and that it doesn't intentionally target anybody. When they resort to present this as the reality with the usage of actual terror attacks footage and call transcripts, it gets tougher to accept the politics behind this. Sure, the attempt is to trigger the strong emotional response which again was possible without over doing it. The film would have remained impactful even without the political appeasement it resorts to doing, not so subtly.

author: siddhantprakash-15733
title: This is what we indian viewers deserve!
text:
Movie feels new, refreshing, and different from other movies which is a very big plus point. The bgm is absolute banger. The best thing which i liked was how real, lively, and also dangerous the Lyari town felt (kudos to the set building team). Aisa feel ho raha tha ki actually Karachi me teleport ho gaya hu.

Glad that the movie showed the emotional issues a spy has to face while living a fake life in another country.

Some issues that i felt - The love story Editing feels choppy in action sequences.

Sound design - Sometimes, the sound of a gun firing doesnt match with the shots being fired(especially in the 2nd half) (MINOR SPOILER AHEAD) The ending chase sequence between SP aslam, Hamza, and Rehman dacait feels a little too "Bollywoodised" and doesn't match the vibe with the rest of the picture(tho it's not that big of an issue).

author: rahulvaidya055
title: The spy movie you deserve
text:
I just watched Dhurandhar on the first day and I am still trying to pick my jaw up off the floor. A 3-hour-30-minute movie that feels like it's 90 minutes long? Somehow they have pulled it off. The way different storylines are woven together is amazing. Every thread gets tied up and nothing feels forced. The tension just keeps climbing and the background music always keeps you engaged.

What really got me was how real everything felt. Real events are seamlessly made a part of the movie. It genuinely feels like you are inside the movie where one wrong move could end up in a catastrophic disaster for the titular characters. Each character got ample screen time to establish themselves in the movie. Dhurandhar is easily one of the best movies I have seen in years and I am already telling everyone that nothing like this is going to come out for the next 3 months. Go watch it on the biggest screen you can find, you ll thank me later.

author: imdbfan-0004576675
title: BEST MOVIE TILL DATE!
text:
Dhurandhar continuously keeps you involved in its storyline, gripping your attention from the very first scene right up to the closing moments. Every sequence feels purposeful, thoughtfully crafted, and emotionally engaging. The pacing is remarkably smooth, giving you no chance to drift away or feel disconnected. In fact, the scenes couldn't have been executed any better-there is truly zero room for improvement in terms of visual storytelling and narrative flow.

One of the film's strongest assets is its casting. All the actors, including those in supporting and side roles, are perfectly chosen and deliver performances that feel natural and convincing. Each character adds value to the plot rather than simply filling space. The leads maintain a strong screen presence, but what makes Dhurandhar feel so complete is how well the ensemble complements them. Their chemistry and timing elevate the film to a whole new level.

The use of music deserves special appreciation, particularly the placement of the title track. It arrives at exactly the right moment, enhancing the emotional intensity of the scene without overpowering it. The soundtrack blends seamlessly with the film's tone, helping to build atmosphere and deepen the audience's connection to the characters.

Visually, the cinematography in Dhurandhar is vibrant and immersive. Every frame appears carefully designed, making even the simplest moments aesthetically pleasing. The direction is confident, and the storytelling feels tight, with no unnecessary subplots or forced drama.

Overall, Dhurandhar stands out as a complete cinematic experience-engaging, beautifully acted, and emotionally resonant. It keeps you hooked, makes you care about its characters, and leaves you with a strong impact long after the credits roll. It's rare to find a film that excels so consistently across performance, music, pacing, and visuals, but Dhurandhar manages to do it all effortlessly.

author: shubhamjaiswal-75927
title: Stars, Action, and Unforgettable Moments
text: The story grips you from its opening moments, pulling you into a world where danger lurks around every corner and loyalty is constantly tested. Ranveer Singh delivers a powerhouse performance, effortlessly balancing intensity with vulnerability, making his character both relatable and formidable. The action sequences are meticulously choreographed, keeping the tension high without ever feeling overblown. Director Dhar weaves a narrative that is as emotionally engaging as it is thrilling, giving depth to each subplot while maintaining a relentless pace. The cinematography perfectly captures both the gritty underworld and the quieter human moments, making every frame visually striking. The supporting cast complements the leads beautifully, adding layers to the political and criminal landscapes. By the second half, the stakes feel monumental, and the climax delivers a payoff that is both shocking and emotionally satisfying. This is a film that commands attention and leaves a lingering impact long after the credits roll.

author: preetishenterprises
title: "Not All Roles Need Loud Dialogues"
text:
Subtle acting works best in espionage dramas, and Ranveer Singh clearly understands that restraint extremely well. His performance is rooted in control rather than exaggeration, which suits the genre perfectly. Espionage is not about constant loud dialogues or dramatic outbursts; it is about silence, observation, internal conflict, and calculated decisions. Ranveer sticks to this realism and plays his character with discipline, allowing the audience to read what is happening beneath the surface rather than spelling everything out.

Akshaye Khanna adds solid depth and balance to the film. His presence strengthens the narrative and complements the lead performance effectively. The chemistry between the two feels organic, and their performances help maintain the serious, grounded tone the story aims for. Instead of competing for attention, both actors serve the film's intent, which is refreshing to see.

The problem lies not in the performances but in how modern audiences often judge cinema. Many online reviews seem to equate good acting with loud dialogues, aggressive expressions, or "mass" moments. Espionage films demand patience and attentiveness, as much of the tension exists internally rather than on the surface. When viewers approach such films expecting instant gratification, they risk missing the subtle layers that make the genre effective.

Online audiences, especially younger reviewers influenced by social-media hype, would benefit from watching such films with more observation and less overreaction. Not every role needs to shout to leave an impact. Quiet, restrained performances often require more skill and understanding of character.

Overall, this film deserves appreciation for attempting realism and for performances that respect the genre. It may not cater to everyone's expectations, but for viewers willing to engage thoughtfully, it offers a controlled and sincere cinematic experience.

author: sainipankaj-74718
title: ‚≠ê 10/10 "Finally, a Spy Thriller India Can Be Proud Of!"
text:
Dhurandhar is the kind of Indian spy movie I've been waiting for years. At a time when most spy films either become too loud or too unrealistic, this one strikes the perfect balance between intelligence, tension, and entertainment.

What impressed me the most is how sharp and grounded the storytelling feels. There's no unnecessary melodrama, no forced comedy just pure, tightly woven espionage with a constant sense of danger. The screenplay is layered, the pacing never drops, and every twist actually feels earned instead of thrown in for shock value.

The lead performance is outstanding. The protagonist carries the entire film with an intensity that feels natural, not exaggerated. Even the supporting cast delivers everyone has a purpose, and not a single character feels wasted.

The action sequences are clean, gripping, and realistic. The background score elevates every moment without overpowering it. And the cinematography... absolutely stunning. It gives the film an international look while staying rooted in Indian intelligence operations.

What truly makes Dhurandhar special is its respect for the audience's intelligence. It trusts you to follow the clues, understand the stakes, and stay invested. I found myself fully absorbed from the first frame till the last.

After a very long time, an Indian spy movie has genuinely impressed me. Dhurandhar sets a new benchmark and proves that India can create world-class espionage thrillers without copying anyone.

A must-watch.

Pure class. 10/10.

Director Dhar navigates the balance between suspenseful strategy and high-stakes combat seamlessly. Each fight feels purposeful, each dialogue carries weight, and the cinematography accentuates both tension and emotion. The score underlines the narrative without being intrusive, ensuring the film's long runtime never feels excessive. It is a masterful convergence of direction, performance, and technical finesse.

author: anjaliknair
title: Awesome
text: Dhurandhar is an explosive, high-adrenaline espionage thriller that commands your full attention for its entire runtime. Director Aditya Dhar delivers a gritty, immersive experience, meticulously building the complex, brutal world of the Karachi underworld. Ranveer Singh is phenomenal, trading his usual flamboyance for a restrained, piercing intensity that grounds the spy-saga, while Akshaye Khanna delivers a masterclass in magnetic, chilling villainy-the highlight of the film. The technical craft is superb, with a pulsating background score that amplifies the tension and raw, impactful action sequences. It is a bold, ambitious, and tightly-woven film that rewards patience and sets a scorching, unforgettable stage for the announced sequel. A must-watch big-screen experience.

author: Wilot
title: A Relentless, Intellectual Bloodbath
text:
If Uri was a surgical strike, Dhurandhar is an all-out siege. Spanning a massive 214 minutes, it avoids the "3-hour slump" by shifting its weight between visceral, R-rated action and a "Trojan Horse" plot that demands your constant attention. It is a rare action film that treats its audience as chess players rather than just spectators.

Action: Grounded, Brutal, and Kinetic Unlike the floaty, digital spectacle of modern blockbusters, the action here feels dangerously heavy.

The "Splatter" Realism: From motorcycle chases through narrow Karachi alleys to the "meat-hook" sequences, the violence is unflinching. It doesn't rely on slow-motion "hero moments"; instead, the choreography emphasizes the raw desperation of a spy fighting to survive deep undercover.

Sound as a Weapon: The background score by Shashwat Sachdev-blending Arabic hip-hop with metallic, industrial beats-turns every shootout into a sensory assault that keeps the adrenaline levels high for the entire runtime.

The Plot: A Labyrinth of Betrayal The "good plot twists" you mentioned are the film's true engine. Rather than a simple good-vs-evil story, Dhurandhar plays with nested identities:

The Long Game: Ranveer Singh's Hamza Ali Mazari isn't just a spy; he is a man playing a role within a role. The script keeps you guessing whether he has genuinely been "turned" by the brotherhood of Akshaye Khanna's charismatic Rehman Dakait.

The Moral Grey: The biggest twist isn't a "whodunnit" but a "who-am-I." The film brilliantly dismantles the bond between the hero and the villain, showing how nationalism can lead to a betrayal that feels as cold as it is necessary.

Standing Out in the Genre While many spy films (like the YRF Spy Universe) opt for "Barbieland" glamour, Dhurandhar feels lived-in. Akshaye Khanna's performance as the calculating mobster is a masterclass in quiet menace, often stealing the screen from the more restrained Ranveer Singh. It's the interplay between these two-and the shocking "Part 1" cliffhanger-that makes the length feel earned.

Final Verdict: Dhurandhar is a "quantum leap" for Indian action cinema. It's long, it's loud, and it's unapologetically violent, but it has the brains to match its brawn.

author: movie_goer82
title: Very lengthy and over stretched
text:
This should have been a web series. It had few moments of its own, but most of the time it was boring and over stretched.

By the end of three and half hours, I had reached the point where I wanted to leave the hall without completing it.

Akshay Khanna did shine as Rehman dakait. He is very talented and underutilized actor in Bollywood. Whatever role is thrown at him, he adds soul into it.

The story is twisted narrative of actual events and the person (Ajit Dobhal in reality) played by the R Madhavn is the real culprit who went to Kandhar to release Azhar masood during Atal Bihari government. Later Azhar formed JeM and did various terror attacks on India.

Don't go to the theatre to learn the history because the fake version of it is shown in the movie. If you are an action spy movie fan, then only go for it.

author: alwayshappy-14068
title: Star-Studded Entertainment for Everyone
text: The storytelling is immersive and layered, drawing viewers into a web of crime, politics, and personal vendettas. Ranveer Singh's performance is electric, balancing ferocity with quiet introspection, while the director's commitment to detail ensures the narrative never loses focus. The action sequences are grounded yet thrilling, blending realistic choreography with cinematic flair. Secondary characters, each distinct and purposeful, add depth to the storyline. Cinematography captures both the grandeur of cityscapes and the claustrophobic tension of alleyways and hideouts. The editing masterfully maintains suspense, gradually building toward an explosive second half. Every beat feels intentional, from the subtle glances between characters to the high-stakes confrontations. The film's ability to mix political intrigue with personal drama results in a rich, unforgettable viewing experience, leaving audiences in awe of its scale and precision.

author: jaydeepmishra-92208
title: Enthralling Movie
text: It's one of the best movies made on espionage...well-researched and well-written, with great acting and great direction...Dhar's direction is a masterclass in tension-building, structured in chapters that mirror a documentary's urgency. The screenplay, co-written with the director, weaves real archival footage with visceral recreations, blurring lines between fact and fiction in spine-chilling sequences-like a red-tinted assault where haunting audio of victims' voices pierces the silence. Action set pieces are choreographed with brutal realism: no glossy CGI excesses, just bone-crunching hand-to-hand combats and sniper duels that leave you breathless. It's a film that prioritizes "we will enter your home to kill" over subtle and useless diplomacy. Ranveer Singh is subtle and layered...easily his best performance...Akshaye Khanna is charming and ruthless at the same time...Arjun Rampal looks like a demon...Madhvan looks uncanny like Ajit Doval...Rakesh Bedi is great in the role of a cunning politician...Sanjay Dutt is Sanjay dutt on screen which suits his character...Sara Arjun also plays her role pretty well...Danish Pandor, Saumya Tandon and actors playing khanani brothers are good too..

author: mayankprakash1979
title: Part 1: Fiction, But Grounded - And Very Watchable
text:
Is the 3 hour 40 minute runtime justified for just Part 1 of a spy thriller? The real answer will only come with Part 2 - but one thing is clear: the film remains consistently engaging. I've enjoyed many 3-hour-plus films in the past, so the length wasn't an issue for me. The pacing is taut, and the violence is relentless but not without dramatic purpose. Most of the lead actors fully commit, and that effort shows.

The film is divided into chapters, but this choice adds little value. The narrative flows linearly, characters overlap across sections, and the chapter breaks feel more cosmetic than structural.

Is it propaganda? Yes and no - and it depends on one's lens. The film is a highly fictionalized account that draws from multiple covert operations and real geopolitical situations: the Baloch struggle, Lyari's underworld, and ISI-backed militancy. Madhavan's character, clearly modeled on Ajit Doval, does push the familiar narrative of a weak UPA vs a strong NDA - just as Uri and Article 370 did - but it never derails the storytelling. This is a well-crafted film first, with strong direction and technical finesse.

Performances are uniformly solid. Ranveer Singh is excellent when he plays it grounded - and though he stays mostly in the background here, his presence is central. Akshaye Khanna shines (as he always does), reminding us of his incredible range and how underutilized he has been over the past two decades. The biggest surprise is Rakesh Bedi, who balances humour and cunning beautifully and holds his own among heavyweights.

The only disappointment in the cast is Sanjay Dutt. He seems disinterested, and his scenes feel flat - though capable direction and stronger co-actors keep them afloat.

The music choices elevate several sequences, though the wedding "item" number could have been replaced with a slick retro track. The action is intense and impactful, but almost every gunfight is marred by excessive shaky-cam, which dilutes clarity and tension. And the final hand-to-hand combat sequence goes on far too long - clunky, old-school choreography that doesn't match the sophistication seen earlier. Interestingly, a much shorter revenge set-piece earlier in the film packs a far bigger punch.

The ending provides closure while leaving us truly curious about Ranveer's past and his next move.

Part 2 arrives in March - and I'm all in for it.

author: nikhileshbhandari
title: Ranbir Singh at His Electrifying Best
text:
Every once in a while, a film comes along that reminds you why you fell in love with cinema in the first place. Durandur, starring Ranbir Singh, is exactly that kind of movie - a heady mix of energy, emotion, and entertainment that keeps you hooked from start to finish.

From the first frame, Ranbir commands the screen with his trademark intensity and effortless charm. His portrayal of Durandur - a rebellious soul chasing both dreams and redemption - feels raw, authentic, and deeply human. There's a vulnerability behind his swagger that makes the character unforgettable.

The film's direction deserves special mention. The pacing is sharp, the visuals are stunning, and the action choreography feels fresh without going over the top. Each frame bursts with color, rhythm, and the kind of cinematic thrill that only a director confident in their craft can deliver.

But what truly sets Durandur apart is its heart. Beneath the stylized sequences and adrenaline-pumping moments lies a story about resilience, love, and the price of ambition. The music amplifies every emotion, and the supporting cast - especially the lead actress and the antagonist - elevate the story with layered performances.

author: chiragrathod09
title: Bollywood's Finest Spy Thriller in Years
text:
Aditya Dhar, the man behind the tectonic shift in Indian war cinema with Uri: The Surgical Strike, returns with Dhurandhar-a film that swaps the "How's the Josh?" adrenaline for a cold, calculated, and often unsettling look at deep-cover intelligence. Clocking in at a massive 3 hours and 34 minutes, it is an epic that demands patience but rewards it with some of the best technical craft and acting seen in recent years.

Film is monumental achievement in Hindi cinema - a nearly 4-hour epic that feels gripping from start to finish without a single dull moment. Ranveer Singh embodies Hamza, the undercover Indian agent infiltrating Karachi's deadly underworld to dismantle the ISI-terror nexus, with remarkable restraint and depth. But the real standout is Akshaye Khanna as the charismatic yet ruthless gangster Rehman Dakait - his swag, menacing presence, and razor-sharp dialogue delivery make him the undisputed MVP.

Dhar masterfully weaves real historical events (IC-814 hijacking, Parliament attack, 26/11) into a fictional Godfather-style mafia saga set in Lyari's gang wars. The world-building is immersive, the cinematography stunning, and the intelligent scripting trusts the audience with complex moral ambiguities and high-stakes espionage.

Dhurandhar is a rare beast: a high-budget blockbuster with the soul of an indie thriller. It is a masterpiece of tension and a testament to Ranveer Singh's versatility. It doesn't just ask for your attention; it commands it.

Bottom Line: If you have the stomach for its length and its grit, Dhurandhar is the most important Indian film of the year.

Rating: 10/10 - A game-changer for Bollywood, it's a theatrical must-watch. Can't wait for Part 2!

author: KetanM-12
title: "Power in Restraint: Dhurandhar Is Intelligent Cinema at Its Best"
text:
With Dhurandhar, director Aditya Dhar delivers a riveting, intelligent political thriller that stands among the finest examples of contemporary mainstream Hindi cinema. Controlled, confident, and uncompromising in its seriousness, the film proves that scale and substance need not be mutually exclusive.

Dhar's direction is exemplary. He demonstrates absolute command over tone, pacing, and narrative intent, refusing to dilute complexity for easy gratification. The film thrives on measured tension, moral ambiguity, and disciplined storytelling, allowing characters - not spectacle - to drive the drama. Every frame feels purposeful, and the director's restraint becomes the film's greatest strength.

The background score and music are near-flawless in their execution. Used with precision, the music enhances atmosphere without overpowering the narrative. Silence is treated as a storytelling tool, and the score steps in only when necessary, elevating key moments with quiet authority.

Performance-wise, Dhurandhar belongs unequivocally to Akshaye Khanna. In a career defined by understated excellence, this ranks among his finest work. Khanna delivers a performance of rare control - internal, intelligent, and deeply absorbing. With minimal dialogue and maximum impact, he commands the screen through sheer presence, making power feel lived-in rather than performed. His portrayal adds gravitas and credibility, anchoring the film's emotional and intellectual core.

Ranveer Singh matches the film's intensity with a committed, finely tuned performance, but it is Khanna's restraint that leaves the deepest impression. The supporting cast complements the narrative without a weak link in sight.

Dhurandhar is cinema that respects its audience - its intelligence, patience, and appetite for complexity. It may not court instant gratification, but it rewards engagement richly.

Verdict: A masterfully directed, superbly acted film that sets a new benchmark for serious Hindi cinema. Anchored by Akshaye Khanna's outstanding performance, Dhurandhar is essential viewing.
