author: drvinaypandey
title: A Controlled, Well-Crafted Spy Thriller Elevated by Performances and Craft
text:
Dhurandhar is a rare Bollywood spy thriller that combines strong performances, tight technical craft, and an emotionally grounded storyline. The film's biggest strength remains its cast. Ranveer Singh delivers a remarkably restrained performance, portraying an intelligence operative with quiet intensity instead of loud heroism. Akshaye Khanna's sharp, calculating presence adds intellectual weight, while Sanjay Dutt's rugged authority anchors the narrative. In supporting roles, R. Madhavan and Arjun Rampal elevate the stakes with layered, convincing portrayals.

The background score deserves special mention. Instead of relying on generic patriotic notes, it uses subtle percussive tension and atmospheric themes that heighten suspense during covert operations. The score never feels overbearing; it moves with the emotion of each scene and helps maintain a gripping tone.

The storyline and plot revolve around cross-border espionage, internal betrayal, and a mission that tests loyalty, fear, and sacrifice. Aditya Dhar keeps the plot lean and focused, allowing characters to breathe without slowing the pace too much. The writing avoids unnecessary melodrama and sticks to mission-driven realism, though a few mid-act turns feel predictable. The buildup to the climax is strong and sets a compelling foundation for Part 2.

Narration is crisp, with limited voiceovers that actually add depth instead of spoon-feeding. The film uses visual storytelling: silent glances, coded exchanges, and detailed operation sequences that make the world feel lived-in.

The editing is tight and purposeful. Action sequences are cut cleanly, without shaky-cam excess. The transitions between narrative threads are smooth, and the film maintains momentum for most of its runtime. The second act slows slightly, but the well-paced final stretch compensates.

Surprisingly, the songs are minimal and placed thoughtfully. Instead of disrupting the pace, they serve as emotional anchors during transitional moments. No random item numbers, no unnecessary romance tracks; the soundtrack stays aligned with the film's tense tone.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a performance-driven, technically polished thriller that respects the viewer's intelligence. Its controlled acting, atmospheric score, sharp editing, and grounded plot make it one of the more refined spy dramas in recent years.

Rating: 8.8/10.

author: rajaryankhan-87030
title: A Thrilling Ride with Epic Performances
text: From the very first scene, the film establishes a tension that never lets up, drawing viewers into a meticulously crafted world of strategy, betrayal, and high-stakes action. Ranveer Singh shines in a role that demands both physical prowess and subtle emotional nuance, making each choice and reaction feel authentic. The supporting actors, including key veterans, add gravitas and complexity, enriching the storyline. Director Dhar's vision is evident in every frame, combining detailed production design with a hauntingly effective score that accentuates the narrative without overwhelming it. Action sequences are intense, yet grounded, serving the story rather than existing for spectacle alone. The film's pacing allows audiences to absorb character motivations and the political intrigue, making the explosive second half even more satisfying. The realism in the portrayal of corruption, crime networks, and moral dilemmas elevates the narrative, creating a cinematic experience that feels both thrilling and meaningful.

author: krunaldesai-79352
title: Stars Shine in Action-Packed Drama
text: Each sequence is crafted with intention, balancing action, suspense, and emotional depth. Ranveer Singh delivers an immersive performance full of moral complexity, while Sanjay Dutt adds weight and menace. Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan elevate the narrative with their intelligent portrayals, and Arjun Rampal's controlled intensity contrasts with Sara Arjun's vulnerable performance. Aditya Dhar's direction ensures that pacing, tension, and character arcs intertwine perfectly. Cinematography captures both chaos and quiet tension, and the music punctuates pivotal moments, culminating in a second half that is both adrenaline-fueled and emotionally satisfying.

author: PKV07
title: A Bold, Riveting Spy Thriller Drenched in Grit and Gore
text:
Dhurandar is a bold and unflinching spy thriller soaked in raw intensity and bloody realism. Director Aditya Dhar pushes the envelope with visceral moments inspired by a true story, crafting a world that is brutal, immersive, and relentlessly gripping.

The action sequences are explosive and brilliantly staged, while the background score elevates every high-stakes moment - adding tension, urgency, and a cinematic punch.

Ranveer Singh shows remarkable maturity and evolution, delivering one of his most controlled performances.

Madhavan and Arjun Rampal amplify the screen with their commanding presence, each adding weight to the narrative.

Sanjay Dutt gets a meaty role and does complete justice to it.

But the biggest surprise is Akshaye Khanna - a silent, simmering force whose possessed rage and menacing aura take over the narration. His performance sends genuine chills down the spine.

The movie portrays the hardship of infiltration, the descent into darkness, and the desperate search for a sliver of light and a stable future.

Even at 3 hours and 30 minutes, the film's momentum never slows. The train keeps charging forward at full steam - and ends with an absolute banger of a climax.

A daring, high-voltage thriller that doesn't hold back.

author: vihaanlaad
title: Action, Emotion, and Star Power Combined
text: Every scene is crafted with precision, balancing action, suspense, and emotional resonance. Ranveer Singh delivers a layered performance, portraying a man whose moral choices are as gripping as the physical risks he faces. Sanjay Dutt adds commanding authority and menace, while Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan enhance the ensemble with nuanced performances. author: RhishikeshA
title: Dhurandhar - Intense, Stylised, Violent... but Not Quite As Good As Uri
text:
Dhurandhar is a film that announces its intent very clearly... this is going to be intense, larger than life, and unapologetically violent. By Bollywood standards, it pushes the envelope on brutality, and that in itself makes it stand out.

Aditya Dhar deserves credit for attempting to stitch together real world inspired events and characters, clearly drawing parallels to known personalities and incidents. The effort is visible, even if the execution doesn't always feel fully real.

Ranveer Singh dominates the screen as a full blown alpha male. He looks dashing, aggressive, and physically overpowering... so much so that his built is too big for his clothes. His clothes were unable to contain the bulge of his muscular built.. :D His presence is raw and commanding, and he fits perfectly into the alpha male protagonist's role!

Akshaye Khanna, however, is the real surprise. His portrayal carries a quiet but deeply unsettling violence. The smile, the posture, the controlled menace... everything is on point. His much discussed dance moves gaining traction on social media seem less about choreography and more about the aura of his character combined with the background score.

On the flip side, the female lead feels completely unnecessary. She adds neither narrative weight nor emotional depth. The film honestly didn't need a heroine at all, and her presence feels like a Bollywood necessity rather than a requirement of the story.

R. Madhavan's character strongly resembles Mr. Dobhal, but sadly, Madhavan doesn't get enough space to explore or elevate the role. It feels like a missed opportunity for an actor of his calibre. Arjun Rampal remains strictly average... no highs, no lows, just present. Sanjay Dutt, on the other hand, brings in a rugged, old school masculinity. Broad shouldered, raw, yet oddly classy... he proves once again that some actors genuinely age well.

A special mention goes to Rakesh Bedi, whose performance feels underrated. His Urdu lehza is authentic, his physicality matches the character, and he looks convincingly real in the role. He was excellent in Uri as well, and his consistency continues here.

That comparison with Uri is inevitable... and unfortunately for Dhurandhar, Uri was far more grounded, believable, and impactful. In comparison, Dhurandhar leans heavily into stylisation and violence, sometimes at the cost of realism.

Final verdict: Dhurandhar is intense, ambitious, and visually aggressive. It doesn't quite reach the emotional or narrative strength of Uri, but it's still a solid one-time watch.. especially for those who enjoy gritty, masculine, high-voltage cinema.

Not flawless, not forgettable... but definitely not Dhar's best.

author: TenzinW-40
title: Authentic, Gritty, and True
text:
Dhurandhar genuinely surprised me-in the best way. As someone from the armed forces, I'm usually very critical of how movies portray intelligence work, but this film felt real, grounded, and respectful of the profession. It didn't exaggerate the life of a spy with unnecessary glamour or over-the-top heroism. Instead, it captured the silent grit, the constant tension, and the unseen sacrifices that define real operatives.

The storyline is tight, the pacing sharp, and the character development subtle yet powerful. What impressed me most was how the film showed the emotional weight carried by those who work in the shadows-how every decision they make comes with consequences the world never hears about. The lead actor delivered a performance that felt authentic, restrained, and deeply human.

For me, Dhurandhar stands out because it offers respect to the intelligence community without turning them into caricatures. It reminds you that true heroes are often the ones who never get recognition.

author: justmailsameer
title: Seedhe baat No Bakwas
text:
I saw Dhurandhar yesterday and was awestruck by the sincerity and clarity with which the whole story has been told - brutally honest, very straightforward. This is unapologetically a pro-India film, and for me, that is exactly why it matters right now. The True Dhurandhar is Mr. Aditya Dhar.

For me, Dhurandhar feels like Hindi cinema's Schindler's List moment in spirit - a long, edge of the seat and essential cinematic document that entertains, disturbs and, above all, refuses to lie about the cost of keeping this country standing. Sidhee baat, no bakwas: this is the kind of film that doesn't just deserve to work at the box office, it deserves to be rewatched, debated and remembered.

author: Kalpesh_Rajdeo
title: A Gripping Saga with a Rushed Finale
text:
A larger-than-life thriller that earns its runtime, despite a messy landing and poor action.

If you see the 3.5-hour runtime and hesitate, don't. Dhurandhar moves with such pace and intensity that it genuinely does not feel like a long movie. It is an excellent thriller anchored by great dialogues and massive screen presence from (most of) its cast.

The absolute highlight is Akshaye Khanna. I predicted this back when the trailers dropped, but the "aura farming" he achieves here is legendary. He cuts a menacing figure throughout the film and steals every scene he is in.

He is backed by strong performances from R. Madhavan, who brings incredible poise to the screen, and Arjun Rampal, whose sinister presence adds a layer of dread to the narrative.

What sets this apart from the standard Bollywood fare, however, is the treatment of the protagonist. It was a swift and welcome departure to see a hero allowed to be vulnerable. Moving away from the "untouchable god" trope made the stakes feel real.

Unfortunately, Sanjay Dutt's SP Chaudhary was a let down. The character felt less capable than the setting demanded, and it felt like a missed opportunity. As for the leading lady, she was just okay, not hateable, but not memorable either.

The biggest technical flaw, however, is the action. It is painful to say, but it seems we Indians cannot choreograph a good gunfight if our lives depended on it. For a movie with such high stakes, the shootouts lacked the tactical grit and polish needed to be convincing.

The film stumbles hardest at the finish line. The story culminates in a chaotic scramble that felt like an absolute mess. It was rushed and missed a golden opportunity to deliver a truly diabolical, dark ending that the tone of the movie deserved.

However, the movie saves face in the dying moments. The final reveal of the plan and the setup for Part 2 were welcome additions that left me wanting more.

text:
This movie is raw and brutal. Not only does it not shy away from showing the truth of state sponsored terrorism, but also shows it with the most grounded and realistic way possible. The action is top notch. The brutality is top notch. The music is top notch. The cinematography is top notch. Story is simple but the way of showing it is amazing and gut wrenching.

It may feel slow in the middle, but the second half picks pace and delivers the ultimate fun that you can expect in a spy film.

author: vidhanjaiswal
title: Big Action, Big Drama, Big Stars
text: The film is an intense exploration of morality, power, and survival in a dangerous underworld. Ranveer Singh delivers a performance full of nuance, seamlessly balancing vulnerability, determination, and strategic calculation. Sanjay Dutt brings weight, authority, and menace to every scene. Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan provide subtle, layered performances that strengthen the narrative. Arjun Rampal exudes quiet menace that keeps tension taut, while Sara Arjun's emotional depth highlights the stakes. Aditya Dhar's direction integrates suspense, strategic plotting, and thrilling action sequences perfectly. Cinematography captures both the chaos of urban landscapes and the intimacy of human moments, while the score heightens suspense and emotion. By the climax, the story delivers a thrilling and emotionally satisfying payoff.

author: AnthonyDsilwa
title: Dhurandhar: A Refreshing Espionage Thriller Bollywood Needed
text: Catching Dhurandhar at Movietime Goregaon East was a refreshing change, especially since high-quality Bollywood releases have felt a bit rare lately. This film is a significant contribution to the industry, proving there is a massive demand among discerning viewers for well-crafted, high-stakes espionage thrillers. The technical precision and focus on authentic intelligence-gathering techniques make it a standout entry that elevates the typical spy genre. I suspect the film will find a particularly deep connection with Muslim audiences, as its narrative layers and cultural nuances are handled with a unique level of relatability. It is exactly the kind of intelligent, mission-driven cinema we need more of to keep the Bollywood industry evolving and engaging for its core audience. Becauz of its sharp execution and much-needed focus on a sophisticated plot, am giving Dhurandhar three and a half stars.

author: manishkj-56342
title: Overrated, Stretched storyline, Great Acting by Akshay Khanna and Ranveer Singh
text:
Despite the stellar acting, the film's biggest enemy is its own ambition. Clocking in at a staggering 214 minutes (over 3.5 hours), the storyline feels significantly stretched.

While the "chapters" format worked for Aditya Dhar in Uri, here it leads to a meandering middle act. The deep dive into the internal politics of the Karachi underworld is atmospheric, but it often loses sight of the central espionage plot. By the time the film reaches its final act, the sheer volume of events creates a sense of fatigue that even the high-octane action sequences can't entirely fix.

Not sure whether to call it a movie or documentary it would definitely leave an impression on you after you walk out of the movie. No romance or cheap dialogues or objectification ,it's a pure art , feel and enjoy. It's a festival or celebration for people who are tired of watching the same larger than life or mediocre movies. It's a fresh genre called not for faint or weak hearts.

I purely went to watch Ranveer Singh on large screen and fell in love with the entire cast and esp the man behind the curtain Mr Aditya Dhar. I felt he might not get the praise he deserves as this movie is meant for less percentage of people and not for masses but please don't stop making them. We all know the acting prowess of ensemble cast and doesn't need any validation from people. If you love pulp fiction or god father or any other classic movie of Hollywood then you will love Dhurandhar.

Sanjay Dutt brings authority, gravitas, and menace, while Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan enhance the story with intelligence and subtlety. Aditya Dhar's direction orchestrates tension, strategic plotting, and action sequences seamlessly. Cinematography captures both chaos and quiet moments with equal skill, and the score accentuates suspense and drama. By the climax, the film delivers both emotional and adrenaline-fueled satisfaction.

author: sureshaug-96608
title: Drama That Punches Straight to the Heart
text: Suspense hangs over every frame, meticulously crafted through clever storytelling and strategic pacing. Ranveer Singh navigates his character's internal conflicts with subtlety, making morally ambiguous choices relatable and compelling. Action sequences are choreographed with precision, each punch and chase sequence serving the story rather than spectacle. Dhar's direction balances tension and emotional depth, creating a cinematic rhythm that captivates. The supporting ensemble delivers layered performances, enriching the narrative's stakes. The visual language, combined with a tense score, amplifies both fear and anticipation. By the climax, the audience is fully invested in outcomes that feel earned and unpredictable.

author: PrittyM-8
title: High Ambition, Moderate Impact!
text: Dhurandhar is an intense action-thriller that aims high but delivers a mixed experience. As a reviewer, I found the premise strong and the setup gripping, with its focus on covert missions, patriotism, and moral ambiguity working well in the first half. The performances are committed and the action sequences are slick, adding weight to the narrative. However, as the film progresses, the storytelling becomes uneven, with predictable turns and emotional beats that don't fully land. While the ambition and scale are commendable, Dhurandhar ultimately feels like a film that had the potential to be sharper and more impactful, making it a decent watch rather than a memorable one.

author: akilg-52
title: Dhurrandar is it worth it?
text: Dhurandhar is a poorly made film whose critical acclaim was baffling. Despite entering with high expectations, I was very disappointed by its repetitive violence and lack of meaningful storytelling. The violence, instead of deepening the narrative, felt cartoonish and excessive, serving only to glorify the protagonist's masculinity. The spy-thriller plot lacked real tension, as the main character never seemed truly in danger, making the story feel hollow. Action sequences, though heavily promoted, were clumsily choreographed and lacked creativity or realism. Ranveer Singh's lead role felt purposeless, existing mainly to serve that political agenda. A few positives were noted - mainly a strong opening and Akshaye Khanna's performance. Dhurandhar had potential, it sacrificed good storytelling for nationalistic spectacle, proving that in modern Bollywood, "nationalism sells."

author: shreyassharma-22107

author: subhsanti
title: A Non-Stop Adventure Led by Big Stars
text: Every frame of the movie feels deliberate, with storytelling that rewards patience and attention. Ranveer Singh inhabits his role fully, delivering a layered performance that oscillates between raw aggression and emotional depth. The female lead adds a quiet yet piercing intensity, creating a perfect counterbalance to the protagonist's energy. Director Dhar's mastery is evident in the way multiple storylines converge seamlessly, maintaining suspense while exploring complex human motivations. Action sequences are not just visually stunning but narratively meaningful, pushing the story forward while reflecting the characters' stakes. The cinematography excels in capturing both sprawling cityscapes and intimate interiors, providing a sense of scale and depth. Each edit is purposeful, ensuring rhythm and flow that never feels rushed. The background score punctuates key moments with subtlety and power, reinforcing tension and emotion. author: KeerthiP-65
title: Good to see Ranveer back in screen
text:
Dhurandhar is that rare film which doesn't let you blink, let alone yawn. From the very first scene to the last, there isn't a single dull moment - the movie grips you, shakes you, and keeps you glued to your seat throughout. The character choices are spot-on, and every role feels deliberate and well-placed. Akshaye Khanna absolutely steals the show with his screen presence. Ranveer gives a stunning performance as well - despite having very few dialogues, his reactions alone carry major portions of the narrative forward. All the supporting actors have delivered excellent work and elevate the intensity of the film.

The action sequences are staged brilliantly - raw, violent, and high-impact. However, they do feel like they're following the current trend in action cinema rather than offering something new. There's also a tiny bit of propaganda sprinkled into the narrative, and it's quite evident, which may not land well with everyone. The cinematography is stylish, and the chapter-based story staging adds a nice structural rhythm to the film.

Ranveer and Sara Arjun's chemistry feels a bit off - maybe because I've seen her as a child actor, so imagining her opposite Ranveer felt slightly strange. The story itself leans heavily to one side, presenting a very singular perspective about India. The music is good, fits the tone, but isn't particularly memorable or groundbreaking.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a solid, engaging film that delivers on intensity and performance. It's definitely a good watch if you enjoy fast-paced thrillers with strong character moments.

author: connectu-162-742401
title: Emotional & Reflective
text:
Dhurandhar is a cinematic wake-up call for every watcher.. top-tier artists, fearless storytelling, and truth presented with unmatched intensity. Finally 4 hours spent wisely. Having left my motherland 25 years ago, going to the cinema has always been a moment of contemplation for me, especially given the reputation Bollywood has carried over the years. But Dhurandar changed something within me and people around me..

This film gave me answers I've been holding inside for decades. When demonetisation happened, many friends from Delhi kept rattling on with negativity, never acknowledging the deeper truth. Most of them, frankly, are businessmen dealing in black money and avoiding taxes, and yet they complained the loudest. This movie finally exposes the mindset and the networks that have been weakening the nation for nearly 50 years. Watching it felt like a personal relief, a sense of peace, because the truth was finally put on screen for all to see.

Coming to the performances.... hats off to Maddy and Akshay Khanna. They have delivered a true definition of art. Their portrayal has reignited in me the desire to return to the cinema and witness meaningful films on the big screen.

For context, the last movie I saw in a cinema was Vikram Vedha (in Tamil)... I didn't understand a single word, but still enjoyed every second of it. That's the power of good cinema.

It is my observation that India is transitioning into a new demographic i.e.- intelligent, aware, wise, and this film reflects that shift beautifully. Ranveer, despite being young and still early in his journey, has done a remarkable job. And Aditya Dhar.. whom I didn't even know before yesterday ... deserves all the credit for such powerful direction. If he ever reads this, I want to send him my blessings and heartfelt wishes for continued success.

Indian cinema is finally moving in a positive direction, destined to become one of the world's finest industries. And seeing self-made artists, especially from the South, getting their due recognition is truly a blessing.

Personally speaking, Dhurandar is more than a movie... it's an awakening. Thanks to everyone involved in the movie for creating those 3 hours that helped me move away from my personal daily race ofroti, kapda, aur makan :)

author: manishratna23
title: Movie of the year
text: Undoubtedly it is the best movie of 2025. The movie is 3 hrs 30 mins long but it's so entertaining that you never feel it to be so long. The acting performances are all top notch with Akshay Khanna stealing the show as Rahman Dakait,Ranvir singh just keeps on improving with time and this might be his best performance. Sanjay Dutt has done exceptionally well with his perfect comic timing. Then thers Rakesh Bedi ,madhavan and Arjun rampal who even with limited time have set the standard high. The music is fresh with no silly remakes. Background score is exceptional throughout. The story keeps you gripped throughout ,the sets are designed perfectly. The level of violence is slightly on extreme side and not everyone might be comfortable with it. Overall a perfect masla entertainer and a must watch.

author: anku_jai
title: One of the Best Film of 2025, Hands down
text: This movie stands tall among one of India's strongest films of 2025. The story pulls you in from the beginning and stays tight throughout. The main characters feel real, carry real emotion, and the supporting cast actually adds value instead of just filling space. The action is sharp, well-shot, and never over the top. The backdrop of India's geopolitical events from 1999 to 2010 is blended smoothly with real news clips, making the film feel grounded. Smart humour appears at the right moments, giving small breathers between heavy scenes. Overall, it's a solid, engaging, and absolutely must-watch film.

author: Ashiiish
title: A Brutal And Unflinching War Drama That Loses Its Grip Along the Way
text:
Dhurandhar opens with a jolt. The film throws you straight into the brutality of its historical backdrop, staging the violence with a kind of cold intensity that doesn't let up. Rumoured to be inspired by the real life of Major Mohit Sharma, the story dives into the world of undercover operations, betrayal, and the constant tension of living behind enemy lines.

The performances are easily the strongest pillar here. Ranveer Singh handles the lead role with solid control, especially in the heavier moments, though the film never lets us truly get under his skin. The real standout is Akshaye Khanna as Rehman Dakait. He barely speaks, yet his eyes carry entire paragraphs. Every expression lands like a threat, and he steals the frame without even trying.

Technically, Dhurandhar is one of the most impressive Indian films in a while. The background score keeps tightening the rope around the audience, the cinematography and color palette create an eerie authenticity, and the VFX work blends so well with the practical shots that you barely notice the seams. Some of the chase scenes use a shaky camera style that actually heightens the panic. The set design is remarkable too. Even though they clearly couldn't shoot in the real locations, the recreation is so convincing you forget you're watching a constructed world.

There's a moment where real footage is folded into an action scene and another where the film cuts from the dramatization of the 26/11 handlers to the actual audio. Both scenes are chilling, and honestly the closest the film gets to brilliance. The action is brutal, grounded, and shockingly raw. Nothing is sugar-coated, and some moments push into gore unlike anything we've really seen in mainstream Indian cinema. The makeup and costuming only make it feel more real.

But the film collapses under its own weight. There are too many characters, too many arcs, and too many threads fighting for attention. With the narrative jumping around so much, there's almost no emotional connection with the protagonist or his mission. It's hard to care whether he succeeds or fails when the film doesn't slow down enough to let us live with him.

The romance between Ranveer Singh and Sara Arjun is easily the weakest part. Both actors perform well individually, but together the chemistry feels awkward and completely mismatched. It pulls you out of the story every time they appear as a couple.

The violence, while impressive in execution, sometimes crosses into excess. There are moments that feel gruesome just for the sake of being gruesome, adding shock but not substance.

The pacing is another major issue. The film feels extremely long, stretched by subplots that don't really need to exist. By the time it announces a second part coming in March 2026, the ending doesn't spark the excitement it thinks it does. Instead of a cliffhanger, it feels more like a pause you weren't ready for.

Dhurandhar is ambitious, technically outstanding, and filled with powerful performances, but it's weighed down by bloat and uneven emotional storytelling. It's a film you respect more than you love.

author: karanpuri-43429
title: A Confused Inspiration That Ends Up Feeling Like a Spoof
text:
Dhurandhar feels like a confused creation-an unnecessary, aimless attempt to mix the cheap, mindless brutality of Animal with the disciplined logic and patriotism of Uri. Predictably, it fails at both.

There is nothing genuinely serious or sincere about this film. The marketing leans heavily on the presence of a real army man in the trailers, only to completely deceive the audience in the climax. What unfolds instead resembles a spoof-loud, hollow, and shockingly disrespectful.

The film offers no real credit to the actual hero whose story it pretends to tell. The so-called 'big reveal' of the protagonist's background is delayed until the very end, only for viewers to discover that it has no connection to reality. One walks out feeling misled and cheated.

title: Visually striking kills and superb plot
text:

Acting and dialogues are spectacular but the direction is what keeps everything well bound and doesn't let the story slip-up. The film absolutely delivers and forces you to think, is this sort of violence the only way to win over Jihadists ?

author: pabloescobar-66603
title: Blockbuster
text:
Dhurandar stands out primarily because of its stellar ensemble. Whether it's R. Madhavan, Ranveer Singh, Akshaye Khanna, Sanjay Dutt, or Arjun Rampal, each actor delivers exactly what the narrative demands of them. The performances feel lived-in, disciplined, and powerful.

From its opening scene, the film pulls you into a world dense with atmosphere and tension. It delivers chills, emotional weight, and a sense of urgency that rarely lets up. The screenplay captures a wide spectrum of emotions experienced by everyday Indians, especially through its sharp dialogues and the haunting struggles of the unnamed gunmen at its core.

Ranveer Singh shines in the emotionally heavy moments and handles the high-octane action with complete command. R. Madhavan is outstanding - one particular moment where he seemingly breaks the fourth wall is both audacious and unforgettable.

Aditya Dhar's vision deserves special mention. As a writer-director, he demonstrates remarkable control over tone, pacing, and thematic depth. His storytelling is bold, cohesive, and unapologetically cinematic. Few filmmakers can balance realism, patriotism, and spectacle with such finesse, and Dhurandar cements Dhar as one of the most exciting voices in contemporary Indian cinema.

In the end, Dhurandar is not just a film - it is an experience crafted with conviction and artistry.

Jai Hind.

author: wazeemhasan
title: Sad reality of Bollywood
text:
Just watched Dhurandhar. Since the story is based on Lyari, a neighborhood in Karachi just a few kilometers from where I live, I was curious to see what version Bollywood would roll out about something we Karachiites actually witnessed during the 2008-09 era.

1. The repeated idea that whoever rules Lyari rules Karachi is absolutely wrong in the movie. They have no idea about the real political power game in Karachi during 2008-09. The Lyari gang war existed, but it was only one small part of a much bigger landscape. Lyari itself is only 0.17 percent of the entire city.

2. No one in Pakistan celebrated the 26/11 Mumbai attacks. That is an impression Bollywood keeps feeding its audience. The whole "We will destroy India" gimmick does not work in Pakistan. People do not buy it. Even political and religious parties tried selling it and failed. People here are simply not interested in that chooran.

3. Lyari gang war was an internal conflict between local gangs fighting for territory and resources, tied to local and provincial politics. Linking it to 26/11 is just ridiculous. There is not even surface-level evidence for such a claim. But since that kind of narrative works for an Indian audience, Bollywood packaged and sold it.

4. In the story, India supposedly had all the intel about 26/11 and it still happened. It actually portrays how weak and incompetent the security layers were. The way the attackers keep communicating so easily on phone devices is not possible without inside help. In their self-victimization kink, they forgot what they themselves showed on screen.

5. The Indian spy repeatedly saying "Jisne Lyari pe hukumat ki, usne puray Karachi pe hukumat ki" is the funniest part. Do some actual research and you will understand who ruled Karachi in that timeline and what kind of power he had. Next time, come to us. We will tell you better stories this city holds.

Summary: This is just another anti-Pakistan movie strategically designed to emotionally trigger the Indian audience through 26/11 and remind them that the-then government (Congress) did nothing, while the current government (BJP) is portrayed as the savior. Two dialogues make this intent obvious. One where the Pakistani General sarcastically says, "We were expecting some reaction from India but they did nothing." The second when the Indian minister says, "Kabhi koi sarkar to aayegi jisko desh ki chinta hogi."

author: veerakonkepudi
title: New school Action unleashed with a old script
text:
Dhurandar is a star studded cast with a heavy script and a thunderous screenplay. A cold blooded Gangster drama unleashes the performance of every star in this film to the roof. But the script is too old pointing to clashes around the line of control. The film traces an old script of a spy winning his battles against criminal networks, shadowy operatives and personal demons - all framed around cross border tensions. The Arabic song that introduces Akshay Khanna in a new avatar scores fandom in a friendly fashion, while steer- rocketing his act to the roof.

Sanjay Dutt was given a heavy role but should have won a larger time on screen. Ranveer in a new fashion, embraces perfectionism with his looks. This film is all glitter as reality is not even close to what's revealed in the movie.

author: JatinD-924
title: Ignore the "intellectual" haters-this is 100% facts and pure Aura.
text:
I've seen some people writing essays on here calling this movie 'misguided noise' or complaining that it 'lacks depth.' Honestly? They watched a different movie.

First off, ignore anyone complaining about the runtime. The length is absolutely not a problem. The storytelling is so good that by the time it ended, the whole theater actually wanted more. It doesn't drag; it builds.

People love to throw around the word 'propaganda' whenever a movie shows India winning, but Dhurandhar just presents facts, not opinions. It's a true story, grounded in reality, not some 'distorted' narrative. It doesn't manipulate you; it just shows you what actually happened, and that reality is gritty enough on its own.

And let's talk performances. Everyone did their job, but Akshaye Khanna was on a different level. He literally 'aura farmed' the entire movie. Even next to Ranveer Singh, Akshaye stole every single scene he was in. He portrayed exactly what that character needed to be-cold, sharp, and commanding.

The fighting scenes? Top-notch. No 'hyper-stylized' fluff, just hard-hitting action.

Bottom line: If you want to read a thesis on 'cinematic nuance,' go read the negative reviews. If you want to watch a top-tier, factual movie where the actors and action deliver 100%, watch Dhurandhar.

author: md_bunny1003
title: Ending the Year with a Bang
text:
The film does not feel like having a runtime of 3h 34m, because of one high octane sequence after the other.

It begins with a tense premise, and picks up from there. Ranveer Singh takes the reins of the protagonist confidently, oozing aura in every slow motion walk and piercing eyes. He is vigilant, charismatic, and knows to deftly manoeuvre his enemies while being in the shadows. He also brings a certain vulnerability into the character despite the intensity, and that keeps you engrossed. Ranveer Singh continues to explore new genres and is one of the most versatile actors we have in Bollywood today.

Gangster politics and mafia being the central theme, there is violence and gore galore. Enough has been said about Akshaye Khanna, but credit is where credit's due. He blends into the character of the savage Rehman Dakait seamlessly, while Arjun Rampal plays Major Iqbal who is out for blood and destruction with an eerie sense of calm.

The songs thankfully do not disrupt the narrative.

I wanted to see more of R Madhavan and Sanjay Dutt here. Perhaps in the sequel?

With a solid first part, here's hoping that Dhurandhar part 2 does not meander from its theme.

Here's to better Bollywood cinemas!

author: nishajamvwal78
title: Of Grit Gore & Glory : Dhurandhar !
text:
Dhurandhar

I walked out of Dhurandhar in a time capsule - I had been living inside another, darker, more dangerous universe for three and a half hours. Rarely does a film hold one so completely, with a pace so assured and muscular, that time ceases to exist. Dhurandhar does exactly that - it grips, tightens its hold, and refuses to let go.

And then came the surprise. The kind that cinema sometimes delivers: I have always been a self-confessed admirer of Akshaye Khanna - his intelligence, his restraint, his eloquent understatement. But nothing had prepared me for the fact that he would walk away with the film. Yes, the film stars Ranveer Singh - the headline name, the force of nature, reportedly paid a staggering fifty crores - while Akshaye Khanna was allegedly paid a small fraction of that. And yet, it is Akshaye who dominates the emotional and psychological landscape of Dhurandhar.

As Rehman Dakait, he is terrifyingly elegant - a royal Don, composed, watchful, lethal. There is a Don Corleone gravitas to his performance: measured silences, piercing eyes, and a menace that doesn't need volume. After Chhaava earlier this year, this performance cements Akshaye Khanna as arguably the most talked-about and celebrated actor of the moment. It's not loud acting - it's authoritative, cerebral, and devastating. No wonder the internet exploded with so much about him and even speculations about his love life .

Aditya Dhar's direction is nothing short of fearless and magnetic. With a formidable ensemble - Ranveer Singh, Sanjay Dutt, R. Madhavan, Arjun Rampal, and Rakesh Bedi - Dhurandhar unfolds as a bold, immersive experience that pushes Bollywood into a braver, grittier, far more authentic zone. The title itself means stalwart, and the film lives up to that promise.

Structured in a chapter-wise, docu-newsy narrative style - borrowing the best from web series storytelling - the film explores across-the-border terrorism with intense research, precision, and nerve. ( journalist Aditya Raj Kaul served as Research Consultant drawing inspiration from real Indian intelligence operations and figures) Each segment adds a new layer, a new tension, a fresh perspective. The storytelling is gripping because it is rooted in truth, analysis, and lived geopolitical realities.

Ranveer Singh as Dhurandhar is dynamite - but not in his usual flamboyant style. As Hamza Ali Mazari he is controlled, coiled, silent. A deadly daredevil who bides his time, watches patiently, and strikes only when it matters to win the trust of Rehman Daikat (Akshaye Khanna) and his men. It's a restrained, internalised performance - and that restraint makes it powerful. You nearly dont recognise Ranveer Singh here!

What elevates Dhurandhar is its extraordinary authenticity. The production design and locations plunge you straight into the claustrophobic, dangerous lanes of Lyari, Karachi - you don't watch it, you walk through it. The dialogues land hard. The action choreography is raw and unvarnished. There is brutality here, yes - but it is honest brutality, exposing systemic flaws without apology or fear. The selective use of cult Bollywood songs only heightens tension and deepens emotional texture.

For once, Bollywood abandons glossy spies, oiled waxed sculpted bodies, and stylised swagger with floosie women dancing around - and instead embraces grit, fatigue, fear, blood, gore and moral ambiguity. The anxiety, anticipation, and suspense are constant companions.

This film is, at its core, a homage - to the countless Dhurandhars: the unnamed, unknown, unsung men and women who operate in shadows so that the rest of us in India sleep in peace.

Madhavan is pitch-perfect as (we suspect) Aditya Duval - intelligent and grounded. Sanjay Dutt is burly, commanding, menacing in a way only he can be. Arjun Rampal as Major Iqbal is chilling and gory and may arguably be the portrayal of one of the most dreaded terrorists, Illyas Kashmiri. But that is speciation. And Rakesh Bedi's return in a completely unexpected avatar as Jameel is one of the film's quiet triumphs. Even the romantic moments never distract - they only intensify the stakes.

Aditya Dhar, take a bow. After Uri and Article 370, he once again proves that Indian cinema can match - and sometimes surpass - the intensity of post-9/11 Hollywood political and spy thrillers. The box-office numbers are obvious proof of how audiences have taken to this film : a film that shakes you. As I watched audiences shouted 'Bharat Mata Ki Jai" in patriotic fervour that gave me goosebumps!

Inspired by real incidents and covert operations, Dhurandhar tracks the perilous journey of an undercover agent behind enemy lines with nerve, nuance, and conviction. Each moment is mesmerising. Each performance, sharply etched.

I'm already waiting - impatiently - for Revenge: Part 2.

Dhurandhar doesn't entertain. It unsettles and shakes you to the core. It awakens. And it reminds us that courage is often silent - and always costly.

Nisha JamVwal.

author: VivekShuklaShuklas
title: Dhurandhar is not just a spy film. It is a lived experience.
text:
A true-event espionage story that does not entertain you from a safe distance, but drags you straight into its moral weight, its fear, and its brutal realism. This is cinema that sits heavy on the chest.

There is a moment during the terror attack scene in front of Humza where the body reacts before the mind does. The helplessness is suffocating. The chanting, the chaos, the paralysis of a man trained to act but forced to watch. It was unsettling enough to make the hands cold and the spine shiver. That is not drama. That is truth hitting without warning.

What makes Dhurandhar a magnet, something you cannot pull yourself away from, is its cinematic confidence. The world feels lived-in, not designed. Lyari is not shown as a backdrop but as a breathing organism. Politics shifts like quicksand. Loyalties bend. Power changes hands silently. Every frame feels intentional. The camera does not shout. It observes.

This is where Aditya Dhar proves once again that he is operating on a different plane. His writing is sharp without being preachy. His direction trusts the audience to think. The craft here is world-class, full stop.

Rehman Dakait's portrayal has already received the praise it deserves, and rightly so. There is no need to add noise there. Some performances speak loudly by saying very little.

But the real surprise, the real anchor, is Ranveer Singh as Humza. This is not the loud, kinetic Ranveer Singh people expect. This is restrained, controlled, and frighteningly internal.

The scenes where he absorbs the planning of ISI and the gangs plotting against India are masterclasses in silent acting. You can see the calculations behind the eyes. Later, when he decides to become the king of Karachi and explains this choice to his girlfriend, the shift is seamless. No grand monologue. Just conviction. That scene alone proves how deeply he understood this character.

What the film captures perfectly is the contradiction of a spy. A man who thinks like a politician, operates like a criminal, loves like a human being, protects like a father, and still remains a patriot. Balancing all those identities without turning caricature is incredibly difficult. This film nails it.

The runtime is nearly three and a half hours, yet when the credits roll, the instinct is not to stand up. It is to sit. To breathe. Three and a half hours pass like twenty minutes. That is the ultimate compliment to storytelling.

Box office numbers will do whatever they do. That is noise. What matters is this: this film is not leaving theatres anytime soon. It will hold its ground until the next release on 19th March, because word of mouth like this cannot be bought.

To the entire cast, crew, production team, and especially to Aditya Dhar: thank you for raising the bar and quietly changing the face of Bollywood. Take a bow. And please, do not make us wait another six years after 19th March for the next one.

Lots of love & Bharat Mata Ki Jay üáÆüá≥

author: amanbhargava-01511
title: Cinema That Brings Audiences Back to Theatres
text:
I watched Dhurandhaar in the theatre last night, and the experience was truly impressive. The theatre was almost full, and in my city all 32 shows were running housefull, which clearly shows the strong audience response. At a time when OTT platforms dominate, Dhurandhaar has successfully pulled people back into theatres-and that itself is a big achievement.

The film has created its own unique identity. The inclusion of real footage and guided segments during the movie elevates it to a completely different level, making it feel more like an experience than just a film.

Talking about performances, the acting across the board is very strong. The film reinforces a powerful message- no matter how much the truth is suppressed, it eventually finds its way out.

I would especially like to appreciate the side characters, who have delivered commendable performances and added depth to the story. Arjun Rampal's role is brief, but it leaves a lasting impact despite the limited screen time.

One small drawback is the chapter-based storytelling. While the concept works, the chapters feel slightly incomplete when they end, as they lack a proper closure, which leaves a sense of incompleteness.

üîπ Overall: A well-made film with impactful storytelling and strong performances that truly deserves a theatrical watch.

Dhurandhaar is a must-watch for those who believe the real magic of cinema belongs on the big screen. üé•‚ú®

author: abhishekmenon-93126
title: Redefining The Indian Spy Thriller
text:
I'm no film critic, just an ordinary guy who loves a good movie, and let me tell you, Dhurandhar is more than just "good"-it's a masterclass in style, swag, and pure presentation.

This film is so well-made that it honestly makes some of the other recent "spy universe" flicks look like garbage. This isn't just a fantasy; it feels real, with its use of genuine footage, real-life references, and locations. It's a deep, gritty dive, and I honestly don't get why anyone would have a problem with its commitment to a grounded narrative. But hey, as they say, no critic is a negative critic; it's all just helping the movie, and I'm glad for that.

I watched it in Canada, so I went through all 3.5 hours without a single break. Not a second of that extensive runtime felt boring or dragged out. That, in itself, is an enormous achievement and a testament to the taut direction and editing. Great job Aditya and team!!

The entire ensemble is unbelievably strong, with every single character being extremely impactful. While there is-and rightly should be-more talk about Akshaye Khanna's brilliant performance, it was Ranveer Singh who blew my mind with his incredible calmness. His portrayal as the collected operative, often in the background or on the back foot, is exactly what the role demanded. Amazing work by the entire cast.

A huge, massive shoutout to Shashwat Sachdev, the music director, because he is truly the soul of this movie! The blend of his score with the "tadka" of artists like Hanumankind and Arijit Singh has instantly become my new, long-term playlist. So many songs, and each one is better than the last. My current favorite is definitely the Diljit's "Ez Ez," and that incredible bagpipe music-just wow.

Madhavan, Sanju, Arjun, Rakesh Bedi, Sara, Danish ++ and every actor was perfectly cast and apt in their role. I never wanted time to move faster in the theatre, and now all I want is for it to speed up until Part 2 arrives in March.

This is an extremely stylish, gripping, and satisfying movie. Go watch it!

author: gauravshah-16434
title: High Voltage Action Drama Movie
text:
Movie Review: Dhurandhar ‚≠ê Rating: 7/10

Dhurandhar is a gritty, high-voltage action drama that dares to blend geopolitics, intelligence operations and raw emotion into one intense package. The story dives deep into RAW-ISI dynamics and India-Pakistan geopolitical tensions, giving the film a strong patriotic flavour that is bound to resonate with audiences in the coming days.

With a runtime of 3 hours and 30 minutes, the film is surprisingly engaging. Except for a few songs that momentarily break the momentum, the narrative remains gripping throughout. One of its major strengths is the chapter-wise storytelling, where each segment unfolds like a new episode-fresh, fast-paced and well-structured.

Ranveer Singh delivers a classy, refined and deeply hard-worked performance. His intensity is magnetic from start to finish. But the scene-stealer is undoubtedly Akshaye Khanna as Rehman Daikat-sharp, fearless and brilliantly unpredictable.

Sanjay Dutt once again brings his iconic swagger, effortlessly owning his deadly-cop avatar. Arjun Rampal adds solid support with a decent and impactful presence.

A noteworthy addition is Sara Arjun, who performs with maturity and confidence, matching the expectations set for her role.

Technically, the film shines bright.

The cinematography is outstanding-realistic, immersive and visually grand. Many scenes look so authentic that it genuinely feels as if they were shot in Pakistan. The frames are raw, gritty and beautifully crafted, adding tremendous depth to the geo-political mood of the film.

Be cautioned: Dhurandhar is loaded with violence and frequent vulgar language, making it unsuitable for family viewing, especially for younger audiences.

Despite its intensity and rough edges, the film stands strong on patriotism, powerful performances and a bold narrative. It's poised to be a huge hit as word spreads.

And with the story ending on a sharp cliffhanger, Part 2 arriving in March 2026 is definitely something to look forward to.

author: akshanshgarg
title: A cinematic masterpiece
text:
After a very long time, Bollywood has come breathtakingly close to cinematic perfection, and Dhurandhar is the reason why.

This is not just a film-it's an experience. Every frame feels intentional, every silence speaks, and every emotion lands with remarkable precision. The storytelling is layered yet accessible, powerful without being loud. It respects the intelligence of the audience and rewards patience with depth.

The performances are nothing short of extraordinary. Each actor inhabits their character so completely that the line between performance and reality begins to blur. The direction is confident and mature, allowing the story to unfold organically rather than forcing moments for effect.

Technically, Dhurandhar is impeccable. The cinematography elevates the narrative, the background score enhances emotion without overpowering it, and the editing maintains a gripping rhythm throughout. There is restraint, balance, and an unmistakable sense of craft-something Bollywood has been searching for but rarely achieves.

What truly sets Dhurandhar apart is its honesty. It doesn't rely on clich√©s or formulaic storytelling. Instead, it trusts its narrative and its audience. This is cinema that lingers long after the credits roll.

Films like this remind us of what Bollywood is capable of when vision, passion, and execution align perfectly. Dhurandhar is not just one of the best films in recent years-it's a benchmark.

author: supreetth
title: Superbly made commercial cinema weaving, underworld & espionage thriller
text:
Watched the Hindi film Dhurandhar for the second time in theatres-nearly a month after its release-and the house was still packed.

This espionage thriller opens with the 1999 Kandahar hijacking, with IB chief Ajay Sanyal (R. Madhavan) at the centre of the crisis-setting the tone for the film's tense, geopolitical canvas.

From there, the story dives into a high-stakes infiltration of Karachi's underworld. The first half tracks undercover operative Hamza Ali Mazari (Ranveer Singh) as he enters Lyari, building credibility from the ground up-often through brute violence, rapid-fire action, and nail-biting underworld escalations. Along the way, he's anchored by Mohammad Aalam (Gaurav Gera), a grounded presence amid the chaos.

The narrative also weaves in depictions of major terror incidents, including the 2001 Parliament attack and the 2008 Mumbai attacks, adding a heavy political and emotional charge to the first half.

The second half moves even faster, stitching together the political ecosystem and its deep links with the underworld. It highlights the power structures that run Karachi from the shadows-where influence, arms pipelines, and backroom alliances matter as much as street muscle. It also touches on the Balochistan angle and the region's simmering tensions, portraying violence and criminal rivalry as a grim, everyday reality.

Without getting into spoilers, the film ends on a sharp final turn involving Rehman Dakait (Akshaye Khanna) that decisively sets the stage for Part 2.

And yes-I tried hard to keep the "spice" in check while writing this review. Not easy at all!

Performances

The film boasts a terrific ensemble. Ranveer Singh as Hamza Ali Mazari delivers a remarkably controlled performance-measured, intense, and completely convincing.

Akshaye Khanna, as Rehman Dakait, is tailor-made for the role-quiet menace, sharp presence, and perfectly calibrated intimidation.

R. Madhavan as Ajay Sanyal brings gravitas and moral weight to the narrative's big decisions.

Sara Arjun as Yalina Jamali looks stunning, commands the screen, and feels like a genuinely strong fit for the part.

Sanjay Dutt as S. P. Choudhary Aslam adds solid heft, and Arjun Rampal as Major Iqbal plays his part with authority.

Technical strengths

Technically, the film is top-class. Shashwat Sachdev's music is terrific, the background score lands cleanly, and the cinematography (Vikash Nowlakha) and editing (Shivkumar V. Panicker) are of a very high standard. The production design feels grounded and real-every department shows up.

Verdict

Overall, Dhurandhar feels like a near-perfect blend of commercial cinema and a gripping thriller-songs, scale, and patriotism, while weaving in espionage and the complexities of Indo-Pakistan dynamics. I'm genuinely eager for Dhurandhar: Part 2, slated for 19 March 2026.

author: harshs-406-598059
title: "A surprisingly gripping and heartfelt experience."
text:
Dhurandhar is one of those rare films that pulls you in quietly and then refuses to let go. The storytelling is tight, the pacing is confident, and every scene feels purposeful. The performances are outstanding, especially the lead, who carries both intensity and vulnerability with ease.

The direction deserves special mention: the film balances emotion, tension, and humor without ever losing its core narrative. Visually too, it's beautifully crafted, with frames that linger in your mind long after the credits roll.

What really sets Dhurandhar apart is its honesty. It doesn't try to be flashy; it just tells a powerful story with conviction. By the end, you're left with that rare feeling of having watched something meaningful.

Highly recommended. One of the most satisfying Bollywood films I've seen in a long, long time.

author: thedesicritic
title: A Ranveer Singh blockbuster where Ranveer Singh is sidelined
text:
Overview This was a star studded blockbuster in every sense of the word. Huge set pieces, gory violence, terrific performances, strong political messaging, and an exorbitant run time. A lot to unpack here so to make it easier:

The Good:
  • Phenomenal performances by the cast, more on that later.


  • Set design and attention to detail when creating Karachi was excellent. References and the look are very on point and added to the realism.


  • Storyline is very compelling.


  • Realistic action sequences. I have been calling out for this as in Hindi cinema action sequences are mostly idiotic and ridiculous with the protagonist usually turning into some sort of avenger. Dhurandhar keeps it as real as possible leading to effective sequences.


The Bad:
  • No sense of nuance at all. The good Indian characters are always good. The bad Pakistani characters are always bad. There's no self-reflection on the part of the protagonist or questioning his own morality as he carries out the most shocking acts. Does not add much depth to the movie.


  • Clunky political commentary. At times it resembles a documentary as Aditya Dhar hits the audience on the head with his views. At one point they even stop the entire movie to show audio of real terrorist interactions. This constantly takes the audience out of the film.


  • Violence and gore. Was really good to a point, but again there is no restraint shown from the director, every scene had be extremely gory and in my opinion, they overdid it.


  • Ranveer Singh is the lead, but he basically has nothing to do. A couple of smart edits and this movie ends up being a good film on Pakistani gang wars. It's almost like there are two separate films going on and there was an awkward attempt to stitch them together.


Overall, a good watch and I enjoyed the film, but it is not the greatest movie of all time that some commentary seems to be pushing, nor is it the worst movie as others imply. It is an entertaining watch but with a fair number of loopholes.

Plot The film follows the protagonist, Hamza Ali Mazari (Ranveer Singh), an agent sent from India to infiltrate the Pakistani underworld based in the city of Karachi with the aim of passing information to India to stop terror related activities.

Acting
  • Ranveer Singh: What I thought was going to be a Ranveer Singh blockbuster ended up being a blockbuster without much of Ranveer Singh. He's a good actor and he did well in the role but was totally overshadowed by his co-stars. His own side quests were probably the least interesting parts of the movie.


  • Akshaye Khanna: Nothing more to say but absolutely brilliant. Easily stole the show as the vicious gangster Rehman Dakait.


  • Sanjay Dutt: A good performance by Sanju brought a grittiness to his police role.


  • Sara Arjun: A bit of a meh showing. To be fair she did not have a whole lot to do, and her character was largely badly written.


  • Arjun Rampal: The epitome of evil in this movie and Arjun Rampal rose to the challenge extremely effectively. The next best performance after Akshaye Khanna.


  • Rakesh Bedi: This was the performance that didn't make sense. This powerful politician being portrayed in a weak and goofy way did not really mesh with the rest of the characters.


  • R Madhavan: A strong showing but was let down by weak writing. Half of his dialogues were not meant to be movie lines but rather overt political messaging. As such at various times he just sounded like a propaganda poster rather than a real person.


Music The music is fantastic really adding to what is going on on screen. Has also added to the virality of the film on social media.

Conclusion If you can handle the violence and gore, I do recommend this as a good watch. With a sequel slated to be released in a matter of months, this movie did its job in building anticipation for the sequel.

7/10.

author: lastsamurai-36154
title: A Powerful, Gripping Spy Thriller That Leaves a Lasting Impact
text:
Dhurandhar is a gripping, large-scale spy thriller that truly delivers on ambition and execution. Inspired by real historical events, the film blends fact and fiction in a way that feels intense, immersive, and emotionally powerful.

Ranveer Singh gives one of his strongest performances to date -> raw, commanding, and completely convincing as a covert operative. Akshaye Khanna is outstanding and easily one of the highlights of the film, while the supporting cast adds depth and gravitas. Aditya Dhar's direction is confident and bold, creating a world that feels authentic, tense, and relevant.

Yes, the runtime is long, but the scale, storytelling, and performances keep you invested. The action sequences are well-choreographed, the background score elevates key moments, and the film sparks thought and discussion long after it ends.

Dhurandhar is not just entertainment, it's an experience. A powerful, ambitious film that stands out in Indian cinema.

Must watch. 10/10.

author: roh-gang
title: Best movie of the year
text: If you can only watch one movie in the remaining few weeks of this year, this has to be the one to be watched. The performances from all the cast re remarkable, Akshay and Ranveer have stolen the show and Aditya has proved once again why he is so highly rated. This film packs the punch like no other and deals with the difficult subject in the best possible manner.

author: AranyakD
title: A Masterclass in Acting Buried Under Exhaustive Action
text:
If you are looking for performances that sear the screen, Dhurandhar is unmissable. The casting is nothing short of a coup, pitting two of the industry's most intense performers against one another in a high-stakes game of cat and mouse. The film thrives when it focuses on the psychological warfare between its leads, who elevate the material far beyond standard genre conventions.

Singh and Khanna: A Volatile Chemistry The film's greatest asset is undoubtedly its cast. Ranveer Singh delivers a "feral" and "electrifying" performance as Hamza, stripping away his usual flamboyance to embody a covert operative with simmering intensity. Opposite him, Akshaye Khanna is terrifyingly calm as the antagonist, Rehman Dakait. Khanna steals every scene he is in, proving once again that he is a master of understated menace. When Singh and Khanna share the screen, the tension is palpable; their verbal spars are far more gripping than any explosion the director could conjure.

Indulgent Action Sequences However, the movie falters significantly in its pacing, particularly during the physical confrontations. While the face-off between Singh and Khanna was highly anticipated, the actual fight sequences feel "made" long-extended well beyond necessity. The runtime drags as the director indulges in exhaustive brawls that seem designed to showcase the stars' stamina rather than advance the plot. These moments of excess dilute the tight, character-driven drama that makes the first half so compelling.

Verdict Dhurandhar is a must-watch for the acting duel between Singh and Khanna, who are in top form. But be prepared to check your watch during the climactic battles, which overstay their welcome in an otherwise gripping thriller.

author: Vinodk-03161
title: Best movie of the year
text:
Best movie of the year 2025. Dhurandhar is a gripping film that lives up to its title, presenting a story full of intensity, strategy, and emotional conflict. The movie stands out for its strong narrative drive and layered characters, keeping the audience engaged from the opening scenes to the final act.

The storyline revolves around ambition, power, and the cost of cleverness. Rather than relying only on action or spectacle, Dhurandhar focuses on mind games, moral dilemmas, and shifting loyalties. This makes the film intellectually engaging as well as emotionally impactful. The screenplay is tightly written, with several moments that surprise the viewer without feeling forced.

Performances are one of the film's biggest strengths. The lead actor's like ranveer , akshay khanna as rehman dakait deliver a convincing portrayal of a complex character, balancing intelligence, arrogance, and vulnerability with ease. Supporting actors also do a commendable job, adding depth to the narrative and ensuring that even secondary roles feel meaningful. The dialogues are sharp and memorable, often carrying more weight than loud dramatic moments.

From a technical perspective, the direction is confident and controlled. The pacing is mostly steady, though a few scenes in the middle could have been trimmed for better flow. Cinematography effectively captures the mood of the film, using lighting and framing to reflect tension and inner conflict. The background score complements the story well, enhancing dramatic moments without overpowering them.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a well-crafted film that appeals to viewers who enjoy intense drama with a strong psychological element. It may not cater to those looking for light entertainment, but for audiences who appreciate smart storytelling and powerful performances, Dhurandhar is definitely worth watching.

author: smioffice
title: Reality of 1 star reviews
text:
It is a masterclass of movie making, storytelling, perfect performances across the charts.

This is the best cinema India has ever created and it is the most honest version of unfiltered truth which Indians never had the courage to speak ever.

3.5hrs of extreme thriller not a single minute wasted. Hats off to Aditya Dhar the real DhuranDhar and the entire team.

I passionately disliked Ranveer Singh before Dhurandhar, I'm his fan. Akshaye Khanna stands at top of the acting Pyramid with Irfan Khan, Manoj Vajpayee and others.

Rakesh Bedi is underrated and delivered such an incredible performace - I watched the movie thrice in 3 different cities - everytime the audience bas the same reaction whe he came on the screen.

I can go on an on about the story, music, performances and everything. Its a 100/100 masterpiece - FINEST MOVIE INDIA HAS EVER PRODUCED.

Waiting for the 2nd part eagerly

PS: 1 star review belongs to a particular type of audience.

author: Vikas-132
title: Movie Asking Questions?
text:

author: touchemerald
title: A Benchmark Moment for Indian Cinema
text: One of the most beautifully and innovatively crafted Indian films ever made. From cinematography and sound design to action, performances, editing, and set design. This film excels in every department. Despite its nearly three-and-a-half-hour runtime, it never drags or feels indulgent; instead, it keeps you constantly engaged, sitting on the edge of your seat. The sheer level of layering in the storytelling is unlike anything seen in Indian cinema before. The editing is bold, inventive, and razor-sharp, perfectly complementing the film's highly stylized action. Yet, despite its stylization, everything feels grounded and real...never overly polished or artificial. This is filmmaking at its highest level, a benchmark for what Indian cinema can achieve.

author: watcher_ikh
title: The new age film-making at its finest
text:
At first glance, it may look like a story of a larger-than-life spy (their typical presentation), but it's the storytelling by Aditya Dhar that sets it apart from anything we have witnessed in not just Bollywood but the whole of Indian cinema.

Ranveer's character may have held back his punches, but the story and presentation, NEVER!!

It was because of this 214-minute length and chapter-wise divisions of the plot that I got invested.

As for performances, Akshaye Khanna and Ranveer were the absolute highlights of the film. Arjun Rampal was menacing as hell, and Madhavan was brilliant with his restrained act. Finally, someone presented Sanjay Dutt as a character who actually had some presence and not some idiotic villain.

You can literally feel the efforts Aditya Dhar has put into this film in every frame.

Part 2 will be even bigger and better!

author: AjeetK-582
title: A superb spy film with great plotting and characters, but the hero's connection feels like it's missing.
text:
This is one of those spy movies that get made only once in a long while. Excellent story. And real events have been woven into the narrative. There's no shortage of scenes that give you a thrilling experience.

From the timeline settings to the scenes, everything feels almost perfect. It's hard not to be captivated by Arjun Rampal's scenes, and your eyes want to know more about his character his thinking and his capabilities which the director has probably saved for the next part.

Akshaye Khanna has once again shown how valuable expressive eyes are in acting. Every expression accurately reveals the character's inner emotions to the viewer.

Because the movie doesn't show what's going on inside the main character at times, the viewers aren't able to connect with his motives.

I don't know why, but the romance feels forced. It could have been portrayed better. The connection between the two needed to be shown in more depth. And I didn't understand why, because of an illegal night party, the police would make so much effort to catch a person the way it's shown? That scene felt illogical to me.

Even though the movie is 3 hours and 40+ minutes long, the first part feels satisfying only by a small margin. Like other two-part films, this one also needed a properly structured first part.

Still, this movie is worth watching in the theater, and I'll probably go to the theater for the second part as well.

author: vivekhegde-21965
title: One of best screenplay and worth to watch it in cinemas
text:
While the film's extreme runtime and graphic violence might be challenging for some, it is a triumph for those who appreciate "substance over style." It is a rare blockbuster that respects the audience's intelligence, trading cheap jokes for sharp dialogue and formulaic plots for complex character arcs.

Dhurandhar is the most polished, immersive cinematic experience of the year-a "must-watch" for anyone tired of the template-driven action genre.

author: RR8
title: Amazing direction and an all star cast to match
text:
While the movie is 3.5hrs long, it's so fast paced with amazing direction, you can't tell. The cast choice is on point and while graphically violent (and some questionable cgi in places), its gripping and fits with the story.
