author: lakshmishaks88
title: Durandhar: A Once-in-a-Generation Triumph (11 out of 10 stars)
text:
I'll admit, I was apprehensive about the length of Durandhar. Too many films mistake runtime for depth. But once it began, time simply dissolved. By the time the credits rolled, I wasn't relieved it was over - I was wishing for more. That's the mark of cinema that grips you completely.

The music deserves special mention. In most films, it's treated like wallpaper - stock tracks pasted in to fill silence. Here, the score is as vital as the narrative itself. It breathes with the story, heightens emotion, and becomes inseparable from the film's identity.

What truly astonishes is how you feel for every character. Even someone like Donga, who could have been a throwaway presence, leaves a lasting impression. That's not just good writing - that's direction and casting working in harmony to give dimension to every role.

The sets are jaw-dropping. The attention to detail is obsessive in the best way, creating a world so textured and authentic that you forget you're watching fiction. This level of craft is rare in Indian cinema, where production design often settles for broad strokes. Here, it's meticulous, immersive, and unforgettable.

Technically, the film is a clinic: cinematography that frames emotion without vanity, editing that respects rhythm, and sound design that knows silence can be louder than noise. Performances are lived-in, not performed - actors chosen for their ability to inhabit roles, not for their surnames.

Durandhar isn't just another release. It's once-in-a-generation cinema - the kind of film that redefines what the medium can achieve.

Verdict: 11/10. Not because it's flawless, but because it makes you believe again in the power of storytelling.

author: ValleDk
title: A good watch.
text:
Bollywood doesn't really make good movies these days.

But then comes something like this. It feels like a little to much on the propaganda side. But still a good watch, the cast did so well. But the made up spy part and etc was a little to much, because none of that really happened so it gives a wrong impression.

I did my fair share of research after watching the movie. And a lot of it, is just claims from one country to another. The same way Pakistan blames India for several attacks on their soil coordinated with the afghans, India blames Pakistan. So it's words against words. Without having any real proof. So I think these 2 countries should stop the propaganda and maybe start getting along. But a good movie nevertheless.

Akshay Khanna stood out and made this long movie worth the while.

author: WorldMovie99
title: Long but Average..
text:
Dhurandhar delivers brutal action sequences and Ranveer Singh's committed performance as the undercover agent keeps things engaging. The Karachi underworld feels vivid, with tense cinematography plunging viewers into gritty alleys. However, the 3+ hour runtime drags in the middle, testing patience despite the high-stakes plot. Solid spy fare, but not groundbreaking.

Aditya Dhar's direction shines in technical craft-score and editing build real suspense amid moral dilemmas. Akshaye Khanna and supporting cast add depth to the criminal ecosystem. Pacing falters with indulgent subplots and overt jingoism that dilute the core tension. Entertaining in bursts, but feels bloated. The film's immersive world-building and disturbing scenes, like the 26/11 nod, evoke strong emotions. Action is raw and immediate, setting a genre benchmark without fluff. Yet, the lengthy runtime and unnecessary elements make it exhausting rather than exhilarating. Worth a watch for visuals alone. Ranveer Singh anchors the chaos with layered intensity, while brutal gore justifies the adult rating. Background score pulses effectively through high-tension ops. Script overloads on politics, losing focus and emotional resonance by the end. Decent thriller, needs trimming. Strong atmosphere in Lyari's dangers and clever strategic planning hook early. Dhar's control over spectacle rewards patient viewers. Prolonged exposition and propaganda vibes undermine the grit, turning potential masterpiece into a slog. Midway appeal only. A 5/10.

author: snehalpatel-07062
title: Awesome
text: Dhurandhar surprised me completely. I watched it and loved every minute of its raw energy, gripping storytelling, and powerful performances. It's the first Bollywood film this year during which I didn't fall asleep. The ending left me excited and eagerly waiting for part two. Truly memorable cinema!!

author: zorrothefox
title: A hard-hitting, uncomfortable watch that needed to be made
text:
Dhurandhar is not an easy film to sit through, and that is precisely its strength.

The acting is outstanding across the board. Performances feel restrained, realistic, and emotionally grounded rather than theatrical. The direction is tight and confident, refusing to dilute the subject matter for mass comfort. This is a serious film with intent, not a crowd-pleasing spectacle.

What Dhurandhar does exceptionally well is its unflinching portrayal of systemic corruption, political cowardice, and the repeated institutional failure of the Indian state when dealing with Pakistan-sponsored terrorism. The film makes it painfully clear how early intelligence warnings were ignored or buried, how responsibility was diffused, and how decisive action was avoided at crucial moments. The portrayal of an impotent government response feels disturbingly close to reality.

The tone is grim and relentless. The violence is graphic and often disturbing. This is not stylized violence. It is raw, brutal, and meant to unsettle. Because of this, it is absolutely not suitable for children below 18. Parents should not underestimate how intense some sequences are.

Dhurandhar does not offer easy catharsis or neat resolutions. It forces the viewer to confront uncomfortable truths and sit with anger, grief, and frustration. That alone makes it stand apart from most mainstream political thrillers.

By the time the film ends, it is clear that this is only part of a larger story. The setup for Part 2 is compelling, and expectations are understandably high.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a bold, hard-hitting film with great acting and direction, unapologetic in its political stance and emotional impact. It is disturbing, thought-provoking, and necessary. Now waiting to see if Part 2 delivers the accountability and closure that Part 1 deliberately withholds.

author: jhadiwakar-10680
title: Dhurandar is dhurandar
text: This is a movie for every nationalist. Dhurandar will give you one more reason to love your nation. Its long, yes, but there are hardly 5-7 minutes that feels unnecessary. If movies like these don't get our attention it would be very disappointing for good nationalist filmmakers. Show this movie to those who are unaware of our recent political history, although if you know of it already you will enjoy or understand this movie morr.

author: TreeFiddy53
title: Hindi movie of the year!
text:
When Bollywood gives you the names and resources to make a spy-thriller film, make a Dhurandhar and not anything that belongs to the YRF-Spyverse. This film was a crazy ride, driven primarily by writing that was miles ahead of War 2 and other commercial goop you've seen this year. (Loki, take notes.) Performances - amazing across the board. As earth-shattering as the media and fans claim? No. Music and sound design - amazing throughout (Ani-bro, take notes) Fasla - catchy, refreshing. One for the ages? No. Cinematography - top notch. Those sweeping shots of the landscape - oof.

You feel the length of the film though. What would I cut out of the film? I don't know. There's a 20-min segment that one would make a case for but without that, the natural progression of the plot falls flat. Commercial? You bet. This will have almost all the mirch-masala you'd expect but it doesn't feel deliberate. I'm glad they didn't overdo you-know-what.

In my books, strictly as a film, this was better than Uri, and easily Bollywood's film of the year (Sorry, Homebound) Eager to see what P2 has to offer in March 2026.

Actors are amazing. Shame on gulf countries for banning of movie. Movie scene like 2011 Mumbai attack instructions are same as reality.

author: AJITS-745
title: Midblowing!!
text: Great movie by Mr. Dhar. Storyline, visuals, acting, BGM and the experience is overall worderful. Akshay Khanna, Ranveer are superb in their roles. Madhavan is incredibly good, and completely justifies the role. The dialogue delivery, expressions are exceptionally well. Moreover, the casting of different roles are superb too.

author: bc_raghavendra-604-485763
title: Watchable
text:
The film Dhurandhar (2025) has few positive and negative points.

Positive points are: 1. Both Ranveer Singh and Akshaye Khanna have performed well.

2. Director Adithya Dhar has shown some courage to show the real color of Pakistan.

Negative Points are: 1. The film has failed to show what was going on in Jaskirat Singh's (Ranveer Singh's) mind when he was crossing Pakistan's border. Because, this becomes a one way ticket for most spy agents. They may feel that their life in India ends there.

2. During the climax, Ranveer Singh turns the car towards a forest where SP Chaudhary Aslam (Sanjay Dutt) keeps waiting to kill Rahman Baloch. This deviation was the plan. But was everybody (except Ranveer) sleeping in the car a part of the plan? Well, there is no answer for this in the movie.

3. The movie should have shown at least some plots on how the terrorists travelled from Karachi to Mumbai on ship. How easy/difficult it was for them to reach Mumbai and how did they cross Indian Navy surveillance are not shown the movie.

4. The film has failed to show what was going on in India concurrently during the terror plans at Lyari. There was only one scene that came and went, which showed that the intelligent offices received message from various places, that's it. Indian audience would expect more about what was happening in India at that time.

5. The acting of Sanjay Dutt as a police officer was very poor. He couldn't even run properly during the climax chase.

6. Foul language is used more than necessity.

Still the movie is watchable because the reality of Pakistan is shown.

author: sumitk-6015
title: A gripping masterpiece
text:
Dhurandhar is a gripping espionage film that fires on all cylinders. From high-stakes intelligence missions to intense undercover sequences, the movie keeps you edge-seated throughout. The twists are clever, action scenes are top-class, and the performances - especially Ranveer Singh and Akshaye Khanna - are powerful and memorable. The story builds tension perfectly, blending espionage, crime, and emotion with rich world-building and a gripping payoff in the climax.

A must-watch for anyone who loves smart spy thrillers with depth, intensity, and cinematic scale! Highly recommended.

author: Jazzy-Jazzy
title: Return of Bollywood
text: After a very long time, finally a high quality movie coming out of Bollywood. No unnecessary bikini songs, no overdramatic story plot, no cheesy dialogue, no over the top computer generated graphics. author: ShubhS-75
title: Dhurandhar doesn't entertain - it dominates.
text:
A cold, calculated story where every move matters and every frame carries weight. Sharp writing, commanding performances, and zero wasted moments. The film thrives on silence as much as dialogue, letting tension build naturally instead of forcing drama. Power, ambition, and manipulation are explored with maturity, making the story feel grounded yet gripping. There are no wasted scenes, no easy shortcuts - only precision and purpose.

This isn't a film you casually watch. It's a film you experience, absorb, and remember long after the credits roll.

author: imdbfan-9312740040
title: Excellent movie, best actor, true story, and nicely showcased.
text:
I was completely surprised and shocked that we were unaware of all these incidents happening right under our noses. The film reveals how some Indian politicians and others were involved and helping Pakistan execute major attacks like the IC-814 plane hijack, the Parliament attack, and 26/11 - with Indian people assisting from within.

On top of that, the acting was fabulous, especially Akshaye Khanna who was absolutely the best - his performance as the gangster is unforgettable and steals every scene. Ranveer Singh also delivers powerfully as the undercover agent. Overall, this is the best movie - gripping from start to finish, with intense action, betrayals, and a story inspired by real events that keeps you on the edge of your seat.

The supporting cast, including Akshaye Khanna, R. Madhavan, Sanjay Dutt, and Arjun Rampal, adds great depth. Bold and ambitious filmmaking that redefines the spy genre. A must-watch in theaters for the big-screen experience! Can't wait for Part 2.

author: arpanp-38965
title: What was that!!!
text:
Dhurandhar is a razor-sharp political thriller that understands the power of restraint. It doesn't rely on noise or spectacle to command attention; instead, it pulls you in with strategy, psychology, and a constant undercurrent of danger. This is a film that treats intelligence as its primary weapon-and trusts the audience to keep up.

At the heart of Dhurandhar is a world driven by agendas rather than emotions. The narrative unfolds like a carefully planned operation, where every move has consequences and every character carries hidden intent. The story refuses to divide people into heroes and villains; instead, it presents operators-individuals shaped by ideology, ambition, and survival. That moral greyness is what gives the film its edge.

The performances are one of the film's strongest assets. The lead commands the screen with a controlled, almost chilling presence, proving that power doesn't need loudness. Supporting actors elevate the tension further, bringing gravitas, unpredictability, and authority to their roles. No performance feels wasted; each character exists for a reason, and each leaves a mark.

Direction and writing work in perfect sync. The screenplay is tight and intelligent, avoiding unnecessary exposition. Dialogues are crisp, layered, and often loaded with subtext. A single conversation can feel more dangerous than an action sequence-and that's where Dhurandhar truly shines. The pacing is deliberate, but never dull; it mirrors the mindset of its characters-patient, calculating, and precise.

Visually, the film maintains a grounded, serious tone. The cinematography complements the narrative without drawing attention to itself, while the background score subtly builds unease rather than dictating emotion. The editing keeps the tension intact, especially during moments of strategic confrontation.

What lingers after the film ends is its unsettling honesty. Dhurandhar doesn't offer comfort or closure. It reflects a world where intelligence can manipulate truth, loyalty is conditional, and victory often comes at a moral cost. It asks difficult questions-about power, nationalism, and ethics-without offering easy answers.

author: worldofskd
title: A action packed spy thriller with a solid antagonist.
text:
Spoilers ahead.

The movie was great and keeps the audience on the edge of the seat throughout the whole movie. Portrayal of hostage negotiation by indian secret service, then start of the DHURANDHAR programme by the Indian intelligence service. The epic entrance of our protagonist Hamza (Ranveer Singh) and the career of the antagonist Rehman Dakait/Galoch ( Akshay Khanna) is seen in the action packed scenes of the Lyari Underworld. How he (Rehman) emerges to power in the political field with Hamza's help and how he establishes his force within the political atmosphere; his connection to Pakistani intelligence to conduct terror attacks is portrayed with raw and vivid imagery. The role of Sanjay Dutt (SP Chaudhuri Aslam) is also relevant to the storyline.

Overall it is violence packed and strongly retains its A+ rating. After his(Rehman's) death, the story is open for a prequel to Hamza (Jaskirat Singh Rangi)'s story of recruitment to Indian intelligence and his training; for the next movie "REVENGE" to be released in 23rd March 2026.

author: AyushP-027
title: best Bollywood big budget movie ever
text:
Matches the hype and even exceeds it. The entire cast performs well. It does not drag on despite the long runtime. The music choice is goated. Dividing the movie into chapters is a novel choice. The action scenes are superb albeit with a lot of gore which I liked(some won't).

All in all a gripping performance by everyone involved. This movie restores faith in Bollywood's ability to make good original films.

author: VivekP-561
title: A Gripping Spy Thriller Worth Every Minute

author: kamal-976
title: Rn it's my favourite
text:
The movie cant bored you , you'll recall the movie , character,and scenes even after some days..

Movie Review: Dhurandhar

Dhurandhar is a gripping and hard-hitting film that lives up to its powerful title. From the very first scene, the movie pulls you into a world of raw emotions, ambition, and moral conflict. The storytelling is intense yet engaging, balancing realism with cinematic flair. Every frame feels purposeful, keeping the audience hooked till the very end.

The performances are the strongest pillar of Dhurandhar. The lead actor delivers a commanding performance, portraying strength, vulnerability, and inner turmoil with remarkable ease. Supporting characters are not just fillers; each one adds depth to the narrative and enhances the overall impact. Dialogues are sharp, meaningful, and memorable, especially during confrontational scenes.

Direction deserves special praise for maintaining a tight pace and extracting powerful performances without over-dramatization. The background score perfectly complements the mood of the film, elevating crucial moments without overpowering them. Cinematography captures the dark and gritty atmosphere beautifully, making the setting feel alive and authentic.

What truly makes Dhurandhar stand out is its underlying message about power, choices, and consequences. It doesn't glorify wrongdoing blindly but presents a thought-provoking perspective that stays with you long after the credits roll.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a compelling, well-crafted film that offers strong performances, impactful storytelling, and emotional depth. It is a must-watch for audiences who appreciate intense, meaningful cinema.

author: sarangidipu
title: Dhurandhar, A Slow-Burn Spy Thriller That Redefines Intelligence Cinema
text:
Dhurandhar, directed by Adithya Dhar, is a refreshing and gripping addition to Indian spy cinema. Told in a chapter-wise format, much like a premium web series, the film takes its time to build characters, tension, and intrigue-and that patience pays off brilliantly. Ranveer Singh delivers a restrained yet powerful performance as Hamza, an Indian spy who infiltrates Pakistan through Afghanistan and embeds himself deep within the enemy's ecosystem. From working at a humble juice shop to gaining the trust of Rahman Dakait (a brilliantly understated Akshay Khanna), the film shows intelligence work as it truly is slow, methodical, and psychologically demanding. Akshay Khanna shines as Rahman, a complex antagonist with deep roots in underworld operations, arms supply, and anti-India conspiracies. Arjun Rampal as the ISI chief brings a calm menace, while Sanjay Dutt adds gravitas as a Pakistani DSP caught between duty and chaos. The inclusion of the 26/11 Mumbai attacks gives the film emotional weight and realism. The narrative boldly highlights how intelligence failures and miscommunication can lead to devastating consequences, making the story feel grounded rather than jingoistic.

Despite its long runtime of 3 hours and 22 minutes, Dhurandhar never feels boring. The screenplay remains tight, the twists are earned, and the final act especially Hamza's calculated endgame involving Rahman shows the cold precision of a trained spy operating without emotional leakage. The film ends on a tantalizing note, clearly setting up a second part slated for 2026, promising deeper revelations about Hamza's past, his recruitment, and the larger dismantling of enemy networks. Dhurandhar doesn't rely on loud patriotism or over-the-top action. Instead, it trusts intelligence, patience, and layered storytelling. It feels less like a conventional film and more like the beginning of a serious spy saga. Highly recommended for fans of realistic spy thrillers.

author: omegaxy
title: Reality smeared onto fiction
text:
Dhurandhar is one of those films that blurs the line between what is real and what is imagined so delicately that the audience is never fully sure which side they're standing on. It presents itself as fiction, yet every frame feels soaked in truths we recognize from the world around us. This is where the movie finds its strongest voice-reality isn't simply adapted into fiction; it is smeared across it, staining the narrative in ways that are subtle, unsettling, and deeply engaging.

The story follows an ordinary man caught in extraordinary circumstances, and though the plot takes creative liberties, the emotions and conflicts feel uncomfortably real. The film uses exaggeration not to mislead but to illuminate. It stretches reality just enough to reveal the cracks that we tend to ignore in everyday life. This technique-half-truths woven into imaginative storytelling-creates a strangely immersive experience. You are aware that you're watching fiction, yet you feel the weight of its truths.

Performances are grounded and sincere, especially the lead, who carries the tension of the film with a rawness that feels unpolished in the best possible way. The cinematography also plays into the "reality smeared onto fiction" theme: scenes shift between gritty realism and stylized surrealism, mirroring the protagonist's uncertain moral landscape.

If there's one drawback, it's that the film occasionally leans too heavily into its metaphorical ambitions, risking confusion for viewers who prefer clear-cut narratives. But for those who enjoy cinema that challenges rather than comforts, Dhurandhar succeeds brilliantly.

author: PrahladK-843
title: A griping tale of a wounded lion
text:
Dhurandar is exactly what it promises to be: the story of a wounded lion, a man driven by nothing but pure, undiluted rage after witnessing atrocities committed against his own pack, his people. This is not a stylized revenge fantasy, it is a personal war.

From the very first trailer it was clear this would not be your typical rom com disguised as an espionage movie. And the film fully delivers on that warning. It does not shy away from brutality, gore, or the emotional weight behind it. Every gruesome moment feels earned, rooted in real human emotions like anger, grief, and betrayal.

The performances are absolutely gripping.

Every actor brings layers to their character, and nobody is presented as a flat stereotype. Akshaye Khanna especially, there is a scene where his character gets slapped by his wife, and he just stands there, absorbing it. No macho reaction, no exaggerated response. Just raw honesty.

And let us be clear, the brutality in Dhurandar is not hyper masculine chest thumping. The violence is narrative driven, emotional, and reflective. It shows the malice of the antagonists and the psychological descent of the protagonist with precision.

People calling the film polarizing are missing the point entirely. The movie does not target any community or group, it aims directly at those responsible for the cruelty shown. Nothing more. Nothing less.

Viewers just need to widen their lens and see the film for what it truly is, a fierce, unfiltered character study wrapped in a gripping narrative of vengeance and sheer nationalism.

author: keshav-722
title: Amazing movie the plot & story & actors all good
text:
All time favorite. Amazing movie the plot & story & actors all India high rating movie. Dhuraandhar is a powerful and emotionally gripping drama that leaves a strong impact on the audience. The film brilliantly combines intense storytelling, strong character development, and meaningful social themes. From the very beginning, the movie creates curiosity and maintains suspense about what is going to happen next.

The lead actor delivers an outstanding performance and carries the film with immense confidence and charm. His character has depth, struggles, and a transformation that feels very real and relatable. The supporting cast adds great value to the story as well, especially during the emotional and conflict-driven scenes.

The direction deserves special appreciation. The filmmaker has ensured that every scene contributes effectively to the narrative. The pacing is tight, and there are no unnecessary moments. Cinematography is visually appealing with well-designed action sequences, beautiful lighting, and strong framing that heightens the impact of important scenes. The musical background score perfectly matches the intensity and mood of the film, making emotional scenes more powerful.

What makes Dhuraandhar special is its message. It highlights courage, justice, and standing up for what is right - even when the world stands against you. It inspires viewers to remain strong, fight challenges, and believe in themselves.

The climax is gripping and satisfying, giving the film a strong finish that stays with the audience long after the movie ends. Overall, Dhuraandhar is an engaging and well-made film that successfully entertains as well as inspires. It is definitely worth watching and highly recommended for people who love movies with emotion, action, and a purpose.

Hatts off to Sachdeva for music. And a lot of Thanks to Aditya Dhar and CBFC. Maybe you will not like this movie, but for me, it's an absolute Perfection. 10/10 !

author: SHREYA_GHOSH
title: A true blockbuster film of 2025
text: Dhurandhar: üî• The best hindi movie of 2025. On the first Monday following its release, I went to see this movie. With its strong screenplay, outstanding writing, and superb world and character development, this 3:30-hour espionage action film has enough substance to keep you interested the entire time. From beginning to end, the film is extremely tight, and the editing and music add to the immersive experience. Since it's not just Ranveer's movie, each character was meticulously and subtly developed, and director Aditya Dhar made sure that each character perfectly leaves a lasting impression on the audience. Just like a real chameleon, Ranveer Singh blends into this role while Akshaye Khanna, Sanjay Dutt, Arjun Rampal, R. Madhavan, Rakesh bedi, Sara Arjun and the rest of the cast make sure the movie runs flawless. As Rahaman Dakait, Akshay Khanna delivers a thrilling performance; his swag, appearance, and dialogue were all extremely powerful. Arjun Rampal's quiet intimidation as Iliyas Kashmiri (the mastermind of the 26/11 attack) contrasts beautifully with Sara Arjun's poignant innocence, while Madhavan adds depth and intelligence to play the real-life role of Ajit Doval. Sanjay Dutt adds a new gear to the film, accelerating the pace with his authoritative screen presence and dialogue. The dynamic performances create a rich tapestry of storytelling, elevating the film beyond mere entertainment. Each actor brings their own flair, contributing to a cohesive narrative that resonates deeply with the audience, making it a must-watch for cinema lovers. The climax is a masterwork of suspense that combines emotional and adrenaline weight with ease. The audience is drawn into a whirlwind of suspense, excitement, fear, and emotion as the performances enhance the content even more. As the resolution draws near, viewers are left on the edge of their seats as each character's journey is meticulously revealed. This is attention-grabbing storytelling that rewards perseverance with memorable cinematic moments. Bravo to the director Aditya Dhar for creating such a genuine spy thriller without squandering the plot with pointless songs or showing off bikini girls or six-pack abs, repeatedly making fun of the same old formula.

author: Pappum-014
title: A Cruel Masterpiece
text:
A Cruel Masterpiece: A Review of 'Durandhar'

"Durandhar" isn't just another movie you watch and forget. It really stays with you, and not always in the easiest way. From start to finish, the film dives headfirst into some tough, raw emotions and doesn't shy away from showing how people endure hardship. It's the kind of film that's beautifully made, but it's also a bit brutal to sit through in the best possible sense.

The director really knows what they're doing-every shot feels like it's been put together with a lot of care to show exactly what the characters are going through. The actors do an incredible job too. They make you feel every bit of the struggle and the rare moments of hope.

In the end, "Durandhar" is the kind of film that might be tough to watch, but it's even tougher to shake off once you have. If you're up for something intense and moving, it's definitely worth your time.

author: rishabh_rajpurohit
title: Ride of Bloodbath in Pakistan
text:
Aditya Dhar's Dhurandhar is a monumental achievement that shatters the mold of the conventional espionage thriller. It's not just an action film; it's a terrifyingly relevant political statement, a stark portrait of the state-sponsored terror infrastructure rooted deep in Pakistan. The film succeeds precisely because it refuses to sanitize the horrific, complex truths that underpin the conflict, offering an unflinching look at the machinery of the ISI and the devastating human cost on both sides of the border.

Ranveer Singh's Career Defining Role Ranveer Singh as the undercover agent Hamza Ali Mazari delivers what is arguably the most controlled, nuanced, and physically demanding performance of his career. Shedding his usual flair, he embodies the silent, simmering intensity of a man living a dangerous double life. The conflict isn't just external; it's a constant, eroding war waged inside his own conscience. The supporting cast, particularly Arjun Rampal as the cold, calculating ISI Major Iqbal and Akshaye Khanna as the magnetic, monstrous crime lord Rehman Dakait, is nothing short of brilliant, creating a web of credible, chilling antagonists.

A Mirror to Reality What elevates Dhurandhar to instant classic status is its horrifying resonance with current events. The film's plot, which meticulously details how terror plots against India are conceptualized, funded, and executed, directly echoes the deep-seated concerns following incidents like the recent Red Fort car blast. The movie doesn't just show a generic 'bad guy' it exposes the systematic exploitation: ISI's Cruel Exploitation: The film is explicit in its depiction of the Pakistani deep state's willingness to use its most vulnerable citizens as disposable assets. It highlights the calculated strategy of using financially struggling individuals, often from non-Punjabi communities, for logistics, and the specific radicalization of educated, impressionable Kashmiri youth to execute high-profile attacks. This theme of preying on the poor and marginalized people of Pakistan (non-Punjabi), along with exploited Kashmiris, gives the narrative a powerful, heartbreaking political weight. It reminds the audience that the true villain is the system that breeds and manipulates the very people it claims to protect.

The Unseen Nexus: The seamless, bureaucratic relationship between the ISI, corrupt politicians, and organized crime shown in the film is a brutal reminder of the real-world intelligence reports concerning the nexus that fuels bombings and infiltrations in India. Dhurandhar is a cinematic acknowledgment of the cold, strategic hand of terror that is not merely ideological, but state-sponsored and methodical.

Technical Brilliance and Emotional Impact Aditya Dhar's direction is a masterclass in tension-building. The pacing is deliberate, establishing the grim, claustrophobic atmosphere of the Karachi underworld. The action sequences are grounded, raw, and visceral, serving the narrative rather than existing purely for spectacle. The technical team from the gritty, authentic cinematography to the pounding, anxiety-inducing background score works in perfect harmony to deliver a genuinely cinematic and unforgettable experience.

Dhurandhar is not an easy watch, but it is an essential one. It is a bold, uncompromising, and deeply intelligent thriller that moves far beyond Bollywood's typical handling of cross-border themes. It is a chilling reminder of the constant sacrifices made by agents on the ground and the relentless, politically-driven machinery of terror they fight.

author: arungeorge13
title: An overlong but a pretty satisfying espionage action thriller. [+64%]
text:
Quick thoughts:

1. Patriotism getting the macho packaging is far from my favorite genre, that's for sure. Dhurandhar is very on the nose from a storytelling perspective, and it's 200% INTENDED to make your blood boil. Some of it, like the red-screen with a highly disturbing voiceover, works.

2. The writing is simultaneously smart and predictable, weaving in real incidents with fictional events. There are some really INTERESTING stretches, and then, there are some really UNINTERESTING ones. Soft propaganda and snide remarks on pre-2014 government aside, the film stays focused on its espionage-thriller core.

3. The 2-hour long first half only makes it obvious that Aditya Dhar had more material for a web series than a film. The screenplay is extremely dense, going deep into a Pakistani gang war with details that matter more for the moment than overall. The chapterwise divisions are a clear indication too.

4. With a properly etched character like Rehman Dakait, Akshaye Khanna is the standout performer here by a mile. Ranveer Singh only needs to play the silent infiltrator with a limited emotional range (until the end), so it feels like PART 2 will have him showcasing more of his acting chops. Sanjay Dutt's and Rakesh Bedi's parts feel like a concerted effort to make one section of Pakistanis look dumb and indecisive; there's some spontaneous fun to be had in the process, however. Also, Arjun Rampal might be the bigger (and more menacing) baddie that the film deliberately places less focus on.

5. Sara Arjun (the cute kid from Saivam and Deiva Thirumagal has hmm.. grown up!) looks amazing but has absolutely nothing to add to the plot, except be another addition to the "dumb girlfriend universe." Even her chemistry with Ranveer feels a bit out of place.

6. Shashwat Sachdev's music is really what kept me hooked for 210+ minutes. Except for that item number and a romantic track, the rest of the OST is FANTASTIC! That also applies to the use of (remixed?) retro songs in various scenes.

7. The violence depicted has a slasher-like vibe at specific points, while sticking to the usual action-thriller aesthetic for the most part. Nothing here is particularly stomach-churning (except maybe THAT post-interval scene), but the director seems to have a clear sense of when to shock the viewer. Screw the insertion of CG blood, though.

8. The VFX in general (blood, explosions, etc.) could look better with the amount of money involved (right?). Yet, the staging of the set pieces and solid set designs deftly mask this.

P. S. Vishwaroopam d√©j√† vu, anyone?

author: A_D_0068
title: Dhurandhar (2025): A Masterclass in Directorial Vision and Acting Ferocity
text:
Aditya Dhar's Dhurandhar has transcended the typical "action-thriller" label to become a cinematic milestone. While its scale is massive, the film's true strength lies in the four pillars that support its weight: the visionary direction of Dhar and the transformative performances of Akshaye Khanna, Ranveer Singh, and Sanjay Dutt.

The Architect: Aditya Dhar With Dhurandhar- Aditya Dhar proves that Uri was no fluke; he is arguably India's most precise technician of action. Dhar's mastery lies in his ability to maintain a "tight" atmosphere even on a "wide" canvas. He treats the lens as an observer, pulling the audience into the dusty, dangerous labyrinth of Lyari with a sensory richness rarely seen in Indian cinema. His decision to blend archival reality with high-stakes fiction creates a "lived-in" intensity that makes every gunshot feel consequential.

The Chameleon: Ranveer Singh (Hamza) In a departure from his flamboyant public persona, Ranveer Singh delivers a masterclass in restraint. As the deep-cover operative Hamza, Ranveer uses his physicality to tell the story-his hunched shoulders and weathered face speak of a man who has lived in the shadows for too long. It is a simmering, soulful performance that acts as the film's moral heartbeat.

The Scene-Stealer: Akshaye Khanna (Rehman Dakait) If there is one reason to watch Dhurandhar multiple times, it is Akshaye Khanna. Playing the sophisticated yet sociopathic Rehman Dakait, Khanna is electric. He brings a "theatrical menace" to the screen, delivering lines with an unpredictable cadence that keeps the audience on edge. It is perhaps the most iconic villainous turn in recent memory-charismatic, terrifying, and impossible to look away from.

The Enforcer: Sanjay Dutt (Chaudhary Aslam) Sanjay Dutt provides the film with its raw, old-school muscle. As the relentless cop Chaudhary Aslam, Dutt brings a "lion in winter" gravitas to the narrative. His presence provides a perfect counterpoint to the calculated espionage of Ranveer and the madness of Khanna, grounding the film in a sense of grit and legacy.

Final Critical Note (my view)- Dhurandhar succeeds because it respects the intelligence of its audience while delivering the "masala" thrills they crave. By leaning on the immense talent of its lead quartet, Aditya Dhar has crafted a film that will be studied for years to come as the gold standard of the Indian spy-epic.

author: posttoricha
title: "A Misguided Spy Drama That Confuses Noise with Narrative"
text:
I watched Dhurandhar yesterday, and here is my review

To begin with, director Aditya Dhar appears to lack the essential depth and research required to create a convincing espionage thriller. A truly compelling spy film demands authenticity, narrative intelligence, and nuanced storytelling - qualities that Dhurandhar consistently fails to deliver.

Instead of substance, the film leans heavily on cosmetic glorification:
  • thunderous background music,
  • hyper-stylized action,
  • exaggerated displays of physical strength, and
  • forced patriotic triggers designed to emotionally manipulate the audience.


This formulaic approach turns the film into spectacle rather than meaningful cinema.

The script takes fragments of real incidents, distorts them for dramatic impact, and then labels the final product as a "patriotic film." However, nothing in its treatment genuinely reflects patriotism.

What the audience ultimately receives is a third-rate, commercially motivated film whose primary intention seems to be box-office returns rather than artistic or ideological integrity.

The most disappointing aspect is the film's marketing. Dhurandhar is promoted as an Indian patriotic drama, but at its core, it revolves around Pakistan's low-grade local political landscape. The disconnect between promotion and actual content makes the film feel disingenuous and directionless.

On a personal note, watching this film with my 10-year-old son turned out to be troubling. Several scenes felt inappropriate and left me deeply uncomfortable as a parent. Throughout the screening, I kept questioning whether bringing him to this film was a mistake.

In fact, the director should take the time to watch an authentic espionage drama like The Spy-a film that succeeds without exaggeration, without glorification, and without manipulating emotions. It is a masterclass in honest storytelling about an intelligence operative. Unfortunately, Dhurandhar seems to operate on the assumption that the Indian audience lacks discernment. Even if that were partly true for some viewers, a filmmaker can never truly connect with an audience that values subtlety, realism, and narrative integrity. He may create a film purely for commercial gain, but he cannot reach those who genuinely appreciate well-crafted spy cinema. Casting R. Madhavan as Ajit Doval and inserting a few real Indian incidents does not automatically make a film patriotic. Instead, it comes across as a calculated attempt to lure attention by exploiting India's growing wave of performative patriotism. This feels less like a tribute to the nation and more like a strategic move to profit from the charged mindset of the masses.

author: SoumikBanerjee1996
title: A gritty, effective espionage drama!
text:
It's gritty and gory, packed with a wealth of research and information; kind of a rarity in Bollywood' spy endeavours, where mindless entertainment often takes precedence over the significance of the source material.

Aditya Dhar, as the director, is breaking the mold without skimping on the entertainment factor, which is refreshing and appreciable.

The film is engaging and soars to incredible heights at certain moments, delivering what audiences typically seek from this genre.

That said, it isn't without its fair share of flaws. The exposition can feel a bit heavy at times, and the stretched-out screenplay eventually starts to weigh down the pacing and rhythm.

The way songs are integrated is interesting, though especially those that play in the background during key activities.

However, the dance number at the wedding felt unnecessary, as did the entire subplot of Hamza and Yalina's budding romance. They could have cut that off entirely and nothing would change.

On the plus side, the film does a fantastic job of drawing you into its expansive world filled with ruthless gangsters, smugglers, and corrupt officials.

A standout element is the performances from the main cast, particularly Akshaye Khanna. He doesn't just play Rehman Dakait, he owns the role, stealing every frame he features in.

author: BibekB-72
title: Totally matured film
text:
This film is genuinely mature. Although I may not fully grasp all of its political implications, it clearly takes a more thoughtful and grounded approach compared to movies like Pathaan and the Tiger series. Cinema should be made in this manner...honest, unfiltered, and rooted in logic.

In contrast, films like Pathaan and Tiger promote unrealistic and exaggerated scenarios that hide the actual narrative purpose behind a hero's sudden appearance. For example, Salman Khan's entry in Pathaan and Shah Rukh Khan's entry in Tiger happen without any meaningful explanation. This kind of storytelling can be harmful for younger audiences, as it encourages unrealistic expectations and distorts their sense of imagination..People may think those movies(pathan, tiger and many old )are made only for entertainment, but that isn't entirely accurate. Entertainment should still be logical and follow a clear path. If not, younger audiences may become overly unrealistic and may struggle to nurture real creativity.

author: gunjan2706
title: Redefining the Spy Genre with Unmatched Vision and Impact
text:
Dhurandhar is an outstanding cinematic triumph that elevates the spy thriller genre to a new strategic benchmark. The storytelling is sharp, layered, and emotionally grounded, with every scene crafted to build tension and purpose rather than superficial spectacle. The action sequences are immersive, intense, and deeply engaging, reflecting discipline and tactical realism. Aditya Dhar's direction showcases visionary craftsmanship, blending patriotism, human conflict, and moral complexity with exceptional finesse. The screenplay maintains grip throughout, and the execution feels monumental. A truly transformative film that sets a gold standard for future spy dramas.

This isn't just a good film, it feels like a 100/10 achievement that raises the bar for Bollywood. A must-watch and a true redefining of modern spy cinema.

author: ashraks
title: Good Moments, But Not the Powerhouse Expected
text:
Dhurandhar is entertaining, but it doesn't offer much freshness in its storyline. The plot feels predictable, and those expecting something uniquely powerful from Akshay Khanna's character may walk away disappointed. Despite the hype on social media, his portrayal isn't as aggressive or impactful as suggested, and the "Rehman Dakait" persona lacks the powerhouse energy one might expect.

Ranveer Singh delivers a solid performance, and Arjun Rampal stands out as the true powerhouse of the film, bringing intensity whenever he's on screen. On the other hand, Sanjay Dutt's character doesn't blend well with the storyline and feels underutilized. Overall, Dhurandhar entertains but doesn't quite live up to the expectations set around certain characters.

author: Gem_Anant
title: Worth every penny and your time.
text:
Argo, Bridge of Spies, and "Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy" these are epitome of espionage movies, which are fundamentally based on facts and real events. Contrastingly, James Bond 007 World: Dr. No through No Time To Die continuum of fictional illustration of espionage. Additionally, espionage documentaries on History Channel have always kept me at edge of the seat.

Dhurandhar, is an amalgamation of all these 3 genres into a bloody hell cinematic experience. The Director, Aditya Dhar has pulled off a chef's kiss for his audience. I was blown away by his brilliant vision and representation onto the stage.

Positives: 1. Direction, direction, and direction.

2. Casting team 3. Cinematography 4. All actors have done perfection to their roles 5. Background score and music 6. Dialogues (Hindi) are ranging from gut wrenching emotions to full of adrenalin.

Negatives: None. However, for non- Hindi speakers it is suggestive to read little about Flight 814 highjack, Indian Parliament Attack, and 26/11 to understand this masterpiece of story telling.

From the "title track" to "ishq jalakar"...from "gehra hua" to "naal nachna"..Shashwat Sachdev has done a wonderful job. 2025 was truly his year with "Bad of Bollywood" and "Kesari 2" as well.

author: SRIMANSATWIK
title: I liked the violence, but hated the forced narrative.
text:
This movie wants your blood to boil before your brain even catches up. One minute it's gripping and properly nasty, the next it's feeding you a version of reality that feels confidently wrong. I enjoyed the raw punch of it and I also rolled my eyes more than once. If you like your thrillers brutal and loud, you'll get your money's worth, just don't expect the politics to play fair. It has a raw, aggressive energy that I actually welcomed, because the violence feels necessary to sell the world it's playing in and the threat it wants you to take seriously. Ranveer Singh is excellent when the writing enables him to stay restrained and even when he hangs back his presence still feels central. Akshaye Khanna once again reminded me how much range the guy has and it's honestly frustrating to remember how underused he's been for years. When the film locks into that gritty mood it has real bite and I enjoyed the essence of it more than I expected to.

Where it starts to wobble is in how it frames Karachi and Lyari, because it leans into punchline politics instead of clean storytelling. The repeated idea that "whoever rules Lyari rules Karachi" just feels lazy and it ignores how complicated the city's actual power dynamics are; Lyari is a tiny slice of Karachi, not the whole chessboard. The movie also tries to weld the Lyari gang conflict to 26/11 in a way that comes off forced, because the gang war angle is shown like a neat external conspiracy when it was more of an internal turf conflict tied to local and provincial power games. The "people in Pakistan celebrated 26/11" vibe also felt like a manufactured trigger and the whole "we will destroy India" framing plays like a shortcut designed for applause rather than credibility. Even a throwaway line like the spy repeating that Lyari quote is so overcooked that it becomes unintentionally funny and not in the way the film thinks it is.

On the craft side, the highs are real. The music choices elevate several sequences and the film does know how to build momentum when it wants to. The action is intense and impactful, but the shaky-cam becomes a consistent problem, because it dilutes clarity right when the tension should be peaking. There's also a strange mismatch in the set pieces: a shorter revenge sequence earlier hits harder than the stretched final hand-to-hand portion, which goes on too long and slips into clunky old-school choreography that doesn't match the sharper staging elsewhere. I also could've done without the wedding "item" number in the exact form it shows up, because a slick retro track would've carried that mood better. The ending does give closure while still leaving curiosity about Ranveer's past and where the story could go next, so it didn't leave me feeling cheated.

My only real sticking point is the politics, because it's both loud and weirdly selective. The film announces that it's inspired by true events and not targeting anybody, yet it leans on real terror footage and call transcripts and that makes the intent harder to shrug off. The emotional punch would still land without hammering the same notes and some of the messaging starts to look like a carefully engineered reminder that a previous government "did nothing" while the current one is painted as the fix, which is blunt in a way that undercuts the story's stronger core. Add to that one clear weak link in the cast, because Sanjay Dutt looks disengaged and his scenes feel flat even when the direction tries to prop them up. So yeah, I'm still on the positive side with this one, but it's a film I'd recommend with a straight face only if you can tolerate the propaganda seasoning and the technical overkill in the action.

Part-2... That's what contains the fun-part for me.

text: Action and original audio an videos of attacks are most impressive. Dhurandhar (2025), directed by Aditya Dhar and starring Ranveer Singh, Akshaye Khanna, Sanjay Dutt, and Arjun Rampal, receives strong positive feedback as a gripping spy thriller praised for its raw intensity, realistic storytelling, and powerful performances. author: ashishakpal
title: A Riveting Powerhouse of Performances - Dhurandhar Redefines Modern Bollywood Storytelling
text:
Dhurandhar is that rare mainstream Bollywood film which not only entertains but also commands your attention with its layered characters, gripping screenplay, and an ensemble cast operating at the peak of their craft. Director ___ (you can add the name) delivers a taut, atmospheric narrative that blends intensity, emotion, and intrigue with remarkable finesse.

Akshaye Khanna, as expected, is the silent storm of the film. His controlled performance, nuanced expressions, and effortless command over tension remind us once again why he remains one of Bollywood's most refined actors. Every frame he appears in carries weight.

Ranveer Singh adds fire to the narrative with an electrifying presence. His kinetic energy is perfectly balanced with moments of surprising restraint. It's one of his most mature performances, proving his ability to shift gears between flamboyance and emotional depth.

Sanjay Dutt brings raw gravitas to the film. With his trademark intensity and towering persona, he reinforces why no one portrays morally complex characters quite like him. His screen presence alone elevates the stakes of the story.

Arjun Rampal delivers one of his most understated yet impactful roles. His calm menace and internalised conflicts make him an integral part of the film's dramatic pulse. Rampal's performance lingers long after the credits roll.

R. Madhavan is exceptional - effortlessly charismatic and emotionally grounded. He delivers a performance rich with subtlety, adding layers to the narrative with every scene. Madhavan once again proves his versatility across genres and languages.

Rakesh Bedi is a delightful and unexpected standout. Known predominantly for lighter roles, Bedi showcases impressive range here. His character offers both emotional weight and much-needed humanity, making him one of the film's quiet triumphs.

The cinematography is atmospheric without being indulgent, the background score heightens the tension masterfully, and the writing smartly avoids clich√©s while still appealing to a broad audience. Dhurandhar is crafted with the confidence of great cinema and performed with the conviction of great actors.

Verdict: Dhurandhar is a compelling, power-packed drama that stays with you long after you've left the theatre. A must-watch for anyone who appreciates strong storytelling backed by extraordinary performances.

author: TheMovieSearch
title: This is action, straight up action
text:
Dhurandhar (2025) is a wild, high-octane Hindi action film that completely commits to chaos from start to finish, and that full commitment is exactly what makes it so effective. From its opening moments, the film makes it clear that subtlety is not on the menu. Instead, it delivers relentless action, shocking violence, and larger-than-life sequences that feel designed to leave your jaw on the floor. This is the kind of movie that doesn't ask the audience to settle in quietly - it grabs you by the collar and drags you straight into its world of danger and intensity.

One of the most impressive aspects of the film is its fearless approach to stunt work and action choreography. The sequences aren't just loud and flashy - they're imaginative, brutal, and staged with an understanding of how to keep tension alive in every frame. There are moments that border on absurdity, yet the film embraces that tone rather than fighting it. It understands that it is an action spectacle first and foremost, and it leans into that identity without apology. Rather than trying to water itself down for international audiences, it proudly owns its style.

The cast delivers performances that feel fully committed on every level. You can tell these actors weren't just showing up for a paycheck - they were invested in making this film feel authentic within its heightened reality. Their physicality, their emotional reactions, and their delivery of dialogue all add weight to the outrageous situations they're placed in. Even during the most unbelievable moments, the performances successfully ground the story enough to keep you locked in and engaged instead of laughing at it.

The direction is a major strength of the film. The director clearly understands how to visually tell a story through movement, framing, and pacing. What makes Dhurandhar especially interesting is how accessible it feels even for viewers who aren't familiar with Hindi cinema. The storytelling is strong enough visually that you don't feel lost. You understand character motivations, danger, and emotional stakes through action and expression rather than exposition. That's not an easy balance to achieve, and this film manages it surprisingly well.

Another standout element is the pacing. The movie rarely slows down, but when it does, it feels intentional. Those brief moments of calm aren't wasted - they're used to build tension and prepare the audience for the next explosion of action. The film doesn't pretend to be something it isn't; it doesn't chase prestige drama territory or try to be overly philosophical. Instead, it focuses on delivering a visceral cinematic experience rooted in adrenaline, spectacle, and momentum.

What ultimately makes Dhurandhar work is that it understands its audience. It knows people are coming in for action, danger, and intensity, and it delivers that consistently. Even as a viewer outside of its primary cultural market, the film remains engaging because of how universal its visual storytelling is. You don't have to fully understand every line of dialogue to feel the stakes, the fear, or the excitement. That's a testament to strong filmmaking instincts.

In the end, Dhurandhar (2025) stands out as a bold and unapologetic action film that thrives on excess, spectacle, and raw cinematic energy. It may not be for everyone, especially those looking for subtle storytelling, but for viewers who enjoy high-intensity action and fearless filmmaking, it's a highly entertaining ride. It succeeds by being exactly what it sets out to be: loud, wild, and unforgettable.

author: Igetnojoy
title: A long runtime that earns every minute.
text:
A three and a half hour film sounds daunting before you walk in, but Dhurandhar makes you lose all sense of time. The storytelling is so well written that you find yourself completely wrapped in it. Inspired by real events, the film does justice to them by presenting things as they were unflinching and honest. The horrifying scenes, the bloodshed, and the humiliation are portrayed without dilution.

The cast is powerful and delivers across the board. Ranveer Singh undoubtedly shines here, but what Akshaye Khanna brings to the screen is on another level altogether. That stare, the hunched posture, and his dialogue delivery mark the work of a master actor. Another performance that deserves mention is Arjun Rampal's. Based on a real person, he carries the look and presence convincingly. I found myself waiting for him to reappear, wanting more of his screen time, but unfortunately it wasn't enough, though the sequel does seem promising.

The love angle, the usual ingredient, didn't quite held my attention. While it made sense within the plot, it wasn't particularly engaging. That said, it did introduce energetic, modern music that worked well and felt like the butter on the bread. The touch of the newbie NE and the Bahraini rapper has stayed living rent-free in everyone's mind.

What truly sets this film apart is that it doesn't pretend about reality. It is a raw expression of what actually happened. Based on real life events and Aditya Dhar's creative vision, this becomes a genuinely captivating piece of art. It deserves the success it has received, despite being shunned by parts of the industry. Even the audience's lighthearted touch of "1st day being a spy" has now become part of the culture. To be rewatched soon on Netflix...

title: "A Lengthy Spy Drama That Works Well Enough"
text:
Dhurandhar is a 3-hour 30-minute spy thriller, but the long duration does not feel tiring. Director Adithya Dhar keeps the narration engaging, and the screenplay moves at a steady pace. The story is divided into nine chapters, and he handles them in a raw and convincing way. Because of the scale of the main plot, this long runtime actually feels necessary.

The movie ends by setting up a second part, and the story definitely has enough potential for a sequel - though the writing will need to be sharper in the next film.

The background score and songs are energetic and add a strong pulse to the film. The production quality is impressive, especially since a major part of the story is set in Pakistan. Ranveer Singh does well with his physical transformation and voice modulation. Akshaye Khanna and R. Madhavan deliver excellent performances. Sanjay Dutt and Arjun Rampal are decent in their roles. However, Sara Arjun feels miscast as the heroine.

Overall, Dhurandhar is not a brilliant spy movie, but it is still a enjoyable watch. Even with its long runtime, the film never becomes exhausting and keeps the audience engaged till the end.

author: NikhilA-875
title: Dhurandhar is not worth watching in theatres.
text: Dhurandhar is a one time watch movie but not in theatres. It feels slow at some parts. I liked the songs especially the Ishq Jalakar and the title track when I listened them in audio form but the way these songs are presented in the movie is not good. It could be better. Also integration of background music to the screenplay felt offbeat. The movie tries, very enthusiatically, to justify some moves of the current central government, so yes it is politically biased, a mild BJP propaganda you can say.

author: kohlitanu-92005
title: A Thrilling Star-Studded Ride
text: The story unfolds like a tightly wound clock, each character movement deliberate and meaningful. Ranveer Singh is captivating in scenes that alternate between cerebral strategy and explosive physicality; his performance in the rooftop confrontation against rival factions demonstrates both precision and emotional depth. Sanjay Dutt's presence dominates boardroom sequences and street confrontations alike, commanding attention with every word and gesture. Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan imbue even brief dialogues with intelligence and gravitas, while Arjun Rampal's silent menace creates constant tension, making viewers anticipate his every move. Sara Arjun's nuanced expressions in tense family sequences provide emotional clarity and contrast. Aditya Dhar's direction balances multi-threaded storytelling with action choreography that feels grounded yet exhilarating. Cinematography and lighting distinguish chaos from quiet reflection, and the soundtrack highlights every suspenseful beat. By the finale, the film masterfully combines intellectual strategy, high-octane action, and emotional intensity, creating an unforgettable cinematic experience.

author: kumararvindh-14062

author: zeeus87
title: One time watch. Well made, but poorly framed
text:
Enjoyed the movie overall, but it felt overrated and didn't fully live up to the hype. The performances were the film's biggest strength. Akshay Khanna and Sanjay Dutt were outstanding and carried their roles with conviction. Ranveer Singh, however, felt bland and was easily overshadowed by the supporting cast.

That said, the film's biggest flaw lies in its treatment of real historical events. If Dhurandar has taken creative liberties with facts surrounding various attacks, it becomes deeply problematic. The Mumbai attacks are not distant history, they are a lived trauma for survivors, families, and the city itself.

Using real tragedies as a backdrop while altering facts or inserting fictionalized narratives for dramatic impact feels insensitive and ethically questionable.

Stories inspired by real incidents demand responsibility. Turning collective trauma into a cinematic device for "impact" or applause crosses a line, especially when accuracy is compromised. Some events deserve restraint, not reinvention.

author: KJKishore
title: Unnecessary Hype
text: There is a lot of hype about this movie and it doesn't live up to that hype. It's just dumb entertainment like Pushpa. There is a lot of ridiculous gore in order to create sensationalism through shock factor. Bollywood clearly doesn't know how to make intelligent entertainment or good art. We manage to copy the bad parts of the cinema from other countries (for example the gore and profanity in this movie) without learning from their good parts (concept, plot, writing, philosophical/intellectual/moral depth). A movie like this getting popular says a lot about the decline of our society. In short, don't fall for the hype and don't waste your money.

author: moviemonkreviews
title: Dhurandhar - A middling story on national security intelligence
text:
Rating - 3.25/5

A socio political mass action violence drama on the backdrop of national security and peace negotiations.

The story follows a mole from India secretly infiltrating into the Pak political landscape and extracting details of their associations with ISI through a highly classified operation.

Adithya Dhar has created a visually appealing movie with action, violence and mass elements satisfying the theatre experience for the audience while the story got more concentrated towards the Pak side and felt like Indian territory was given least importance which may hopefully be given attention in the next chapter. The filmmaker has highlighted some raw torture and violence sequences in the movie as demanded in the story.

Akshay Khanna is the showstealer with his poignant performance. Ranveer Singh got ample action sequences and he has given a pretty decent delivery in the movie. Sanjay Dutt, Rakesh Bedi & Arjun Rampal also gave incredible performances in the movie. Sara Arjun with her charmness and beauty grabbed the attention of the audience.

Good Cinematography by Vikash Nowlakha, great music and scores by Shashwath Sachdeva and felt the film could have been finetuned to less than 3 hours for a better experience.

A middling film in a large visual landscape giving a decent theatrical experience altogether.

author: sudpta
title: The Unease It Leaves Behind
text:
My Detailed Take on Dhurandhar - Craft, Choices, and the Unease It Leaves Behind I want to begin by clearly stating that Dhurandhar is a technically strong film. The scale, performances, production design, and sheer effort behind achieving this magnitude of filmmaking are evident throughout. Some scenes are genuinely powerful, and the actors look convincing and committed. From a craft perspective, the film largely succeeds.

Yet, as an Indian audience member, I walked out deeply conflicted-not because the film lacked quality, but because its narrative choices repeatedly worked against emotional alignment with the audience.

For most of its 3.5-hour runtime, I felt like I was watching a Pakistani gang-war film with an Indian spy embedded inside it, rather than an Indian spy film about protecting Indian interests. The focus overwhelmingly stays on the rise, dominance, brutality, and internal workings of terror networks. They plan, execute, expand, and adapt on screen with remarkable narrative weight. Meanwhile, Indian intelligence appears reactive, constrained, or simply absent for long stretches.

I understand the premise of deep-cover espionage-that a spy must do morally questionable things to gain trust. That is acceptable and even expected. But in Dhurandhar, the Indian spy's violent actions largely serve one purpose: to help terrorists trust him more. These actions rarely translate into visible strategic gains for India-no prevention of attacks, no dismantling of networks, no sense that the balance is slowly tilting. This creates a troubling ambiguity: is Hamza meant to be a hero, or a tragic figure failing despite personal sacrifice? The film never clearly answers this, and that confusion weakens the emotional payoff.

One moment that crystallises this problem is the handling of Rehman Baloch. When Rehman is dying earlier in the film, Hamza saves him-despite already being deeply embedded within the group. From an operational and spycraft perspective, eliminating him then would have involved lower risk and higher strategic value. Later, Hamza kills Rehman at a far riskier moment, nearly losing his own life in the process. This decision feels less like strategy and more like plot convenience, designed to stretch the narrative into a sequel. It undermines Hamza's credibility as a trained operative and makes the arc feel artificially delayed.

Another issue is how Indian intelligence and the Indian state are framed historically. The film revisits events like Kandahar, the Parliament attack, and the Mumbai attacks, but largely through the lens of Indian helplessness and failure. What's missing is context-intelligence recalibration, behind-the-scenes countermeasures, and long-term strategic responses. Kandahar, for instance, was not simply incompetence; it involved intense diplomatic and intelligence pressure. By omitting that nuance, the cumulative impression becomes unsettling: Pakistani terrorists are shown as "dhurandhar," while Indian systems are not.

From a pacing perspective, the film feels like an extended setup. In my view, the infiltration arc could have been contained within 1 to 1.5 hours. The remaining runtime should have shown the spy "working his magic"-outmanoeuvring handlers, neutralising threats, and systematically weakening the network. Instead, the audience is asked to wait for catharsis in Part Two. By the end, my adrenaline wasn't excitement-it was frustration. The film withholds narrative closure while demanding patience.

From a character and emotional alignment standpoint, I also felt something important was missing. While the film understandably shows key terror leaders as dominant-which makes sense from a craft perspective-I wanted to see their vulnerability, not just their power. In Raazi, the protagonist is not physically dominant, but her quiet intelligence and moral resolve give the audience deep satisfaction. In The Family Man, both villains and hero are brutal and competent, but the balance is clear: even when villains win battles, the strategic triumph ultimately lies with India. That balance is missing in Dhurandhar, leading not to tension but to emotional fatigue.

As a neutral viewer, I was also forced into an uncomfortable political reading. The film seems to suggest that earlier Indian governments lacked prudence, while later leadership enabled decisive action. This interpretation may not be intentional, but it emerges naturally from how failures are framed and how Operation Dhurandhar is eventually positioned as a corrective moment. Once the operation is attributed to Ajit Doval, the narrative begins to resemble a historical argument rather than a purely cinematic one. Whether meant to or not, the film opens itself to the charge of political signalling.

Finally, the most puzzling narrative choice for me is Hamza's backstory. He is shown as a trained, capable, mentally resilient spy-not weak or impulsive. Yet the film roots his recruitment in a criminal past and a life sentence. Even if we assume a softer justification-that he killed to protect his family and is not inherently criminal-the operational question remains: why place someone with such a background in one of the most sensitive, long-duration, high-risk espionage roles imaginable? Deep-cover intelligence work demands extraordinary patience, ideological clarity, emotional discipline, and sustained loyalty over years. This is not about morality but about operational logic. In reality, India has entrusted such responsibilities to rigorously trained defence and intelligence personnel-individuals with proven institutional grounding, such as officers like Mohit Sharma, who undertook covert missions based on professional military conditioning and accountability. Against that reality, the decision to anchor Operation Dhurandhar in a life-convict recruit feels unnecessarily contrived and weakens the film's realism.

In the end, I don't dislike Dhurandhar because of poor acting or weak filmmaking. On the contrary, the performances are strong and the ambition is commendable. I dislike it because it prioritises portraying the enemy's dominance over India's counter-capability, defers payoff for too long, and leaves the audience questioning the credibility and intent of its own narrative.

For me, it remains a one-time watch-worth seeing for the performances and scale, but emotionally unsatisfying as an Indian spy story. I genuinely hope Part Two restores balance, agency, and closure. If it doesn't, this first part will age poorly-not because it lacked craft, but because it forgot the audience it was speaking to.

author: karansharmaks-83038

author: sahildesai-91359
title: ‚≠ê Dhoorandhar - Spellbinding. Brutal. Honest. A Must Watch. ‚≠ê
text:
Ohh. What did I just witness? Let me pen it down for you all.

WOW. What. A. Movie.

For years, we've been waiting for cinema to show things as they are - without sugarcoating, without fake love angles between India-Pakistan, without unnecessary "Aman ki Aasha" romance, without bikini distractions, without RAW-ISI love stories.

Dhoorandhar finally delivers that raw truth.

The film opens with a powerful Bhagavad Gita shloka üî• From the first frame, it grips you.

Then comes the IC-814 hijack (Kandahar) sequence - intense, real, chilling.

Madhavan is extraordinary. His gaze, his frustration, his helplessness - brilliant. He wants more time, he wants to stop terrorism, but fate had other plans.

Then the narrative jumps to the Parliament attack - the day India cannot forget.

You feel that pain all over again.

From here enters Pakistan, the mountains, tension, silence... and then Ranveer Singh appears - long hair, sharp eyes, fire inside him. He disappears into the world across the border and what follows is pure cinema.

But then comes the man who steals the entire show - Akshaye Khanna as Rehman Dakkait.

He enters like a storm - cigarette, rage in his eyes, pain on his face.

Every frame he appears in... electrifies. He dominates the screen so fiercely that everyone else feels small next to him.

Mind-boggling. Spine-tingling. Award-worthy.

Sanjay Dutt and Arjun Rampal are powerful and classy as always - solid, impactful.

But the part that makes this film unforgettable is how they show the truth of 26/11 Mumbai attacks.

Not just visuals - but the conversations between handlers in Pakistan and the terrorists, live instructions, live reactions.

The screen turning RED, the voices echoing, the helplessness you feel - goosebumps, silence, tears, anger- all at once.

In that moment, the entire theatre froze.

Everyone felt it. Everyone lived it again.

**This film is not entertainment - it is an experience.

A reminder. A punch in the gut.**

If you miss it, you will regret it.

Please watch it. Feel it. Think about it.

Don't miss Dhoorandhar. üî•üé•üáÆüá≥

author: nakenergy-78627
title: Great storytelling, commanding performances but could have been better technically
text: Dhurandhar was good story telling; this is where Aditya Dhar excels. Some of the scenes created great tension and excitement. The performances of all actors are compelling. Ranveer Singh being the weakest of all - he gets a chance post the scene of the Mumbai attack but doesn't come convincing enough on his guilt. Hopefully he has some meatier things in the second part. Akshaye Khanna is in an excellent form here and he lives the part. Rakesh Bedi is super while Sanjay Dutt and Rampal are solid. Overall the performances are top notch. Technically the film falters. Dhar has captured the action really well but the CGI is weak - especially during the violent and gory scenes. The sound effects are another let down. It was really shrilling to hear all sorts of sound effects when the cars collide. The film is divided in to chapters and the final chapter is the weakest - it just drags too much where Akshaye Khanna seems to be a super hero. The wedding scene shoot out is also immature with no choreography regarding who is shooting whom. Bullets just fly all over in this movie and the take a lot of time to get one. Overall a good original plot and worth the ticket price.

author: GaneshP-543
title: It seems without facts.
text:
Dhurandar seems like is a textbook example of how ambition without structure can completely derail a film. What starts with the promise of intensity and depth quickly collapses into an irrational, poorly coordinated mess that lacks both direction and purpose.

The biggest flaw of the movie is its absence of narrative logic. Scenes unfold without cause-and-effect, characters appear and disappear without development, and events seem to exist only to fill screen time rather than serve the story. The so-called "chapters" feel randomly stitched together, with no emotional or thematic continuity. Instead of enhancing the storytelling, the chapter format exposes the film's weak writing and lack of planning.

Equally frustrating is the non-existent ending. The film simply stops rather than concludes. There is no resolution, no payoff, and no sense of completion-leaving the audience confused rather than contemplative. An open ending can be powerful, but Dhurandar mistakes incompleteness for depth.

The characters lack motivation and consistency. Their actions often defy basic logic, making it impossible for the audience to emotionally invest. The film seems more interested in appearing intense and philosophical than actually earning those moments through solid storytelling.

In the end, Dhurandar feels like a collection of disconnected ideas masquerading as cinema. Without a coherent structure, a meaningful conclusion, or coordinated chapters, the film fails to engage, satisfy, or even provoke thought. What could have been a compelling narrative instead becomes an exhausting experience that tests the viewer's patience.

Verdict: A confusing, irrational film with no narrative discipline-Dhurandar is more chaotic than crelative.

author: sudarshan-47109
title: Entertaining Spy Masala With A Heavy Ideological Undertone
text:
Watched the Hindi movie Durandhar with subtitles in the theater. It is perfectly fair to say that the film is entertaining, even while dealing with serious subject matter.

The story revolves around planned terrorist attacks involving Pakistan, with fiction skillfully woven around historical incidents. The first half moves at a good pace and keeps you engaged. After the interval, the narrative slows a bit but does not completely lose grip. The climax is pure masala and could easily have been trimmed by about twenty minutes.

I enjoy spy stories, and this movie worked for me at that level. The concept is similar to classics like Day of the Jackal and Eye of the Needle, where fictional characters move through real historical settings. However, this film is not at that level. Those movies felt tighter, subtler, and more grounded. Durandhar borrows the same spy framework but leans far more into commercial cinema and spectacle.

The background score deserves a mention, especially the use of Bhangra music during action scenes, which was energetic and surprisingly effective. The film is packed with stars. Ranveer Singh delivers a solid performance. Akshaye Khanna stays true to his understated style and adds depth. Sanjay Dutt and Arjun Rampal bring screen presence. Madhavan does not stand out dramatically but fits the role well and looks convincing. Seeing Sara Arjun as a grown up was a pleasant surprise, especially after remembering her from the Tamil movie Saivam.

Where the film becomes uncomfortable is its messaging. While terrorism is unquestionably wrong, the narrative often paints an entire country and an entire religion in broad, dark strokes. The use of chants, background slokas, and symbolic cues feels deliberately designed to provoke emotion and reinforce bias.

Durandhar succeeds as an engaging spy thriller but leaves you thinking not just about the story, but also about the intent behind how that story is told.

author: anuragdey-09282
title: A must watch theatrical experience!
text:
Dhurandhar is easily one of the standout films of 2025. Yes, the movie is lengthy, but not for a single moment does it feel dull-the screenplay and pacing keep you completely invested from start to finish.

The star cast delivers superb performances across the board, with each actor bringing depth and intensity to their roles. The story is gripping, layered, and unfolds with just the right amount of tension. Credit also goes to the director, whose vision, execution, and attention to detail elevate the entire film.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a powerful cinematic experience and arguably the best movie of 2025. Highly recommended!
