author: rana-tanushree
title: Brilliant but gory
text:
It's a brilliant movie no doubt. Great direction, strong performances, and impressive attention to detail. Akshaye Khanna is outstanding, especially given how challenging his character is. The mannerisms he adopts are spot-on and elevate the role even further. Ranveer Singh is solid and fits his character well. R. Madhavan appears in a look none of us could've ever imagined! He truly is a gem of an actor.

Sanjay Dutt, in my opinion, felt unnecessary. His humour doesn't land, and his character could've easily been removed, though I suppose they wanted someone with a personal agenda against Akshaye Khanna. Rakesh Bedi was excellent in his role, while the new girl could've performed better. Gaurav Gera was another surprise! None of us would've pictured him in that kind of getup.

The most powerful aspect of the film is how starkly it portrays the gory reality of terrorists - how they think, operate, and inflict fear and "enjoy" watching innocent people die :( It also highlights the immense pressure, pain and challenges the Indian government faces during terrifying times like terrorist attacks.

The movie could easily have been 30-40 minutes shorter. Some of the action sequences are too graphic and difficult to watch. I've rated it a 7 primarily because of the excessive gore and the entire Sanjay Dutt segment.

Once again, Akshaye Khanna shines the brightest! He truly deserves multiple accolades for this role. Salute for portraying such a complex character with so much depth and dedication!

Hats off to the entire team and crew. It's difficult to not clap for their extreme hard work in making this film!

Are people really that uni-directional, so black and white, either good or bad? Would enjoy more with some feelings and emotions - so many bold characters could reveal so much deep psychological realities.

author: sudhanshums
title: Dhurandhar - A Cinematic Triumph Bollywood Truly Needed
text:
Dhurandhar is a refreshing jolt of quality cinema that Bollywood has been craving for a long time. The film impresses right from the opening frame with its stunningly realistic locations and vibrant, alive atmosphere. The colour grading and cinematography are of top-tier quality, often giving the film a grand, Hollywood-like visual language. The immersive camera angles make you feel as if you're standing right inside the story.

The screenplay is tightly woven, and the direction is sharp, ensuring that not a single moment feels dull. When it comes to performances, Akshaye Khanna steals the show effortlessly-his screen presence is magnetic. Ranveer Singh delivers yet another brilliant performance, while R. Madhavan portrays his role with remarkable precision and maturity. The dialogues are strong, memorable, and elevate several scenes to another level.

In a time when Bollywood is struggling with identity and originality, Dhurandhar stands tall as a reminder of what true storytelling looks like. This is the kind of film that can revive the industry's spirit and mark the end of the unnecessary remake culture.

author: sikhamehra
title: Action That Shakes the Screen
text: Tension mounts steadily, blending psychological intrigue with high-impact action. The lead performance is nuanced and captivating, conveying moral conflict and courage authentically. Action sequences are carefully staged, intense, and narratively justified. Cinematography captures both intimate moments and large-scale chaos with equal finesse. Supporting cast performances are memorable, adding depth to the narrative. The screenplay builds suspense deliberately, rewarding audience attention with a thrilling climax. The result is a film that combines intellect, adrenaline, and emotion, leaving a lasting cinematic impression.

author: juhikumari-23427
title: A bold, uncompromising spy thriller that delivers both substance and spectacle.
text:
Dhurandhar is the kind of spy thriller that grabs you from the very first scene and refuses to let go. It's intense, atmospheric, and built with a level of ambition that instantly sets it apart from most films in the genre.

At the heart of the story is Hamza, played by Ranveer Singh, who delivers one of the most powerful performances of his career. As a young recruit pushed into a perilous mission deep inside Karachi's crime-infested underworld, Ranveer brings a fierce physicality and emotional weight to the role. His eyes, his stillness, his bursts of controlled aggression-everything comes together to create a character who feels both dangerous and deeply human. Even without dialogue, he communicates the turmoil of a man trying to stay alive while walking the razor's edge between duty and survival.

The supporting cast is equally compelling.

Akshay Khanna is magnetic as Rehman Dakait-calm, sharp, and unsettlingly unpredictable. He doesn't need theatrics; every glance and pause carries a quiet threat.

Sanjay Dutt adds gravity with his seasoned presence, grounding the story with maturity and raw strength.

Arjun Rampal brings an enigmatic, steady intensity that keeps you guessing until the end.

Together, they form a constellation of performances that elevate the film far beyond a conventional action thriller.

The world-building is one of Dhurandhar's biggest triumphs. The longer runtime actually works in its favour, allowing the narrative to slowly reveal the tangled web of crime, politics, and terror the characters are navigating. When the second half explodes into high-voltage action and emotional stakes, the buildup feels completely earned.

On the technical front, Vikash Nowlakha's cinematography paints Lyari's gritty lanes with immersive realism, while Shashwat Sachdev's pulsating background score never lets the tension drop. The action sequences are raw, ruthless, and refreshingly grounded, no unnecessary flash, just pure impact.

Dhurandhar is a rare blend of strong performances, tight direction, and gripping atmosphere. It's intense without being messy, emotional without being melodramatic, and stylish without losing authenticity.

If you love gritty espionage dramas with powerhouse performances, Dhurandhar is absolutely worth a big-screen watch.

author: nitinkumar-94040
title: Emotions, Thrills, and Big Screen Magic
text: The film blends strategic storytelling with high-intensity action. Ranveer Singh portrays a morally conflicted character with depth, while Sanjay Dutt adds gravitas and menace. Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan enrich the ensemble, and Arjun Rampal and Sara Arjun provide emotional weight. Aditya Dhar's direction ensures suspense escalates naturally, with action sequences that are thrilling and meaningful. Cinematography and score enhance tension and immersion, creating a gripping narrative. By the second half, stakes rise dramatically, delivering both emotional and adrenaline-fueled satisfaction.

author: arohipatil-08895
title: A Pulse-Pounding Journey with a Mega Cast
text: Every storyline twist in this film is carefully planted, rewarding attentive viewers with layered revelations. The protagonist's performance is commanding, showing both raw physicality and subtle emotional intelligence. Action sequences are designed to feel tense and consequential, with choreography that complements the narrative rather than overshadowing it. Dialogue and interactions reveal complex motivations, making relationships feel authentic and dynamic. Cinematography captures both the grandeur of set pieces and the intimate moments of character development. The sound design amplifies suspense without ever overwhelming the scene. Supporting cast members elevate the story, adding nuance and unpredictability. The interplay between crime, politics, and personal stakes creates a gripping backdrop, while the finale delivers a powerful, cathartic resolution that lingers long after viewing.

author: sainbuxdev
title: A Loud, Hollow Spy Drama
text:
Dhurandhar mistakes noise for narrative. Despite its star cast and claims of being inspired by real events, the film lacks the research, depth, and authenticity required for a credible espionage thriller. Instead of intelligent storytelling, it relies on thunderous background music, over-stylized action, exaggerated heroics, and forced patriotic cues that feel more manipulative than meaningful.

The script loosely borrows from real incidents, distorts them for drama, and labels the result as "patriotic," though nothing in its treatment genuinely reflects true patriotism. The marketing further misleads-promoted as an Indian patriotic saga, the film largely revolves around a shallow political portrayal, creating a clear disconnect between promise and content.

author: shivanshusharma-44555
title: marvelous
text:
Dhurandhar is a gripping, 10/10 spy thriller that feels inspired by true events and unfolds against the backdrop of gang wars and terror networks, yet never loses sight of its human core. The storyline has enough meat to keep you engaged throughout, the writing is brilliant, and every character is crafted with nuance and detail while the sincere, steadily building screenplay keeps growing on you with every passing scene.

Ranveer Singh is a true chameleon and he disappears into his role here, while Akshaye Khanna, Sanjay Dutt, Arjun Rampal, R. Madhavan, Sara Arjun, Manav Gohil and the rest of the ensemble ensure there is not a single weak link in the cast. Aditya Dhar delivers a film that feels so real and authentic that you genuinely feel like you're on the streets with these characters, and the way he blends real-life style footage and grounded sound design into the narrative results in several absolutely spine-chilling moments, including a key sequence where the screen turns red and you hear haunting recorded voices during an attack.

author: Priyam-730
title: Fantabulous
text: "Dhurandhar" is a gripping, power-packed film that blends emotion, intensity, and compelling storytelling. The performances are exceptionally strong, especially the lead's commanding presence. Its sharp direction, impactful music, and engaging twists keep you hooked throughout. A bold, entertaining, and applause-worthy movie that celebrates courage and resilience while delivering a memorable cinematic experience.

author: hauntedstripclubmusicbyabel
title: a film that punched me straight in the chest
text:
Dhurandhar honestly shook me. It wasn't just inspired by 26/11, it went way deeper. The way they used real footage, real audio, real news clips hit so hard. I actually felt sick at moments because it reminded me how ruthless those terrorists were and how many innocent people suffered. The movie didn't sugarcoat anything. It showed how even boys and young people weren't safe, how fear spreads, and how a whole city can bleed because of a few monsters. That rage came back while watching it.

Ranveer singh was fire like always, my forever fav. But akshaye khanna and arjun rampal had this calm, sharp intensity that made every scene feel personal. The way they acted, the way the story moved felt heavy, tense and real. I swear it was 3 hours but i didn't get bored for even one second. Every minute mattered.

The politics, the investigation, the emotional weight blended perfectly. It felt like a reminder of how cruel terrorism can be and how strong people have to be to fight back. I walked out angry, emotional, proud, shaken all at once. This movie isn't just entertainment, it's a reality check. And bro, i seriously can't wait for part 2.

author: sachin_rautela
title: "Ghayal hoon, Isliye Ghatak hoon."
text:
Usually, I don't write movie reviews, but this time I felt compelled to share my thoughts.

First of all, can we please appreciate and bow down to Aditya Dhar and his team for creating such an exceptional film. Honestly, I have never seen a movie like this in Hindi cinema before, and I truly believe this will mark a new era for the action-thriller genre in Bollywood.

Dhurandhar is perfect in every aspect - characters, story, narration, depiction, and direction. Everything is executed flawlessly.

This is the kind of movie people have been desperately waiting for and expecting from Bollywood.

Every actor delivered their best performance - Ranbir Singh, Arjun Rampal, Sanjay Dutt, and especially Akshaye Khanna, who was absolutely commendable. Each character added depth and intensity to the film.

I've also seen people comparing this movie to other spy films or Animal. Please don't lower this movie's value by comparing it to others. Dhurandhar stands on its own.

The best part of the movie is that there is no unnecessary negativity, no nudity, no sexual exploitation, and no forced love angle - just pure cinema.

And in the end, one line that defines the soul of this film:

"Ghayal hoon, Isliye Ghatak hoon."

author: ishaan-84263
title: Unforgettable Drama Backed by Massive Action
text: The narrative unfolds like a tightrope, balancing high-octane action with deep psychological tension. The lead's performance is magnetic, conveying internal conflict while commanding physical presence in intense sequences. Action scenes are exhilarating, precise, and grounded in realism, elevating the story rather than distracting from it. Supporting characters are fully fleshed out, adding complexity and unpredictability. Cinematic framing is both grandiose and intimate, capturing every heartbeat of suspense. The score subtly underscores emotion, complementing rather than overwhelming the visuals. Every scene contributes to the rising tension, culminating in a finale that is both satisfying and emotionally charged. The film is a masterclass in pacing, character development, and adrenaline-fueled storytelling.

author: milindtokarkar
title: Excellent spy movie
text: Dhurandhar is an engaging and entertaining film that successfully blends strong storytelling with impressive performances. The lead actors have delivered powerful performances that bring their characters to life, and the direction is commendable for maintaining a fine balance between drama and excitement. The music and cinematography further enhance the overall experience, making Dhurandhar a memorable watch. author: bpyhggh
title: One of the best
text:
Dhurandhar is one of those rare films that stays with you long after the credits roll. For me, it stands out as one of the best films I have watched in recent years, not just for its storytelling but for the emotional depth and craftsmanship behind every frame. It is a film that deserves far more attention, and I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone who appreciates meaningful cinema.

What sets Dhurandhar apart is its powerful narrative, which balances intensity with subtlety. The film doesn't rush; instead, it unfolds gradually, allowing you to truly connect with the characters and feel the weight of their experiences. The performances are exceptional-each actor brings authenticity and emotional honesty to their role, making the story feel deeply real and relatable. Whether it's the quiet moments of introspection or the dramatic turning points, every scene feels purposeful and beautifully executed.

The direction deserves special appreciation for its clarity of vision. The filmmaker manages to create an atmosphere that pulls you in instantly. The cinematography is equally impressive, offering striking visuals that enhance the tone of the film without overshadowing the narrative. The background score complements the storytelling perfectly, adding emotional resonance without ever feeling intrusive.

What I love most about Dhurandhar is its ability to make you reflect. It's a film that speaks about life, resilience, choices, and consequences in a way that feels genuine and thought-provoking. It is impactful without being preachy, gripping without relying on unnecessary spectacle.

In a world filled with formulaic films, Dhurandhar stands out as refreshing and unforgettable. If you haven't watched it yet, I sincerely recommend giving it your time. It's a cinematic experience worth having, and it leaves you with something meaningful to carry forward.

author: abitask-89087

author: Shrutesh0203
title: The Goat Spy Movie from India
text: Man, just watched *Dhurandhar* and it's straight fire! Ranveer Singh absolutely kills it as the intense spy Hamza Ali Mazari juggling crazy missions and personal baggage - the guy's got that perfect mix of swagger and depth that had me hooked from the first scene. Sanjay Dutt brings raw power as SP Chaudhary Aslam, Akshaye Khanna chills as the menacing Rehman Dakait, R Madhavan commands as Ajay Sanyal, Arjun Rampal terrifies as Major Iqbal, and Sara Arjun shines as Yalina Jamali, with solid support from Rakesh Bedi as Jameel Jamali, Manav Gohil, Gaurav Gera, Naveen Kaushik, Danish Pandor and the rest of the ensemble adding grit to every frame. The action is non-stop but smart, with twists that actually hit hard, and the whole vibe feels fresh for Indian spy flicks, no unnecessary fluff. Movies like Dhurandhar are reminders of the countless sacrifices made by our brave hearts to keep us all safe. Kudos to the raw, gritty and gutsy storytelling of Aditya Dhar. Pacing is spot-on, visuals pop, and that score amps up every tense moment. Left the theater buzzing - easily one of the best entertainers this year, go watch it if you haven't......

author: yedu-25924
title: Good movie with lots of errors !
text:
I expected hyper-nationalism, but the director was witty enough to avoid such cringe. The subject was very interesting, and the performances by all the actors were great. The screenplay could have been better, though.

However, the major flaws were in the art direction. Although Pakistan was portrayed almost correctly, the movie could have been much better with more accurate detailing. I noticed a Bajaj Pulsar, Bajaj Auto rickshaw (during a major sequence), and Tata buses and trucks - automobiles found here in India, not Pakistan. With the kind of budget they spent, they could have created a far more realistic portrayal of Pakistan.

author: ataltanwar
title: Best movie of the Decade
text:
Dhurandhar isn't just a film, it's an experience that stays with you long after the credits roll. In a decade filled with big budget spectacles and formulaic blockbusters, this movie stands out with pure storytelling brilliance.

From the very first frame, Dhurandhar grips you with its atmosphere, its magnetic performances, and its razor-sharp writing. The director's vision shines through every scene, balancing intensity, emotion, and suspense with flawless precision. The lead actor delivers a career-defining performance, embodying the character with such depth that you forget you're watching fiction.

What sets Dhurandhar apart is how effortlessly it blends mass appeal with artful filmmaking. The pacing never falters, the soundtrack elevates every moment, and the cinematography turns even the simplest scenes into visual poetry.

The last 30 minutes? Goosebumps. Absolute goosebumps.

If there is one movie this decade that deserves to be called a masterpiece, it's Dhurandhar. This film raises the bar and reminds us what great cinema truly looks like.

A must-watch. A modern classic. The best movie of the decade.

author: priyanshi-03264
title: Wonderful movie crazy edit
text:
What a movie eating for 2 part. Durandar isn't just a film it's a full blown cinematic punch that refuses to let you breathe. From the first frame, the movie reminds you exactly why mass cinema exists: to make you whistle, clap, scream, and forget the world for 3.5 hours. What a movie. And honestly, after watching it, you'll find yourself waiting for Part 2 like your life depends on it. Durandar isn't just a film - it's a full-blown cinematic punch that refuses to let you breathe. From the first explosive frame, the movie reminds you exactly why mass cinema exists: to make you whistle, clap, scream, and forget the world for 3.5 straight hours.

What works instantly is the film's unapologetic confidence. It doesn't waste a second convincing you of its madness - it throws you right into a world charged with intensity, swagger, and relentless momentum. The hero's presence is electric, the kind that makes the audience whistle even before he says a word. And the film milks that aura brilliantly without ever feeling repetitive.

The writing keeps things tight and engaging. Even without revealing a single plot point, it's fair to say the film balances drama, action, and emotion with a surprisingly smooth flow. Every scene feels like it's building toward something bigger, making you lean forward, curious about what the next punch, line, or twist will bring.

The music and background score deserve their own applause. They elevate ordinary moments into goosebump-worthy experiences and turn high-voltage scenes into pure euphoria. Cinematography is equally charged, capturing mass action with clarity and style.

What truly makes Durandar stand out is its energy. It doesn't drop. Not even for a moment. This is the kind of film that celebrates heroism in its most dramatic form, yet still keeps enough emotional depth to stay grounded.

Verdict: An explosive, addictive, high-octane entertainer that grips you from start to finish. If you love mass cinema, this one will stay with you long after the credits roll.

author: purucha-53950
title: A Gritty, Gripping Tribute to India's Unsung Heroes
text:
Dhurandhar is not just a film, it's an experience that drags you straight into the raw, unpolished world of spycraft and political espionage. What truly sets it apart is its unapologetic honesty; it doesn't glamorize the life of an agent, but instead shows the harsh, chilling, and often heartbreaking reality behind the shadows they operate in.

Ranveer Singh delivers a phenomenal performance as Hamza Ali Mazhari (also a potential connection to Aditya Dhar's directed movie URI), a character inspired by multiple real-life missions carried out by India's intelligence community. While the role is fictionalized, it carries the soul, grit, and silent bravery of countless RAW operatives who have risked everything for the country. His portrayal feels lived-in every expression, every decision, every moment of anguish reflects the weight of duty these agents carry.

The film keeps you on edge, giving you chills, anger, even helplessness at times, only to later reward you with the deep satisfaction of justice served. It's a powerful reminder of the immense horror, danger, and emotional toll an agent undergoes, and yet how firmly they stand by their kartavya.

A special mention must go to Aditya Dhar. His direction is sharp, immersive, and respectful. The execution is top-tier, and the storytelling stays true to the spirit of those unsung heroes. He balances intensity with emotion, ensuring the narrative never loses its heart.

In short: Dhurandhar is a must watch.

A bold, gripping, and honorable tribute to the brave individuals who protect the nation from the shadows.

author: pradeepthakur-09208
title: Dhurandhar: Strong Start, Mixed Impact
text:
Dhurandhar is a movie based on a true event that took place between India and Pakistan.

The star cast has been chosen wisely; however, a few actors could have been ignored and replaced with more suitable choices.

The movie revolves around an incident where an Indian agent is sent to Pakistan to infiltrate and take control of internal gangs, with the objective of curbing anti-India and terrorist activities.

Ranveer Singh plays the role of the Indian agent who enters Pakistan and joins the gang led by Akshay Khanna, a powerful local goon operating there.

Violence scenes are limited, but whenever they appear, they are extremely impactful and executed so effectively that they create a palpable sense of fear in the audience.

Ranveer Singh's acting is good compared to some of his other films. However, Akshay Khanna's performance feels average. It's unclear why there is so much hype around his role, as his acting appears quite normal.

The first half of the movie is very strong. The second half feels slightly stretched, but the climax ultimately covers up the shortcomings and leaves a satisfying impact.

Overall, Dhurandhar is an engaging watch with a strong first half, impactful action sequences and a well-executed climax.

#IndomitablePradeep.

author: kunalshera
title: Durandar: A Spy Story Without the Masala
text:
Just finished Dhurandar and honestly, what a banger of a film.

First thing the music is insane. Every track hits perfectly. I was literally vibing on empty roads after the movie because the soundtrack stays with you.

The realism is next level. Real names, real photos, real locations, real clips-it all makes the story feel crazily authentic. And the way they show an actual spy's struggle is so raw, nothing like those over-the-top "spy universe" movies. This one genuinely makes you think, "Damn, this is what a real spy's life looks like."

Aditya Dhar, you've done something incredible. No flashy hero entries, no glam, no unnecessary mass moments. Everyone-Ranveer Singh, Akshaye Khanna, Arjun Rampal, R. Madhavan, Sanjay Dutt-just enters like normal people, and that subtlety makes the film feel so real.

Ranveer is raw and brilliant, and Akshaye Khanna is effortlessly charming throughout. The locations, fight scenes, and production design are all super authentic.

My ratings: Music: 10/10 Acting: 10/10 Casting: 100/100 (Mukesh Chhabra, what a job.)

The suspense holds you from start to end-even the build-up is gripping. Honestly, this film is a gem, and everyone should watch it. In a world of glam and commercial masala, Durandar feels refreshing and real.

Big salute to Aditya Dhar and the whole team.

author: denilkatariya
title: Spy thriller
text:
As far as spy thrillers go, only a handful manage to leave a lasting impression on the big screen. Dhurandhar comes close to joining that list, largely due to its gripping premise and powerhouse performances.

Ranveer Singh delivers a deeply immersive performance as Hamza Ali, an Indian spy embedded as part of a long-term intelligence operation to destabilize enemy forces from within. His infiltration into the Karachi underworld brings him face to face with Rehman Dakait (Akshaye Khanna), a formidable gangster whose influence extends into the political power structure. Akshaye Khanna is excellent-calm, authoritative, and quietly intimidating-making their dynamic one of the film's biggest strengths.

Set against the backdrop of real-life events like the IC-814 hijacking and the Parliament attack, the film also explores the strategic mind of Ajay Sanyal (R. Madhavan), the IB chief attempting to outmaneuver systemic corruption and internal failures by planting assets deep inside enemy territory. As Hamza earns Rehman's trust, he gains access to key ISI players, steadily climbing the ladder in a dangerous game of deception.

Sanjay Dutt is menacing as SP Aslam Choudhary, a ruthless cop determined to wipe out the underworld. The performances across the board are strong, supported by striking cinematography and an effective background score that maintains tension.

Where Dhurandhar falters is its runtime and climax. The narrative becomes dense as multiple plotlines unfold simultaneously, and the ending feels underwhelming compared to the buildup. While the action is fast-paced and several scenes land well, tighter editing could have elevated the impact.

Overall, Dhurandhar is largely a Ranveer Singh-Akshaye Khanna show, offering an engaging glimpse into the dangerous, unseen world of intelligence operatives. Despite its flaws, it stands as a solid and ambitious spy thriller.

author: nirbhaysharma-90901
title: A Cinematic Ride That Hits Hard & Stays Long üé¨üî•
text:
I watched Dhurandhar and I'm still not getting over it. I left the theatre in awe - this is the movie everyone has been yearning for üé¨üî•

Dhurandhar is not just a film. It's a thrilling, immersive experience that shakes you, pulls you in, and refuses to let go. It is a long movie, yet it never feels dull or drawn-out; every moment is gripping. The writing is razor-sharp, the screenplay masterful, and the direction fearless, raw, and grounded - creating a world that feels brutally authentic. All credit goes to the visionary genius, Aditya Dhar. You nailed it, man!

The archival footage from the Parliament attack and 26/11 lands profoundly, a stark reminder that behind this spy thriller lies real history, anguish, and memories our nation still carries.

And the performances... üò≥üî•üî• Ranveer Singh is the anchor of the film. He carries it entirely on his shoulders. He doesn't just play the character - he becomes it. His piercing, expressive eyes convey more than words ever could. Every glance, every silence, every subtle emotion lingers. He brings depth, authenticity, and ferocious intensity to the role of a spy, making you root for him completely. That line, "Ghayal hoon, Isiliye Ghatak hoon" - oh man, chills everywhere.

Akshaye Khanna dominates every frame he's in. Magnetic, commanding, captivating, and powerful, he elevates the energy and leaves a lasting imprint.

Sanjay Dutt accelerates the pace with his formidable screen presence. R. Madhavan and Arjun Rampal may have limited screen time but their presence is memorable and impactful.

The background music flows seamlessly, enhancing every beat, while the carefully placed old classics add nostalgia, charm, and unexpected emotion. Masterfully executed by Shashwat Sachdev.

Dhurandhar is a must-watch - raw, emotional, gripping, exhilarating, and utterly unforgettable.

author: aasfakhatoon
title: love intense political thrillers and strong dialogue-driven cinema.
text:
The film opens with an intense and gripping scene - a plane hijack by terrorists. Indian Intelligence Bureau chief goes for negotiation but is captured, and just then the heroic entry sets the tone. From this moment, the story revolves around Hamza, a character whose life takes an extremely difficult turn when he is sent to Pakistan as a spy by the Indian Intelligence.

Hamza lives a brutal life among gang wars and political corruption. He struggles for survival, working at a juice stall while planning to infiltrate the Rehman Balouch gang - the most powerful family in Pakistan. The Balouch family history is dark: one son supporting the rival party, and another son, Rehman, controlling power.

During a wedding organized by Hamza's juice stall, Rehman Balouch's elder son arrives, and his stepbrother tries to assassinate him. A younger son suddenly appears, and although Hamza fails to save the elder one, he heroically saves the younger boy. This leads to the powerful entry of Rehman Balouch, played by Akshaye Khanna. His wife's emotional slap - full of pain and rage - is one of the most satisfying scenes. Her breakdown and Rehman's silent hug made the moment incredibly real.

Hamza refuses reward money saying, "I am Balouch. I have already lived a tough life. This was my duty." That dialogue hit hard.

Then enters the political uncle - a perfect depiction of a poisonous politician, like a dark snake. He forces Rehman to wait till elections and not take revenge. But Hamza convinces him that if he stays silent, he has already lost. They strike back, killing the attackers. In a shocking moment, Rehman even kills his own mother when he learns a dark secret of lineage - a brutal scene that changes everything.

The film heavily relies on punchlines, retro background music, and intense emotions of patriotism and betrayal. Then the heroine enters - the politician uncle's daughter, only 19, while Rehman is in his 40s. Their chemistry is emotional, not physical - not even a single adult scene, only a forehead touch conveying everything.

Rehman joins ISIS for selfish political power, delivering guns and bombs. The film connects to real history by showing 26/11 attacks, reminding audiences never to forget. It portrays ISIS brutality - killing Balouchi people, raping women, murdering kids. These scenes shake the soul.

Then comes Chaudhary Aslam, played by Sanjay Dutt - suspended for 7 years. His entry is full of raw abusive language, pure thrill. Arjun Rampal as ISI agent performs superbly.

Hamza becomes aggressive seeing 26/11 and plans to kill Rehman. Meanwhile betrayal unfolds - a servant involved, fingers cut brutally, and Hamza receives a video proving political conspiracy. To save his career, the politician leaks Chaudhary's base and attacks happen. Rehman joins politics, becomes powerful, but Hamza hunts him down.

A thrilling car-fight chase scene ends with Rehman shot in the neck. Hamza pretends to save him, sending him to hospital in an auto, but he dies. The ending clearly hints a sequel.

Arjun Rampal is fierce like a storm, the fight scenes, music, everything electrifying. Heroine looks innocent but stunning in party scenes. Typical Bollywood - hero can be father's age and it's okay.

R. Madhavan as Intelligence Chief - cold face, brilliant strategy. Before 26/11 he warns government about attacks but ignored. The film shows corruption, fake currency printing, black money, terrorist support and political betrayal.

The movie's spine is powerful performances: Akshaye Khanna, Sanjay Dutt, Arjun Rampal, the politician uncle, and Madhavan - every character sharp and unforgettable.

And the dialogue that stays with you: "Ghayal hoon, isliye ghatak hoon." At the end Madhavan reveals Hamza's new identity, sending him again into the field: "Samay kitna bhi bura ho... acchi baat yeh hai ki badalta hai." The entire movie structured like chapters - butterfly effect, jinn, destiny. Hard scenes, heavy emotions, patriotism, betrayal - all balanced. Not a bad film at all - actually very good. Powerful. Human. Emotional. Real.

My rating:(4/5) A must-watch for those who love intense political thrillers and strong dialogue-driven cinema.

author: Pankaj-6417

author: sandipkabra
title: Blockbuster
text:
"Dhurandhar" is one of those rare films that manages to keep the audience hooked from the first frame to the last. With a tightly woven storyline, exceptional performances, and brilliant direction, this movie delivers cinema at its finest.

The film's narrative is long but never once loses grip. Every sequence contributes meaningfully to the plot, keeping the tension high and the curiosity alive. The screenplay is layered, and the twists are intelligently placed-just when you think you've understood the game, the film flips the board.

What truly elevates Dhurandhar is its cast. Each actor contributes depth and authenticity to their character. The lead carries the film with commanding presence, while the supporting cast complements him flawlessly. Emotional scenes land powerfully, action scenes look real, and even the quiet moments are impactful.

The direction deserves special applause. The filmmaker has executed a complex plot with absolute clarity and confidence. The setting, pacing, and background score merge perfectly to deliver a cinematic experience that is thrilling and thought-provoking.

The storyline boldly explores the hidden agendas, misinformation networks and anti-national forces, peeling back layers that many movies shy away from. It sheds light on how biased narratives and external propaganda can influence society, and it does so without losing its entertainment value. The way the film handles themes of patriotism, integrity, and national security is intense yet well-researched.

By the time the climax arrives, the entire theatre sits in silence - because the truth the film uncovers hits hard.

author: navreview
title: Bloody Indian Espionage Saga
text:
It has taken Bollywood a long long time to produce something that can be truly labelled as a thrilling espionage and all thanks to Aditya Dhar, can no longer say India produces garbage in the name of thrillers and spy movies and can definitely move from one dimensional and garbage YRF spy universe, which should not be called as a universe. This is what Indian audiences have waited for so long where a superstar is not worshipped but story has been given priority, where one man is not carrying the entire burden of the movie, but all actors whether lead or supporting actors has been portrayed magnificently. In fact Akshay Khanna was supposed to be supporting actor but overshadowed Ranveer Singh completely. What makes this movie work is not just one aspect but everything in this movie clicks at the same whether storytelling, acting or music, all works together perfectly.

Now eagerly waiting for second part with high hopes.

author: kulbhushanmohit
title: A New Benchmark for Indian Political Thrillers
text:
Dhurandhar is a masterclass in how to blend "inspired by true events" storytelling with the high-stakes tension of a cinematic thriller. While officially a work of fiction, the film pulses with an authenticity that makes it feel like an undercover documentary.

The Gold Standard of Research The secret sauce of Dhurandhar is clearly its depth of research. With significant inputs from veteran journalist Aditya Raj Kaul, the film avoids the "filmy" tropes usually found in Indian espionage or political dramas. Instead, it offers a granular look at strategic affairs and internal security. This realism is bolstered by character designs-faces and names-that subtly mirror real-world figures, creating an instant, relatable connection for the audience.

Structural Precision: Chapters of Intent Despite its significant runtime, the film never wavers in its momentum. This is largely thanks to a chapter-based structure.

Clear Objectives: Each segment has its own mission and payoff.

Pacing: This prevents the narrative from sagging in the middle, ensuring that the audience remains locked into the "how" and "why" of every scene.

Clarity: It breaks down complex political maneuvers into digestible, high-stakes goals.

Atmosphere and Performance It is rare for a long-form movie to maintain pin-drop silence in a theater. This speaks to the immersive direction and the nuanced performances of the cast. Every actor plays their part with a grounded intensity-no one overacts, and no one is wasted. The silence of the audience is a testament to the film's ability to engage the brain as much as the pulse.

author: prakharkrishnatripathi
title: Dhurandhar
text:
Dhurandhar is a high-scale espionage-crime thriller that clearly aims to be larger than life. Directed with ambition and packed with powerful faces, the film works strongly in performances and technical detailing, though it slightly stumbles in pacing and certain casting choices.

Ranveer Singh, as the undercover operative, delivers a powerful and intense performance. He balances restraint and aggression well, especially in emotional and action-heavy scenes. While a few patriotic-heavy dialogues feel exaggerated, his physicality and screen control become one of the film's biggest strengths and keep the narrative engaging.

Akshaye Khanna completely steals the show as the crime lord. His calm menace, controlled dialogue delivery, and psychological dominance make him the most memorable character in the film. He elevates every scene he appears in and is widely regarded as the strongest performance. His role gives Dhurandhar its real psychological depth.

Sanjay Dutt as the SP is where opinions divide. The character itself is very strong-a feared, legendary officer-but the casting feels slightly mismatched. Dutt's style feels dated for this sharp, grounded role. Actors like Manoj Bajpayee, Pankaj Tripathi, or Nawazuddin Siddiqui would have suited this character better with their natural intensity and realism.

R. Madhavan and Arjun Rampal give solid, dignified support, adding weight to the intelligence and power structures within the story. The child actor adds emotional depth and a strong human connection to the film.

The music and background score are major highlights. They elevate action scenes, emotional moments, and tension beautifully. Several tracks leave a lasting impact even after the film ends. The jump cuts and chapter-style editing work brilliantly in high-energy sequences but feel abrupt during emotional transitions.

The biggest weakness remains the long runtime and uneven pacing, especially in the second half. Still, Dhurandhar stands as a stylish, performance-driven, and powerful big-screen experience.

The film often leans into loud ideological and hyper-dramatic expression instead of subtle psychological tension. This reduces interpretive depth and may disengage viewers who prefer layered, understated thrillers.

author: HollyGolightly123
title: Bigger Bolder but not better movie from Dhar
text:
A film from the maker of Uri - arguably one of India's finest war/mission movies - naturally raises sky-high expectations. Sadly, Dhurandhar doesn't live up to them.

What we get is a full-throttle action spy thriller that's all muscle and very little heart. It's so aggressively macho that it often tips into corniness. The characters, loosely inspired by real-life figures, are inherently fascinating, and weaving fictional gang wars, betrayals and political intrigue with actual historical events is a smart touch. Yet the plot itself feels painfully familiar - we've seen this cocktail many times before.

The casting is stellar on paper, but the performances remain merely serviceable. The single biggest crime, however, is the bloated 3-hour-32-minute runtime. Huge chunks are spent on sluggish character introductions, pointless chapter breaks, a completely gratuitous item song, and endless slow-motion shots that add zero impact could have been trimmed without losing a thing.

The romantic track neither distracts nor convinces, though it does serve the story to some extent.

With tighter editing and a little more emotional depth, Dhurandhar could have been a gripping thriller. As it stands, it's a disappointing follow-up. For now, Uri remains the superior film by a wide margin.

author: danishshaikh-05891
title: One way to show the terrorism history in india
text:
Having viewed the film on three occasions, I am consistently impressed by Aditya Dhar's directorial prowess; I believe he is poised to significantly innovate Indian cinema. author: Apeksha_Shah
title: A Cinematic Thunderbolt!
text:
Aditya Dhar's 'Dhurandhar' isn't just a movie, it's a monumental cinematic event that redefines the spy-thriller genre in Indian cinema. Running at over three and a half hours, it's a testament to gripping storytelling, where every minute is earned, every plot turn is impactful, and every performance is a masterclass.

Akshaye Khanna as the formidable crime lord, Rehman Baloch, absolutely steals every scene he's in.

Ranveer Singh delivers the performance of his career as Hamza/Jaskirat. His transformation into a ruthless, deeply conflicted undercover agent is total. He's feral, electric, and utterly brilliant, inhabiting the role with a level of intensity and physical prowess we've never seen from him. His eyes convey the weight of his mission.

R. Madhavan is pitch-perfect as the deeply troubled, Ajit Doval-inspired Intelligence Bureau Chief, Ajay Sanyal, the mastermind behind Operation Dhurandhar.

Sanjay Dutt and Arjun Rampal are phenomenal, bringing grit and menace to their respective roles.

A special mention must go to Rakesh Bedi, whose transformation into a menacing, opportunist politician is a revelation.

Also, The background score of this movie, primarily crafted by Shashwat Sachdev, is nothing short of a sonic marvel and is arguably the best BGM for an Indian action-thriller in years. It functions not just as accompaniment, but as a relentless, pulsating character in the film itself.

Lastly, To Aditya Dhar & the entire cast, and the crew: Thank you for daring to dream this big. This film is a monumental achievement in technical excellence, storytelling ambition, and raw emotional power. You have given Indian cinema a new high-water mark to strive for. The hard work and dedication of every single person involved shines through every frame.

author: Aarav2191
title: Heartfelt Drama Wrapped in Cinematic Chaos
text: From the opening frame, the film throws the audience into a meticulously built world of danger and moral ambiguity. Sanjay Dutt's commanding presence adds gravitas, his every line charged with authority and menace. Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan contribute with intelligence and subtle tension, enhancing the story's complexity. Arjun Rampal's quiet menace lingers in every frame he inhabits, while Sara Arjun's emotive sequences provide the human heart to the narrative. Aditya Dhar's direction is precise, blending intricate plotting with visually stunning, high-octane action. The cinematography captures both the chaos of Karachi's underworld and intimate emotional beats, while the score heightens suspense without overwhelming the scenes. Every twist in the second half feels earned, leading to a finale that is both thrilling and deeply resonant, leaving audiences breathless.

author: TheRealDarkFang
title: LADIES AND GENTLEMAN YOU ARE NOT READY FOR THIS!!!
text:
"Dhurandhar" is that one film for which any amount of appreciation feels too little; even if my review reaches its end, Dhurandhar's roar simply won't.

For the first time in Indian Cinema, the audience has witnessed something this grand, this powerful, and this overwhelmingly well-crafted. I genuinely want to know how Sir Aditya Dhar managed to create a masterpiece of this scale.

The film is packed with moments that send adrenaline rushing through your veins, with goosebumps that feel like they're roaring straight into your soul. The editing, the timing, the catchphrases, the character introductions-everything is executed with such precision that I could easily write multiple reviews just to cover every single quality of this film.

There isn't even one moment where the movie fails to deliver. The music, the set locations, and the performances of every actor are stunning-so naturally done that they stop feeling like actors and completely transform into their characters. That level of immersion is rarely seen in Bollywood.

Who would've thought a patriotic film could be this perfect? Even with a lengthy runtime of 3 hours and 34 minutes, not a single millisecond feels boring or stretched. I honestly didn't even realize when the time flew by. The movie doesn't revolve around just one character; it explores each character deeply, giving all of them proper screen time and pacing in a way I've never seen before in Indian Cinema.

Being an 18+ R-rated film, it uses its rating in the correct way-maximizing the intensity without dipping into unnecessary vulgarity. The most interesting thing is that despite being R-rated, there isn't a single lewd scene, which immediately puts it above films that rely on kissing or lust to boost popularity. This film knows what it's doing and never compromises its integrity.

Even the item song wasn't over-focused, and that restraint made it stand out more. The pacing doesn't break, the theme doesn't shift; the film stays loyal to what it wants to show and why it is showing it. It's spectacular to witness, mesmerizing in every second.

Bollywood spy-action-thrillers or real-life-based films usually try to show that maybe the villain has a soft side or that India's agency could be wrong. This film doesn't play that game. It shows the truth, the bravery, and the emotions of what an actual spy or agent goes through and how they handle impossible situations.

This film has all my respect. The decision to avoid glorifying death or over-the-top gore was brilliant. It keeps a realistic approach, making you feel like you're right there in the scene, witnessing everything with your own eyes. From the action choreography to makeup, from VFX/CGI to all the departments we know and don't know-every single thing is perfect. And I hope, and even believe, that the next part will carry the same perfection.

IF YOU HAVE READ MY REVIEW ALL THE WAY TILL HERE, THEN JUST GO WATCH THE FILM. GO SHOW YOUR SUPPORT TOWARDS OUR BHARAT, OUR NEW BHARAT. MOVIES LIKE THIS DESERVE TO BE MADE AND PROMOTED, MOVIES THAT SHOW REALISM AND BRAVENESS LIKE NO OTHER. ONLY YOUR SUPPORT CAN MAKE THIS A BLOCKBUSTER AT THE BOX OFFICE.

I DON'T KNOW HOW MUCH THIS FILM WILL EARN, BUT IT IS ALREADY A BLOCKBUSTER, AND NOTHING CAN STOP IT FROM BEING ONE. HELP OUR NATION-JUST LIKE CHINA SUPPORTED NE ZHA 2. WAKE UP, LADIES AND GENTLEMEN! YOU ARE NOT READY FOR THIS!!!

author: anshikamehta-81613
title: A Spectacle of Stars, Story, and Speed
text: Dhurandhar is storytelling at its finest, showcasing a director who understands the rhythm of a complex narrative. Every frame reflects careful planning, whether it's an intimate dialogue scene or a high-stakes action sequence. The lead actors excel in delivering layered performances, bringing authenticity, tension, and emotion to their characters. The supporting cast adds texture, giving weight to every subplot. The director's choices in lighting, music, and pacing elevate the performances, making each moment resonate deeply. Political intrigue, personal conflict, and underworld drama converge seamlessly. This film demonstrates how powerful acting, guided by visionary direction, can transform a story into an experience rather than just a movie.

author: mdonickislam
title: Adorable funny Movie!!!
text:
Let's break down the absolute cinematic masterpiece we're talking about here. Hold on to your popcorn-it's about to get wildly creative.

So apparently, some GCC countries were like, "Nope, not on our screens!" And honestly, after hearing the plot, I'm not even surprised. It's like the writers were playing a game of "Pin the Blame on Pakistan" and went full WWE smackdown on the map.

First scene: Plane hijack? Pakistan.

Second scene: Parliament attack? Pakistan.

At this point, I'm waiting for a scene where someone in India stubs their toe, and the camera dramatically zooms in on a made-in-Pakistan chair.

Then it gets better. They've got Lyari town running a full-service destabilization package: weapons to Kashmir, and they're printing fake rupees to crash the Indian economy? Bro, Lyari's got more side hustles than a Mumbai tapori with three phones!

And don't get me started on Major Iqbal-apparently, this guy is like the Bogeyman of Bollywood Spy Universe. Taj Hotel attack? Him. Bad weather in Delhi? Probably him. Wifi not working? Definitely him.

The obsession is so next-level, it's almost adorable. Like, in every action scene, some hero has to growl, "Ghar ke ghus ke marenge!" and you can almost hear the director whisper, "Yes beta, sleep well tonight." It's their version of counting sheep-except the sheep are all wearing Pakistani uniforms and getting blown up in slow motion.

At this rate, I won't be shocked if the next plot reveals that Pakistan is also behind India's traffic jams and rising tomato prices. Modi Vakht really said: Why make fiction when you can make fan-fiction about your neighbors?

It's not a movie-it's a national therapy session with VFX and a patriotic soundtrack. And we're all just here watching, equal parts confused and entertained, wondering if we're seeing a film or a geopolitical roast session.

author: JadadiDas7
title: Super oscar level work by ADITYA DHAR
text: Watched today's morning show of Dhurandhar, and the movie is epic! Finally, after all the pre-release drama from lefties and Bollywood's ecosystem obsessing over "violence" while celebrating art by MF Husain, Aditya Dhar's spy thriller dropped like a bomb. Ranveer Singh infiltrates Pakistan's Lyari mafia as the Dhurandhar operative, with Akshaye Khanna owning as a chilling gangster, R Madhavan as intel boss Ajay Sanyal (Ajit Doval vibes), Sanjay Dutt, Arjun Rampal-pure fire cast! One of the best political spy thrillers ever, it slams real events: IC-814 hijack, Parliament attack, 26/11 with actual footage and terrorist call recordings. Exposes ISI's terror hand, fake notes flooding UP via mafia-politico nexus-can't touch 'em due to "political vendetta" fears, but **"luck changes, our time will come." ** Classy action piece, no slow-mo hero flexes, just brutal realism on 2.5 front wars where India's real first enemy is internal riot-mongers with political shields. Pride in India first throbs-shatters Bollywood's "ISI fights terror for humanity" propaganda! It's got everything: Geopolitical digs at 2008 IAF strike denial by then-govt, immersive Pakistan sets with era vehicles, slogans, newspapers. Pulsing score remixing classics, no sex/nudity (just A-rated violence), Ranveer's feral intensity, Akshaye stealing scenes. Edge-of-your-seat content global hits like rivals Fauda. 10/10 big screen must! INDIA üáÆüá≥

author: WrittenbyN
title: Good to see veterans are making powerful comeback
text:
"Dhurandar" was a treat to watch-definitely a movie worth saving. It's great to see veteran actors returning and delivering powerful performances. I'm happy their potential is finally being utilized. From Ranveer Singh's appearance to Akshaye Khanna's acting, everything was excellent. I think this is the first Bollywood movie I've seen in decades where the love story actually serves the script instead of being forced in for the sake of having one.

The makers released a carefully crafted trailer that kept the audience guessing about the storyline. It's a smart movie with smart execution. One of the best things I noticed is that although the movie is long, it never feels that way. The writers and actors made sure the audience stayed engaged throughout. I'm already looking forward to the next part.

author: OnkarGemini
title: A bold, brilliant and unforgettable film, Dhurandhar is a triumph of direction, storytelling, and performance.
text:
Dhurandhar is one of those rare films that grips you from its very first frame and refuses to let go. Bold, unsettling, and deeply emotional, it's a cinematic experience inspired by true events-and it leaves a lasting impact. The tension, authenticity, and rawness give you goosebumps throughout.

The director deserves immense praise for the fearless vision and masterful execution. Every moment is crafted with intention, every emotion hits with precision, and the atmosphere remains gripping from start to finish. It's rare to see direction this assured and unapologetically powerful.

The story is equally compelling-layered, intense, and rooted in realism. It doesn't shy away from uncomfortable truths. Instead, it confronts them head-on, drawing the audience into a world that feels painfully real. The climax is especially shattering.

The screenplay is a standout strength: tight, immersive, and consistently engaging. Not a single scene feels unnecessary. The narrative flow, the dialogues, the emotional pacing-everything aligns perfectly to create a gripping experience.

And then there's Akshaye Khanna, delivering one of his most striking performances in recent years. His screen presence is magnetic, his expressions speak volumes, and he brings a depth and intensity to the role that elevates the entire film. Whether in moments of silence or explosive confrontation, his performance stands out brilliantly and anchors the film with maturity and finesse.

The picturization, gritty and haunting, enhances the impact even further. The visuals carry the weight of the real events that inspired the film, making the emotional beats hit even harder.

author: ravigupta-49570
title: Star-Studded Entertainment for Everyone
text: From the opening moments, the film establishes an atmosphere of tension and unpredictability, slowly immersing the audience in a morally ambiguous world. Ranveer Singh's portrayal is exceptional, balancing internal conflict with external decisiveness. Dhar's direction is masterful, weaving political intrigue and human emotion into a cohesive narrative. Every action sequence is precise and grounded, serving both the plot and character development. Supporting actors enrich the story, each performance adding nuance and depth. Cinematography captures both the claustrophobic intensity and expansive chaos of the criminal underworld, while the score subtly amplifies suspense. The story builds to a finale that resonates long after the credits roll.

author: amittkumarr-37927
title: Larger-Than-Life Drama and Excitement
text: The tension in this film grips you from the first frame, weaving a narrative that is as much about strategy as it is about raw emotion. Ranveer Singh delivers a career-defining performance, portraying Hamza with layers of vulnerability and steely resolve. The action sequences, choreographed with precision, feel grounded and visceral, while director Dhar's attention to detail ensures that every political subplot enhances the main story. The cinematography captures both the beauty and brutality of Karachi, and the score intensifies every heartbeat, making the film an immersive cinematic journey that lingers long after the credits roll.

author: gurungamit-07744
title: Heart, Action, and Incredible Performances
text: From the opening moments, the film establishes a tense, immersive world. Ranveer Singh anchors the narrative with intensity, subtlety, and emotional depth. Sanjay Dutt dominates key confrontations, adding weight and menace. Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan provide critical support with nuanced performances. Arjun Rampal's quiet menace heightens suspense, and Sara Arjun's emotional scenes provide grounding and stakes. Aditya Dhar orchestrates suspenseful sequences, action, and plot progression with precision. Cinematography emphasizes both scale and intimacy, while the score accentuates tension and emotional beats. The finale is thrilling, shocking, and emotionally satisfying.

author: magadalwarmayur
title: Certified banger.
text:
Aditya Dhar's Dhurdar is a smart, skilfully crafted espionage thriller.

When terror attacks on India escalate, the IB Chief takes a desperate call - send an undercover operative into Pakistan. Enter Ranveer Singh, and what follows is a film that delivers both the bloody satisfaction of raw action cinema and the precision, intensity, and political sharpness you expect from a top-tier spy thriller.

(May contain spoilers.)

Akshaye Khanna absolutely dominates every frame he's in. His screen presence is on another level - calm, magnetic, dangerous.

And then... those dance moves. Absolutely mind-blowing. Pure goosebumps.

Arjun Rampal has never been this evil in his entire career.

Unhinged, demonic, ruthless - a straight-up monster of a villain.

It really makes you realise how criminally underutilised he has been in Hindi cinema.

Shashwat Sachdev has cooked. üî• The collaboration with Saregama hits hard, with fresh twists on classic Bollywood tracks.

But the standout? An original song where Akshaye Khanna grooves in his hometown in Balochistan - pure vibe, pure swagger.

Certified banger.

A film that fires on all cylinders: action, performances, visuals, music, and political intrigue.

author: dasesha-12025
title: Non-Stop Fun, Action, and Drama

Arjun Rampal's quiet menace maintains tension, and Sara Arjun's emotional scenes make the stakes feel personal. Aditya Dhar orchestrates suspense, action, and character development flawlessly. Cinematography captures both sprawling urban chaos and intimate character-driven moments, and the score elevates tension. The second half delivers a thrilling and emotionally resonant climax.

author: Tushar_kumar_tk
title: Action That Fires Up Every Moment

author: rahul_prasad_01
title: Ranveer Singh's Subdued yet Scorching Screen Presence Fuels this Power-Packed Karachi Mafia Thriller !!!
text:
Inspired by real-life incidents, Aditya Dhar's Dhurandhar is a sprawling action drama that plunges into the dark underbelly of Karachi's criminal world. The film follows Hamza Ali Mazari (Ranveer Singh), a shadowy Indian operative who infiltrates the city's powerful mafia network, rooted in the Lyari gang wars, to dismantle terror operations from within. Told across multiple chapters, the narrative unfolds with deliberate, immersive world-building, drawing viewers into a brutal, morally murky universe that stretches close to three and a half hours. Remarkably, the runtime seldom feels exhausting, thanks to Dhar's confident, tightly controlled storytelling.

One of the film's standout elements is its music and background score. By reimagining 70s and 80s Bappi Lahiri classics within a modern sonic framework, the soundtrack becomes an integral narrative force, sustaining momentum and amplifying the film's raw energy.

While "Dhurandhar" is positioned as a spy thriller rooted in the familiar RAW-versus-ISI conflict, its soul lies elsewhere. At heart, it resembles a 'Godfather' style crime saga, an epic of power, loyalty, and betrayal set against Karachi's violent underworld. The scale and structure strongly suggest the foundation of a trilogy rather than a standalone film.

That said, the film isn't without flaws. Despite being set in the past, certain production design elements feel conspicuously contemporary and occasionally generic, slightly disrupting the period authenticity. The screenplay also slips into familiar stereotypes-such as a terrorist sneering, 'Hindus are darpok', a reminder of Bollywood's enduring reliance on well-worn narrative shortcuts.

Ranveer Singh delivers a commanding return to form, reclaiming his position at the top with a performance that is layered, controlled, and deeply internalized. Sporting long hair, a rugged beard, and an intense, unflinching gaze, his appearance may invite superficial comparisons to Ranbir Kapoor's "Animal", but the tonality and emotional register are vastly different. Singh plays Hamza with restraint and menace, allowing silence and stillness to do much of the work. The supporting cast including Sanjay Dutt, Akshaye Khanna, Arjun Rampal, Rakesh Bedi, and Danish Pandor, add gravitas and texture, while Sara Arjun leaves a pleasant impression in her role.

An ideological extension of Uri's defining line "Yeh naya India hai, yeh ghar mein ghusega bhi aur maarega bhi, Dhurandhar is unapologetically violent and unflinchingly long. Yet, for all its brutality and density, it remains gripping throughout, refusing to loosen its hold from the first chapter to the last.

author: iammuzwer
title: Strong Performances, Weak Impact
text:
Dhurandhar is technically well-made. The visuals are impressive, the hero delivers a solid performance, and the villain is effective. The music and background score are good and help maintain the film's tone.

That said, the movie struggles to create impact. The storytelling feels overloaded with forced patriotism, making the narrative preachy rather than powerful. The portrayal of Pakistan is overly dark and simplistic, which removes any sense of realism or nuance from the conflict.

There are no real wow moments, no engaging twists or turns, and nothing that truly surprises. The film moves in a very predictable direction, making the experience feel flat despite its scale.

The hero-heroine pairing is another weak point. The chemistry doesn't work, and the noticeable age difference makes their scenes uncomfortable at times - occasionally feeling more like a father-daughter dynamic than a romantic pairing.

Overall, Dhurandhar has good visuals, performances, and music, but lacks freshness, emotional depth, and memorable moments.

author: enjoyingengland
title: Pen's tremendous win over gun
text:
Dhurandhar proved something rare

You don't need hype, noise or controversy.

Respect the audience, tell the truth quietly and let people think. The masks people wore fell off on their own - not on screen but after.

Cinema won. Thank you Aditya Dhar, long live every individual who worked for Dhurandhar.

Entire Bollywood and Tollywood is silent, But the silence feels so loud. Dhurandhar challenges the assumption that scale, mythology, or language spread are necessary for historic success.

I never spent money to watch Bahubali 1 or RRR or Pushpa or KGF or animal in a theatre, I watched Bahubali 2 in theatre and regretted the loss of my time and money. But Dhurandhar I'm so proud I watched it on a cinema screen.

It has been a week since I watched it but I just cannot get it off my head, I'm a female and I am fine to excuse the extreme gore because everything else is top notch. Music is dope, I keep coming back for this drug every time Dhurandhar tries to slip away from my head.

Aditya Dhar respected audience by treating us like intelligent adults. This is clever cinema, money is the aftermath of the conviction this movie displayed. I wish it makes a record so high that only another Aditya Dhar movie can overcome it ever.

100/10 is my rating. Never felt a movie can win me over like the way this one did.

Bollywood has risen.

#Dhurandhar.

author: Lois_lane18
title: Relentless, Stylish, and Unapologetically Cinematic!!!
text:
2025 really saved its best for the end. Aditya Dhar, take a bow. If a 3.5-hour mammoth makes you completely lose track of time and still leaves you wanting more, you know it worked. This feels like Dhar fully absorbed the traditional action-entertainer template and then outgrew it on his own terms. To quote him, "Cinema remembers the brave, not the agreeable," and that line fits this film perfectly.

Performance-wise, Akshaye "Aura" Khanna absolutely eats every scene he's in. So damn satisfying to see him finally get his due...charisma is so unreal, you end up rooting for him without even realizing it. Ranveer clearly understood the assignment, calm and composed when needed, absolute wrath of god when it matters. Arjun Rampal is menacing as hell and really needs to keep working with directors like this. Sanjay Dutt genuinely surprised me, way better than expected. Sara fits perfectly, gorgeous and vulnerable where required, and the supporting cast is solid across the board.

The action choreography is stylized but purposeful, it actually serves the narrative instead of existing just for spectacle. The soundtrack absolutely slaps. Shashwat goes insane here and elevates every scene to another level.

I need to talk about that car sequence bcz my god it's been living in my head rent-free ever since. Hamza driving, Rehman stuck in the back, tension squeezing tighter by the sec in that claustrophobic space...absolute cinema. I don't think I breathed once.

Late to the hype, but this is absolutely a big-screen film. I'm going back for another watch. With the love it's getting, it already feels like it's earned that cult-classic status.

author: ankit4y
title: UNAPOLOGETIC. HIGH-VOLTAGE. ACTION
text:
Ranveer Singh delivers a career-best, intense performance in Aditya Dhar's sprawling spy saga. It's a gritty journey into the heart of conflict, anchored by the sheer brilliance of Akshaye Khanna as the ruthless villain.

Aditya Dhar's Dhurandhar is an uncompromising, high-stakes action drama about a covert RAW mission infiltrating the deepest parts of the Pakistani underworld. Despite its lengthy runtime, the film grips you with its stylish direction and intense, realistic action sequences.

Yes, it's long (3h 34m), but the raw action, incredible background score, and relentless storytelling make it worth every minute. Go watch this cinematic epic!

Sequel of Dhurandar coming on 19 March 2026.

author: daisyshah_official

author: thetanmaygupta
title: Espionage at Its Fiercest Dhurandhar Is a Monster of a Film
text:
Dhurandhar is a masterclass in how to make a lengthy movie without ever letting the audience feel the runtime. Not a single scene drags, not a moment feels stretched the tight pacing, crisp writing, and gripping screenplay keep you hooked from start to finish.

The film is gory and loaded with cuss words, yet none of it feels forced or added for shock value; it blends naturally into the brutal, lived-in world Aditya Dhar builds, raw, grounded, and intensely real.

Akshaye Khanna is an absolute monster as Rehman Dakait hypnotic, terrifying, unforgettable.

Sanjay Dutt's SP Chaudhary Aslam brings that trademark heavyweight intensity, and Arjun Rampal as Major Iqbal looks ready to unleash his full monstrous aura in the second part you can already feel the storm gathering. Hats off to R. Madhavan and the entire team, because every performance and every technical choice lands with precision.

And despite its 3 hour 40 minute runtime, the film never feels draggy. Time just flies, and I didn't even realise it something that's happened to me only with a few truly immersive epics. I've only felt this level of engagement in long films three times first with The Lord of the Rings, second with Zack Snyder's Justice League, and now with Dhurandhar. All three prove that runtime means nothing when the storytelling is powerful and the pacing is immaculate.

Honourable Mention Sashwat Sachdev's background score is pure adrenaline. It doesn't just support the film it drives it. Every beat hits like a pulse, every drop tightens the tension, and the whole soundtrack supercharges the film's spy-espionage mood.

This is the kind of BGM that turns scenes into moments and moments into goosebumps. Absolute fire.

#Dhurandhar #DhurandharReview.

author: iAshu21
title: Dhurandhar - A Movie That Grabs You and Never Lets Go
text:
Dhurandhar doesn't waste a second. From the very first scene, it pulls you into the harsh reality of secret operations and the brave people who walk into danger like it's just another day at work. The performances hit hard. Ranveer brings that calm but deadly intensity. Akshaye Khanna barely speaks yet steals every frame. Arjun Rampal and Madhavan add real weight, and Sanjay Dutt is a complete powerhouse.

What really surprised me was how real everything felt. The shootouts, the tension in every mission, the details around the Parliament attack and 26/11... nothing feels exaggerated. The music and background score are mind boggling, giving the film that heartbeat you feel in your chest. Even the use of real clips and sounds made a few scenes straight-up chilling.

This is the kind of film that makes you feel proud, angry, emotional, and pumped all at the same time. I walked out thinking, this wasn't just entertainment... this was an experience.

author: harshitamishraaa
title: Drama That Paints Every Frame
text: What begins as a slow, strategic exploration of a complex underworld gradually transforms into a high-stakes thriller that refuses to relent. Ranveer Singh's performance is layered, portraying courage, vulnerability, and calculated intellect with equal conviction. Director Dhar's storytelling combines psychological tension with kinetic action, making each scene impactful. The supporting cast complements the leads, each character contributing to the intricate web of crime and politics. The cinematography captures both grandeur and intimacy, making the cityscape a character in itself. The editing ensures that even the longest sequences remain taut, while the score amplifies suspense without overpowering the narrative.

author: sanjibanisudhasarangi
title: A Dark, Gritty and Deeply Engaging Thriller
text:
Dhurandhar is not just a film - it's an experience. From the very first scene, it pulls you into a world built on fear, power, and deception, and it never lets go. The story of an undercover Indian agent infiltrating Karachi's mafia-terror network is handled with remarkable maturity. Instead of relying on typical spy clich√©s, the film focuses on psychological depth, moral conflict, and the dangerous grey zones of loyalty and identity.

Ranveer Singh delivers one of the strongest performances of his career. His transformation from a determined officer to a man slowly consumed by the world he's pretending to belong to is incredible to watch. Akshaye Khanna is equally brilliant - calm, clever, and quietly terrifying. Sanjay Dutt, R. Madhavan, and Arjun Rampal add immense weight to the narrative, making the film feel truly epic in scale.

The writing is sharp and layered. Every scene has purpose, every conversation pushes the story forward, and every character adds a new dimension to the central conflict. The world-building is exceptional - the film presents Karachi's underworld with such detail that it feels real, dangerous, and unpredictable.

The cinematography is breathtaking. Dark alleys, tense meetings, silent betrayals - everything is captured with a sense of style that enhances the mood without overshadowing the story. The background score is another triumph, turning simple scenes into moments filled with tension and emotion.

Yes, the film is long. Yes, it is heavy. But that's exactly what makes Dhurandhar special. It refuses to simplify the world it portrays. It makes you think, it makes you feel, and it stays in your mind long after the credits roll.

In a time when thrillers often feel repetitive, Dhurandhar stands out as a bold, ambitious, and beautifully crafted film.

author: msgopikrishnan-24694
title: One infiltrator. Two ruthless gangs. Velu Naicker vs. Reddyar - with an Indo-Pak undercurrent engineered as deception.
text:
It's a well-made film and an engaging thriller-but it is not a spy thriller, at least not yet.

The film lifts heavily from Nayakan, almost scene for scene:

Rehman's son being killed by rivals mirrors Surya's death.

The senior dacoit gang being wiped out at multiple locations in parallel is straight out of the sequence where the Reddiyars are eliminated after Surya's death.

The last rites of Rehman's son are visually and emotionally identical to Surya's funeral-religion aside.

Rehman stepping onto the balcony and waving to supporters after being rescued from the police is a clear echo of Nayakan's iconic balcony scene.

Nayakan works for Tamils; Rehman works for Balochs-both positioned as protectors of marginalized communities in their respective territories.

Rehman kills the senior dacoit; Nayakan kills the senior Reddiyar.

Rehman runs schools and hospitals for Balochs; Nayakan does the same for Tamils.

And this list could go on endlessly.

If anything, I'm proud that Nayakan continues to influence Indian filmmakers decades later.

The film also borrows liberally from another classic gangster movie-Satya (Hindi). The entire infiltrator/outsider arc comes from there. Satya enters Mumbai as an outsider, works menial jobs (doodh-soda, anyone??), and gradually enters Bhiku Mhatre's gang. The scene where Ranveer Singh is shown his flat in a busy Mumbai locality, while Rehman's backstory is explained, is an almost exact lift.

Audiences today have short memories and are easily distracted. Label it a "spy thriller," and many will miss how deeply it is stitched together from films people have already watched a hundred times-Nayakan and Satya.

Yes, Aditya Dhar has clearly done extensive "research" on Nayakan and Satya. And yes, I enjoyed the film. But I genuinely wish he had acknowledged Mani Ratnam and Ram Gopal Varma.

That's where Anurag Kashyap stands apart. In Gangs of Wasseypur, he openly acknowledged Bala, Ameer, and Sasikumar. Inspiration is fine. Borrowing is fine. But owning up to it matters.

My small comparison on Dhurandhar scenes with scenes from Mani Ratnam's Nayakan and Ram Gopal Varma's Satya (Hindi).

author: cksquare
title: Gang War movie disgiused as a Spy Thriller
text:
Basically it turned out to be a gang war/mafia movie. Where gangs were killing each other like Godfather etc.

These were interspersed with events that were meant to look real, ie Pak against India.

Look at this way... they made a gangwar movie... and then threw in Madhavan to show up every once in a while in the play, to make this a spy thriller.

And then of course to please today's bosses they also added dialogues.

Waste of time. Not sure what people who rave this, are watching!

author: dhruvprajapati-74681
title: Must watch, Best film of 2025üî•
text: "Dhurandhar" is absolute cinema at its finest-a relentless powerhouse that flawlessly blends raw intensity, bold storytelling, high-octane action, heartfelt romance, and edge-of-the-seat thrills. From start to finish, this film grips you with a rare combination of grit and passion, delivering an unforgettable experience that stays with you long after the credits roll. What sets "Dhurandhar" apart is its fearless narrative approach. The boldness in the screenplay, weaving together complex characters with authentic emotions, is refreshing and compelling. The story pulses with raw energy, never shying away from the darker, grittier elements that make the plot so immersive and realistic. Action sequences are choreographed with precision and flair, radiating pure fire with every punch and chase. Each scene is crafted to keep the adrenaline pumping without sacrificing clarity-making the thrills genuinely intense rather than chaotic noise. It's truly a masterclass in balancing action with storytelling. The love story is beautifully interwoven, providing genuine emotional depth amid the high stakes and relentless pace. This balance adds a human touch, making the characters' journeys even more impactful and relatable. Cinematographically, "Dhurandhar" is stunning. Every frame is thoughtfully composed, blending dark hues and vibrant moments that visually echo the film's intense mood and tone. The camera work enhances every emotion and action sequence, amplifying the immersive quality that pure cinema should evoke. In short, "Dhurandhar" is everything a top-tier film should be-raw, bold, thrilling, passionate, and visually spectacular. It isn't just a movie; it's a flawless experience. A perfect 10/10 that sets a new benchmark for cinema lovers everywhere.

author: akshatmahajan
title: Amazing!!
text:

The direction was good and you could see that the director had done proper homework before making the movie. The performances by all the cast members was just brilliant, everyone gave their best.

Overall, it was a good spy action drama and you should definitely give it a try. Its a must watch!

author: arindam-97289
title: Finally, a Spy Film That Feels Real - Dhundhkar Review
text:
Dhundhkar is raw, unapologetic, and right in your face-but that's exactly why it works. The film is incredibly engaging from start to finish, and the political backdrop feels strikingly real because it's rooted in actual events. This is a real spy movie-gritty, grounded, and atmospheric-not the glossy "spy universe" style we're used to seeing from YRF.

The performances are exceptional across the board. Sanjay Dutt still delivers his usual style of acting, but the director uses him so smartly that he fits perfectly into the film's tone. Akshaye Khanna and Ranveer are absolute standouts; both bring intensity and nuance that elevate the entire narrative. By the end, I was genuinely excited for the next installment. Overall, this is a solid 8/10.

As for the propaganda angle-yes, the film definitely leans into certain political messaging. It openly criticizes previous governments and positions the 2014 (present-day) administration as the turning point in India's fight against terrorism. But surprisingly, this doesn't hurt the story. If anything, it heightens the stakes and makes the film more entertaining and impactful.

Dhundhkar is bold, gripping, and absolutely worth a watch.

author: Feel-the-truth
title: Dhurander.... Explains everything!!
