Acting wise, Akshay was standout, and every actor played their role to the letter, let's not forget Dhurander himself, Ranveer played his role to the letter, he isn't meant to be the front man, he is the man in shadows, listening, watching... He is brilliant.

Great movie, who cares about the running time.

author: yashhraaj
title: A Relentless Spy Thriller That Holds Its Nerve Till the End
text:
Dhurandhar arrives as a fully loaded, large-scale spy action thriller that knows exactly what it wants to be and commits to it with confidence. Written, directed, and co-produced by Aditya Dhar, the film unfolds as a dark underworld saga where criminals, informants, and covert operatives move through a world defined by secrecy, shifting loyalties, and high-stakes betrayals.

From its very first scene, the film is magnetically gripping. There is no indulgent buildup or unnecessary hand-holding. Instead, the narrative pulls the viewer straight into its tense atmosphere and maintains that grip across its ambitious 3-hour-and-32-minute runtime. Remarkably, despite the length, the film never feels bloated. Each chapter is sharply executed, flowing into the next with seamless transitions that keep the momentum intact.

The ensemble cast is one of the film's strongest assets. Ranveer Singh delivers a controlled and commanding performance, anchoring the film with intensity and presence. Akshaye Khanna, R. Madhavan, Arjun Rampal, and Sanjay Dutt bring depth and gravitas to their roles, each adding distinct layers to the interconnected world of espionage and crime. The supporting cast is equally effective, ensuring that even smaller roles feel purposeful and well-etched rather than ornamental.

A special mention must be made for the background score, which stands out as truly exceptional. It heightens tension without overpowering scenes and plays a crucial role in sustaining the film's brooding, high-stakes tone. The technical departments work in impressive harmony. The cinematography captures both scale and intimacy with finesse, while the editing ensures smooth scene-to-scene transitions that enhance narrative clarity rather than disrupt it.

Aditya Dhar's direction reflects confidence and maturity. The storytelling, dialogues, and screenplay are tightly aligned, allowing the film to balance action, intrigue, and emotional undercurrents without losing focus. The world of Dhurandhar feels dense, lived-in, and convincingly dangerous.

Overall, Dhurandhar is an excellent example of contemporary Hindi cinema aiming high and delivering with precision. It is stylish, intense, and consistently engaging, making it a standout entry in the spy action thriller genre.

Rating: 10/10.

By the finale, the film delivers thrilling action, narrative resolution, and emotional payoff.

author: subhash-33123
title: Can't Get Over Dhurandhar - What a Movie!
text:
Just finished watching Dhurandhar, and I'm honestly still processing how gripping and relentlessly engaging the entire experience was. From the opening scene, the film grabs you by the collar and refuses to let go. The background score deserves a special standing ovation-it's not just "good," it's electrifying. The BGM pulses through every high-tension moment, amplifies every emotional beat, and keeps you hooked scene after scene.

What surprised me the most is how effortlessly the film sustains its momentum over a massive 3 hours and 30 minutes. In an age where even two-hour movies feel stretched, Dhurandhar turns its long runtime into a strength. Not once does your attention wander. There isn't a single dull frame, and the pacing is so sharp that you barely register how much time has passed.

Another bold move by the filmmakers is the unapologetically graphic violence-something you rarely see executed with such rawness and intensity in Hindi cinema. The action sequences have weight, brutality, and a kind of grim authenticity that lingers long after the scene cuts. It's not violence for shock value; it's woven into the very fabric of the story, heightening both the stakes and the emotional payoff.

And the audience reaction? That, in itself, was an experience. Even after the final scene ended, people simply refused to leave. Everyone just sat there, stunned, excited, whispering theories, soaking in the impact of what they had just witnessed. You could feel the anticipation in the air.

Now the countdown begins-for March 19, 2026, when the second installment drops. If the title "REVENGE" is anything to go by, we're in for something even more explosive. Bring it on.

author: shuklaabhi-47514
title: True Indians please please dedicate 3 hrs
text:
Hi viewers,

This movie is largely inspired by real events. It highlights how threats can exist all around us and emphasizes the importance of strong, patriotic leadership at the central government level to tackle terrorism and protect national security.

The screenplay is decent-nothing extraordinary-but it could have been sharper in certain areas. Since the film is based on a true story, it's understandable that not every detail could be revealed. Still, the narrative feels believable, and I trust the intent behind the storytelling.

As for the performances, everyone has done justice to their roles. There are no over-the-top star moments or attempts to overshadow the story-no flashy Akshay, Ranveer, or Sanjay moments. Instead, every actor fits naturally into the film, and that collective effort works well for the kind of story being told.

Overall, it's a sincere film with a serious theme, driven more by realism than cinematic hype.

author: bsangramsing
title: Dhurandhar: A Fearless Spy Thriller Exposing Weak Politics and Celebrating National Strength
text:
Dhurandhar stands out as a bold, high-impact spy-action drama that combines powerful performances, gripping action, and strong nationalist emotion, making it highly effective on the big screen.

One of its most talked-about aspects is how the film's narrative portrays Congress-led governments in a sharply negative light, depicting them as politically weak, compromised, and willing to sacrifice national interest for power, including appeasement of Pakistan, erosion of India's global reputation, and weakening of the country's strategic strength-all shown within the film's storyline. This political angle gives the movie an extra layer of intensity and controversy, which many viewers find courageous and refreshing.

Alongside this, the film excels in performances (especially Akshaye Khanna and Ranveer Singh), realistic action, tense dialogues, strong background score, and large-scale storytelling that keeps the audience emotionally invested. Though the runtime is long and a few sections feel stretched, the film's conviction, scale, and unapologetic stance outweigh its flaws.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a must-watch for viewers who enjoy intense spy thrillers, strong nationalist themes, and politically charged storytelling that doesn't hold back.

author: officialkingayush
title: Change for the indian spy cinema scene
text:
Watching Dhurandhar felt like cinematic electricity - exactly the kind of film that reminds you why you go to the movies. The way Ranveer Singh's character blends into the gritty gang world of Rehman Dakait (as fictionalized in the film) is brilliant - he's not the flashy hero, but the silent, calculating agent whose quiet presence anchors the entire story. As you said: everything felt "perfect." That immersive underworld, the tension, the danger - it all felt real.

But the real thunderbolt of the movie is Akshaye Khanna. His portrayal of Rehman Dakait is magnetic. Every time he enters a scene, the energy changes. His aura - from cold menace to unpredictable violence - is so potent that it lifts the film beyond a typical thriller. Critics too called his performance a "masterclass," and many agree that he steals virtually every moment he's on screen.

The supporting cast - including veterans like Sanjay Dutt and Rakesh Bedi - also deliver solid performances. Bedi's character - a crafty politician - adds depth and unpredictability to the underworld-politics game. The side characters, as you felt, are all "dhansu" - they don't feel like padding but actual players in this dangerous world. Overall, the ensemble works as a tightly-knit gang: each adds flavour, weight, and intensity.

From a technical point of view, the direction by Aditya Dhar deserves huge credit. The world-building - recreating the gang-ridden underbelly, the political machinations, the moral ambiguities - is immersive and textured. The film unfolds like a raw gangster saga rather than a typical glam Bollywood thriller. The background score and music complement the vibe, amplifying every moment of tension, betrayal or brutality.

Of course - and even critics agree - the film isn't without flaws. At nearly 3.5 hours, it drags slightly in the second half. Some scenes linger a bit too long, and a few subplots seem set up more for future installments than satisfying resolution now. But for you - and clearly many fans - that's a small price to pay for such a powerful, engrossing ride.

In short: Dhurandhar delivered - and then some. What you described as "every character being dhansu," the gritty atmosphere, the perfect blend of Ranveer's undercover calm and Akshaye's killer aura - all of that came together to create one of the most enthralling Bollywood thrillers in recent years. I'd echo your verdict: 10/10.

author: shubhraaggarwal
title: Dhurandhar: Naming the Unnamed, Showing the Unshown
text:
Watched Dhurandhar recently - a film I believe was long overdue. It powerfully captures critical events from Indian history, especially those that much of the international media chose to underplay, often avoiding naming the real perpetrators.

What stands out is the way the story unfolds the journey of an Indian officer determined to neutralise some of the deadliest terrorists on their own soil. The narrative is gripping and unapologetic, rooted firmly in the complex geopolitical realities of the subcontinent - realities shaped by proxy wars, cross-border terrorism, and strategic silence on the global stage.

The director has done complete justice to the subject, and the casting director deserves special praise for handpicking actors who fit their roles to perfection. A special mention for the background score - what music! It elevates every scene and adds immense emotional weight to the storytelling.

That said, I do feel this film could be a lot to take in for viewers who are not well-versed with the geopolitical and historical context. Perhaps a full-fledged series would have allowed even deeper exploration. But for someone like me, who follows this subject closely, I lived every bit of it.

Now eagerly waiting for the second chapter in March. Kudos to the makers and the entire cast for telling this story with such conviction and courage.

author: Ashish_3
title: Amazing Masterpiece Based on True Events
text:
Dhurandhar is a powerful and gripping cinematic experience that truly lives up to the tag of an "amazing masterpiece." Inspired by true events, the film keeps you engaged from start to finish with its intense storytelling, strong emotional depth, and realistic portrayal of characters.

Akshaye Khanna delivers a standout performance, proving once again why he is one of the finest actors in Indian cinema. His screen presence, subtle expressions, and controlled intensity add immense depth to the film. He carries his role with remarkable maturity and makes every scene he appears in impactful.

Ranveer Singh also deserves appreciation for his performance. He brings energy and commitment to his character, balancing intensity with emotion, and complements the overall narrative well. His dedication to the role is clearly visible and adds strength to the film's storytelling.

The direction is confident and focused, making every scene feel purposeful. The background score and cinematography further elevate the impact, perfectly matching the film's serious and thought-provoking tone.

What makes Dhurandhar special is its honesty. It doesn't rely on unnecessary exaggeration; instead, it presents the truth with courage and clarity, leaving a lasting impression on the audience. This is not just a film, but an experience that stays with you long after the credits roll.

Highly recommended for anyone who appreciates meaningful cinema based on real-life events.

author: itssaurav_1
title: Dhurandhar - Raw, Realistic & Riveting Cinema
text:
Overall Impression: Dhurandhar is a hard-hitting and engaging film that blends realism with powerful storytelling. It keeps you emotionally invested from start to finish and leaves a lasting impact.

Music Usage Through Scenes: The music is used with great sensitivity. It enhances key moments without overpowering the narrative, making scenes more impactful and emotionally resonant.

Background Music (BGM): The BGM deserves special appreciation. It perfectly matches the mood of the film-intense during action, subtle during emotional moments, and gripping during dramatic turns.

Casting: Casting is one of the film's biggest strengths. Every actor fits their role naturally, adding authenticity and depth to the story.

Direction: The direction is sharp and focused. The director maintains excellent pacing and storytelling control, ensuring the film never feels dragged or disconnected.

Performances: Performances are powerful and convincing. The lead actor delivers a standout performance, while supporting actors contribute strongly to the film's realism.

Action Sequences: Action scenes are realistic, gritty, and well-executed. They feel grounded and meaningful rather than exaggerated, adding to the film's intensity.

Use of Real Incidents: The incorporation of real-life incidents adds depth, credibility, and emotional weight to the story. It makes the film more relatable and impactful.

Final Verdict: Dhurandhar is a must-watch for viewers who appreciate realistic cinema, strong performances, and meaningful storytelling. A well-crafted film that balances action, emotion, and reality effectively.

title: All-Star Cast, All-Out Action
text: The film excels in balancing action, strategy, and emotion, with each character given space to shine. Ranveer Singh's performance is a masterclass in portraying internal conflict and courage. Sanjay Dutt provides gravitas, Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan enrich the ensemble, Arjun Rampal injects menace, and Sara Arjun provides emotional depth. Aditya Dhar's direction ensures tension escalates naturally while maintaining clarity. Cinematography highlights both scale and intimacy, and the soundtrack emphasizes suspense. By the second half, action, revelation, and emotional arcs converge, delivering a powerful finale.

author: Rajit_thebingewatcher

Kudos to Aditya Dhar for analysing the "Pakistan" Ecosystem through laiyari and bringing lot of events from the past to create high octane in the movie. However, in between it feels mildly propogandist as well (doesn't cross the line , and may be because of my neutral perspective as well). I must say dhar has created bollywood version of "Departed" Finally. Definitely watch part 2.

Cinematography captures the sprawling urban environment and intimate character beats, while the score heightens tension. By the finale, the film's combination of thrilling action and emotional payoff is fully realized.

author: itachiu-11653
title: High-Stakes Action with a Heartfelt Core
text: The film is an immersive journey through danger, loyalty, and moral conflict. Ranveer Singh portrays his character with layered complexity, while Sanjay Dutt brings commanding gravitas. Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan elevate the ensemble with compelling performances, and Arjun Rampal's quiet menace lingers on screen. Sara Arjun provides emotional weight, highlighting the human cost of power struggles. Aditya Dhar's direction expertly blends suspense, drama, and meticulously staged action. The cinematography captures both explosive chaos and subtle tension, while the musical score enhances every pivotal moment. The story escalates naturally to a climax that delivers both emotional and cinematic satisfaction.

author: lokeshvt
title: Excellent Movie.
text:
Bollywood films usually fall into two extremes: either painfully bad, or so unexpectedly brilliant that they completely floor you. Dhurandhar belongs firmly in the latter category. From start to finish, it keeps you captivated.

The performances are excellent, no over-the-top melodrama, no lazy, half-hearted acting that plagues so many mainstream hindi films. Everything felt balanced. The story unfolds smoothly, the pacing works, and the action is tight and grounded, thankfully none of that exaggerated, cartoonish chaos you'd expect in something like a Rohit Shetty film.

This movie really proves that, in the right hands, Ranveer Singh can absolutely shine and be shaped into a true superstar. And then there's Akshaye Khanna, legend is the only word that fits that man. He's Bollywood's secret weapon: used sparingly, but every time he appears, he elevates the entire film. His presence alone adds weight and credibility.

The supporting cast is equally strong, with every role feeling thoughtfully cast and well performed. No weak links here.

All in all, this is one of those rare films that comes along once in a blue moon and reminds you just how good Bollywood can be when everything clicks. Easily one of the finest films the industry has produced.

author: MarwinSingh2001
title: Raw, Real and Brutal. Dhurandhar is a must watch for everyone..
text: I went expecting another spy thriller from Bollywood with over the top action scenes and aura and hype moments, but what I saw on the screen just blew me away.. This film is not like your average Bollywood big budget film where there are slow mo shirtless shots or stupid one liners but this is the best historical spy thriller ever came out of bollywood which is shockingly very real.. I was surprised by the performances of this film, after many years it felt like I'm watching a film of a bollywood actor instead of a bollywood star.. Calm and calculating , Ranveer Singh delivered one of the best performances of his career. But all the praise should go to the Akshay Khanna as Rehman Dacoit he stole the every scene he was in and actually managed to outshadow the main star of this movie, he delivered the greatest performance of his career without any doubt.. Rest of the cast like Sanjay Dutt and Arjun Rampal was great too but I won't go further into it.. Talking about historical accuracy this film showed us the real face of terrorism and it also included the real clips and recordings of some most famous terrorist attacks happened in India and those scenes actually hits very hard, on other hand it showed us the most realistic deception of our neighborhood country which no Indian film has never shown before... Watch it and you'll realise it. Talking about technical aspects sometimes films feel too long but some great performances and a realistic story keep things interesting for the audience and it actually sets up the stage for the next half story in the second part, also this film is mostly based on real world events so filmmakers tried to show everything surrounding these events.. But some cringe scenes should've been removed and overusing of vulgar language should've been toned down too.. Don't go with thinking about an full blown action movie sure there are some action scenes and especially the final fight scene during the climax which will give the action fans what they want, but action is only here to serve the story instead of vise versa like a typical Bollywood film which is i truly loved about this film, but whatever is shown is raw and very brutal which feels real also most of the action related things are saved for the next part.. At last without saying any spoilers i will say again that Dhurandhar is a must watch for the fans of Spy thrillers and also it is one of the most important and impactful movies I've seen from Bollywood in a long time. This is how a real Spy film should be made, instead of showing terrorists as sympathic figures and allies of Indian Spies as in YRF spy universe Dhurandhar showed us the real face of terrorism.. Can't wait for the second part in Next March where hell breaks loose..

author: mobashir_rahman
title: Great Characters. Great looks. Story is intriguing. Action scenes are filmsy at best, stupid at worse. And all the propaganda is even worse.
text:
Dhurandhar is, at its core, a strong drama film with a compelling premise. The plot is ambitious and gripping, delivering a brutal spy thriller that does not shy away from R-rated violence. When the film works, it is genuinely intense-often shocking-and succeeds in creating a dark, unsettling atmosphere that keeps the viewer engaged.

One of the film's greatest strengths is its character development. The story of an Indian prisoner on death row being recruited by Indian authorities to infiltrate the Pakistani mafia is both morally complex and dramatically rich, and the film takes its time building this arc effectively. Ranbir Kapoor (or Ranbheer, as commonly referred to) convincingly embodies a battle-hardened Baloch spy-physically brutal, emotionally scarred, and psychologically convincing. His performance anchors the film and gives weight to the narrative.

The antagonists are equally well-realized. Akshaye Khanna's portrayal of Dacoit Rehman is particularly chilling. A man who murdered his own mother at the age of fifteen, Rehman is depicted as someone capable of a level of violence that goes far beyond normal human comprehension. Khanna brings a cold, restrained menace to the role, making Rehman feel genuinely dangerous rather than theatrically evil. Arjun Rampal also delivers a strong performance as a shrewd Pakistani intelligence officer, adding another layer of tension and strategic complexity to the story.

Unfortunately, many of these strengths are undermined by consistently weak action sequences. The action often feels random, poorly staged, and narratively incoherent. Scenes such as people casually opening fire to kill Rehman's son lack emotional grounding or logical buildup. The escape sequence involving Hamza and his partner is unintentionally laughable, draining tension instead of heightening it. Even the final killing of Rehman-a moment that should have been climactic and devastating-feels oddly flat and underwhelming. These issues are not isolated but symptomatic of Bollywood's long-standing struggle with believable, well-choreographed action.

More troubling than the action, however, is the film's overt ideological messaging. Beneath the surface, Dhurandhar strongly suggests that the previous secular Indian government was corrupt, weak, and unpatriotic, while implicitly aligning itself with the worldview promoted under the current ultra-nationalist, ultra-religious Modi government. Given the political climate, it is difficult to ignore the incentives to advance such narratives-particularly those that delegitimize Congress while reinforcing a nationalist moral framework.

The film claims to be fictional, yet it deliberately invokes real, sensitive terrorist attacks on Indian soil and even incorporates real audio tapes from actual events. This selective "fictionalization" feels disingenuous. Rather than serving the story, it functions as a tool to stoke fear, reinforce the idea of a perpetual external enemy, and subtly normalize suspicion toward India's Muslim minority. In this sense, the propaganda is not just heavy-handed-it is ethically troubling, using cinematic spectacle to legitimize political narratives and social pressure.

In the end, Dhurandhar is a film full of contradictions: strong performances, an intriguing plot, and impressive brutality weighed down by weak action execution and deeply problematic ideological messaging. What could have been a powerful, morally complex spy drama instead becomes a film that entertains, disturbs, and frustrates in equal measure.

author: IsfakR
title: Old Spy Formula, New Packaging
text: The same concept has been made a thousand times. The director says the movie is fictional, but the entire film uses footage from real events, and the story clearly mirrors real incidents. The only part that deserves appreciation is Akshaye Khanna's acting. Otherwise, it's just a higher-quality version of the old India-Pakistan spy concept.

author: DhirajK-020
title: Dhurandhar experience
text:
Dhurandhar sets out to deliver a sharp action drama with a strong emotional core, and for the most part it holds your attention. The story follows a man trapped between loyalty, revenge and his own moral boundaries. The plot feels familiar at times, but the film keeps you engaged with its steady pace and a few solid twists.

The lead performance is the real highlight. The actor carries the film with confidence and brings weight to the emotional scenes. The supporting cast does a decent job, although some characters could have been written with more depth.

The action scenes are well-shot and pack good energy. The background score lifts many moments and gives the film a stylish feel. On the other side, the screenplay dips in the middle and a few scenes stretch longer than needed. A bit more polish in the writing would have made the experience tighter.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a watchable entertainer with strong moments, good action and a committed lead performance. It isn't perfect, but it delivers enough to keep you invested, especially if you enjoy gritty emotional dramas.

author: areeb-50613
title: A Canvas of Charm: Dhurandhar is a Delightful Masterpiece!
text:
The film Dhurandhar is an intense spy thriller powered by some incredible acting. The main actors are: Ranveer Singh, Akshaye Khanna, R. Madhavan, Sanjay Dutt, Arjun Rampal, and Sara Arjun.

Ranveer Singh (The Lead): Delivers a "feral and electrifying" performance. His commitment to the intense, gritty role is total, making his character the compelling anchor of the entire film. Critics are calling it one of his most powerful acts.

Akshaye Khanna (The Antagonist): He is the undisputed scene-stealer, giving a "masterclass in acting." His portrayal of the menacing villain is hailed as chilling and formidable, commanding every moment he's on screen with magnetic, underplayed intensity.

R. Madhavan: Provides a strong, authoritative presence as the sharp intelligence strategist, rounding out the core team with gravitas and maturity.

Sara Arjun: Her performance is praised for providing essential emotional depth to the high-stakes narrative, showing great range opposite the veteran stars.

In short, you go for the action, but you stay for the phenomenal acting, particularly the powerhouse showdowns between Ranveer Singh and Akshaye Khanna!

author: vimarshmunsif
title: Dhurandar:- A Long And Engaging Bollywood Flick After A Long Time
text:
/Dhurandar:- A Long And Engaging Bollywood Flick After A Long Time/

Amidst the ever reducing attention span of human beings, and the constant urge to chop and change, to do multi-tasking all the time, watching long movies has become almost obsolete. Even the makers have noticed this change of guard and are not indulging in making long flicks. Thus, knowing beforehand that Dhurandhar was a long movie made me a tad bit sceptical. But still, as has been the norm of late, I didn't watch the trailer and was keenly looking forward to watch the movie on the big screen.

The presentation of chapter wise progression was different and unique. It enabled succession and gradual movement of the plot towards its ultimate destination.

For a long time now, Bollywood has become propaganda driven and tilted history in the name of showing new reality or hidden reality. Thus, believing stuff has become difficult. Hence, for this movie, I went with a clear mindset of only watching it as a movie. It helped in staying put throughout without seemingly reaching to any sort of conclusion or judgements.

Dhurandhar is a typical Bollywood masala flick, comprising of all the relevant ingredients required for providing entertainment and content. It has a lot of violence, set-up, strategising, deceits, suspense, thrill, action and some songs too. The chapters are well compiled, with the perfect Bollywood touch, making for a delightful experience of watching the movie on the big screen.

The length of the movie is 3 hours 32 minutes with the first half being over 2 hours long. Some of the Bollywood movies these days end by the time this movie's first half got over. I had no issues with the length of the movie though. Yes, some scenes could surely have been removed or shortened, but never did it feel like the movie was boring in parts. There was always some twist, some new plot, some new character, that brought excitement and the urge to know what's next as such.

What I find amusing every time I watch a Bollywood movie is the writing of the fight sequences. Please make it believable man! Too much cinematic liberty spoils the fun. I would suggest the makers to hire some WWE script writers to officially write proper fight sequences for Bollywood movies, so that they can seem a tad bit believable too.

The writing and direction by Aditya Dhar was engaging and compelling. The chapter wise setup made it feel like a long web series being shown on the big screen. Again, just like the web series', the ending left a lot to be desired. We would have to cling on to what next now to see where it all ends. There was a big disclaimer in the beginning of the movie, which felt a bit too much. Some real life clips were slipped in amidst the written script, to boast the movie watching experience. Still, the kind of intense buildup which the first half had, I expected it to go up a notch in the second half. But the film fell flat instead.

The casting by Mukesh Chhabra was brilliant. I would point out on some amazing picks later. The ensemble cast together did a really good job. The look, the get up, were all outstanding too.

Cinematography by Vikash Nowlakha was good. The colours used, a nice blend of dark and light, the frames captured, some really close and difficult for the eyes, were all terrific.

I don't know if editing was bad or needed polishing coz I didn't feel bored. Yes, the second half should have been more intense and some scenes could have been removed or cut short. But I would say that Shivkumar V. Panicker has done an average job as an editor for this movie.

The dialogues were heavy, with abuses being hurled for fun too. There were adult dialogues aplenty. There were some over the top Urdu dialogues too, which gave a good listening without much understanding!

The music of the film was composed by Shashwat Sachdev. I felt the music was decent, given the dreadful quality of it these days. Nothing outstanding, but still, quite okay.

However, the film has used so many of the yesteryear gems. I don't know if enough credits were given to the original makers or not. But songs like Chupke Chupke Raat Din, Ramba Ho, Om Shanti Om, remix version of Monica Oh My Darling, Piya Tu Ab To Aaja, Hawa Hawa and Dum Maaro Dum were used big time in the movie. Again, it just shows how they ain't able to make proper music and have to go back to the old gems for survival. Surely, these gems added to the plus points of the movie.

Coming to the performances, I have never been a fan of Ranveer Singh. I have only liked his performance in Lootera. However, he has done a really good job here. He hasn't gone overboard this time. A bit bulky, with long hair, looking a tad bit like Ishant Sharma, he stuck to his role and did a decent job.

The look of R Madhavan was outstanding. He spoke his dialogues brilliantly and showed some emotions perfectly too.

Akshay Khanna was good too. He had that constant look and persona that defined him. Also, I loved the couple of instances wherein he danced a bit, especially the dance sequence in Balochistan, with the Valla Valla and marshmallow song.

Chapter 5 was titled Jinn and the way the Chapter 4 had ended, I surely knew it was time for Sanju Baba to arrive. There's an aura of awesomeness that governs Sanjay Dutt. I just loved his screen presence. They had mentioned "Special Appearance" in his name but I didn't feel like it was such a role. He was an integral part of the movie.

Danish Pandor had a big role and he did a really good job. I loved his performance. Rakesh Bedi was in a pivotal role and he delivered a great performance too. Arjun Rampal had a good role and he surely made an impact too.

Saumya Tandon came in as a surprise in the movie and it was good to see her again on the big screen. Also, the girl Sara Arjun impressed with her looks and dialogue delivery.

Now, lemme focus on the 3 best performances in the movie for me. First, it was an absolute delight to see Akash Khurana in a role in the movie. He's still got it and his look was really good too. I've been a fan of Naveen Kaushik since Rocket Singh days. He was outstanding as Donga here, as the loyal servant. Such a phenomenal performance from him it was. He has also become a bit bulky now.

And now, guess what, the best performance for me was that of Gaurav Gera, as Mohammad Aalam. Remember him, yeah! It is difficult to even recognise him but what a sheer class performance it was from him! I totally didn't expect him and was pleasantly surprised with both seeing him and also him delivering an excellent performance overall.

All in all, there's a lot of violence, action, fights and revenge in the movie. The efforts that have gone into making the looks of the cast is commendable.

Also, some chapters started and ended. However, there's still more to come from how things unfolded in the end.

Thus, Dhurandhar was a long but an engaging movie. The first half was incredible. Comparatively, the second half left a bit more to be desired. The usage of old songs felt bad but added so much to the flavour of the movie.

I would rate the movie 3.5/5.

author: officialshubham-26194
title: ‚≠ê 11/10 - "Dhurandhar" is a must-watch!
text:
Dhurandhar grabbed my attention right from the first scene. The story is tight, engaging, and never drags for a moment. The direction is sharp, and every frame feels purposeful.

The performances are outstanding. The lead actor, especially, brings so much depth and emotion that you genuinely feel connected to the character. The film's visuals are stunning, and the background score adds the perfect amount of tension and atmosphere.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a brilliantly made film that stays with you. Highly recommended!

author: dhananjaygole-27565
title: AKSHAYE KHANNA - THE REAL DHURANDHAR
text:
Dhurandhar presents a strongly written story undermined by weak direction and a poorly structured screenplay. The film feels unnecessarily long and stretched, with inconsistent sequencing that makes it difficult to understand what is happening and when. Instead of creating intrigue, the non-linear narration often leads to confusion.

The direction is the film's biggest drawback. Apart from the action sequences, the movie lacks narrative clarity, emotional flow, and pacing discipline. Poor scene transitions and an overextended runtime further dilute the impact.

However, the action choreography is top-notch and clearly stands out. The story writing holds the film together and prevents it from completely falling apart despite flawed execution.

Performances

Akshaye Khanna emerges as the film's strongest pillar, leading it almost single-handedly with an authoritative and controlled performance. Ranveer Singh supports the narrative with solid acting and impressive action sequences, though the story unrealistically bends around his character's will.

Sanjay Dutt appears distracted and oddly powerless in several scenes, reducing the weight of his character. Arjun Rampal has minimal screen presence and fails to add meaningful depth to the narrative.

R. Madhavan, portrayed as the head of the Intelligence Bureau and positioned as a "charioteer of karma," ironically comes across as powerless-more like a silent observer than an authority figure. Rather than influencing events, he seems to suffer from karma himself, with little real control over the unfolding story.

Overall, events rarely feel planned or strategic, yet they unfold as if driven solely by Ranveer Singh's character, with negligible intervention from the intelligence machinery. This weakens the credibility of the narrative.

Final Verdict

Dhurandhar is a well-written film with excellent action and strong performances, but it is held back by confusing screenplay structure, weak direction, and excessive runtime. Despite its flaws, the acting and core story make it a watchable but frustrating experience.

text:
Dhurandhar stands out as a rare film that dares to be unapologetically honest. In an industry where comfort often outweighs courage, this movie chooses truth - and that alone makes it extraordinary.

What makes Dhurandhar truly path-breaking is its fearless storytelling. It doesn't dilute, sensationalize, or play safe. Instead, it presents its narrative with remarkable integrity, trusting the audience to engage, reflect, and feel. That honesty stays with you long after the screen fades to black.

The film challenges conventions - in tone, structure, and intent - and sets a new benchmark for meaningful cinema. It's not just a movie you watch; it's an experience that provokes thought and conversation. One can sense the conviction behind every creative choice, making it clear that Dhurandhar is driven by purpose rather than formula.

This is the kind of cinema that pushes boundaries and opens doors for more courageous storytelling in the future. Dhurandhar isn't just a film - it's a statement, and a powerful one at that.

author: devulapallic
title: A gritty, realistic big screen spectacle backed by solid performances.
text:
Dhurandhar (2025), a big screen spectacle, is a high-stakes espionage thriller that follows a covert Indian intelligence operation to dismantle a powerful terrorist-gangster nexus operating out of Karachi, Pakistan.

Aditya Dhar's writing & direction and the film's technical execution sets a very high standard for the spy thriller genre.

(This guy is no fluke. Another National Award in the offing.) The film's events are set against the backdrop of real-life incidents that shook India, primarily the 1999 IC-814 hijacking, the 2001 Indian Parliament attack and the 26/11 Mumbai Attacks.

Blending facts with fiction, the sprawling narrative is divided into 8 chapters. This structure helps manage the extensive world-building and character development spanning nearly a decade of real-life events, making the story feel less like a single long film. As a stylistic choice, this format offers a deliberate, novelistic approach to storytelling, treating each segment as a movement within a larger, classified file or document.

Gritty, Realistic Action: The action sequences are meticulously choreographed and grounded in reality, avoiding over-the-top stunts. The brutal, visceral hand-to-hand combat and realistic set pieces enhance the film's raw feel. The action sequence in Chapter 3 is terrific and well-choreographed!

Immersive World-Building: The film excels at creating an authentic sense of place, transforming locations in India and Thailand into the dense, chaotic alleys of Karachi's Lyari district.

The cinematography uses muted tones and shadows to create a dark, gritty, and tense atmosphere.

The background score is relentless. The use of real audio recordings from the 26/11 Mumbai attacks is chilling and impactful, connecting fiction to a real tragedy.

The ensemble cast is the film's greatest strength, with every actor delivering powerful performances.

Akshaye Khanna Ji is the film's soul and scene-stealer. His portrayal of the complex, charismatic, and chilling gangster Rehman Dakait (~based on Sardar Abdul Rehman Baloch) is laudable for its depth and menace. A sureshot contender for the National Award.

Ranveer Singh churns out a restrained and intense performance, a departure from his usual energetic roles. He effectively embodies the quiet determination and inner conflict of an undercover agent, letting subtle gestures speak volumes. His character Hamza Ali Mazari/Jaskirat Singh Rangi is a composite of multiple Indian Para Special Forces (Para SF) and Research and Analysis Wing (R&AW) operatives who have conducted covert operations.

R. Madhavan, Sanjay Dutt, Rakesh Bedi and Arjun Rampal all make significant impacts ensuring there are no weak links in the cast.

R. Madhavan's character, Ajay Sanyal, is inspired by India's current National Security Advisor, Ajit Doval.

Sanjay Dutt's character SP Chaudhary Aslam is inspired by the real Chaudhry Aslam Khan, a renowned Pakistani "encounter specialist" police officer who targeted and eliminated many major criminals, including Rehman Baloch.

Rakesh Bedi's character Jameel Jamali is inspired by the real-life Pakistani politician Nabil Gabol.

Arjun Rampal as Major Iqbal is modelled after Ilyas Kashmiri, a dangerous Pakistani ex-Special Forces operative who became a high-ranking Al-Qaeda commander linked to major terror attacks, including the 26/11 Mumbai attacks.

The film weaves these real-life figures and events into a fictional narrative centered around a large-scale covert operation in Karachi's Lyari district, known as "Operation Lyari".

This film will be talked about for many years for its strong performances, gritty direction, and intense, grounded action.

Fact-checkers and critics will cry factual inaccuracies in the film. Just ignore! Propaganda accusations? None. Don't trust the negative reviews!

The sheer volume of information and characters may overwhelm the audience. (information overload) But, if you loved Black Friday (2004), trust me Dhurandhar is much more and beyond.

This is an example of how a two-part film must be treated. Can't wait for the Part-2 of this film March 2026.

author: shivamsemwal
title: Engaging but Excessive
text:
Dhurandhar positions itself as a large-scale spy thriller inspired by real events, and from a technical standpoint, it does several things right. The background score, sound design, and overall audio treatment effectively build tension and add to the thriller atmosphere. Viewed purely as a genre film, it is engaging and works reasonably well.

However, the film relies more on emotional amplification than on strong storytelling. Instead of letting the narrative and characters naturally drive the impact, it often turns to exaggerated dramatic moments, heavy-handed dialogues, and repeated emphasis on familiar conflict themes. This comes across as an attempt to compensate for a weaker script rather than a confident storytelling choice.

The use of real-life footage and audio clips from past terrorist attacks adds shock value, but it feels excessive and avoidable in many places. Similarly, the level of on-screen violence and gore is pushed far beyond what the story actually demands. Rather than increasing tension, the excessive gore often feels like it is there purely for effect, reducing its overall impact.

The film also suffers from its length. At close to three and a half hours, Dhurandhar noticeably drags, and a tighter edit would have made the experience far more effective without sacrificing key moments.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a decent one-time watch if approached strictly as a spy thriller with strong technical execution. That said, its overreliance on heightened emotions, excessive violence, and overstated themes prevents it from becoming a sharper and more refined film. A more restrained approach and a stronger script could have elevated it significantly.

author: saliltheinvincible
title: Hard hitting, well crafted and brilliantly performed
text: Apart from the long running time (it could have been series) for world building, which does pay off, the film does justise to what a espionage film be like. The critics have lost their chill, labelling the film as communal, hypermasculinity, propaganda and misogynistic. Well the community that have been mentioned are terrorists and violent gangs, on which multiple global documentries exists. There are two strong characters who have been slapped by their female partner without any retaliation, that seems more feminist than misogynst. Propaganda, well Pakistan and ISI don't have India's prosperity as their propaganda, and thats shown in the movie. For people who are targetting the age gap between the romantic leads of the movie, technically its 20 years, 1 less than the age gap between Shah Rukh and Deepika! There is no hero worshipping, physics defining scenes, illogical action sequences in the name of creative liberty and mostly no ISI agents in bikini. For those who say they are not able to see this movie with their family and children, its a 'A' rated movie you should not be watching this until you are 18+. There is a dialogue in the movie which says "India ka sabse bada dushman Indians hai, Pakistan dusre number pe aata hai" is aptly highlighting those who are spreading hate against the movie, some even without watching it!

author: Sangramk-31
title: DHURANDHAR MOVIE üçø
text:
Aditya Dhar proves once more that he is a force to reckon with. After the massive impact of URI: The Surgical Strike, expectations from Dhurandhar were sky-high-and Dhar not only meets them, he surpasses them with striking confidence. Dhurandhar is an intense, gripping, and emotionally charged experience that showcases Dhar's evolving mastery over storytelling and mood-building.

From the very first frame, the film pulls you into its world. Dhar uses a mix of taut writing, sharp pacing, and stunning visual design to create an atmosphere that rarely lets you breathe. The narrative blends action, drama, and emotion with a precision that feels both bold and incredibly assured. Each scene lands with purpose, each character arc feels meaningful, and the stakes escalate in a way that keeps you glued throughout.

The performances are top-tier, elevating the already powerful script. The background score and cinematography work in perfect harmony, adding weight to the film's most explosive as well as its quietest moments.

author: amir-22569
title: LENGTHY AND BORING
text:
Dhurandar tries hard to make an impact but falls short in many areas. The only real saving grace of the film is Akshay Khanna, who once again delivers a solid and controlled performance. His expressions, timing, and intensity stand out and keep you watching even when the film itself starts losing grip.

Unfortunately, the storyline is weak, with a plot that feels predictable from the very beginning. Many scenes drag on unnecessarily, making the movie feel lengthy and boring at times. The screenplay lacks freshness and fails to build any real excitement or emotional depth.

Overall, Dhurandar could have been much better if the script matched the quality of Akshay Khanna's acting. Good performance, but poor writing holds the movie back.

Arjun Rampal's controlled menace contrasts with Sara Arjun's emotional authenticity, raising the narrative stakes. Aditya Dhar's direction balances action and strategy, while cinematography captures the setting with realism and beauty. The score enhances tension, and the editing ensures pacing remains taut. By the final act, the film achieves a thrilling and emotionally resonant cinematic experience.

author: sonamdolmak
title: Cancel your plans. Dhurandhar not be missed on Big Screen
text: Dhurandhar isn't just a spy thriller-it's a masterclass in espionage cinema that demands to be experienced on the big screen. The film's technical brilliance is staggering; every frame feels meticulously crafted, with cinematography that rivals international standards. What sets it apart is the evident research into tradecraft-the Lyaari gangs, the attire, dead drops, and operational protocols feel authentic rather than Hollywood-ized. The direction is taut and precise, maintaining tension without ever feeling manipulative. The DOP's work is exceptional, using shadows and negative space to amplify paranoia. This is intelligent, grown-up filmmaking that respects your intelligence. Cancel your plans. This deserves your undivided attention in a theater where its craft can truly breathe.

author: happys-49
title: Dhurandhar: A Gripping Spy Thriller That Delivers Intensity
text:
This spy action thriller plunges into the dark underworld of Karachi's Lyari gang, where Indian agent Hamza Ali Mazhari (Ranveer Singh) goes undercover to dismantle terror networks. Loosely inspired by real events like Operation Lyari and geopolitical tensions, the film weaves espionage, betrayal, and raw patriotism into a sprawling narrative.

Ranveer Singh shines as the conflicted operative, delivering a restrained yet explosive performance full of charisma and vulnerability. He's brilliantly countered by Akshaye Khanna as the ruthless gang lord Rehman Dakait, whose menacing presence dominates scenes. The ensemble-R. Madhavan as the sharp IB chief Ajay Sanyal (echoing Ajit Doval), Sanjay Dutt as the fearless cop SP Chaudhary Aslam, and Arjun Rampal-adds layers of tension and depth.

Dhar crafts a Godfather-like saga with gritty action, realistic violence, and masterful tradecraft. The cinematography captures Karachi's shadowy streets evocatively, while Shashwat Sachdev's thumping score heightens suspense. At 214 minutes, the runtime allows rich world-building and character arcs.

author: abhinavdhaka
title: Extraordinary movie
text:
Dhurandhar absolutely blew me away. What a gripping, intense, and unapologetic film! I loved every minute of it. The storytelling, performances, and raw execution kept me hooked from start to finish.

One of the things I appreciated the most is how boldly the film exposes the brutality shown by Pakistan's military and intelligence establishment in the story. It doesn't sugarcoat anything . It shows the harsh reality of cross-border aggression and the destructive mindset of those hostile elements. The film captures this with honesty and impact, without feeling exaggerated or filmy.

Ranveer Singh delivered one of his best performances, and the entire cast elevated the narrative beautifully. The action, emotion, intensity - everything landed perfectly for me.

For me, Dhurandhar is not just a movie, it's an experience. A must-watch for anyone who enjoys powerful, patriotic thrillers with substance.

author: kumuddubey
title: Not Animal-This is Cinema
text:
I'll be honest, when I saw the Dhurandhar trailer, I braced myself for another loud, self-indulgent ride like Animal. But what I got instead was a masterclass. Dhurandhar absolutely floored me. I genuinely don't understand why it's even being compared to Animal. This film is tight, focused, and surprisingly fat-free, despite being 3.5 hours long, a rare brilliance in editing and direction.

That final stretch... goosebumps.

When Akshaye Khanna tells Ranveer to stop the car, and that score kicks in, bro, that moment had me gripping the seat.

This is Aditya Dhar's magnum opus. He has crafted something bold, emotional, and cinematic without drowning it in noise. Go watch it.

author: PriyanshuA-35
title: A Chilling, Immersive Masterclass in Spy Thrillers
text:
Dhurandhar is a riveting, top-tier spy thriller that feels rooted in reality, set against a world of gang rivalries and terror networks while never losing its emotional depth. The plot is rich and consistently engaging, the writing is razor-sharp, and every character is rendered with striking nuance. Its sincere, steadily intensifying screenplay pulls you in deeper with each scene.

Ranveer Singh completely transforms for this role, and the supporting cast-Akshaye Khanna, Sanjay Dutt, Arjun Rampal, R. Madhavan, Sara Arjun, Manav Gohil, and others-ensure the film never falters for a moment. Aditya Dhar crafts a world so authentic and immersive that you can almost feel yourself walking the streets alongside the characters. His integration of real-life-style footage and grounded sound design leads to several chilling moments, including a standout sequence where the screen bleeds red and haunting recorded voices echo through an attack.

In the end, Dhurandhar is both edge-of-your-seat and emotionally resonant-cinema meant to be experienced in a full theatre. And with that tantalizing final note, the wait for March 2026 to see what Aditya Dhar and Ranveer Singh unveil next feels almost unbearable.

Every scene feels purposeful, and the narrative flows seamlessly, keeping the audience fully invested throughout.

The performances are outstanding across the board. The lead actor delivers a career-defining performance, bringing raw intensity and emotional depth that feels completely authentic. The supporting cast complements the story perfectly, adding layers and nuance rather than just filling screen time. The direction is confident and precise, showing clear vision and control.

Technically, the film excels. The cinematography is striking, the background score elevates every key moment, and the editing keeps the tension alive without unnecessary distractions. What truly sets Dhurandar apart is its emotional impact - it doesn't just entertain, it makes you think and feel long after the credits roll.

This is the kind of cinema that reminds you why movies matter. Bold, immersive, and unforgettable, Dhurandar is a must-watch and fully deserves a perfect score.

author: SohanP-09
title: Action That Roars and Drama That Resonates
text: From start to finish, the movie is a masterclass in tension and storytelling. Ranveer Singh delivers a performance that is commanding yet nuanced, fully inhabiting a character who navigates danger with courage and internal conflict. The director's vision elevates the film, ensuring that every subplot, action sequence, and political maneuver feels interconnected and essential. Action scenes are sharp, meticulously choreographed, and heightened by cinematography that emphasizes both scale and intimacy. Supporting actors enhance the story, adding complexity and authenticity to the underworld's dangerous ecosystem. The background score heightens suspense without overshadowing dialogue or emotion. Each scene serves to advance both plot and character arcs, making the long runtime feel purposeful. The climax blends emotional and narrative resolution with heart-pounding action, leaving a lasting impression of intensity and mastery.

author: Ara-394
title: A must watch for every Indian who loves their country and has respect for its army and intelligence bureau
text:
I can't praise this movie enough. It's a movie that literally gives you goosebumps. A big salute to Aditya Dhar for giving Indian cinema a refreshing change, and a realistic and raw masterpiece. The whole casting is god-tier with every single actor giving a terrific performance. And Ranveer Singh...the man that you are üôá‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è This is the comeback that he deserved. He once again proved why he is such a powerful actor who could do wonders when given the right movie. He had this nuance, raw and visceral way of expressing himself that felt realistic and not cheap at all. He acted like an actual spy would. The action scenes were gory and gritty in the best way possible, with superb action choreography that didn't involve the quintessential Bollywood style action which involves nonsensical drama and heroism. The music was fire and creative, with the whole album being an absolute banger. The set, costume design and makeup was spot on. I could honestly go on and on about how good every element of this movie was but then we would be here all night.

All I have to say is that India was hungry for a movie like this. The sheer agony and anger that this country holds for centuries, from countless terrorist attacks and havoc caused by Pakistan, has finally been shown in cinema. Indians won't tolerate any more sugar coating and glazing of Pakistan and terrorist sympathisers, and will rise stronger like a tiger who doesn't back down from taking revenge. The Indian army, Intelligence Bureau, unknown gunmen, etc, who have made countless sacrifices and taken immeasurable amount of pain upon themselves to defend our country, deserve to be praised and showcased in the way Dhurandhar has.

Jai Hind.üáÆüá≥üôè

author: prateekdubey7
title: Dhurandhar: A Gripping Masterpiece That Demands Multiple Viewings
text:
I've watched Dhurandhar five times already since its release, and honestly, I'm still itching to book another ticket for the sixth. This isn't just a movie-it's an experience that pulls you into the gritty underworld of Karachi and doesn't let go, even after the credits roll. Directed by Aditya Dhar, this spy-action thriller is a game-changer for Bollywood, blending raw intensity, stellar performances, and edge-of-your-seat tension like nothing I've seen in years.

Ranveer Singh delivers a career-defining performance as the undercover agent Hamza/Jasikirat. His transformation is mesmerizing-subtle yet explosive, with that piercing stare and restrained power that keeps you hooked. But the real scene-stealer is Akshaye Khanna as Rehman Dakait; his chilling swagger and dialogue delivery are pure fire. The supporting cast-Sanjay Dutt, R. Madhavan, Arjun Rampal, and others-elevate every scene, making the ensemble feel like a perfectly oiled machine.

What makes Dhurandhar so rewatchable? The storytelling is tight and immersive, despite the 3.5-hour runtime (which flies by, trust me). The action is gritty and realistic-no over-the-top heroism, just brutal, visceral sequences that hit hard. Shashwat Sachdev's background score pulses through the film, blending seamlessly with clever nods to classic tracks, amplifying the tension and emotion. The world-building in Lyari's underbelly feels authentic and dangerous, drawing you deeper with each viewing as you catch new layers in the betrayals, espionage, and character arcs.

Sure, it's violent and intense (A-certified for a reason), but that's what makes it stand out-it's bold, unapologetic, and refuses to spoon-feed the audience. Every repeat watch reveals more nuances in the script, performances, and technical brilliance (cinematography and editing are top-notch).

If you're a fan of intelligent thrillers with heart-pounding action and powerhouse acting, Dhurandhar is a must-watch on the big screen. It's not just entertaining; it's addictive. Can't wait for Part 2-Aditya Dhar has created a franchise that'll redefine the genre. Highly recommended-go watch it again (and again)! üáÆüá≥üî•

author: SandeepK-1732
title: Just Awesome üòé Pure Cinema
text:
DHURANDHAR is one of those rare films where you feel everything is perfectly placed - direction, music, performances, and overall impact. From the very first scene till the end, the film keeps you completely hooked. The director deserves full credit for handling such a powerful subject with control and maturity. The storytelling is sharp, engaging, and emotionally strong. Every frame feels purposeful.

The songs are beautifully blended into the narrative and never feel forced. Background score quietly lifts the intensity and makes key moments even more impactful. The technical quality, camera work, and editing are top class and give the film a big-screen feel in the true sense.

Coming to performances - this is truly a multi-starrer done right. @ActorMadhavan once again proves why he is one of the most reliable actors in Indian cinema. @akshaye_khanna delivers a performance full of depth and silence that speaks louder than words. @Rampal72 brings solid intensity and control to his role. @duttsanjay commands the screen with his strong presence and experience. @RanveerOfficial surprises with his range and energy, showing a completely different side.

What really works is that no one tries to overpower the other. Everyone supports the story. That is the biggest strength of this film.

DHRANDHAR is not just entertainment, it is proper cinema with substance. It makes you think, feel, and stay with the characters even after the movie ends. The ending clearly opens doors for the second part, and honestly, the wait has already started.

Stop listening to random opinions and online noise. Some films are meant to be experienced, not judged through reviews. DHRANDHAR is one such film. Just go, watch it on the big screen, and feel it yourself.

author: rajroy-06121
title: Truth is Stranger than Fiction
text:
As a 90's kid who grew up watching socio-political thrillers like Spygame, Pelican Brief, The contender, Enemy of the state, Clear and Present Danger, Bourne series, Body of lies to The Departed, I have to admit Dhurandhar surpasses the benchmark set by those Hollywood films. The execution was beyond my very humble knowledge of film making. What Adiyta Dhar has made possible is that in the theatre I found myself in the shoes of the character of Ranvir Singh - and it was a roller-coaster ride. The leftist cabal is not only wrong about their criticism, they are actually the ones who are making propaganda against such a revolutionary Indian film.

They say truth is stranger than fiction - the amount of reserach that has gone behind the movie is incredible. As viewer although you all will be tempted to think it was a fictional story but I got a sneaky feeling the storyline is actually fact.

Spoiler Alert : The movie is NOT anti-Muslim, it is NOT even anti Pakistan, if anything, it is pro-India which the movie will make you feel with very subtle nuances.

author: hyitsdp

author: akashpaul5
title: A Very Solid, Expansive Spy Thriller
text:
This film is a triumph of world-building and character development. Spanning an impressive 3 hours and 32 minutes, Dhurandhar is a gripping spy thriller that justifies every minute of its runtime. The narrative never loses momentum, keeping the audience utterly engaged in the sprawling world it creates.

The war between the rival gangs felt incredibly natural and organic within the setting of Lyari. The screenplay ensures that every single character feels important and contributes meaningfully to the overall story. You can feel the meticulous thought that has gone into every frame.

The casting is truly exceptional and feels entirely natural across the board.

Akshay Khanna as Rehman Dakait completely steals the show. His performance is defined by a captivating aura and swagger that commands the screen.

Ranveer proves he is a true chameleon, doing complete justice to his demanding role as the spy at the centre of the conflict.

The one casting decision I was initially sceptical about, Sara Arjun, turned out to be a wonderful surprise. She looked like a dream and successfully injected the necessary innocence and freshness into the narrative.

While I am giving it 9 stars because I feel a few moments could have been slightly trimmed or polished, this is a minor critique. Overall, this is a masterful piece of cinema.

Man oh man, I am beyond excited for the second part coming next year!

author: avinashiitkgpbharat

text: Having watched Munich, Schindler's list - I always thought when would India make such a globally appealing movie showing the real story of India's global diplomacy. Right from the trendsetter soundtrack, the engaging plot, the god level narration, and the alpha mode acting by the ensemble cast, Dhurandhar is a coup'd'etat. And surprisingly, despite being banned in the Islamic countries, Dhurandhar becomes a 1000 Cr+ madness at the global box office.

author: igoyry
title: Hard slap to the Bollywood mafia
text: Dhurandhar is a knockout answer to the cheap star praised Bollywood formula films. This movie proves what real cinema looks like when content comes first. Every actor delivers with full conviction. Akshay Khanna is outstanding, controlled, intense, and deeply convincing. Ranveer Singh brings raw energy and precision, never overdoing a single moment. Not one frame feels wasted. Scene sequencing is razor sharp, building tension naturally and holding it till the end. The storyline is fearless, grounded, and hits hard without spoon feeding. Compared to the so called spy universes and recycled narratives, Dhurandhar feels bold and honest. No noise, no gimmicks, just powerful storytelling. Bollywood producers and the mafia driven ecosystem should be nervous. This film raises the bar and changes the game completely.

author: Chandu-23

While a few scenes feel slightly stretched, the emotional depth and intense climax leave a lasting impact. Overall, Dhurandhar is a well-crafted entertainer that balances action, drama, and suspense effectively.

author: SiddheshJ-88
title: Absolute Chaossss with a spicy magic
text: A must-watch! With a gripping runtime of over 3 hours, this film delivers a masterclass in thrill and epic storytelling. To those calling it propaganda or anti-Pakistan - let's be clear: this is not anti-anyone, it's unapologetically *pro-India*. Every nation has the right to present its truth and protect its global image. Yes, we have our internal challenges - but that doesn't justify tarnishing our country on the world stage. If you live here, take pride in being a responsible citizen. Watch this film not just with your eyes, but with an open mind.

author: aakashshukla-10226
title: Action That Excites, Drama That Moves
text: The film's narrative architecture is meticulous, balancing suspense, action, and character development. Ranveer Singh delivers a layered performance, embodying intelligence, moral conflict, and raw intensity. Sanjay Dutt dominates scenes with gravitas, while Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan provide intelligent, subtle performances. Arjun Rampal's quiet menace heightens tension, and Sara Arjun's emotional portrayal provides humanity and stakes. Aditya Dhar's direction choreographs action and suspense seamlessly, allowing narrative, emotion, and spectacle to coexist. Cinematography captures urban chaos, intimate beats, and visceral action with precision, and the score punctuates suspense and emotion. The film's climax is thrilling, strategic, and emotionally resonant, leaving viewers fully immersed.

author: leenad-0
title: Watch It. Feel It. Promote It. Dhurandhar Is Unmissable.
text:
Dhurandhar is not just a movie-it's an experience that grips you from the very first frame and refuses to let go till the very last second.

Every single actor delivers a power-packed, unforgettable performance, making each character feel intense, real, and deeply moving. There isn't a single dull moment-every scene builds tension and keeps you fully invested.

The story is nerve-wracking and unpredictable, making you bite your nails and sit on the edge of your chair throughout the film. The screenplay is razor-sharp, the pacing is relentless, and the twists hit hard when you least expect them.

A massive, heartfelt shout-out to Ranveer Singh as Hamza - this is not acting, this is absolute transformation.

He doesn't play Hamza; he becomes him. Every expression, every silence, every explosive moment is delivered with terrifying honesty and emotional depth. His screen presence is electrifying, and his performance elevates the entire film to another level. This is a career-defining, out-of-this-world performance and easily one of the finest acts ever seen in Indian cinema.

What truly elevates Dhurandhar is its emotional depth and fearless storytelling. The performances are raw, honest, and impactful-this is cinema at its finest.

If you're a true Indian, you won't just watch this movie-you'll feel proud of it.

You'll be inspired to take your friends, family, relatives, and everyone you know to watch it, and to spread positive word of mouth on social media. This is an international-level, world-class movie, and the whole world deserves to see the power of such brilliant storytelling.

Don't miss Dhurandhar. Watch it. Support it. Share it.

This is Indian cinema shining on the global stage. üáÆüá≥üé¨üî•

author: rathorevishal-53378
title: A Story That Packs a Punch
text: The film meticulously constructs a world of crime, politics, and human conflict, where trust is fragile and danger omnipresent. Ranveer Singh anchors the story with a performance that is simultaneously intelligent, intense, and emotionally resonant. Sanjay Dutt adds gravitas and an intimidating presence that commands attention. Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan enrich the story with subtle performances that heighten the narrative's complexity. Arjun Rampal's quiet menace creates palpable tension, while Sara Arjun's scenes provide a poignant emotional counterpoint. Aditya Dhar's direction blends suspense, strategy, and high-octane action seamlessly. Cinematography captures both the chaotic scale of the setting and intimate character moments, while the score punctuates key beats of tension and drama. The second half escalates with shocking twists, breathtaking action, and emotional resonance, culminating in a finale that is both thrilling and satisfying.

author: roshpolekar
title: Not your typical 'RAW' thriller
text:
From the trailer I knew this is not typical spy movie where an agent goes into enemy territory, falls in love with a beautiful women, and fights off bad guys.

I went to this movie with zero expectations from Ranveer. I only wanted to enjoy good acting from some of my favourite old-school actors like Akshay Khanna, Sanjay Dutt, and R Madhavan.

Not only Ranveer took me by surpsise, the rest of the cast exceeded my expectations. I haven't seen sucha a perfect casting.

The story telling was amazing. It effortlessly invokes patriotism, sadness, anger, and conveys the emotion of a spy.

You could feel the emotion ranveer is feeling from his acting, which shows how much he has grown as an actor. I hope he matures too as a person after this movie. Love his goofy persona, but sometimes its kinda bit much.

This movie is not a documentary so I did not see it that way. But it takes you close to the reality like no other espionage bollywood movie. It will forever change how Indians see the spy movies and their expectations from it.

author: dubeyakashm
title: "Dhurandhar: When Music, Direction, and Reality Collide"
text:
Dhurandhar is a powerful and thought-provoking film that leaves a lasting impact right from the very beginning. The movie opens with a shlok from the Bhagavad Gita, instantly setting a profound and intense tone-something rarely seen and deeply effective.

What truly stands out is the direction and the bold choice of background music. The way songs are placed during crucial scenes is simply unbelievable. No one would imagine playing "Loot Le Gaya" during an election candidature announcement, yet it worked brilliantly. Similarly, using the Dhurandhar title track during the car fight sequence elevates the scene to another level. These creative risks make the audience go "wow" repeatedly.

Beyond the cinematic brilliance, the film courageously showcases the harsh realities of heinous terror attacks in India by Napak and highlights the importance and impact of demonetization-handled with clarity and conviction.

Overall, Dhurandhar is not just a movie; it's an experience that blends storytelling, music, and realism with purpose.

A must-watch for each and every Indian. üáÆüá≥

author: sandybindass-24445
title: A Realistic Spy Thriller That Redefines the Genre
text:
The action scenes are amazing. The intention behind these scenes was to show cruelty, and they succeed in doing so very effectively. The screen time given to each actor is perfectly balanced and according to the requirement of the story. The dialogues are beautifully written.

A spy movie should not be overly heroic; instead, it should feel real-like a true mole story that makes the audience feel the fear of being caught and the terror of punishment. This movie serves that purpose very well. The collections are impressive, especially considering that the movie was banned in Gulf countries, from where a major portion of overseas collections usually comes.

Aditya Dhar has changed the dynamics of the spy movie genre. This will be a real challenge for YRF Productions in the future.

Another beautiful aspect of the movie is its songs. You hardly feel like you are listening to songs; instead, they feel like a continuation of the story the director wants to narrate. The songs play a vital role-without them, the movie would feel incomplete. Kudos to the music director for composing/recomposing such beautiful tracks and to the director for using them at the right moments.

The promotions of this movie were minimal. Only word of mouth worked, and I believe this is how it should be for all movies. If a movie is good, no negative hate can stop it. Dhruv Rathee tried hard to defame it and portrayed it as propaganda, similar to a Vivek Agnihotri movie, but he did not succeed.

Therefore, this movie is a perfect example for filmmakers: focus on making a good product. Don't worry about promotions or negative criticism. If your product is good, word of mouth will help fill the seats.

#Pacifistsandeep.

author: ReelMysterySeeker
title: A Gritty Beast of a Film - Raw, Relentless & Intensely Engaging
text:
Dhurandhar is not just another Bollywood thriller; it is a heavy, unfiltered experience that grips you from the first act and refuses to let go. Set against the backdrop of crime, espionage, and political tension, the film dives deep into the underworld with courage and ambition. What stands out immediately is how unapologetically gritty it is - no sugar-coating, no restraint, just pure high-voltage storytelling.

The performances are a major driving force here. Ranveer Singh delivers one of his most layered roles in recent times, balancing aggression, conflict, and vulnerability with finesse. Akshaye Khanna, calm but dangerously compelling, steals scenes without effort. Supporting actors like R. Madhavan and Sanjay Dutt bring their own weight to the narrative, making the film feel rich in character and presence. Each face on-screen adds to the story rather than just filling space.

Cinematography and sound design elevate the tension - dimly lit alleys, chaotic shootouts, and atmospheric background score create a world you can feel. However, Dhurandhar isn't a light watch. At nearly three and a half hours, the length is noticeable. The story is loaded with subplots, violence, and emotional weight, which may overwhelm viewers who prefer tighter or softer films. But for those who appreciate bold storytelling, the runtime serves as immersion rather than drag.

What makes Dhurandhar memorable is not just the action, but the emotion beneath it - loyalty, sacrifice, betrayal, and the cost of power. It leaves you thinking, even after credits roll.

A long, intense, and hard-hitting film - not perfect, but undeniably impactful.

author: newtonbon
title: Dhurandhar is a film
text:
Dhurandhar is a film that seems ambitious on the surface, but the moment it begins, it becomes clear that the execution is far from effective. The story lacks originality and feels like a collection of familiar plotlines seen many times before. There is no real novelty, no surprise element, and no emotional depth that keeps the audience hooked. The narrative moves at a frustratingly slow pace, dragging through scene after scene without meaningful progress.

The characters feel hollow due to poor writing. The protagonist doesn't have a strong personality or compelling motivation. His emotional journey is inconsistent, and his reactions often feel misplaced. The supporting characters exist only for the sake of filling space and do not contribute meaningfully to the storyline. Even the villain lacks presence, making the conflict feel weak and unexciting.

The direction lacks clarity and confidence. Many scenes feel stretched without purpose, while others feel rushed and unfinished. Emotional scenes fail to connect, action scenes lack intensity, and dramatic scenes feel over-performed. The film struggles to maintain the audience's attention because it doesn't offer any memorable or engaging moment.

Technical aspects also fall short. The cinematography feels flat and uninspiring, with very few visually interesting shots. The editing is sloppy, causing abrupt scene transitions that break the flow. The background music feels repetitive and often fails to match the tone of the scene.

By the time the movie reaches its climax, the audience is already exhausted. The conclusion feels weak and unearned, leaving viewers unsatisfied. The film attempts to end with an emotional resolution, but since the journey itself lacked emotional weight, the final scene also feels meaningless.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a disappointing film with weak writing, poor direction, dull performances, and slow pacing. It lacks the energy and emotional impact needed to make it memorable. It's not a movie I would recommend to anyone looking for a strong or engaging cinematic experience.

author: twinkle-04212
title: Dhurandhar: Intense, Unfiltered, and Worth Every Minute
text:
Genuinely enjoyed watching Dhurandhar. Even though it's a lengthy film, not a single minute felt wasted. The narrative is gripping, the performances are solid, and the film keeps you hooked with its intensity and realism.

One of the most impactful aspects of the movie is how boldly and accurately it portrays Pakistan, its terror outfits, and their deep nexus with criminal gangs operating across the border. The film doesn't shy away from exposing the machinery behind terror-how handlers, networks, and gangs operate as one coordinated system. It presents this dark reality without exaggeration, and that honesty hits hard.

But the moment that shook me the most was the 26/11 sequence. Hearing the actual recorded conversation between the terrorist and his handler sent chills down my spine. It was unsettling, infuriating, and emotional all at once. That scene alone reminds you why such stories need to be told-so we don't forget what happened and what still threatens us.

Overall, Dhurandhar is more than just a film-it's an experience. Intense, revealing, thought-provoking, and absolutely worth your time. I walked out feeling both impressed and deeply moved.
