author: madhabikanayak
title: This is cinema
text:
This is mad Bollywood is so back.

Dhurandhar is not just a movie, it's an experience that slowly grips you and refuses to let go. From the very first frame, the film pulls you into a dark, intense world where silence speaks louder than dialogues and every look carries weight. The storytelling is raw, layered, and unapologetically bold.

The performances are the backbone of this film. Each character feels lived-in, especially the ones walking the thin line between right and wrong. There are no easy heroes here-only humans shaped by circumstances. The emotions feel real, sometimes uncomfortable, and that's exactly what makes Dhurandhar stand out. You don't just watch the characters; you feel their struggles, their rage, and their quiet moments of vulnerability.

The direction deserves special mention. The pacing is deliberate, allowing scenes to breathe and tensions to build naturally. The background score subtly enhances the mood without overpowering the narrative, and the cinematography captures the grit and intensity perfectly. Every frame feels purposeful, adding depth to the story rather than just looking visually appealing.

What truly makes Dhurandhar memorable is its ability to stay with you even after the credits roll. It makes you think-about choices, consequences, and the price one pays for power and survival. The film doesn't spoon-feed answers; instead, it trusts the audience to interpret, question, and reflect.

In an era of loud and predictable cinema, Dhurandhar chooses to be different. It's brave, thought-provoking, and emotionally heavy in the best way possible. This is the kind of film that grows on you with time, leaving an impact that doesn't fade easily.

Dhurandhar is cinema that demands attention-and rewards it fully.

author: ShikhaB-082
title: Rekindled my love for cinema
text: Where shall I begin? I loved and enjoyed this movie thoroughly. This movie rekindled my love for action movies again and took me once again to theatres after many years. This is the film I wanted for so long. This is an excellent well made movie without having over the top action and is grounded in reality driven by a compelling storyline and good acting which is not the case with action movies these days which are just massy and over the top action. Don't get me wrong I like massy film but I think india has stretched it too far. Even if I put aside this fact this film is good by its own merit. The characters drives the story forward and are so impactful. I know everybody is gasping about Akshay Khanna's character, yes sure he has done an exceptional job with his character and is very impactful throughout the film but I loved and deeply resonated with Ranveer Singh's character. His eyes did all the work, he barely had any dialogues in the film. I connected with him instantly with the opening song "na karwan ki talash na humsafar ki talash hai". This sets the characters motivation so perfectly and to see the pain and hardship his character goes through makes you realise what the people in this work go through in real life to protect this nation. Ranveer Singh's character is so small and purposefully so and yet so impactful. Especially the scene of 26 11, I literally cried reminiscing of what a horror it was back in the day. It was conveyed from the perspective of ranveer singh so beautifully that you feel all his helplessness and pain. The fact that the horror of the reality is front of him and he s shocked and hyperventilating but he cannot react in that moment. His character deeply touched me because I think the people who only exist just to protect a nation sacrificing everything that life could offer, choosing hardship for others, truly are the most noble people on this planet. I think that's the highest form of love that the person is capable of. I could feel the emptiness and holoness of his character and yet I could feel his pure sense of love for his nation. It is great acting. Sanjay Dutt's character was fun and the conflict and face off between Akshay Khanna's character and his was truly a delight to me. It was entertaining to the core. Sanjay Dutt's madness and his self driven motivation to kill Akshay Khanna's character was pure entertainment. This movie was so much more on the deep level than just on the surface is what makes it an outstanding piece of art. Aditya dhar has given us yet again another film which we all indians can be proud of.

author: borkarfaiz
title: Akshaye Khanna Shines, the Film Doesn't
text: Dhurandhar doesn't divide people by country; it divides them by religion. The film subtly reinforces a narrative that certain entities have already normalised in our society, repeatedly hinting that one particular community is the problem. It ends up feeling more like a propaganda piece than a genuine thriller. Apart from Akshaye Khanna's acting, there's nothing here worth holding on to. If you enjoy violent action, the movie has some of that, but I'm not a fan of that style anyway. For me, the whole experience falls flat.

author: vartikav-68317
title: Dhurandhar is blockbuster..
text:
I genuinely have no words to describe how magnificent Dhurandhar is. I'm still in absolute awe of what I just witnessed. It's one of those rare cinematic experiences that stays with you long after the credits roll. Every frame, every beat, every performance feels like a reminder of what exceptional filmmaking truly looks like.

Aditya Dhar's direction is nothing short of tremendous. The command he has over the craft, the clarity of vision, and the sheer boldness with which he brings this story alive is remarkable. It genuinely feels like after ages, Bollywood has delivered something so powerful, so purposeful, and so worth watching. He is truly a boon to our industry.

And then what an extraordinary cast. I have honestly never seen such accurate casting in the history of Bollywood. It feels almost unreal how perfectly every actor fits their role.

Akshaye Khanna has my whole heart. He is par excellence, an actor who doesn't just perform but becomes the soul of the film. His screen presence is magnetic, when he appears, your eyes simply cannot look anywhere else. The depth, intensity, and honesty he brings to his character is beyond brilliant.

Ranveer Singh delivers what I believe is his finest performance to date. This new avatar suits him unbelievably well, controlled, powerful, and refreshingly nuanced. He looks absolutely dapper throughout and performs with a maturity that demands applause.

R. Madhavan once again proves that he can effortlessly slip into any role given to him. His versatility and conviction shine through. Arjun Rampal too is outstanding, impactful, composed, and perfectly cast.

The cinematography is breathtaking, each shot crafted with such precision and visual depth that it pulls you right into the world of the film. The screenplay is tight, immersive, and brilliantly layered, keeping you invested every single second. And the background score.. outstanding. Shashwat Sachdev's work elevates the narrative to another dimension; his soundtrack isn't just music, it's emotion, woven so seamlessly into the storytelling that it becomes a character of its own.

Dhurandhar is not just a film; it is an experience, stunning, immersive, and unforgettable. It reignites hope in Bollywood, reminding us that brilliance is still very much alive when the right minds come together. This movie will stay with me for a long, long time.

I still can't believe the masterpiece I've just witnessed.

author: kjain-04759
title: Edge-of-Seat Action, Powerful Story
text: The film's narrative is both ambitious and immersive, gradually escalating stakes and tension. Ranveer Singh shines in a role demanding nuance, intensity, and moral reflection, while Sanjay Dutt provides a powerful counterbalance with his commanding presence. Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan enrich the ensemble with subtle yet impactful performances. Arjun Rampal's menace and Sara Arjun's heart-rending portrayal deepen the emotional resonance. Aditya Dhar's direction ensures that action sequences are thrilling but never gratuitous. Cinematography captures the harshness and beauty of the setting, while the score elevates suspense, creating a gripping cinematic experience.

author: sair-11163
title: Big Stars, Bigger Action
text: From the opening sequence, the narrative grips with precision, establishing both the grandeur of Karachi and the intimate, morally complex struggles of its inhabitants. Ranveer Singh navigates Hamza's transformation with finesse-his subtle hesitation in strategic meetings contrasts with his raw intensity in the film's brutal action sequences. Sanjay Dutt radiates gravitas, whether orchestrating underworld dealings or delivering sharp dialogue that lingers in memory. Akshaye Khanna's analytical mind and R Madhavan's measured calm anchor critical scenes, while Arjun Rampal's quiet, smoldering threat injects tension into every frame he inhabits. Sara Arjun's moments of vulnerability-particularly a scene in a dimly lit alley-remind viewers of the human stakes behind political and criminal chaos. Dhar's direction ensures tension builds organically, blending meticulously choreographed action with narrative suspense. Cinematography captures the scale of the city and the intimacy of hidden conflicts, while the score punctuates every dramatic turn. The climax delivers adrenaline-fueled action intertwined with emotional revelations, leaving viewers breathless and reflective.

author: abhisharma-64026
title: Hunuman ar soponr dos
text:
Visually, the film does not offer anything impressive. The cinematography feels flat, with very few creative angles or visually appealing sequences. The background score is inconsistent and sometimes feels completely disconnected from what's happening on screen.

The climax is abrupt and unfulfilling, failing to provide a proper closure to the story. It feels as if the filmmakers wrapped it up quickly without thinking through the emotional or narrative impact. The movie tries to deliver a message, but due to poor execution, the message gets lost along the way.

Overall, Dhurandhar feels like a missed opportunity. With better writing, stronger characters, and more focused direction, this could have been a much better film. Instead, it ends up being slow, predictable, and disappointing. Not worth the hype or the time.

author: LunaD-791
title: Action, Stars, and Big Emotions
text: The film's deliberate pacing allows suspense and emotion to grow organically. Ranveer Singh's performance is a remarkable blend of intensity, moral ambiguity, and subtle vulnerability. Sanjay Dutt brings gravitas and a threatening presence that commands attention. Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan offer understated yet impactful performances, providing depth to the ensemble. Arjun Rampal's quiet menace keeps viewers on edge, and Sara Arjun's performance adds emotional resonance, highlighting the human stakes. Aditya Dhar's direction expertly balances slow-building tension with explosive action sequences. Cinematography captures sprawling chaos and intimate human moments, while the score heightens suspense and emotional impact. The finale combines narrative payoff, high-octane action, and emotional depth in a thrilling crescendo.

author: kmogqggd
title: A Fierce Tale of Fight, Faith, and Fire
text: Watching Dhurandhar feels like witnessing cinema at its most refined. The lead's performance is magnetic, conveying a range of emotions from fury to vulnerability with effortless skill. The supporting cast is exceptional, each actor contributing to the richness of the story. The director demonstrates unparalleled vision, crafting a narrative that is intense, layered, and gripping from start to finish. The integration of real geopolitical events adds authenticity, while the fight sequences are meticulously choreographed to serve the story. The screenplay balances tension, drama, and subtle humor, allowing the audience to breathe between moments of high intensity. Every technical aspect, from lighting to background score, is crafted with precision. Dhurandhar is a triumph of direction and acting, a film that will be remembered as one of the best of its decade.

author: deepakraj-89555
title: ‚≠ê DHURANDHAR - A POWERFUL BLEND OF PERFORMANCE, PURPOSE & PURE ENTERTAINMENT ‚≠ê
text:
Dhurandhar is one of those rare films that pulls you in from the very first frame, not through loud spectacle but through sheer narrative confidence. It is a film that knows exactly what it wants to say - and says it with style, intensity, and surprising emotional depth. What truly sets Dhurandhar apart is its ability to balance mass appeal with meaningful storytelling, creating an experience that stays with you long after the credits roll.

The storytelling is crisp, tightly woven, and never wastes a moment. Each scene contributes to the unfolding drama, slowly revealing layers of the protagonist's journey. The character arc is beautifully constructed - a mix of vulnerability, ambition, conflict, and triumph. There is a sense of realism in the way the characters speak, act, and react, making the audience feel genuinely connected to their struggles.

The performances are undoubtedly the film's backbone. The lead actor delivers one of his most compelling roles to date, capturing both strength and subtle emotion with effortless ease. The supporting cast is equally strong, breathing life into roles that could have easily fallen flat in a lesser film. Chemistry, dialogue delivery, and screen presence come together to create scenes that feel almost poetic.

Technically, Dhurandhar shines. The cinematography is rich and atmospheric, making even ordinary locations feel cinematic. The background score is powerful yet perfectly restrained, enhancing the tension and emotion without overpowering the storytelling. Editing is sharp, giving the film a smooth rhythm that keeps you engaged throughout.

Most importantly, Dhurandhar has a message - one that is socially relevant, thought-provoking, and delivered without preachiness. It manages to entertain while also inspiring reflection, a combination that very few films achieve today.

In short, Dhurandhar is not just a movie; it is an experience. It is a bold, well-crafted, and emotionally resonant film that deserves appreciation from every type of viewer. A must-watch for anyone who loves cinema with heart, soul, and purpose.

author: samratrc1417
title: Very well crafted, gripping as well as entertaining!
text:
This is what they call in tapori Mumbaiya boli "Pura paisa wasool picture"!

I have to agree that I went in at the insistence of family members and came out a fan. In my defense, I hadn't known that it was directed (as well as written and produced) by Aditya Dhar, who is turning into someone who is the equivalent of Michael Bay in Bollywood. He has found his niche. Taut spy thrillers.

This has a long timeline with events starting from the IC-814 Kandahar hijacking and presumably to the present day. I don't know if I should mention it or if it is a spoiler, the movie has a part 2 coming out in March where the premise ties up all the loose ends.

With a brilliant and very capable cast, who played every role very well, this has been written very well. There has been some jumps and connections made which will escape audience members who aren't well versed in world events. They will find it difficult to understand but the whole screenplay was executed so well. And I wholeheartedly agree that a part 2 was absolutely necessary because of the long timeline and bringing the resolution of so many characters. And I look forward to it eagerly.

Akshaye Khanna, Ranveer Singh, R Madhavan and good ole Sanju baba are excellent and the side cast who play a myriad of characters do a fantastic job. That is what makes it so good...

I think a thriller loving audience will enjoy it and it is NOT for rom-com lovers and fans of family dramas. I might even have a second visit. My wife had refused to go thinking it will be a boys dishum-dishum kind of film but now she wants to go hearing me rave about it. Go figure!!

author: PradeepN-86
title: Must watch movie
text:
I don't why this is movie is getting hate if you are 18+ you should must watch it. Dhurandhar, directed by Aditya Dhar, stands out as a sharp, high-intensity thriller that blends emotional depth with a gripping narrative. Dhar, known for his command over storytelling and atmosphere, takes a bold leap with this film, delivering a story that feels both grounded and larger-than-life. What makes Dhurandhar compelling is its ability to maintain suspense while exploring themes of morality, power, and human resilience.

The film's strength lies in its layered writing. Dhar constructs a narrative that keeps the audience guessing at every turn-revealing just enough to pull you deeper into the mystery without ever giving away too much. The pacing is tight, the conflicts feel authentic, and the twists arrive at just the right moments. Every scene is crafted with intention, and the buildup pays off effectively in the final act.

Performance-wise, the cast elevates the film. The lead protagonist delivers a nuanced, emotionally rich performance, portraying inner conflict and determination with striking clarity. The antagonist is equally fascinating-charismatic, calculated, and terrifying in a quiet, restrained way that makes him unforgettable. Their face-offs form the emotional and dramatic core of the movie.

Visually, Dhurandhar is stunning. The cinematography makes clever use of shadows, color palettes, and scale to heighten tension. The action sequences are well-choreographed-stylish yet realistic-and the background score amplifies the suspense without overpowering the storytelling.

What sets Dhurandhar apart is Dhar's ability to balance intensity with meaning. The film never feels like a mindless thriller; it carries emotional weight and raises thoughtful questions about justice, truth, and the cost of doing what is right.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a powerful, immersive thriller that showcases Aditya Dhar's mastery as a filmmaker. It is engaging, smartly written, and leaves a lasting impact long after the credits roll.

author: keshavbansll
title: A Different Kind of Chess Game.
text:
Exceptional filmmaking with precise direction and quality performances by all the actors.

Instead of a typical "Hero vs Villain" template, it rolls out like a twisted chess game. We have two players, India and Pakistan, playing against each other. But there are multiple assets and players from each team. Some are playing along, some are having their own game. No team among both is perfect among themselves as well. Remember "Siyaasat mein koi sagaa nahi hota".

This is nearly perfect for its genre. An espionage thriller film that does not lean heavily on action to create massy moments.

The Main Protagonist is overshadowed by an antagonist in 80% of the film!! This is a good thing when you have to show your hero as an undercover agent.

The action was not disgusting. It was real. It was brutal where it had to be. It was raw where it had to be. Politics plays a major role, but it never feels boring.

AND THE MOST IMPORTANT THING - It does not feel repetitive. Bollywood has produced numerous content on the Ind vs Pak formula, but this is not the same. It shows internal gang wars, connections, struggles, a story told from a different perspective, from a grounded perspective of a person on the other side of the border.

author: giriarpit-79670
title: Walked in Blind, Walked Out Speechless
text:
I went into Dhurandhar with absolutely no expectations, but I walked out completely blown away. Being from Nepal, I had previously studied the history of the terrorist attacks in India, but reading about it is one thing, seeing it visually represented is another.

When the film utilized real footage mixed with the cinematic scenes, it was absolutely heartbreaking and thrilling at the same time. It brought a level of reality that just shocked me.

Performance-wise, everyone talks about Ranveer Singh, but for me, Akshaye Khanna is the soul of this film. He completely outplays everyone, including Ranveer. You can tell it was designed that way, his presence grounds the movie in a way that is hard to describe until you see it.

Don't let the runtime scare you. Every minute is worth it; the movie needs that time to let the story grow and unfold properly. Huge praise to director Aditya Dhar. The man is genuinely changing the landscape of cinema. Highly recommended!

author: Ajay-145
title: Intense, long but effective
text:
Dhurandhar is undoubtedly long, but for anyone who enjoys spy thrillers, the length never feels like a burden. The story grips you from the start and rarely loosens its hold.

Ranveer Singh delivers an intense performance and looks convincing in Pathani suits as a Baloch character, thanks to his muscular build and height.

A pleasant surprise in the film is Rakesh Bedi. Known mostly for comic sidekick roles, he shines here as a cunning politician. Full credit to the casting director for this unexpected yet effective choice.

Sanjay Dutt plays a character that suits his persona perfectly.

But the highlight of the movie is undoubtedly Akshay Khanna. We always knew he was a brilliant actor, but here his brilliance dominates the screen. After Chhava, this film becomes another milestone where he fully lives the character.

Arjun Rampal's character seems underdeveloped for now-almost as if he walked straight from the sets of Rana Naidu Season 2. Not very impressive, but his arc will likely build in the next chapter.

R. Madhavan is impactful in a short role and bears a striking resemblance to Ajit Doval-credit to the makeup team.

Sara Arjun looks beautiful and shows immense promise; she definitely has a bright career ahead.

The script is tight and engaging, but one noticeable drawback is the accent work. The accents do not resemble Karachi's Baloch or local dialects; they should have invested more effort here.

Overall, it's a beautifully made movie with great performances, and the sequel will surely be even more intense.

However, I personally did not like the part involving an Indian handler supplying ammunition to terrorists, especially those responsible for massacres in India.

A message to the screenplay writer: Sir, we don't need this type of twist - real or fictional. Let the villains be villains without giving them unnecessary Indian li.

author: SaikatChoudhury2602
title: Dhurandhar: A Masterstroke in Spy Action Cinema
text:
Dhurandhar establishes itself as a one-of-a-kind spy action thriller, staying true to its vision and delivering on every promise. The dialogues are sharp and thoughtfully crafted, while the screenplay-arguably the film's strongest pillar-fires on all cylinders. The narrative remains uniquely and beautifully structured, and the background score goes absolutely wild, elevating every moment. Each of these elements is tightly executed and contributes immensely to the film's overall impact.

Akshaye Khanna delivers a career-defining performance, commanding such a powerful aura that he effortlessly overshadows every other character. His screen presence is nothing short of exceptional.

R. Madhavan's intensity is unmatched-lethal, gripping, and compelling enough to make you crave more of him on screen.

Arjun Rampal appears with thunderous dialogue delivery and sheer brutality, instantly dominating every frame he enters.

Sanjay Dutt, even amidst such an extraordinary ensemble, manages to leave a strong mark with his commanding delivery.

Aditya Dhar pulls it all together masterfully, not faltering even for a moment.

If Part 1 was explosive, Part 2 is poised to blow the roof off the house.

title: Dhurandhar is Masterpiece.

author: mikhilsaluja
title: Trying too hard to be cool
text:
Dhurandhar has a promising premise but collapses under the weight of its own styling.

The chapter structure is the first giveaway. Chapters arrive without narrative purpose. There's no shift in perspective, no temporal leap, no thematic transition. It's often just the same scene continuing under a new title. For an otherwise linear story, the excessive chaptering feels like borrowed grammar from auteur cinema, without understanding why that grammar exists. It's form for the sake of form.

Ranveer Singh's performance is equally puzzling. His voice is pushed into an exaggerated baritone, unnaturally gruff throughout, to the point where it feels imposed rather than organic. Instead of adding gravitas, it distances the character from any emotional credibility.

The music is where the film truly unravels. There is no musical language, only a playlist. Folk, Indian classical, guitar-heavy rock, rap, old Hindi film music, Arabic textures, and then suddenly American jazz playing during a casual evening scene in Pakistan. The transitions are abrupt and unmotivated. It feels less like a score evolving with the narrative and more like the filmmakers trying to justify the rights they purchased. Compare this to a well-made Hollywood action film, where the score may evolve but still feels like it belongs to one world, one story. Here, every genre is fighting for attention.

The action sequences are styled to look "cool" rather than feel real. Slow-motion entries, loud needle drops, stylised gunplay, bodies flying with visibly poor CGI. Physics is treated as optional. Indian mainstream cinema still struggles with action that respects weight, impact, and consequence, and Dhurandhar doesn't break that pattern.

Narratively, key emotional beats are rushed or mishandled. Akshay's son's death, for instance, is treated with startling superficiality. There's no real inquiry into how it happened, no emotional processing, no investigative weight. Instead, the film jumps straight into formalities, interviews, rewards, and exposition-heavy dialogue that conveniently pushes Ranveer into the next plot role. It feels mechanical, like ticking story boxes rather than telling a story.

Ultimately, the film is obsessed with looking suave. Every moment is engineered for swagger. Loud music, slow motion, stylised violence, cool poses. But none of it feels grounded. The irony is that the core premise is strong. With restraint, coherence, and emotional discipline, it could have worked. Instead, the execution leans heavily into a glossy, Rohit Shetty-esque spectacle that mistakes noise for impact.

Style overwhelms substance. And the film never recovers from that imbalance.

author: AVNEESHK-523
title: A brutally realistic spy film
text:
A unflinching spy thriller that portrays the Pakistan-sponsored terrorism with gritty realism. Its rough, documentary-style approach makes every scene tense and unsettling. A stark, compelling watch that refuses to sugarcoat the world of covert conflict.

This spy thriller stands out for its unfiltered, unpolished look at a world usually dressed up with glamour. Instead of slick action sequences and invincible agents, the film delivers a tense, ground-level view of espionage and conflict. What makes it especially gripping is its fictional portrayal of Pakistan-sponsored terrorism, shown not through dramatic exaggeration but through small, chilling details that make the story feel disturbingly plausible within its narrative universe.

From the first scene, the film throws the audience into a world where chaos is routine, trust is scarce, and survival depends on decisions made in split seconds. The cinematography is intentionally rough-handheld shots, muted colors, and unsteady close-ups that make you feel like you're right there with the characters, breathing the same dusty air and absorbing the same fear. Nothing here feels staged or sanitized.

author: gklolge
title: Dhurandhar isn't just a film it's a reminder of how a spy thriller should be made: raw, fearless, and unapologetically real.
text:
Dhurandhar isn't just a film; it's a reminder of how a spy thriller should be made: raw, fearless, and unapologetically real. It strips away the glamour often attached to espionage and replaces it with authenticity, danger, and emotional truth. The narrative is intense, grounded in real-world intelligence operations, and crafted with a seriousness that demands attention. Only the patriotic have the guts to watch a film this honest, this brutal, and this close to reality.

The screenplay is crisp, layered, and constantly building. Every scene serves a purpose, whether adding psychological depth, advancing intelligence strategy, or sharpening the tension in the ongoing conflict. The realism of the storytelling keeps viewers alert, and there isn't a single dull beat.

Ranveer Singh delivers a career-defining performance: controlled, silent, and deeply internal. His character feels lived-in, shaped by sacrifice and national duty. Akshaye Khanna's cold precision, Sanjay Dutt's commanding grit, R. Madhavan's gravitas, Arjun Rampal's brooding presence, and Sara Arjun's emotional depth form a cast with no weak links. Each character is written with purpose and performed with conviction.

Technically, the film excels. The raw soundscape, minimalistic score, and grounded action sequences immerse the audience in a world that feels disturbingly close to real. The red-screen sequence paired with chilling intercepted audio remains one of the film's most haunting moments a reminder of the cost of freedom and the unseen war fought in the shadows.

Verdict: Dhurandhar is gripping, intense, and emotionally heavy not a comfort-watch, but a necessary one. It is edge-of-the-seat cinema with a conscience, crafted for viewers who understand the weight of patriotism, sacrifice, and truth. With its bold ending, the wait for March 2026 already feels long.

author: imdbfan-43050
title: Dhurandhar: A Gutsy, Unflinching Epic that Dares to Speak the Truth!
text:
Dhurandhar: A Gutsy, Unflinching Epic that Dares to Speak the truth Dhurandhar is more than just a spy thriller; it's a monumental, adrenaline-soaked epic that pulls absolutely no punches. Director Aditya Dhar proves he has the courage and vision to tackle India's most complex security challenges with unflinching honesty and breathtaking scale.

The film is set against the backdrop of real geopolitical conflicts and the dark underbelly of covert operations, primarily in the terror-infested zones of Karachi. What sets this movie apart is its sheer audacity. Dhar doesn't shy away from the truth, taking a definitive, ballsy stance by explicitly calling out Pakistan for its state-sponsored terror bases and the nexus between its intelligence agencies, crime syndicates, and fundamentalist groups. This level of clarity in a mainstream film is both rare and incredibly powerful.

From the heart-stopping re-creation of the Kandahar hijacking to the infiltration of Karachi's crime world, the narrative is taut, dense, and relentlessly gripping. Every action sequence is grounded, brutal, and brilliantly choreographed, giving you goosebumps.

The performances are stellar across the board, particularly the leads who fully embody the grit and complexity of their roles. They bring a grounded patriotism that feels earned, not shouted.

Yes, the film is long, but not a single frame is wasted in building this high-stakes, realistic world. This is essential cinema-a necessary, must-watch experience that will stay with you long after the credits roll. Aditya Dhar has delivered a definitive statement and an unforgettable cinematic triumph.

author: Rushi-52
title: Classic and real with magnificent acting
text:
Dhurandhan is a compelling blend of mass entertainment and smart storytelling-a film that understands exactly what its audience wants and delivers it with confidence, style, and surprising emotional depth.

Story & Screenplay

The narrative follows a familiar yet engaging trajectory: a larger-than-life protagonist caught in a web of rivalry, loyalty, and hidden truths. What makes Dhurandhan stand out, however, is the sharp writing. The screenplay keeps the momentum alive with clever twists, well-timed humor, and moments that punch straight to the heart. The pacing rarely dips, and every scene feels crafted with purpose.

Performances

The lead actor, in particular, commands the screen from the very first frame. His charisma, dialogue delivery, and emotional range elevate the film significantly. The supporting cast is equally impressive-each character has weight, giving the story richness and dimension. The antagonist, especially, is memorable, adding real tension and intensity to the narrative.

Direction & Technical Brilliance

The director brings a strong vision to the film, balancing high-voltage action with grounded emotional arcs. The cinematography deserves special mention: dynamic camera work, thoughtfully framed shots, and visually stunning action sequences make Dhurandhan a treat to watch.

The music and background score amplify the drama beautifully-songs complement the story rather than interrupt it, and the BGM enhances every high-stakes moment.

Action

If you're a fan of mass-appeal action sequences, Dhurandhan will not disappoint. The choreography is slick, impactful, and perfectly in sync with the hero's persona. Each fight sequence feels earned, not overdone.

Emotional Core

Beneath its action-packed exterior, Dhurandhan has a surprisingly heartfelt core. Themes of family, friendship, and personal responsibility give the film depth, making audiences care about the characters beyond the thrills.

Verdict: A Powerful, Massy, and Emotionally Satisfying Watch

Dhurandhan fires on all cylinders-action, drama, emotion, music, performances, and style. It's a film that entertains thoroughly while offering more substance than one might expect. Whether you're in it for the adrenaline or the emotion, Dhurandhan delivers a memorable cinematic experience.

Highly recommended for fans of engaging storytelling and strong mass-appeal cinema.

author: akxhayk
title: Cinematic Spectacle You Can't Miss
text:
Dhurandhar is the Cinematic Spectacle You Can't Miss Genre: Spy Thriller / Action Drama Director: Aditya Dhar If you're looking for a reason to head to the theaters this week, Ranveer Singh's Dhurandhar is it. Directed by Aditya Dhar (the mastermind behind Uri: The Surgical Strike), this film isn't just a movie; it's a visceral, high-octane experience that reminds us why we love the big screen.

Here is why Dhurandhar is an absolute must-watch: 1. Ranveer Singh Like Never Before Ranveer sheds his usual flamboyant energy to deliver a performance of simmering intensity. As Hamza, an undercover intelligence agent infiltrating the hostile underworld of Karachi, he is restrained, gritty, and explosive. His transformation, both physical and emotional,into a man living on a razor's edge is arguably one of the finest of his career. You don't just watch him; you fear for him.

2. The "Apex Predator" ,Akshaye Khanna Every great hero needs a terrifying villain, and Akshaye Khanna steals the show as Rehman Dakait. His portrayal of a menacing crime lord is chilling. The psychological cat-and-mouse game between him and Ranveer is the heartbeat of the film. Their face-offs are not just about punches; they are masterclasses in acting.

3. A Stellar Ensemble Cast The supporting cast is a dream team. R. Madhavan brings quiet authority as the intelligence strategist, Arjun Rampal is formidable as the ISI adversary Major Iqbal, and Sanjay Dutt adds raw power as SP Chaudhary Aslam. It's rare to see so many heavyweights sharing the screen, and each one gets a moment to shine.

4. The Scale and Action Aditya Dhar has crafted a world that feels dangerous and real. The action sequences,especially the hand-to-hand combat,are raw and brutal, avoiding unnecessary slow-motion for a more grounded impact. The recreation of the gritty Lyari town and the high-stakes espionage operations will keep you on the edge of your seat.

5. It's an Epic Saga Be prepared: this is a massive film (clocking in at over 3 hours), but it uses that time to build a dense, complex story inspired by real geopolitical events. It feels like an epic novel brought to life. Plus, the ending perfectly sets up the confirmed sequel (Part 2 arrives March 2026), leaving you desperate for more.

Dhurandhar is a masterclass in tension, patriotism, and storytelling. It's gritty, emotional, and visually stunning. Don't let the runtime scare you-this is a saga that demands to be witnessed.

author: moturiaditya
title: Dhurandhar the beast of movie
text:
Dhurandhar: The Beast is a gritty action-drama that blends raw physical power with deep emotional conflict. The film centers on Dhurandhar, a feared and misunderstood man whose brute strength and violent reputation have earned him the label of a "beast." Raised in an environment of cruelty, injustice, and survival, Dhurandhar grows into a lone warrior shaped by pain rather than compassion. Society sees him as a monster, but beneath his ferocity lies a man struggling with his humanity.

The story unfolds as Dhurandhar becomes entangled in a corrupt system ruled by ruthless criminals and power-hungry elites. His uncontrollable rage makes him a weapon-used by others or hunted when he refuses to submit. While his actions are often brutal, they are driven by a strong moral instinct to protect the weak and punish oppressors. This internal contradiction-violence versus justice-forms the emotional core of the film.

As the plot progresses, Dhurandhar is forced to confront his past, including betrayals that turned him into what he is. A key relationship-whether with a loved one, mentor, or innocent victim-begins to awaken his suppressed emotions, challenging the idea that he is beyond redemption. The film explores whether a man branded as a beast can reclaim his soul, or if destiny has already sealed his fate.

The climax delivers intense action and emotional resolution as Dhurandhar faces the ultimate choice: embrace the beast within to destroy evil, or sacrifice himself to end the cycle of violence. Dhurandhar: The Beast is ultimately a story about identity, redemption, and the thin line between man and monster, questioning who the real beasts are in a corrupt world.

author: SakshamR-03
title: One in a Light years Film

Dhurandhar is a bold, uncompromising film that hits with clarity and conviction and Reality. It doesn't shy away from hard truths-exposing terrorist networks and the machinery that enables them with rare cinematic courage. The film refuses false neutrality and instead presents a gripping, grounded narrative that feels urgent and necessary.

Strong performances, tight pacing, and fearless storytelling make Dhurandhar stand out. This is cinema with purpose-impactful, intense, and unforgettable.

author: Harshalp-732
title: Unapologetic, Hard hitting movie
text: From the opening shot to the final frame, Dhurandhar is a cinematic triumph that redefines what a modern Indian action-drama can achieve. The film weaves intense emotion, razor-sharp storytelling, and breathtaking visuals into a seamless experience that grips you from start to finish. What sets Dhurandhar apart is its perfect balance - every element feels deliberate and masterfully crafted. The writing is taut, the pacing relentless, and the dialogues strike deep without ever feeling overdone. The direction deserves special praise for maintaining both scale and intimacy, giving every moment emotional weight even amidst high-octane sequences. The lead actor delivers a powerhouse performance, embodying both the raw physicality and emotional depth the role demands. The supporting cast complements him beautifully, each character adding a distinct flavor to the narrative. The score is electrifying yet soulful, elevating key scenes to near-mythic intensity. Visually, the film is stunning - every frame looks like it was painted with purpose. Whether it's the gritty streets or the majestic aerial shots, cinematography and color grading combine to heighten the story's realism and grandeur. In an era filled with formulaic blockbusters, Dhurandhar stands out as smart, heartfelt, and unapologetically bold. It's more than a film - it's an experience. A solid 10/10.

author: dixit9
title: Movie Review: Dhurandhar - A Masterclass in Gritty Storytelling
text:
Dhurandhar is not just a movie; it is an immersive experience that commands your attention from the very first frame. Directed by Aditya Dhar, this political spy thriller takes a complex, multi-layered story and simplifies it into a gripping narrative that keeps the audience hooked for over three hours.

The Performance: A Tale of Two Halves The film's greatest strength lies in its character arcs.

The First Half (Akshaye Khanna's Territory): Akshaye Khanna delivers a powerhouse performance that reminds us why he is one of the finest actors in the industry. He centers the movie with a calm yet terrifying intensity.

The Second Half (The Rise of Ranveer Singh): The transition is seamless. As the story evolves, the focus shifts beautifully toward Ranveer Singh. He brings a raw, subdued energy that perfectly balances the earlier chapters, proving his versatility in a more restrained role.

The Supporting Cast: Veteran actors like Rakesh Bedi add significant depth. In a film with so many characters, every role feels essential and meticulously detailed, a testament to Dhar's vision.

Direction & Craft Most directors struggle with large ensembles and long runtimes, often losing the thread in the second act. However, Aditya Dhar maintains a "masculine spine" throughout the film. The world-building-recreating the gritty atmosphere of Karachi's Lyari-is textured and believable.

The Technical Edge Music: The soundtrack by Shashwat Sachdev is "spot on." From the high-energy title track to the clever use of 80s and 90s nostalgia, the music acts as a lead character itself, driving the psychological tension of the film.

Impact: This is the kind of cinema that stays with you. It doesn't rely on over-the-top action but on realistic, grounded confrontation that sparks deep discussion long after the credits roll.

The Verdict: Dhurandhar is a "quantum leap" for Indian cinema. It is rare to see a film handle such scale with so much heart and precision.

author: aritra_jana
title: Dhurandhar = Total Mass + Solid Class! Akshaye Khanna just stole the whole show! üî•üé¨
text:
Dhurandhar is an absolute cinematic blast! The film runs for 3 hours 30 minutes, but not for a single moment does the duration feel stretched - the gripping pace and tight storytelling keep you glued to the seat.

While Ranveer Singh is the official lead and gives a powerful performance, it's Akshaye Khanna who truly steals the show. His screen presence, dialogue delivery, and layered expressions make every frame he's in feel electrifying. Arjun Rampal and Sanjay Dutt also deliver brilliant performances, adding depth, style, and menace to the film.

The background music (BGM) deserves a special mention - it elevates every big moment and gives the action sequences a massive adrenaline boost. Speaking of action - it's massive, raw, and thrilling, with some scenes that will make the audience cheer loud!

The film also touches upon the 26/11 chapter, delivering emotional weight and patriotic fire - moments that hit like a truck and leave your eyes moist.

In short: Great performances Killer BGM Massive action Emotionally impactful Totally worth the long runtime

Verdict: A powerhouse entertainer with style, emotion, and badass action - a must-watch on the big screen!

author: ranrock-51550
title: A nightmarish boring long stunt movie- too bad.
text:
Watching Dhurandhar in a multiplex, with expectations inflated by relentless media hype and social media noise, turned out to be a thoroughly disappointing experience. The film sinks far below even the formulaic stunt movies of the 1950s and 60s starring N. A. Ansari or Sheikh Mukhtar. What unfolds on screen is an over-imagined, chaotic mess-one jolt and shock after another-packed with poorly digested supernatural elements that feel more nauseating than engaging.

The visual palette is relentlessly ugly: grimy, filthy street locales of Karachi and grotesque, almost monstrous-looking characters make the viewing experience intolerable. Adding to the misery is the continuous assault of ear-splitting noise-endless shouting, shrieking, African tribal chants masquerading as rap, and Punjabi nonsense passed off as music and background score. This sonic chaos feels completely out of place in a Sindhi- and Urdu-speaking city like Karachi and becomes an endurance test rather than entertainment.

Sanjay Dutt appears in his familiar, tired rogue avatar-nothing new, nothing memorable. Akshaye Khanna fails to convince as Rahman Dakait, looking more like a fatigued, aging man with hollowed cheeks than a fearsome outlaw. Ranvir Sara Arjun is undoubtedly pretty but appears more like Ranveer Singh's daughter than his romantic counterpart, making the pairing awkward and unconvincing.

The only performances that stand out positively are those of Madhavan and Rakesh Bedi, both of whom deliver their roles with sincerity and restraint amid the surrounding chaos.

Technically, the film fares no better. Action scenes are shot with frantic, shaky camerawork, often resembling footage stuck permanently in fast-forward mode. Fight sequences are incomprehensible-you can barely tell who is hitting whom. Excessive and unjustified darkness dominates most scenes, continuing Bollywood's unfortunate trend of mistaking poor lighting for cinematic mood.

The story is weak and wildly unrealistic, with characters that are neither believable nor justified. Babu Dakait, supposedly a feared don ruling the city, comes across as a petty street thug. Seeing him zip around Karachi in a broken autorickshaw with his accomplices is unintentionally comic and outright laughable.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a nightmarish experience-badly written, poorly directed, atrociously edited, and shot with substandard cinematography. Performances are largely below average, barring Madhavan and Rakesh Bedi. One is left wondering where viewers found "emotion," "patriotism," or "fine performances" in this unimpressive and forgettable film.

Verdict: A complete waste of time and money.

Rating: 2/10.

author: upinderswork
title: Cinematic Trauma
text:
I regret watching Dhurandar. The film is an unbearable stretch of narrative. The plot is nonsensical. A spy agent enters Pakistan, becomes instantly famous and persuades a politician to marry his daughter. This is implausible. The story lacks realism and logic. The screenplay, editing and writing are tedious and unengaging. The plot attempts to be a "mass patriotic thriller" but ultimately resembles low-quality fiction. The only saving grace is Akshaye Khanna, who attempts to salvage the film. Without him, the movie would collapse within the first 30 minutes.

Final Verdict: If you value your time, money and mental well-being, do not watch this film. It is not entertainment; it is cinematic trauma.

author: Aaryankumar006
title: Dhurandhar (ragefilled filmmaking used at it's best)
text:
Dhurandhar Part 1 is an raw and gritty action thriller and it is awesome.

Dhurandhar wastes no time of it's huge 214 minutes runtime which feels like 120 minutes, I mean seriously the length of this film was never an issue for me it was paced perfectly- no scene or sequence felt out of place unnecessary or boring. Dhurandhar also uses practical locations largely and to it's huge advantage and it also adds to the gritty and raw nature of this film- you cannot pinpoint and say that this looks fake because it isn't.

Dhurandhar is also an multistarer and seriously each and every cast member was a standout Ranveer Singh was so great and seeing him on big screen you realize how much we missed him Akshay Khanna and Arjun Rampal were bloody brilliant they both looked and felt so convincing on screen, R. Madavan and Sanjay Dutt might have less screentime but they undoubtedly left an strong mark on screen and on us.

Dhurandhar also uses the A rating to it's advantage and it is more unfiltered and raw with it's dialogues than any other mainstream hindi film since- Udta Punjab.

The editing pattern in the starting portion of the film felt very distracting especially those cut to black screen for transitions the next chapters at start it more feels like an highlight rather than cohesive chapter, leaving this aside i had a blast watching Dhurandhar and cannot wait for the next chapters (part 2).

author: issolanki-48421

text:
Dhurandhar is not just a movie, it's an experience. If you enjoy serious spy dramas, intense storytelling, and strong acting, this film is worth watching.

Dhurandhar is a powerful, intense, and ambitious spy-thriller that leaves a strong impact. The film stands out mainly because of its strong performances, gripping subject, and grand scale.

Ranveer Singh delivers one of his most intense performances, completely owning the role with raw emotion and screen presence. Supporting actors like Akshaye Khanna, R. Madhavan, and Sanjay Dutt add depth and seriousness to the narrative.

The story dives deep into espionage, patriotism, and the darker side of intelligence operations. While the second half is gripping and emotionally heavy, the first half feels a bit stretched, mainly due to the long runtime. However, once the film picks up pace, it keeps you engaged till the end.

The background score, cinematography, and action sequences elevate the cinematic experience, especially on the big screen. Some scenes are disturbing and intense, so this movie may not be for everyone.

author: Kshitiz-13
title: Amazing
text:
Dhurandhar is one of those rare films that doesn't just entertain - it leaves a mark. Aditya Dhar proves once again that he isn't just a filmmaker; he's a precision storyteller with fire in his vision. Every frame feels intentional, every scene purposeful, and every emotional beat lands exactly where it should.

From the very beginning, the movie grips you. The storytelling is layered yet smooth - complex themes delivered without ever losing clarity or momentum. Dhar builds tension like only he can: not loud, not rushed, but steadily rising until your pulse syncs with the rhythm of the film.

The background score deserves its own applause. It's atmospheric, intense, and immersive - the kind of score that doesn't just accompany the visuals, but elevates them. In action sequences, it punches. In emotional moments, it breathes. It's a rare example of music being as much a character as the actors on screen.

Speaking of action - flawless. Brutal, sharp, grounded and filmed with a commitment to realism rather than chaos. No unnecessary slow-mo, no over-stylization - just pure craft. The choreography, cinematography, and editing combine into a visual language that feels both cinematic and personal.

Performances across the cast are strong, but what stands out is how Dhar uses his actors. Nobody feels wasted. Nobody feels like filler. Every role matters. Every role moves the story.

The film may be facing some negativity online, but much of it feels less like genuine criticism and more like reactionary noise from people who seem uncomfortable with the film's confidence, tone, or national identity. Unlike those voices, the audience response inside theatres tells a different story - applause, silence when needed, and that collective breath-holding feeling only great films create.

author: shubhj-29931

The supporting cast enhances the story's richness, with each interaction layered with tension and meaning. Action sequences are brutal yet meticulously choreographed, and the director's storytelling combines political realism with emotional authenticity. Cinematic framing and lighting elevate even the quiet moments, while the music subtly underscores the stakes, creating an engrossing and sophisticated narrative.

author: anjalisen-42522
title: Star-Studded Magic with Thrills and Heart
text: The film is a slow-burning masterpiece, layering tension with each scene. Ranveer Singh anchors the narrative with a performance that skillfully navigates internal conflict, moral ambiguity, and physical endurance. Sanjay Dutt's scenes resonate with authority and menace, often stealing the frame with a single glance. Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan add depth, their interactions loaded with subtext and quiet intensity. Arjun Rampal's subtle threats loom over the narrative, creating a constant sense of danger. Sara Arjun's emotional presence offers a tender counterbalance to the violent world around her. Aditya Dhar's direction orchestrates suspenseful sequences with surgical precision, making action scenes feel both thrilling and consequential. The cinematography highlights contrasts between urban chaos and intimate character moments, while the soundtrack punctuates tension, amplifying every heartbeat. The climax ties together narrative threads with satisfying emotional and visual impact.

author: arnikajaisval
title: Action That Electrifies, Drama That Moves
text: Tension, strategy, and emotion converge in every frame, creating a cinematic experience that's both thrilling and profound. The lead's performance is electric, perfectly blending vulnerability, intellect, and physicality. Action sequences are meticulously designed, visually stunning, and narratively meaningful. Supporting characters are layered and memorable, enhancing the story's depth. Cinematography captures scale and intimacy with equal precision. The score heightens suspense and emotional resonance without overpowering the narrative. The film's intricate plot, grounded in political and criminal realities, raises stakes at every turn. By the finale, both adrenaline and emotion reach a crescendo, leaving viewers deeply satisfied and awestruck. Every sequence builds tension and delivers narrative payoff, making the story impossible to ignore. The protagonist is compelling, portraying both internal conflict and outward decisiveness with finesse. Action is choreographed to emphasize stakes and character, never feeling gratuitous. Supporting characters contribute richness, enhancing the story's authenticity. Cinematography captures the chaos and quiet with equal skill, while the sound design amplifies suspense and emotion. Political and criminal elements give depth and realism, while the screenplay balances strategy, intrigue, and personal stakes masterfully. The climax ties together action and emotion flawlessly, leaving an enduring impression of cinema at its peak.

author: RajibR-96
title: Action Peaks and Emotions Rise in This Epic
text: The film crafts a tense, atmospheric journey that combines strategy, emotion, and adrenaline. Ranveer Singh portrays moral conflict with subtle mastery, while Sanjay Dutt's commanding presence amplifies suspense. Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan create memorable supporting roles, and Arjun Rampal delivers a chilling, understated menace. Sara Arjun provides poignant emotional depth. Aditya Dhar's direction ensures that the story's intensity escalates naturally, blending meticulously staged action with character-driven drama. Cinematography captures chaotic urban environments and intimate moments alike, while the score underscores tension and emotional resonance. By the conclusion, the story leaves a powerful and lingering impact.

author: PriyanshuA-35
title: A Chilling, Immersive Masterclass in Spy Thrillers
text:
Dhurandhar is a riveting, top-tier spy thriller that feels rooted in reality, set against a world of gang rivalries and terror networks while never losing its emotional depth. The plot is rich and consistently engaging, the writing is razor-sharp, and every character is rendered with striking nuance. Its sincere, steadily intensifying screenplay pulls you in deeper with each scene.

Ranveer Singh completely transforms for this role, and the supporting cast - Akshaye Khanna, Sanjay Dutt, Arjun Rampal, R. Madhavan, Sara Arjun, Manav Gohil, and others - ensure the film never falters for a moment. Aditya Dhar crafts a world so authentic and immersive that you can almost feel yourself walking the streets alongside the characters. His integration of real-life-style footage and grounded sound design leads to several chilling moments, including a standout sequence where the screen bleeds red and haunting recorded voices echo through an attack.

In the end, Dhurandhar is both edge-of-your-seat and emotionally resonant - cinema meant to be experienced in a full theatre. And with that tantalizing final note, the wait for March 2026 to see what Aditya Dhar and Ranveer Singh unveil next feels almost unbearable.

author: Ishanman
title: Dhurandhar - A Masterclass in Tension, Heart, and Craft
text:
From the opening frame to the final credit, Dhurandhar unfolds as a rare cinematic achievement-the kind of film that lingers long after the screen goes dark. It isn't merely entertainment; it's an experience that lingers in the memory, inviting both awe and reflection.

Plot and Pacing Dhurandhar crafts a taut, sweeping narrative that balances grand, high-stakes twists with intimate, character-driven moments. The pacing is meticulous: every scene earns its keep, everyline of dialogue lands with precision, and the tension builds with an almost mathematical inevitability. The central mystery hooks you in seconds and never lets go, yet the film never loses sight of the emotional throughline that gives it real soul.

Performances Lead Performance: A tour de force. Ranveer Singh navigates a roller-coaster of grit, vulnerability, and quiet resolve with a magnetic clarity. Subtle choices-a look here, a tremor there-reveal a character who is both formidable and human.

Supporting Cast:The ensemble elevates the material. Each actor brings texture, nuance, and purpose, turning even small roles into memorable pivots in the story.

Villain/Antagonist: Written with psychological depth, the antagonist is never a caricature. The tension arises from genuine understanding of motive, making confrontations electric and morally complex.

Direction and Craft The director orchestrates a symphony of tension and tenderness. Visual storytelling is lush yet purposeful-mesmerizing cinematography, purposeful blocking, and a keen eye for detail that rewards repeat viewing. The score is not merely accompaniment; it's a co-protagonist that amplifies emotion and suspense without ever.

author: PrathamP-89
title: Best Movie Of 2025
text:
Fantastic acting fantastic story fantastic vfx fantastic direction fantastic everything must watch movie...Dhurandar is a high-octane Hindi action-thriller that keeps you hooked from the very first frame. Directed with strong vision and intensity, the film delivers a gripping blend of espionage, drama, and raw emotion. It follows a dangerous mission filled with betrayal, hidden agendas, and relentless pursuit, making it a compelling watch for fans of serious thrillers.

The movie shines brightest in its action sequences. Every fight scene feels powerful, well-choreographed, and grounded in realism. Whether it's close-combat hand-to-hand action or explosive gun battles, Dhurandar maintains an adrenaline-filled pace throughout. The cinematography adds to the film's gritty appeal, capturing the tension and fear of a spy's life with dark tones and sharp visuals. Background music is another strong element, enhancing the suspense without overshadowing the storytelling.

Performances are solid across the board. The lead actor delivers one of his most intense roles yet-balancing vulnerability with strength. Supporting characters add depth to the narrative, each contributing significantly to the mission's twists and emotional beats. Antagonists are equally well-portrayed, with their motivations rooted in realism rather than exaggerated villainy.

Where Dhurandar truly excels is in its storytelling rhythm. The screenplay is tightly structured, revealing secrets and surprises at just the right moments. The film explores themes of loyalty, sacrifice, and patriotism, but does not drown in melodrama. Instead, it uses emotions to strengthen the urgency of the mission.

The movie does run on the longer side, and a few scenes might feel stretched, but the overall intensity keeps the momentum alive. The climax is thrilling, dramatic, and satisfying-delivering the emotional punch a film like this deserves.

author: VISHALT-06
title: Review: Dhurandar (2025)
text:
Dhurandar" is a gripping action-drama inspired by real incidents, though the core premise may feel familiar to viewers because a similar storyline was earlier explored in Mission Majnu. Despite that, the film manages to stand strong on its own with engaging execution and impressive performances.

The movie is visually striking, and every character is crafted with attention to detail. Ranbir Singh delivers one of his most impactful roles, both in terms of looks and emotional presence. The supporting cast fits their parts well, enhancing the film's overall intensity.

The action sequences are commendable, though one slight drawback is that Ranbir Singh's action could have been more hard-hitting-something closer to the raw power seen in KGF 2 with Rocky's character. Another minor negative is that while Sanjay Dutt plays a strong and dominant role, his one-on-one encounter with Akshay Khanna feels oddly imbalanced, reducing the weight of his character.

On the positive side, the music album is excellent, with "Ishq Jalakar" standing out as a soulful, unforgettable track that elevates the emotional depth of the film.

Overall, "Dhurandar" is a well-made, entertaining film with solid performances, great visuals, and memorable music. Despite a few shortcomings, it remains a highly enjoyable watch for action lovers.

‚≠ê IMDb Rating (My Opinion): 8/10.

author: Surajk-7808
title: Best Indian spy movie of all time?? Yes!!!
text:
Aditya Dhar's Dhurandhar is a groundbreaking spy thriller that masterfully blends gritty realism, high-octane action, and raw patriotism into an unforgettable cinematic experience. At 3.5 hours, it never drags-every minute immerses you in the dark underworld of Karachi, inspired by real events like IC-814, Parliament attack, and 26/11. Ranveer Singh delivers a career-defining performance as undercover agent Hamza, with brooding intensity and nuance. Akshaye Khanna steals the show as the swaggering Rehman Dakait, explosive in every scene.

The stellar cast, R. Madhavan, Sanjay Dutt, Arjun Rampal, and Sara Arjun-adds immense depth. Dhar's direction is visionary, visceral action, intelligent screenplay, stunning cinematography, and a haunting score. It's bold, unapologetic, and honors unsung heroes while thrilling audiences.

Verdict: 10/10 - A masterpiece redefining Bollywood. Essential big-screen watch!

author: 187puneet
title: Absolute Gem
text:
This movie blends real-life incidents with fiction in an intricate, gripping way. At its core, it's a spy thriller-India's covert response to the relentless terror attacks originating from Pakistan. It's structured as a two-part story, with the second chapter still to come.

Every character is given a proper backstory, and the film does justice to each one. The entire cast brings their A-game, and it shows. The background score hits the right notes, and the songs actually serve the narrative instead of interrupting it.

Be warned: the movie is bloody, and it embraces its "A" rating without hesitation.

If there's any criticism, it's the runtime. While I personally didn't feel the length-because I was fully engrossed-a tighter edit of 20-25 minutes might have elevated it even further.

author: SweetyH-5
title: üî• Dhurandhar: A Full-Throttle Cinematic Knockout üî•
text:
Dhurandhar is a cinematic knockout that delivers on every front. The casting feels spot-on, with each performance adding weight and authenticity to the narrative. Aditya Dhar's direction is confident and razor-sharp, proving once again that he knows how to craft a truly theatre-worthy experience.

The cinematography elevates the film to another level, capturing both scale and intensity with striking visuals. The action sequences are exceptionally choreographed-raw, impactful, and never overdone-keeping the adrenaline high throughout.

A special mention goes to the music. Shashwat absolutely nailed the remixes, seamlessly blending modern energy with the film's mood, making the soundtrack a major highlight rather than just a background element.

Overall, Dhurandhar isn't just a good film-it's a full-blown banger. Aditya Dhar doesn't just meet expectations; he smashes them, delivering a powerful, immersive cinematic experience that demands to be watched on the big screen.

author: ddevashish-04953
title: Best movie
text: The brilliance of Dhurandhar lies in its ensemble cast and the director's meticulous guidance. Each actor is given space to shine while maintaining the story's momentum. The lead delivers a performance full of gravitas, balancing power, vulnerability, and intelligence. Supporting characters are equally strong, adding texture to the plot. The director's attention to detail is evident in every sequence-from political strategy discussions to heart-stopping action scenes. Visual storytelling, combined with smart editing, ensures that even complex subplots remain easy to follow. The film's score intensifies emotions at key moments, making the audience feel the stakes. Dhurandhar demonstrates how strong direction and brilliant performances can elevate cinema to an art form.

author: singhrajawatr

author: SayantanP-9
title: #Dhurandhar
text:
Just walked out of the cinema after watching #Dhurandhar, and I'm still processing the sheer scale and intensity of Aditya Dhar's vision. This isn't just a spy thriller; it's a gritty, complex underworld saga that uses the espionage framework to explore the brutal realities of covert operations. The film's strength lies in its refusal to offer easy answers, instead plunging us deep into the perilous world of Lyari, where the lines between criminal, politician, and spy are constantly blurred.

The performances are truly the foundation of this masterpiece. Ranveer Singh as Hamza Ali Mazari delivers a performance defined by restraint and explosive intensity-his transformation from a green operative to a feared figure of authority is a masterclass in controlled acting. But the undeniable show-stealer is Akshaye Khanna as Rehman Dakait. His introduction scene, set to the viral 'FA9LA' track, is one of the most electric cinematic moments of the year. He doesn't shout to exert dominance; he simply is the power, making his character an unforgettable, chilling antagonist.

The film's runtime is long, but Aditya Dhar utilizes every minute to meticulously build the world and its complex politics, a treatment rarely seen in mainstream Bollywood. The technical departments-from the raw, dusty cinematography to the hard-hitting sound design-deserve special mention for creating such an immersive, unsettling atmosphere.

If you're looking for a spectacle with depth, incredible performances, and a story that genuinely grips you until the final, shocking tease for the sequel, Dhurandhar is absolutely essential viewing. Go watch it on the biggest screen possible. It's a bold, brilliant piece of cinema. üáÆüá≥üî• #DhurandharReview #RanveerSingh #AkshayeKhanna #AdityaDhar #MustWatch.

author: RegalsReelView

To prevent future terrorist attacks and to cut the head of the snake off, a man embeds himself in the belly of the underworld to gather intel and commit espionage.

The story's timeline is built around tragic events, but the story itself is fiction. The story blends the many genres well, switching between them seamlessly. The action is sparse, but well done, with just a bit being over the top. The three-hour and thirty-four-minute runtime flies by and is worth it. This is definitely a movie worth a ticket.

author: rkworld-65912
title: Superbbbbbb!
text:
Story: The way it blends real-life history (like the Lyari gang wars and intelligence ops) with high-stakes drama is incredible. It feels grounded yet massive in scale.

Music: Shashwat Sachdev has outdone himself. The way the soundtrack integrates with the tension-especially the use of those classic ghazals and high-energy tracks-makes the 214-minute runtime fly by.

Action: Unlike the usual "gravity-defying" stunts, the action here feels raw and realistic. The car chases and the tension in the Karachi sequences are world-class.

Performances: Ranveer Singh's restrained performance as Hamza is a career-best, and Akshaye Khanna as Rehman Dakait is absolutely terrifying.

The Verdict: "Jordar Movie Che!" It's not just a spy thriller; it's a landmark for Indian Cinema. If you haven't seen it yet, you are missing out on a masterpiece.

author: chetan-146
title: Akshaye Khanna Steals the Show in This Gripping Thriller
text:
Honestly, I went into Dhurandhar without huge expectations, but I walked out completely blown away - mainly because of Akshaye Khanna.

He is on another level in this film. There's no loud drama, no over-the-top shouting - just pure, controlled, razor-sharp acting. The way he uses his eyes, his pauses, that calm but dangerous energy... he makes every scene feel tense even when he's just standing quietly in the frame. Whenever he comes on screen, the whole film suddenly feels more serious and important.

The movie itself is gripping - dark, pacy, and engaging from start to finish. The plot has enough twists to keep you hooked, the action scenes are well done, and the world of politics, crime, and power games feels very real. The background score and visuals add a lot to the mood, too.

But for me, this is Akshaye Khanna's film.

He doesn't just play the character, he owns it. It's the kind of performance that reminds you how underrated he actually is and makes you want to see him in many more lead roles.

If you're a fan of strong acting and intense thrillers, Dhurandhar is a definite must-watch. 10/10, especially for Akshaye Khanna's brilliant performance.

author: SurbhiS-413
title: A First Theatre Experience I'll Never Forget
text: Dhurandhar will always be special to me because it was the first movie I ever watched in a theatre, and that too on the first day, first show, and it honestly couldn't have been a better choice. The film pulls you in quietly and keeps tightening its grip through strong writing and a steadily building screenplay that never feels rushed. Ranveer Singh completely disappears into his role, bringing intensity, vulnerability, and moral conflict in a way that feels very real. Aditya Dhar's direction is confident and grounded, balancing action with reflective moments that add depth instead of just spectacle. Performances by Akshaye Khanna, Sanjay Dutt, Arjun Rampal, R. Madhavan, Sara Arjun, and Manav Gohil add weight and realism, making the world of crime, politics, and espionage feel lived-in. The cinematography and sound design enhance the tension without overpowering it, and the layered storytelling keeps you engaged till the very end. Watching this unfold on the big screen for the first time made the experience intense, emotional, and unforgettable, and it's a film that genuinely stays with you long after it ends.

author: niteshnivas
title: Dhurandhar Review
text:
Dhurandhar is a film that commands attention from its very first frame and holds it firmly till the end. Despite its long runtime of nearly 3 hours and 30 minutes, the movie never once feels exhausting - a rare achievement in itself. The narration flows with confidence, making the audience completely surrender to its world.

The music is beautifully integrated into the storytelling. The songs arrive naturally, enhancing emotions rather than interrupting the pace. The background score is one of the film's strongest assets - intense, haunting, and powerful - it amplifies every dramatic moment and elevates the film to a grand cinematic experience.

What truly sets Dhurandhar apart is its stellar casting. Ranveer Singh dominates the screen with a performance full of intensity and raw energy. Sanjay Dutt brings gravitas and authority, making his presence felt in every scene. Akshaye Khanna impresses with his restrained and layered acting, while R. Madhavan adds emotional depth and balance to the narrative. Each actor fits their role perfectly, making the characters feel lived-in and real.

Visually, the film is striking. Strong cinematography, detailed frames, and sharp editing ensure that the pace never dips. The screenplay is tightly woven, keeping the tension alive throughout and making the lengthy runtime feel surprisingly crisp.

Final Verdict: Dhurandhar is not just a film, but an experience - powerful performances, stirring music, and confident storytelling come together to deliver a gripping cinematic journey that never feels long. A must-watch for those who enjoy grand, intense cinema.

author: deboo-c
title: An Ensemble-Driven Thriller Where Every Character Matters
text:
This is a long film, but once it starts, you're completely pulled in and genuinely don't realise how time flies. I watched it on a large screen in Brisbane, and the 7:50 pm show was a full house, which is quite rare here, that alone says a lot.

The director deserves massive credit for giving every character equal importance. Not a single role felt like a supporting one; each character had a crucial part to play, and the actors delivered accordingly.

One of the most impressive aspects was the casting. Actors who are mostly known for comedy were given serious, intense roles, and it worked brilliantly. Dhar truly saw the untapped potential in Gaurav Gera and Rakesh Bedi, and it was refreshing and powerful to watch them in such a new light.

Akshaye Khanna, R. Madhavan, and Arjun Rampal were solid as always, they never disappoint. Ranveer Singh once again proved that he's an exceptional actor who just needs the right director to bring out his best. He should definitely do more films like this. Sanjay Dutt also did a great job.

That said, the real star of the film is the director and the story writer, who brought together such an engaging vision and gripping narrative. There were multiple nail-biting, edge-of-the-seat moments throughout the film.

I genuinely cannot wait for 26th March 2026 to watch Part 2.

The storytelling is tight, the performances are brutally honest, and the message is loud without being preachy. What makes the movie stand out is that nothing feels exaggerated for drama - these are the kind of situations people actually face but never talk about openly.

If someone wants entertainment with truth, this is it. Dhurandhar is a reminder that the world is not as simple or fair as we like to pretend. It's absolutely worth watching.

The action, performances, star cast, cinematography, direction, and the art itself were absolutely mind-boggling. Every element felt so perfectly executed that I couldn't find a single flaw in any scene. I was completely spellbound from start to finish.

author: aadhithyagopal
title: Best spy movie
text:
Here is a 300-word expanded version of your review, keeping the same tone but making it richer, smoother, and more impactful:

Don't watch this movie if you're expecting the usual Bollywood fantasy where the ISI suddenly becomes best friends with RAW, where national agencies shake hands like schoolchildren after a cricket match, or where the heroine randomly appears in a bikini for a beach song that has no connection to the story. If you're looking for villains who turn into comedians, heroes who defy gravity with cartoonish stunts, and a plot that treats espionage like a superhero comic, then this film is absolutely not for you.

But if you want to watch one of the most realistic, grounded, and uncompromising spy thrillers ever made in Indian cinema, then this movie is nothing short of a masterpiece. It doesn't sugar-coat geopolitics, it doesn't dilute the brutality of espionage, and it doesn't insult your intelligence with easy resolutions. Instead, it delivers a tense, gritty, and emotionally charged narrative that respects both the craft of filmmaking and the audience's maturity.

Every frame feels researched, every character feels lived-in, and every decision carries weight. The film shows espionage not as a glamorous profession but as a world filled with moral ambiguity, sacrifice, and constant danger. There are no superheroes here-only humans pushed to their physical and emotional limits.

The performances elevate the movie even further. The lead actor gives one of his most intense portrayals, carrying the story with raw vulnerability and controlled aggression. The supporting cast, especially the antagonist, adds layers that make the conflict feel chillingly real.

The direction, cinematography, and sound design work together to create an immersive world that pulls you into the tension and never lets you breathe easily.

In short: this is not just a movie, it's an experience-a rare spy thriller that prioritizes authenticity over spectacle. If you want reality, depth, and world-class storytelling, don't miss this film.
