author: Gauravr-6450
title: Review
text:
Just woww Dhurdhar is a remarkable and emotionally gripping masterpiece that leaves a lasting impact on every viewer. From its very first frame to the final moments, the film holds your attention with its raw realism, powerful performances, and deeply meaningful storytelling. What makes Dhurdhar stand out is its courage to explore human emotions and social truths without any filters. The narrative does not rely on unnecessary glamour or exaggerated drama; instead, it rises on the strength of honesty, sensitivity, and a profound understanding of life.

The characters are beautifully written, each carrying layers of depth and complexity. Their struggles, dreams, and internal conflicts feel incredibly real, making it easy for viewers to connect with them. The lead performance is exceptional-subtle yet intense-perfectly capturing the emotional weight of the story. The supporting cast also shines, giving life to every scene and enriching the film's atmosphere.

The direction of Dhurdhar deserves special praise. Every scene is crafted with purpose. The pacing is steady, allowing the audience to absorb the pain, hope, and beauty hidden in small moments. The cinematography enhances the storytelling with stunning visuals that feel both artistic and authentic. The music and background score are soulful, elevating the emotional experience of the film.

What truly makes Dhurdhar a masterpiece is its message. It challenges social norms, encourages self-reflection, and brings out the reality many choose to ignore. The film doesn't just entertain-it educates, inspires, and provokes thought. Even after the credits roll, its impact stays with the viewer.

In a world full of superficial content, Dhurdhar stands tall as a rare gem-bold, meaningful, and unforgettable. It is not just a film;

author: navkishlay
title: A Masterstroke of Grit and Grace - "Dhurandhar" Redefines Indian Storytelling
text:
Dhurandhar is not just a film-it's a force of storytelling that grips you from its very first frame. Every element, from the rugged landscapes to the haunting silences between characters, speaks of a director in complete command of his craft.

The narrative doesn't rush; it breathes, allowing each moment to build tension, emotion, and meaning. The ensemble cast elevates this film to powerhouse status, with each actor delivering career-defining turns.

Ranveer Singh commands the screen as the unyielding protagonist, channeling raw fury and vulnerability in a transformative performance that swings from explosive energy to heartbreaking subtlety-his best work yet.

Akshay Khanna brings chilling precision to his antagonist role, his steely gaze and measured menace making every scene crackle with dread.

Rakesh Bedi shines in a pivotal supporting part, infusing warmth and tragic depth that grounds the chaos with authentic emotional heft.

Sanjay Dutt roars back with gravelly intensity as the grizzled mentor figure, his presence a thunderous reminder of his enduring charisma. Arjun Rampal, brooding and magnetic, delivers a layered portrayal of conflicted loyalty that adds moral complexity, stealing scenes with his brooding physicality and quiet rage.

Technically, Dhurandhar is a visual triumph. The cinematography captures contrasts-light and shadow, chaos and calm-with poetic precision. The background score never overpowers; it heightens.

Together, they create an immersive experience that feels both intimate and epic. But where Dhurandhar truly excels is its storytelling. It fuses socio-political commentary with personal struggle, making you question what heroism really means in today's world.

There's an honesty here that's rare in contemporary cinema-gritty, unflinching, and profoundly moving.

Dhurandhar isn't a film you merely watch; it's a film you live through. It's cinema that dares to challenge, to move, and to stay with you long after you've left the theatre.

author: Heroman-7
title: perfecto
text:
Dhurandhar is one of those films that doesn't try to shout at you from the very first frame - instead, it slowly pulls you in and makes you stay. What I really liked is how grounded the movie feels. The story isn't overloaded with unnecessary twists; it moves at its own pace, letting the characters breathe and feel real.

The lead character is easily the backbone of the film. You can actually sense the weight he's carrying - the frustration, the small victories, the quiet anger. Nothing feels overly dramatic or "movie-ish." Even the supporting characters have purpose, especially in the way they shape the main character's journey.

What surprised me most was the tone. It balances intensity with subtle humor and emotional moments without turning into melodrama. The dialogues feel natural, like conversations you'd actually overhear in real life. And the direction deserves credit for keeping things controlled instead of flashy.

Visually, the film has a slightly raw look, which works really well. The background score doesn't overpower scenes; it gently pushes them forward. A few moments feel stretched, and there are places where you wish the pacing was tighter - but nothing that completely pulls you out.

Where Dhurandhar really wins is in its message. It doesn't preach, yet it leaves you thinking about choices, ego, pride, and the quiet battles people fight behind closed doors. When the credits roll, you don't feel "wow, that was huge" - instead, you feel a quiet satisfaction, like you just watched something honest.

Is it perfect? No. But it is sincere, well-acted, and meaningful - the kind of film that stays with you for a bit after you leave the theater.

If you like character-driven stories over loud action or forced comedy, Dhurandhar is definitely worth watching.

author: akshanshsharma-75983
title: Dhurandhar
text:
Dhurandhar is a gripping blend of slick action, emotional storytelling, and strong character-driven drama, making it one of the more engaging Indian thrillers of the year. Scored at 8 out of 10, the film stands out for its confident direction, atmospheric tension, and a lead performance that elevates nearly every scene.

The story follows its central character-an enigmatic, morally complex figure whose past haunts every decision he makes. The writing excels in the way it balances his inner conflict with high-stakes external threats. Instead of relying only on action, the film invests time into building his personal relationships, motivations, and vulnerabilities. This makes the emotional beats feel genuinely earned.

Visually, Dhurandhar is impressive. The cinematography creates a gritty yet cinematic world, with well-composed shots and fluid action sequences that avoid unnecessary over-stylization. The background score complements the tone without overpowering it, and the pacing, though occasionally uneven in the second half, stays engaging overall.

Performances are one of the film's strongest pillars. The lead actor brings depth and intensity, portraying the character's turmoil with subtlety. The supporting cast also shines, especially in moments where the film slows down to explore trust, betrayal, and survival.

Where Dhurandhar falters slightly is in its predictability during a few key twists. Some plot points follow familiar genre beats, and certain characters could have benefited from more development. However, these shortcomings don't take away from the overall experience, which remains consistently entertaining.

In conclusion, Dhurandhar delivers a compelling combination of storytelling, action, and emotion. With strong performances and a gripping narrative at its core, it earns a solid 8/10-a must-watch for fans of stylish thrillers with substance.

author: vartikagupta-75671
title: An edge of the seat thriller that will make you wanting more!
text:
Here's a breakdown of what this movie contains:

200% Character acting 200% Set Design 150% Music + Sound design 150% Cinematography 100% Exceptional story and script 30% violence and gore 5% propaganda

  • If violence, gore or propaganda is the reason for anyone to "boycott" this movie, know this- You're missing out on one of the most amazing cinema experiences of your life.


  • Take your family with you. You'll rob them of the experience.


  • Most importantly, stop asking around and being afraid of booking tickets. Good or bad, decide for yourself.


This movie is a collaboration, a team work. It refuses to ride on just the star power of the actors. Every script writer, lyricist, cinematographer, supporting actor, set designer, sound designer, editor, makeup artist, hair stylist, costume designer, and the long credit list have done a fab job! They all came and gave their 2000% to give us audiences a ride of a lifetime!

I went to watch this movie before any reviews were out. First day, 3rd show. I'm also not into celeb worship. So, the only motivation was to purely experience a Bollywood movie. And MAN! It. Did. Not. Disappoint.

What you see in the trailer, is what you get for 3.5 hours. By the end, you'll want to keep wanting more. No, and I mean, no OTT, piracy, small screen phones, laptops can replicate the experience. Heck, I didn't even realise Ranveer's eye color had changed while watching the trailer. It's these details that just pop out on a big screen.

Aditya Dhar has created a masterpiece through and through!

The depth and detail of the world of Lyari stays with you long after (in my case 5 days atp)...you just won't be able to shrug it off.

My soul has been craving for an immersive escape and Dhurandhar delivers like it's nobody business. You're hooked, you're connected, you're rooting for the protagonist but acting so goated, you're also rooting for the antagonist. And then they remind you, with real clips of how our agents feel working in the depths of a place with no moral compass. The anger, the shock, the intensity will keep you on the edge.

If you think you won't watch the movie because of your ideological stance, well you're smart to see through it. But don't lose out on an experience of a lifetime.

author: PoonamD-07
title: Best movie of this year
text:
The film stands out as a powerful blend of storytelling, visual style, and emotional depth. From the very first scene, it pulls the audience into its world with striking imagery and a strong sense of atmosphere. The director shows a clear vision, balancing entertainment with meaningful themes that stay with you long after the credits roll.

One of the biggest strengths of the movie is its cast. Each actor delivers a convincing and heartfelt performance, making the characters feel real and relatable. Whether it's moments of tension, humor, or vulnerability, the actors handle every emotion with authenticity. Their on-screen chemistry adds even more weight to the story and helps keep the audience engaged throughout.

The writing is equally impressive. The screenplay manages to be sharp, thoughtful, and engaging without ever feeling slow. The dialogues feel natural, and the story moves at a steady pace, revealing just enough at each step to keep viewers curious. Even the quieter moments feel purposeful, helping to build the world and deepen our connection to the characters.

Visually, the film is stunning. The cinematography uses colors, framing, and movement to create scenes that are not just beautiful but also meaningful. The music and background score complement the visuals perfectly, enhancing the mood of every moment without overpowering it.

While no movie is perfect, the strengths of this one easily outweigh its small flaws. Some scenes might feel slightly extended or predictable, but the overall experience remains captivating and memorable.

In the end, the film succeeds in delivering entertainment, emotion, and artistry all at once. It's the kind of movie that leaves you thinking, feeling, and wanting to revisit it again. A truly impressive piece of cinema that deserves all the praise it receives.

author: sanket12
title: A Star-Lit Adventure of Intensity and Emotion
text: From the very first frame, Dhurandhar announces itself as a cinematic achievement. The director demonstrates extraordinary control over tone and pace, balancing intense action, political drama, and emotional storytelling. author: Sachin-620
title: Best movie of Spy verse
text:
Dhurander isn't just another spy film filled with flashy gadgets and over-the-top action-it's a gripping portrayal of intelligence work as it truly unfolds in the shadows. What makes the movie stand out is its raw honesty. Instead of glorifying agents as invincible heroes, it shows the emotional strain, sacrifice, and constant pressure that comes with operating in a world where every step is a risk.

The narrative moves with purpose: no unnecessary drama, no exaggerated heroics. The screenplay beautifully blends patriotism with practicality, showing that real espionage isn't about glamorous chases but about information, strategy, psychological endurance, and moral dilemmas.

The performances are tight and believable. The lead actor delivers intensity without theatrics, portraying a spy who is human first-vulnerable, flawed, and deeply committed to duty. The supporting cast complements the story without overshadowing the core mission.

Technically too, Dhurander impresses. The cinematography captures tension without noise, the background score elevates the suspense rather than overpowering it, and the dialogues feel grounded and sharp.

In a genre often dominated by fantasy-driven spy spectacles, Dhurander is a refreshing shift-a film that respects intelligence work and presents it with authenticity. It's not just a movie based on espionage; it's a mirror to the unseen lives of those who protect from the shadows.

author: NeeleshA-05
title: Mind blowing
text:
Here's a clear, straight-talk review of Dhurandhar (2025) based on critics, audience reaction, and industry voices.

What the movie is Dhurandhar is a high-budget Hindi spy action thriller directed by Aditya Dhar, starring Ranveer Singh, Akshaye Khanna, R. Madhavan, Sanjay Dutt, Arjun Rampal and Sara Arjun. It's a long film - over three hours - that places an Indian agent deep in Karachi's underworld as part of a covert mission.

Strengths You'll hear a lot of praise for the performances. Ranveer Singh and Akshaye Khanna are frequently singled out as the anchors of the story, giving intense and committed turns. Many viewers and peers in the industry have called it powerful, gripping and entertaining, with strong direction and a compelling narrative that holds attention despite its length.

The background score and production values also stand out, and audiences have reacted very positively on social platforms, with many calling it a "blockbuster-level" experience.

It's also doing exceptionally well commercially, crossing big box office milestones and becoming one of the top Hindi films of the year.

Weaknesses Not every reviewer is enthusiastic. Some critics feel Dhurandhar is overly long and at times loses focus under its own ambition. A few point to pacing issues, a heavy dose of violence, and what they see as jingoistic or politically loaded themes. The storytelling can feel uneven, especially in the second half, according to certain reviews.

There's also been controversy around how it's interpreted and discussed online. Some reviews prompted strong reactions from fans, and critics' groups had to speak out against harassment over differing opinions.

Overall take This is a major commercial and cultural moment movie. If you like big, heavy-emotional action thrillers with strong performances and cinematic scale, you'll probably enjoy it. If you prefer tighter writing and subtler themes, it might feel overblown or heavy-handed. It's ambitious, flawed, but hard to ignore - a film that's as likely to be talked about for its craft as its impact outside the theater.

It's worth watching for the craft and performances, while being aware it isn't a small, nuanced thriller.

author: hanan-77633
title: A Knockout punch to the YRF Spy Universe.
text:
I was waiting for this film since the last year and it pretty much met my expectations. I was a mind-blowing experience to see such an unfiltered, violent and masculine story which revolves around true events.

Let's talk about each aspect one by one.

Film has an exceptionally great production design. The world it builds. The ganglands of Lyari and even the little details, like vehicles, shops, buildings and even the roads, look exactly as they are in Pakistan. Each and every element regarding the world-building in this film adds a lot to the story makes uplifts the experience by many fold. Even the characters feel real as they don't use the clich√© words like "Jaan", "Miyan" and "Adaab" only a little bit but very wisely. That makes the film very authentic.

Casting deserves great appreciation as each actor feels like he was meant to play that role. Akshaye Khanna and Sanjay Dutt looked almost the same as real Rehman Dakait and Chaudhary Aslam. Arjum Rampal and R. Madhavan were great choices too and I believe we'd see more of their work in the next part. Even small characters like the guy appeared as "Ajmal Kasab" and Rakesh Bedi as "Jamil Jamali", were exceptionally great casting choices as well. Each actor delivered his best performance as well but the crown goes to Akshaye Khanna and Runner-up to Rakesh Bedi. Ranveer Singh's character was literally getting outshined by everyone else around him and I've seen people complaining about it but I believe that was necessary because he is playing a spy and a spy must remain in the shadows, not like those YRF films that just revolve around the spy.

Shashwat Sachdeva nailed it. Literally each track in the film is pure masterclass. The title track was a banger and every other track was amazing. Even the old songs that were edited and used in the films were too good and elevated the scene. The only part where the music felt off track was the track "Shararat" which felt completely useless and out of place. The makers should've skipped that track. Otherwise, the music was great.

Adithya Dhar went beast mode with this film. I mean, I was seen his other two films as well but man, this time, he is unstoppable. Film is over 210 minutes long, which is too much nowadays but still it doesn't get boring or clich√© over even a second. Dividing the entire film into chapters was a great choice as it divides the time duration and the film as a whole never feels too long despite its absurdly long runtime. The use of real footages and recordings, the gut-wrenching violence and the masterful direction made this film a must-watch.

The part where this film felt slightly weak was the the writing. Although the film was great but the lack of thrill element makes it a bit predictable. I mean, the spy gets his way too easily into the gang, which felt a bit off. There isn't any high-tension point in the story where we get thrilled about what would happen next. It's just a bit too straight. Also, the love angle in the film is a bit awkward as well. I mean, they have acknowledged the age gap between the characters of Sara Arjun's and Ranveer Singh's characters in the film and tried to justify it too but still, I felt a bit uncomfortable when they came together. There wasn't any chemistry between the two actors and the makers should've thought of something better.

Finally, I'd say that the film is definitely not for everyone. It's great but for some sections of the audience, it's going to be a tough sit. The film is filled with violence, adult language and some parts of the story are fictionalized. I have researched about the Lyari gang wars years before this film was made and I can say the film is a work of fiction, blend into real life events, much similar to what Tarantino did in "Inglorious Basterds". So, if you can handle some violence and are done with stupid spy films like "Pathaan", "War 2" and other piles of sh#t, I'd highly recommend you to watch it. It might just turn out to become the greatest Indian Spy Film saga because it's Part 2 is near as well and I'm waiting for it.

author: imdbfan-5934137486
title: Big Screen Action with Powerful Acting
text: From the quietest moment to the most explosive sequence, the film maintains a remarkable balance between narrative depth and visual spectacle. Ranveer Singh delivers a riveting performance that anchors the story, while the supporting cast adds layers of complexity and realism. Director Dhar's skillful handling of pacing and tension ensures that every scene contributes to the overarching narrative. Emotional beats are thoughtfully executed, and the final act delivers a satisfying convergence of suspense, action, and moral reckoning.

author: sangitamukherjee-61853
title: Stars Shine in a Thrilling Story
text: The film's layered storytelling allows each character to flourish while driving the narrative forward. Ranveer Singh delivers a nuanced performance that alternates between moral hesitation and fearless action, creating a protagonist whose complexity keeps audiences invested. Sanjay Dutt's commanding presence elevates confrontations and strategic sequences, while Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan provide intelligence and depth to critical scenes. Arjun Rampal's quiet menace and Sara Arjun's vulnerability add tension and humanity, respectively. Aditya Dhar's direction ensures the pacing never falters, blending suspense, intricate plotting, and action. Cinematography and lighting distinguish emotional beats from chaotic sequences, while the score heightens tension. The second half delivers meticulously staged action intertwined with emotional revelations, culminating in a finale that is both thrilling and poignant.

author: PraveshS618
title: Best Spy movie from Indian Cinema
text: Honestly the finest Indian spy movie I've seen. Every technical element - cinematography, color grading, editing, acting and music - is exceptional. Far from glamorizing espionage, it pulls back the curtain and shows Pakistan and the ISI in their true, unvarnished light, dismantling the romantic myths promoted by films like Tiger and Pathaan. The film also documents India's long suffering from terrorist attacks and makes a powerful case that previous governments did not respond as they should have. It doesn't shy away from exposing corruption and anti-national behavior among certain Congress leaders. Compelling, necessary viewing.

author: KrishnaK-4100
title: A Rush of Action and Pure Fun
text: The film opens with a quiet intensity that gradually evolves into a narrative of escalating stakes and emotional complexity. Ranveer Singh's nuanced performance makes the protagonist's journey compelling, balancing moral conflict with raw energy in tense confrontations. Director Dhar's skillful storytelling keeps the audience engaged, blending political intrigue, crime, and personal stakes seamlessly. Every supporting actor contributes meaningfully, ensuring the ensemble cast elevates the narrative rather than merely filling space. The action sequences are choreographed with precision and grit, providing excitement while advancing character arcs. Cinematography captures the visual contrasts between danger-filled streets and private, introspective moments. The soundtrack complements the pacing, subtly enhancing tension and emotional resonance. By the climax, the story achieves a satisfying balance of spectacle and heart, leaving a lasting impression that resonates well beyond the screen.

author: kumarkyle
title: Dhurandhar is a complete masterpiece - Indian filmmaking has truly come a long way with this one.
text:
Dhurandhar is probably one of the most raw and real films seen in a long time. Aditya Dhar's magic is evident in every frame and dialogue. Ranveer Singh delivers a beast of a performance, and his portrayal of infiltrating Pakistan's terror camps is top-notch. R. Madhavan is almost unrecognizable. The man who steals all the limelight and is the true aura king is Akshaye Khanna as Dacait Rehman. Arjun Rampal makes a fiery impact, and Sanjay Dutt is in his natural element. Every member of the supporting cast is convincing, and nothing feels out of place. You genuinely feel like you are in the streets of Pakistan because of the splendid production design.

The first half is close to two hours long and does start to feel stretched at points, with a few scenes that could have been trimmed, but it still builds the right emotions. The second half is crisp and tight. The movie has multiple impactful dialogues that evoke the right rage and emotion. The action sequences deserve all the praise for their merciless and gory nature. Shashwat Sachdev deserves full acclaim for the powerful music and the fusion of old tracks. Overall, Dhurandhar is an absolute blast in theaters. Runtime flaws aside, set aside four hours and have a wild time.

Sanjay Dutt dominates the screen with gravitas and subtle menace, creating an air of unpredictability. Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan deliver intelligent, restrained performances, adding depth to the story's secondary arcs. Arjun Rampal's quiet menace permeates scenes with tension, while Sara Arjun brings a haunting innocence that highlights the stakes. Aditya Dhar's direction orchestrates suspense, dialogue, and high-octane action seamlessly. Cinematography balances expansive cityscapes and intimate interiors, while the score amplifies tension and emotional resonance. The second half escalates with strategic confrontations, shocking twists, and a satisfying, emotionally charged climax.

Dhurandhar is a powerful cinematic experience that leaves a lasting impression through its intensity, craft, and emotional depth. The film stands out for its gripping narrative, which balances raw realism with strong dramatic moments. From the very beginning, Dhurandhar pulls the audience into its world and refuses to let go, maintaining a tight pace while allowing key scenes to breathe and resonate.

The performances are one of the film's greatest strengths. The lead actor delivers a commanding portrayal, capturing both the vulnerability and ferocity of the character with remarkable authenticity. Supporting performances add further depth, making the relationships feel grounded and believable. Each character feels purposeful, contributing meaningfully to the overall story.

Visually, Dhurandhar is striking. The cinematography enhances the mood with well-composed frames, effective lighting, and a color palette that reflects the film's darker themes. The background score complements the narrative perfectly, heightening tension without overpowering the scenes.

What truly elevates Dhurandhar is its thematic weight. The film explores power, resilience, and the consequences of one's choices in a way that feels both relevant and thought-provoking. It does not rely on spectacle alone but uses substance to leave an impact. Overall, Dhurandhar is a bold, well-executed film that deserves appreciation for its storytelling, performances, and technical excellence.

author: manishnair-44565
title: Dhurandar: Hype Aside, This Is Ranveer Singh's Film
text:
Watched Dhurandar in theatres today, and it was a magnificent theatrical experience overall. The plot, characters, and storyline are well conceived, with meaningful connections to real-time scenarios that make everything fall into place seamlessly.

That said, I find it slightly difficult to understand the excessive hype around Akshaye Khanna's performance when it is Ranveer Singh who delivers a smashing act from the very first frame to the last. Interestingly, much like the social-media narrative around the film, Ranveer often remains in the side frame for a large part of the movie, an approach that is understandable and justified given the plot and the presence of larger-than-life characters.

Akshaye Khanna is undoubtedly terrific, and the appreciation he's receiving may be long overdue. His character portrayal is strong and impactful, second only to Ranveer's. But it is Ranveer who truly nails it.

All in all, Dhurandar is a deeply satisfying Bollywood cinematic experience after a long time.

author: virogenpune
title: Class in all
text:
Dhurandar has earned its status as a cult classic because it combines sharp storytelling, bold political commentary, and gripping drama. The film stands out for the way it portrays India's internal political environment and its complex relationship with Pakistan-elements that are woven into the narrative without diluting the entertainment value.

One of the strongest aspects of Dhurandar is its unfiltered depiction of the functioning of the Indian government during the era in which the story is set. The film does not hesitate to show bureaucratic delays, political power struggles, and the influence of the ruling Congress leadership. While the portrayal may feel controversial to some viewers, it adds realism and depth, making the audience reflect on how political decisions impact common citizens.

author: rjmandhane
title: A Masterclass in Cinematic Ambition and Technical Excellence!
text:
Dhurandhar stands as a remarkable achievement in Indian cinema-a sprawling, ambitious spy thriller that demonstrates why patience and meticulous filmmaking can transform a nearly three-and-a-half-hour runtime into an utterly captivating experience. Director Aditya Dhar has crafted a film that refuses to be confined by conventional narrative formulas, instead delivering a visually and thematically rich epic that engages audiences throughout its considerable length while leaving them eagerly anticipating the promised sequel.

From its opening frames, Dhurandhar announces itself as a film of uncommon ambition and technical precision. Aditya Dhar's directorial vision is evident in every meticulously composed frame, transforming the gritty criminal underworld of Karachi's Lyari district into a character unto itself. The director's commitment to immersive world-building creates an atmosphere of palpable tension-one that never relinquishes its grip on the viewer despite the film's substantial length. What could easily have become a cumbersome narrative instead becomes a methodical, deliberate unfolding of a complex geopolitical chess game, where every scene serves a purpose in building the film's layered complexity.

The technical execution deserves singular praise. Cinematographer Vikash Nowlakha delivers visually stunning work that captures both the sweeping vistas and claustrophobic intensity of the underworld setting, plunging viewers directly into the dusty, dangerous alleys of Karachi. The editing by Shivkumar V. Panicker maintains remarkable control over the narrative's rhythm, ensuring that even the film's longest sequences never feel bloated or self-indulgent. This technical precision is crucial-it transforms what could have been an exercise in excessive length into something genuinely cinematic, where every minute finds justification in Dhar's ambitious world-building.

The background score by Shashwat Sachdev deserves particular commendation for its intelligent use of classic, vintage soundtracks that serve as a constant emotional undercurrent throughout the film. Rather than relying on bombastic, intrusive scoring, Sachdev crafts a musical landscape that functions as a pulsating heartbeat beneath the narrative-ensuring tension never dips while maintaining an authentic, lived-in quality. The score's sophisticated composition reveals itself as a character in its own right, subtly elevating emotional beats without ever overshadowing the intimate character moments that anchor this sprawling epic.

The ensemble cast delivers performances of remarkable depth and nuance. Ranveer Singh's portrayal of Hamza Ali Mazhari represents arguably the finest work of his career-a transformation so complete that the actor essentially disappears into the character. His performance navigates the treacherous emotional terrain with surgical precision: displaying steely determination in one moment, raw vulnerability in the next, creating a protagonist whose internal dilemmas feel profoundly relatable despite his extraordinary circumstances. Alongside him, Akshaye Khanna provides a superbly controlled, scene-lifting performance as Rehman Dakait that proves utterly magnetic. The chemistry and friction between these two actors form the electric core of the film, generating some of the most compelling dramatic moments in contemporary Indian cinema.

The supporting cast elevates the entire enterprise. Sanjay Dutt brings an understated menace to his role as SP Chaudhary Aslam, while Arjun Rampal's quiet intimidation creates an unsettling contrast with other performances. R. Madhavan and Akshaye Khanna add intelligence and depth to the ensemble, ensuring that even smaller roles feel fully realized and contribute meaningfully to the narrative's intricate tapestry.

What makes Dhurandhar particularly impressive is its refusal to apologize for its ambition. Rather than trimming itself to fit conventional expectations about commercial cinema, the film invests its considerable runtime in character development, relationship building, and world-establishment that pays extraordinary dividends when the action sequences erupt with brutal precision. The action choreography itself is meticulous, immediate, and entirely free of unnecessary flourish-each confrontation feels earned and meaningful rather than inserted merely for spectacle.

The narrative structure, while occasionally testing audience patience with its deliberate pacing, ultimately justifies its length through sheer craftsmanship. The film's multiple chapters create a visually stylish architecture that compartmentalizes its narrative while maintaining forward momentum. This approach transforms what could have been an unwieldy runtime into a sophisticated, multi-layered exploration of espionage, betrayal, political intrigue, and the moral compromises demanded of those operating in shadowy spaces between nations.

The ending, in particular, proves tantalizing enough to generate genuine anticipation for the promised sequel scheduled for March 2026. Rather than attempting to wrap everything into neat resolution, Dhurandhar leaves narrative threads deliberately open, establishing questions that demand answers and character arcs that cry out for continuation. This approach demonstrates confidence in the property and pays respect to the complexity established throughout the film's runtime.

Dhurandhar is ultimately a film for those willing to surrender themselves to its vision-an immersive, technically brilliant, and deeply engaging experience that rewards patience with spectacle, intelligence, and genuine emotional resonance. It represents a bold statement about what Indian cinema can achieve when a director commits fully to his artistic vision, and the technical and creative team executes with precision and passion. For audiences seeking a film that respects their intelligence while delivering the visceral thrills of a world-class spy thriller, Dhurandhar stands as an essential cinematic experience that justifies every one of its 214 minutes.

author: grumpyfanatic
title: Indian cinema at its PEAKKKK
text:
Dhurandhar is one of those rare films that quietly enters the theatres but leaves an unforgettable mark on everyone who watches it. In a time when cinema is often driven by noise, spectacle, and formula, Dhurandhar stands tall as a reminder of what sincere filmmaking truly looks like. This movie deserves not just our attention, but our respect and support-because every little detail about it is crafted with intention, skill, and a deep understanding of storytelling.

Right from the opening frame, you can sense the care poured into the film's creation. The cinematography sets the tone beautifully, capturing both the intimacy of the characters' emotions and the vastness of the world they inhabit. Nothing feels forced or exaggerated. Even in its simplest shots, the film manages to communicate more than many big-budget blockbusters do with mountains of visual effects. The colour palette, the lighting, the framing-each element contributes to the emotional weight of the story.

The performances are another standout. Every actor, regardless of screen time, adds something meaningful. The lead delivers a layered, honest portrayal that draws you into the character's journey rather than demanding your sympathy. The supporting cast complements this beautifully, grounding the narrative with authenticity. There are no weak links, no over-the-top dramatics-just pure, heartfelt acting.

What truly elevates Dhurandhar is the writing. The screenplay is tight, purposeful, and immersive. Every dialogue serves the narrative; every silence carries meaning. The character arcs unfold organically, giving the audience time to connect with the emotions at play. There's a maturity in the storytelling-no shortcuts, no pandering. The film trusts its viewers and respects their intelligence, which is refreshing.

The background score and music deserve special mention. Rather than overpowering scenes, the music enriches them. Subtle notes enhance delicate moments, while stronger compositions bring depth to the film's more intense sequences. It's the kind of soundtrack that lingers in your mind long after the credits roll.

Equally impressive is the film's production design. Whether it's the interiors of a modest home or the dynamics of a bustling street, everything feels lived-in and real. The attention to detail is astonishing-props, costumes, and locations all reflect the world the characters belong to. It's clear that every department worked with passion and clarity of vision.

author: bansalgaurav
title: Dhurandhar: A Bold, Brilliant Masterpiece That Redefines Reality Through Cinema
text:
Dhurandhar is an absolute masterpiece-a film that doesn't just tell a story, it unravels history, psychology, and geopolitics with rare cinematic courage.

What truly sets Dhurandhar apart is the way the reality of Indo-Pak relationships is shown in an exceptionally imaginative way. Instead of relying on loud nationalism or predictable tropes, the film dives into the grey zones-where intelligence, sacrifice, deception, and diplomacy collide. Every scene feels layered, intentional, and deeply researched, making the narrative gripping without ever feeling exaggerated.

The fact that it is based on true events makes this even more realistic and public-expectation-defying. You constantly feel the weight of authenticity-this isn't fiction designed to please; it's truth designed to provoke thought. The storytelling respects the audience's intelligence, trusting viewers to connect the dots rather than spoon-feeding emotions or conclusions.

Performances are razor-sharp, with characters that feel lived-in rather than written. The tension builds quietly but relentlessly, and the emotional payoff lands hard because it feels earned. The direction deserves special praise for balancing realism with cinematic brilliance-never documentary-dry, never melodramatic.

In short, Dhurandhar is not just a movie; it's an experience. Bold, intelligent, unsettling, and unforgettable.

A film that stays with you long after the credits roll-and one that raises the bar for political and historical cinema in India.

author: parthpandotra

The ensemble cast is a major strength. Ranveer Singh leads with quiet intensity brooding and determined, his character carries the film's emotional weight well. But the film truly shines when Akshaye Khanna steps in: his performance is chilling, compelling and memorable a standout that elevates the entire movie. Supporting actors add depth, and even smaller roles feel lived-in, authentic which adds to the immersive ambience. Technically too, the film is impressive. The cinematography captures both sprawling underworld grime and tense interior moments with equal skill. The background score and music weave through the narrative, amplifying tension, emotion and drama often giving you goosebumps, especially during the climactic scenes. Dhurandhar leaves an impact. It isn't light entertainment it demands attention, but rewards it with raw emotion, high stakes and powerful performances. For those who appreciate bold, intense spy-thrillers that don't compromise on grit or scale, Dhurandhar is not just a film, it's an experience.

author: Divyansh_Verma_2003
title: Gourmet Cinema: A Benchmark Above the Sloppy Universes
text:
Honestly, this film is a pure masterclass. Everything-from the tight, snappy editing and pulse-pounding stunts to the razor-sharp dialogues, committed acting, and decisive direction-delivers exactly what you want a spy espionage film to stylistically have. We've hit a true breakthrough moment in Indian cinema here.

I sincerely hope the audience support matches this quality (because, let's be real, this needs to succeed on a level far beyond the generic, certified-low-effort slops we've seen recently, like War 2 or Gadar 2, and the various sloppy cinematic universes. You get the point!).

The Cast: Unhinged, Unrecognizable, and Phenomenal Akshayae simply out-classed everyone; he absolutely owned the screen!

Ranveer had a perfectly built-up mysterious aura that anchored the story.

All the supporting casts were phenomenal and totally deserved their screen time.

Madhawan was genuinely unrecognizable in his role-a phenomenal transformation.

Dutt's presentation is surprisingly fresh and different, playing out against what most viewers might expect.

Rampal was unhinged in the best way. Given his role, I'm expecting them to explore much more of his story in the next film.

Sara Arjun's character also worked incredibly well. The level of self-awareness in this film is brilliant; they even managed to mock her relationship through a quick dialogue!

Spinoff Potential & The Aditya Dhar Universe There's a serious potential Aditya Dhar Universe building up here, based on a single reference dropped from URI. Time will tell if that's true, but I genuinely think they should pursue it aggressively. They need to teach a lesson to the sloppy cinematic universes we've been subject to in recent years!

Yes, some specific dialogue placements do feel slightly propagandous or overly patriotic, but honestly, that's entirely forgivable when everything else surrounding it-the plot, the pace, the technical execution-has been knocked completely out of the park.

The Technical High & Music I was hooked right from the first shot of the first chapter. The music and the cinematography just instantly pulled me into this world. Right from that opening moment, I knew I was in for a real cinephile's treat, and I never felt the length-absolutely not!

This is the exact testosterone high I was deprived of since Animal. I was actually worried beforehand (from the music launches) that this might end up being too heavy on the love and romance between Sara and Ranveer, but thankfully, that concern didn't materialize.

And a major shout-out to the music department: they hit a home run. So much of the background music and the various background tunes used here are straight-up jams! I am convinced the makers will have to upload them straight to YouTube on public demand very soon.

The Wait for Part 2 is Torture!

LAST BUT NOT LEAST: I absolutely cannot wait for Part 2! March 19 feels way too long, darn it! They should have kept the gap shorter, maybe at eight weeks, or at least closer, like Nishanchi, Gangs of Wasseypur, and Sapta Sagaradaache Ello.

author: dineshkumar16
title: Action That Brings You to the Edge
text: Every frame is meticulously crafted, reflecting Dhar's commitment to storytelling that blends realism with cinematic flair. Ranveer Singh's portrayal of Hamza is magnetic, effortlessly switching between vulnerability, determination, and rage. The film's pacing allows tension to simmer, making every confrontation impactful. Action sequences are choreographed with a brutal elegance that feels earned, not gratuitous. Cinematography captures the stark contrasts of Karachi's underworld, from shadowed alleyways to tense boardrooms. Supporting characters are fully fleshed out, adding moral complexity and emotional depth. The narrative culminates in a finale that's both shocking and satisfying, leaving viewers reflecting on the intricacies of power, loyalty, and betrayal.

author: harshsharma-54638
title: Unapologetic, Raw, and Absolutely Gripping
text:
Dhurandhar is a masterpiece that finally tells the story India needed to hear. Director Aditya Dhar delivers a hard-hitting narrative that does not hold back.

First, the movie beautifully captures the intense struggle of our intelligence agencies. It pays a perfect tribute to the sacrifice of the unknown men who protect us from the shadows.

Second, you will appreciate the unapologetic way the film exposes the political class of 15-20 years ago. It highlights the frustrations faced by our agencies due to lack of political will.

The depiction of Pakistan and the ISI feels chillingly authentic. It peels back the layers to show the "true side" of our neighbors without sugarcoating the threats.

Ranveer Singh and the ensemble cast deliver career-defining performances, bringing the grit and emotional weight required for such a sensitive subject. The pacing is tight and the background score keeps you on the edge of your seat throughout the runtime.

This film is a must-watch for every Indian. March 2026 cannot come soon enough for Part 2.

author: shreyasalkod
title: People who deny reality will hate this movie
text:
When we talk about spy movies in India, it's just about how cool do you want your lead actor to look, and crazy the stunts should be, but never really focus on story or narration or screen play, we as audience never really felt the actually danger these leading hero's were in. But this movie showed the reality, and I could feel the tension of some of the sense as if I lived it, which tells you a lot about how well this movie was made.

Great work.

Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan's performances are subtle yet impactful, reinforcing the story's emotional and strategic complexity. Aditya Dhar's direction balances explosive action sequences, meticulous plotting, and character-driven drama, ensuring that each sequence advances the story meaningfully. Cinematography captures both the sprawling chaos of Karachi and intimate human moments, while the score elevates every suspenseful, emotional, and action-packed moment. The final act delivers high-octane confrontations, strategic revelations, and emotional payoffs that leave audiences thoroughly engaged and exhausted in the best possible way.

author: ayanchakrabarty
title: A Pulse-Pounding Spy Action Thriller That Delivers From Start to Finish
text:
This spy action thriller is an absolute adrenaline rush-slick, sharp, and relentlessly gripping. From the opening frame, it throws you into a world of shadowy intelligence networks, ruthless operatives, and high-stakes missions where every choice feels like life or death. The pacing is electric, balancing explosive action sequences with tense, edge-of-your-seat espionage drama.

All the lead characters are magnetic, carrying the film with a perfect blend of intensity and vulnerability. This is a movie that other directors can learn a lot from and that stands out as a benchmark of espionage films. But what stands out is Akshaye Khanna's performance. His presence elevates the entire film-every expression, every line, every calculated move adds a layer of menace that lingers long after the moment has passed. It's the kind of portrayal that doesn't just challenge the hero-it defines the movie. The choreography of the action scenes is outstanding-clean, brutal, and brilliantly shot, proving that the genre can still surprise with fresh, inventive set pieces. The plot is layered without ever feeling confusing, rewarding the viewer with twists that land and emotional stakes that matter.

What truly elevates the movie is its atmosphere, the double-crosses, and the globe-trotting danger-all executed with cinematic finesse. It's the kind of thriller that keeps your heart racing long after the credits roll.

What brings this to life more is the truthfulness of the director and not something like a fancy spy thriller. Dhurandhar is a must-watch for anyone who loves smart espionage, fierce action, and storytelling that never lets go off the audience's attention.

author: ayushzade
title: best movie ever
text:
.*Dhurandhar* is a compelling cinematic experience that leaves a strong and lasting impression. From the very beginning, the film establishes a confident tone, drawing the audience into a world that feels intense, layered, and thoughtfully constructed. The storytelling is one of its greatest strengths-tight, purposeful, and emotionally engaging without ever feeling rushed or overindulgent. Every scene appears to serve a clear narrative function, which keeps the momentum steady throughout.

The performances are particularly noteworthy. The lead character is portrayed with remarkable depth, balancing strength, vulnerability, and resolve in a way that feels authentic and powerful. Supporting performances further elevate the film, adding nuance and emotional weight to the story. The chemistry between characters feels organic, making their conflicts and alliances genuinely engaging.

Visually, *Dhurandhar* is striking. The cinematography enhances the mood of the film, using framing and lighting to reflect the inner turmoil and determination of its characters. Action sequences, where present, are well-choreographed and impactful, prioritizing storytelling over spectacle. The background score complements the narrative effectively, heightening tension during critical moments while allowing quieter scenes the space to breathe.

What truly sets *Dhurandhar* apart is its thematic depth. The film explores ideas of resilience, ambition, and moral complexity in a way that encourages reflection rather than offering easy answers. It respects the audience's intelligence, trusting viewers to engage with its subtleties and emotional undercurrents.

Overall, *Dhurandhar* is a strong, well-crafted film that combines solid performances, refined technical execution, and meaningful storytelling. It stands as a confident piece of cinema that entertains while also leaving room for thought, making it a highly satisfying watch and a memorable addition to its genre.

author: detectivebarbareek
title: Bangerrrr!!!
text:
First of all salute to all those unknown agents because of them only we are safe here at home. One have ever dreamt of such a movie made by Indian, story and entertainment both are covered very beautifully. Dhurandhar is nothing short of fantabulous-a gripping cinematic experience that leaves a lasting impression long after the credits roll. From its powerful opening sequence to its emotionally charged climax, the film maintains a tight grip on the audience, blending storytelling, performances, and technical brilliance with remarkable finesse.

The narrative of Dhurandhar stands out for its depth and conviction. It is not just a story; it is a statement-bold, intense, and thought-provoking. The screenplay is sharp and well-paced, ensuring that every scene contributes meaningfully to the overall arc. Moments of tension are balanced with emotional depth, making the journey engaging rather than overwhelming.

Performances are one of the film's strongest pillars. The lead actor delivers a commanding performance, embodying the spirit of "Dhurandhar" with raw intensity and nuanced emotions. Supporting characters are equally impactful, adding layers to the story instead of merely filling space. The dialogues are hard-hitting and memorable, often resonating with realism and power.

Visually, the movie is a treat. Cinematography enhances the mood of the film, whether it's portraying conflict, silence, or inner turmoil. The background score deserves special mention-it elevates key scenes without overpowering them, perfectly complementing the narrative flow.

What truly makes Dhurandhar fantabulous is its ability to connect with the audience on multiple levels-emotional, intellectual, and cinematic. It is a film that entertains while making you think, proving that strong content and commercial appeal can go hand in hand. Dhurandhar is a must-watch and a commendable addition to meaningful cinema.

author: amritanshcityhunter
title: Amazing.......
text:
I will just request everyone to watch this movie in theatres , one of the best movies I have watched in my entire life .... I am eagerly waiting for part 2 .

Dhurandhar stands out as one of the most compelling political crime dramas in recent years, blending gritty realism with sharp storytelling. The film dives deep into the underbelly of power, crime, and corruption, presenting a narrative that feels uncomfortably close to real life. What makes Dhurandhar truly engaging is its refusal to oversimplify-every character is layered, morally grey, and driven by believable motivations.

The direction is crisp, maintaining a tense pace without sacrificing depth. The screenplay cleverly intertwines multiple storylines, gradually revealing hidden connections that keep the viewer fully invested. The performances are a major highlight: the lead actors deliver intense, controlled portrayals that bring authenticity to each scene. The supporting cast, too, adds weight, especially in moments dealing with political manipulation and gangland dynamics.

Cinematography effectively captures the rawness of urban chaos, using shadows, tight frames, and atmospheric lighting to build a sense of constant unease. The background score amplifies this tone without ever becoming overwhelming.

Overall, Dhurandhar succeeds as both entertainment and commentary. It doesn't just tell a story-it forces viewers to reflect on the blurred boundaries between governance, crime, and ambition. A must-watch for fans of hard-hitting, intelligent cinema.

author: thybhatta
title: One of the most well made bollywood films of recent times
text:
Dhurandhar is the kind of that deserves the big screen, the grandeur, and the audience hooting along all add to the experience. While some far left critics have labelled them as 'pure propoganda' which much like the film is an exaggeration of truth. Sure, the film is probably not a historical recount, but that aside it is an extemely well produced film.

The background music absolutely bangs, the performances feel real, and Akshay Khanna is going to stay with you long after the film ends. The story and the timelines are woven really well and the action is entertaining.

Where the film falters-and why it isn't a 10/10 for me- Some of the gore doesn't land because the VFX feels off, the bloodied faces look too animated and break the immersion. Sanjay Dutt's intro scene is a green screen shot, the kind that immediately pulls you out of the moment. The film could also have been tighter by at least 5-10 minutes, Ex- Ranveer's club entry could've been straightforward instead of dragging through the "no stags" bit.

But the film deserves an unbiased watch for the sheer production scale. Jaao, you'll have fun.

author: soniya-77807

author: icrkphqg
title: A Bold Tale of Battles and Bonds
text: Dhurandhar is a cinematic powerhouse where every performance feels intentional and precise. author: kashishnada-92389
title: It's a masterpiece, Indian Film Making has come a long way
text:
Wow, just wow. Dhurandhar is a complete masterpiece - Indian filmmaking has truly come a long way with this one. Aditya Dhar is hands down the best director working in Bollywood right now; he doesn't give up on that classic Indian style but elevates it to something world-class. This is pure entertainment, a thrilling ride with an incredible storyline that keeps you hooked from start to finish. I'm not here to judge anyone or anything - it's just a fantastically engaging movie that delivers non-stop tension and excitement.

The acting is great across the board. Ranveer Singh is phenomenal, totally immersed in his character, and the supporting cast - Akshaye Khanna, R. Madhavan, Arjun Rampal, Sanjay Dutt - everyone brings their A-game. Sanjay Dutt's entry is pure fire - that massy, over-the-top moment with the upbeat track, raining bullets, and all that swagger as he takes on the gangsters. And trivia: it's straight-up mature Bollywood cinema in 2025, embracing that heroic, larger-than-life vibe we love, especially in a gritty underworld setup involving arms trafficking and high-stakes ops. Lol, it had the theater erupting!

Character development is spot on; you really feel for these people as the story unfolds. The background music is killer, building the atmosphere perfectly.

Cinematography is stunning - those gritty shots of the underworld pull you right in. (Spoiler ahead, skip if you haven't seen it) One sequence where Ranveer's character sees the ghost of Akshaye Khanna's character is straight out of a Julius Caesar reference, with that Shakespearean betrayal vibe - it's haunting and brilliantly done.

It's a slow burn that reminds me a lot of The Departed, with all the infiltration, betrayals, and moral gray areas. I don't know how historically accurate the representation of the Baloch people is, but I really liked how it was portrayed - felt authentic and added depth.

Sure, there's a bit of bias towards India, but come on, it's made for a mass audience here, and at its core, it's about national identity and pride - religion aside, it's just a solid thriller. The movie shows both sides too, even the failures and complexities on the Indian side, which makes it more balanced than you might expect.

I usually don't watch much Bollywood these days, but this one? It's going to be a cult classic, right up there with Devdas and Gangs of Wasseypur. The level of ambition, execution, and sheer guts is unmatched.

I really hope Aditya Dhar stays original in the second part and doesn't get swayed by critics or the success - keep it as raw and authentic as this one.

One suggestion: it should be dubbed properly in other languages (they can even use AI now for better quality), so international audiences can enjoy it too. But honestly, watch it in the original Hindi with subtitles - that's the best way to experience the dialogues and performances.

If you love intense spy thrillers, go see this in theaters. You won't regret it! Can't wait for Part 2.

author: piyushpadwale
title: Powerful Performances Drive This Hard-Hitting Drama
text:
Finally, I got to watch this film after its glorious run, and without getting into any socio-political commentary, let's just stick to its cinematic qualities, which absolutely make for an entertaining time in the cinema halls.

Intense from the get-go, really well-written dialogues and powerful performances by the starcast, with Akshaye Khanna being a clear standout.

Splitting the entire storyline into chapters, complemented with a great soundtrack and sound design, especially the integration of popular retro songs and giving them a contemporary touch, makes it a very engaging watch and a great directorial move that keeps the screentime balanced and doesn't feel rushed.

Several of the action scenes prove to be extremely gory, brutal, and violent. You would really have to shut your eyes and look away from the screen.

Sprinkled with a few lighthearted moments that lighten the rather intense story. The romantic subplot slows down the story. Even if it is somewhat integral in taking it forward, I found it to be the weakest link in the narrative.

The story also delves into some gut-wrenchingly painful real-life footage that is bound to break you in ways you can't imagine, and leaves you in awe of how it was able to be filmed, given its sensitive and traumatic nature.

The climax is exhilaratingly thrilling, which keeps you hooked to your seats until the penultimate scene. It immediately hooks you and eagerly anticipates the next part.

Given the excitement, I shall definitely find myself in the cinema hall at the time of its release.

author: KrishnamK-7
title: A Fun, Fast-Paced Entertainer with Heart
text:
Dhurandhar delivers exactly what it promises-a lively mix of comedy, drama, and action wrapped in a massy, feel-good package. The film centers around a quirky yet determined protagonist whose chaotic life spirals into a hilarious adventure filled with twists and unexpected emotional moments.

The first half is light, humorous, and engaging, with sharp dialogues and fun character interactions that keep you hooked. The pacing rarely dips, and the director balances comedy and sentiment well.

The lead actor shines with an energetic performance, making even the silliest situations feel enjoyable. Supporting characters add spice, especially in the comedic segments. The cinematography and music match the film's tone-vibrant, colorful, and upbeat.

The second half leans a bit more into drama, but the emotional payoff works. While the plot may not be groundbreaking, Dhurandhar succeeds because of its charm, performances, and its ability to entertain without overcomplicating itself.

author: divakrkumarp
title: One of the Best "True-Event-Inspired" Movies with a Powerful Star Cast, Outstanding Performances, and Exceptional Sound & BGM
text:
Dhurandhar is one of the finest films of recent times and easily stands out as one of the best movies of 2025. Bollywood has rarely attempted storytelling at this scale or depth. The way the film blends real-life-inspired events-such as the Parliament attack and 26/11 Mumbai attacks-into a gripping narrative is both bold and impactful.

The movie powerfully portrays how terror networks operate across borders, showing the interconnections between Pakistan-based terror groups, local criminal gangs, and the alleged involvement of intelligence networks like the ISI, as represented in the film. It also highlights how masterminds operate from across the border while maintaining layers of deniability-an angle that mainstream cinema often avoids or softens.

The second major theme explored in the movie-the circulation of fake currency through routes like Nepal and Bangladesh and the expansion of hawala networks-adds another chilling layer to the story. The film depicts how these underground financial systems helped sustain terror operations for years. It also raises uncomfortable questions about systemic failures and how such networks managed to thrive even as financial systems evolved-points that have been discussed in documentaries and eyewitness accounts over time.

Director Aditya Dhar deserves immense credit for crafting a true cinematic masterpiece. The way he connects every scene, character, and event with precision shows exceptional vision and storytelling maturity. Each sequence feels purposeful, intense, and rooted in realism, making the narrative both engaging and thought-provoking.

The performances elevate the film to another level.

Akshaye Khanna delivers a controlled yet powerful performance.

Ranveer Singh brings intensity and depth to his role.

Arjun Rampal, Sanjay Dutt, and Rakesh Bedi contribute strong, memorable performances that leave a lasting impact.

The sound design and background score perfectly complement the tension and emotional weight of the story, enhancing the cinematic experience throughout.

Final Verdict

Dhurandhar is undoubtedly one of the best films in Indian cinema in recent years-a bold, intense, and must-watch movie for anyone who appreciates powerful storytelling rooted in real-world events.

‚≠ê Highly recommended. Must watch.

author: Avinash29
title: A Brutal, Gripping Masterpiece - The Rise of Dhurandhar Hits Hard! (Spoilers)
text:
I went into Dhurandhar expecting a regular action-crime film, but what I experienced was beyond anything I've watched lately. This movie doesn't just tell a story, it drags you into the brutal world of a man shaped by injustice, betrayal, and survival.

From the opening moments, where the young protagonist watches his world collapse due to a corrupt political system, the film sets the tone: raw, emotional, and unapologetic. The transformation from a helpless boy to the monstrous force known as Dhurandhar is one of the best character arcs I've seen.

The action sequences are not just flashy, they are visceral and meaningful. Every punch, every bullet has a purpose. And that interval block? Absolute goosebumps. The BGM roars like a war cry every time Dhurandhar unleashes his rage, turning simple scenes into iconic moments.

The real shocker is the betrayal twist, the friend he trusted the most ends up being the one who sells him out, pushing him into full-fledged vengeance mode. The final showdown, with Dhurandhar standing alone covered in blood, choosing to embrace the monster society forced him to become, that hit hard. The movie doesn't end with a clean victory. Instead, it leaves us questioning justice, power, and survival.

Despite the violence, the film has a heart, the emotional scenes with his mother and the gut-wrenching loss he faces remind us why he became what he did.

From start to finish, I was fully locked in. 3 hours and 32 minutes felt like a rollercoaster of tension and triumph. The screenplay is tight, the performances are intense, and the music carries the soul of the film.

For me, this is the best movie I've watched in years. Brutal, stylish, emotional, a cinematic punch straight to the heart.

üî• 10/10 - Dhurandhar isn't just a film, it's an experience! üî•

author: Tadikondak
title: Movie is very nice
text:
Dhurandhar is a full-on commercial entertainer that aims to deliver action, comedy, and emotion in a single package. The story follows a bold, street-smart hero who never steps back when it comes to fighting injustice. From the opening sequence itself, the film establishes its mass attitude with larger-than-life heroism and punchy dialogues meant to excite fans who love high-voltage cinema.

The narrative is simple, built around social issues that many people can relate to. Instead of focusing on too many subplots, the screenplay keeps the mission of the protagonist clear: protect the weak and punish the corrupt. This makes the audience quickly connect with the hero's intentions, even if the story becomes predictable at times.

The lead actor is the biggest strength of Dhurandhar. His swag, emotional intensity, and comic timing keep the film entertaining throughout. Even routine scenes become enjoyable because of his strong presence. The heroine doesn't get much screen time, but she adds charm and contributes to a few feel-good romantic and comedy moments. The antagonist is powerful, with a good backstory and strong motives, which helps create a convincing clash between good and evil.

The first half is filled with fun comedy, stylish action scenes, and energetic songs. The interval twist successfully builds curiosity for what comes next. The second half focuses more on emotional drama and the hero's personal struggle. A few scenes feel lengthy and could have been trimmed, but the climax once again raises the energy with intense stunts and a meaningful message.

Technically, the film scores well. The background music enhances every action block. Cinematography captures both the mass crowds and emotional close-ups effectively. Songs are catchy, especially the hero introduction song and the celebratory track.

Overall, Dhurandhar may not offer a new storyline, but it definitely delivers solid entertainment. Fans of mass action films will enjoy its energy, heroism, and crowd-pleasing moments.

author: Anurag25
title: A Must Watch Spy Thriller
text:
Dhurandhar is one of those rare Hindi spy thrillers that grips you from the opening frames and never loosens its hold. It unfolds against a backdrop of gang wars terror networks and geopolitical tensions yet always keeps its focus on human emotions and moral dilemmas. The narrative builds steadily layering tension and clues rather than rushing from set piece to set piece so by the time the bigger operations erupt you are completely invested in what happens to each character.

Ranveer Singh is a true chameleon here disappearing into his part instead of playing a loud showy hero. His performance is beautifully supported by a stellar ensemble Akshaye Khanna, Sanjay Dutt, Arjun Rampal, R Madhavan and others all feel perfectly cast and get moments that genuinely stand out. No role feels wasted as even supporting characters add meaningful weight to the story.

What elevates Dhurandhar further is Aditya Dhar direction and the film technical polish. The use of grounded action street level sequences real world style events and news like footage gives the film a sense of authenticity that makes several scenes genuinely spine chilling. Sound design is used cleverly especially during attacks and interrogations to pull you right into the chaos and fear of the situation.

Dhurandhar is not just loud patriotism or glossy espionage. It is a tense emotional and intelligent thriller that respects the audience intelligence. If you are tired of formulaic action films and want a big screen experience that combines sharp writing powerful performances and realistic politics this movie is absolutely worth your time. Grab your friends or family and catch it in a theatre while you can. You will walk out discussing scenes and characters for days.

Sources.

author: ravatarjun
title: Thrills, Drama, and Unforgettable Stars
text: The story slowly tightens its grip on the audience, revealing a labyrinth of political intrigue, betrayal, and underworld strategy. Ranveer Singh's performance is layered and immersive, balancing physical intensity with emotional nuance, making his journey relatable yet extraordinary. Sanjay Dutt's commanding presence provides a strong anchor to the narrative, while Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan offer intelligent, understated performances that enrich the story's depth. Arjun Rampal's quiet menace keeps suspense high, and Sara Arjun's emotional moments provide heart and humanity. Director Aditya Dhar seamlessly integrates action, strategy, and psychological tension, orchestrating breathtaking sequences that feel both realistic and cinematic. Cinematography captures sweeping city landscapes, intimate interior moments, and high-stakes action with equal mastery. The music elevates suspense, accentuating the tension in both quiet and explosive scenes. The final sequences deliver a masterful blend of action, emotional resonance, and narrative closure, leaving a lingering impact.

author: surbhi-80
title: Evoking past emotions of terror attacks
text:
Watching Dhurandhar was far more than a three-hour ride on a popular filmi rollercoaster where Akshaye Khanna's dancing or violence takes the spotlight. It was an emotional, heartfelt journey through three decades of terror incidents that anyone born in India in the 1980s has grown up witnessing. I was fortunate to have never been directly in harm's way-or, when I was, to have escaped unscathed-but the shadow of those attacks left deep, invisible scars, a constant undercurrent of fear that you never know when tragedy might strike.

The opening scene transported me straight back to the 1990s, to the Air India flight hijacking that ended at Kandahar. The hijackers demanded the release of terrorists, and the nation watched helplessly as Home Minister Jaswant Singh escorted them to comply. The tragedy of Ripin Katyal, a husband returning from his honeymoon, slashed and left to die in front of his wife, flashed vividly in my mind. Those moments, seen through the lens of news channels, left an entire nation frustrated, powerless, and questioning its ability to confront the unimaginable.

The IC 814 hijacking instilled in me a lifelong fear of flying. I later read the account by Captain Devi Sharan, whose description of what unfolds during a hijack cemented my unease. Since then, airports feel less like gateways to adventure and more like spaces where vigilance outweighs excitement; more than my passport, I scan my surroundings; more than the thrill of takeoff, I feel the anxious pull of "what if?"

The attack on the Indian Parliament was another stark reminder that safety is never guaranteed. While Dhurandhar doesn't attempt to depict every bomb blast that Delhi or Mumbai endured, it evokes the terror of those days. I recall leaving Sarojini Nagar market when a blast ripped through the crowded streets at peak hour. My mother's voice, trembling with fear upon seeing the news, still echoes in my memory. Simultaneously, a blast struck Karol Bagh, where my father usually spent his evenings. Phones went unanswered; my brother dashed through streets on his scooter. By sheer luck, my father returned home unharmed.

The film moves on to the Mumbai attacks of 26/11, recreating two harrowing days of terror broadcast live on Indian television. Pools of blood at Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus, bullets tearing through innocent lives, explosions in the Taj Mahal Palace Hotel-the horror played out in real-time, with media coverage sometimes inadvertently guiding the terrorists. Watching these scenes unfold on screen is chilling, not as fiction, but as a haunting echo of lived reality.

Perhaps Dhurandhar resonates so deeply not only because of its powerful performances but because it strikes a nerve with those of us who have lived through these moments. It reminds us of fear, loss, and the desperate hope that terror might one day be over. For many, it is more than a film; it is a mirror reflecting decades of collective trauma and the resilience to carry on with life.

Director Aditya Dhar orchestrates suspenseful plotting, explosive action, and narrative twists with precision. Cinematography captures both sprawling urban chaos and intimate character beats, while the score punctuates tension and emotion. By the finale, the film delivers both adrenaline and cathartic emotional resolution.

author: pariyanshitomar
title: Adrenaline Rush with Every Scene
text: The film's strength lies in its ability to balance high-octane action with deep emotional resonance. The lead actor commands the screen, while the ensemble cast adds depth and nuance.
