author: kumarprasun-12547
title: Very eye opening and based on true incidents
text: This movie is based on the true incidents of terror network operating in Pakistan and plotting several terror attacks on India, particularly Hindus, this movie touches a major aspect of spy movies and shows the true condition of an Indian spy whose undercover mission is to infiltrate gangs operating in Pakistan who work with terrorists and supply them with arms and ammunition.

author: ArvantP
title: Must Watch Movie
text:
Aditya Dhar's Dhurandhar after URI and Baramulla, honestly feels like the best spy movie India has produced in years. It isn't loud, flashy, or cartoonish like the Pathan, Tiger, War universe; instead, it is grounded, sharp and terrifyingly close to real life. The film shows how intelligence officers actually think, plan, make mistakes, recover, and put their lives on the line for the country. What impressed me most was how the movie connects every mission with real-world tensions, cross-border infiltration, and the emotional pressure our agents carry. It highlights the cruelty and brutality performed by extremist terrorist groups against innocent Indian citizens, without unnecessary exaggeration. The scenes of captives, bomb factories, and hidden bases feel painfully real, and Akshaye Khanna's calm intensity mixed with Ranveer Singh's raw energy makes the narrative even more gripping. Their performances feel less like acting and more like they are living the mission especially in the interrogation sequences and the final infiltration scene.

What truly sets Dhurandhar apart is that it respects the idea of a spy thriller. Instead of turning heroes into superheroes like in Pathan, Tiger, or War, this film shows strategy instead of slow-motion, intelligence instead of random action, and purpose instead of just style. When Ranveer silently tracks a terror cell through the narrow lanes or Akshaye Khanna breaks down the enemy network using pure mind power, you feel the tension in your stomach. The movie also doesn't shy away from exposing the dark realities of cross-border extremist groups operating from Pakistan, how they manipulate young minds, and the inhuman torture methods they use. But the film is careful it targets terrorists, not ordinary people, and that realism makes the story more powerful. The last 30 minutes are enough to make you sit frozen in your seat, thinking about the sacrifices made by the unseen heroes of India. For me, "Dhurandhar" is not just a spy movie; it is a reminder of a world we choose not to see, and a tribute to the people who protect us without asking for credit. A full 10/10 from my side.

author: harshawasthi90
title: Best Spy Movie Bollywood has ever offered.
text:
The film runs for 3.5 hours, yet not for a moment does it lose momentum. It holds your attention with an almost hypnotic grip.

Special praise for the BGM. The way it blends with the narrative rhythm, and the way it rises and recedes with the tension, is genuinely masterful.

Outstanding performances Most compelling performances, in order:

Arjun Rampal - Major Iqbal Jameel Jamali - Jameel Jamali Akshaye Khanna - Rehman Dakait Ranveer Singh - Hamza Ali Mazhari Madhavan - Ajay Sanyal

The tight close-up shots, especially the ones capturing Ranveer Singh's micro-expressions, are brilliantly executed.

The production design feels remarkably authentic. Even the green-screen sequences have a level of realism rarely seen in mainstream cinema.

What I particularly appreciate is the film's unapologetic portrayal of Pakistan and the ISI.

This is a refreshing change from the sanitised, commercially driven crap seen in Jawan, Ek Tha Tiger, and similar franchises.

When the film ended, it genuinely caught me off-guard.

It felt as though I did not want it to finish, because the rising momentum had created such an immersive flow.

Please watch it.

Support it.

Make it a blockbuster,

so that more filmmakers gain the confidence to attempt bold and uncompromising storytelling.

Improvements I felt.. 1. Action sequences could be shorter and more grounded.

2. Romantic songs can be avoided to maintain the narrative flow.

3. Movies should have ended on an unresolved moment, making the audience want to return badly for the 2nd part.

(Something like the curiosity created by Why did Kattappa kill Baahubali? Just saying..)

author: AnubhavM-05
title: This is the perfect way to expose Atankistan.
text:
The story is set against the backdrop of real historical events, specifically the 1999 IC-814 Kandahar hijacking and the 2001 Indian Parliament attack. Following these attacks, Indian intelligence chief Ajay Sanyal (played by R. Madhavan and loosely based on Ajit Doval) decides that India needs to stop playing defense. He devises a long-term covert operation to infiltrate the "terror factory" inside Pakistan.

The Mission: Operation Dhurandhar Sanyal recruits a young prisoner with no family and a violent past named Jaskirat Singh Rangi (Ranveer Singh). Sanyal trains him to become a lethal "weapon" and gives him a new identity: Hamza Ali Mazari.

Hamza is sent to Lyari, a notorious neighborhood in Karachi, Pakistan, known for its gang wars. His mission is to infiltrate the local underworld, which is being used by the Pakistani state (ISI) to fund and organize terror attacks against India.

Infiltration & Rise Hamza manages to join the gang of Rehman Dakait (Akshaye Khanna), a feared Balochi gangster who wants to transition into a legitimate political leader. Hamza wins Rehman's trust by saving his family and proving his loyalty. Over time, Hamza rises through the ranks to become Rehman's right-hand man.

While deep undercover, Hamza navigates a complex web of power: Rehman Dakait: The gangster with political ambitions.

**Jameel Jamali (Rakesh Bedi): A corrupt politician using the gangs for votes.

**Major Iqbal (Arjun Rampal): An ISI officer who orchestrates terror plots against India using the gang's resources.

**SP Chaudhry Aslam (Sanjay Dutt): A ruthless Pakistani cop (the "Encounter Specialist") trying to clean up Lyari, who becomes a major obstacle for Hamza and Rehman.

The Turning Point Hamza falls in love with Yalina (Sara Arjun), the daughter of the politician Jameel Jamali, complicating his mission. However, the emotional core of the movie shifts during the 26/11 Mumbai attacks. Hamza is forced to watch helplessly as his "bosses" in Pakistan celebrate the attacks on his homeland. This fills him with rage and solidifies his resolve to destroy the network from within.

Ending Explained The Betrayal The climax sees the lines between loyalty and duty blur. Hamza uses the conflict between the police (SP Chaudhry Aslam) and the gangsters to his advantage. Although Hamza has built a brotherhood with Rehman Dakait, his duty to India comes first.

After Rehman is injured in a confrontation with SP Aslam, Hamza takes him to safety-only to reveal his true allegiance. In a heart-wrenching scene, Hamza kills Rehman Dakait, fulfilling the first major step of his mission. This is significant because he has to kill the man who treated him like a brother to serve his country.

The Cliffhanger The movie does not end with a "happily ever after." After killing Rehman, Hamza returns to his cover life. In the final scene, he is seen looking at a secret diary/list of targets. Rehman Dakait was just the first name. He crosses it out, revealing the next major target: Major Iqbal (the ISI officer).

The film ends with the promise of Dhurandhar Part 2 (slated for March 2026), where Hamza will likely go after the state-sponsored actors (ISI) directly.

Real-Life Inspirations The movie is a fictionalized account but draws heavily from reality: Hamza Ali Mazari: A fictional deep-cover agent.

Ajay Sanyal: Based on India's National Security Advisor, Ajit Doval.

Rehman Dakait: Based on the real-life Lyari gangster Rehman Dakait, who was a central figure in the Karachi gang wars.

SP Chaudhry Aslam: Based on Chaudhry Aslam Khan, a real Pakistani police officer known for his encounters against terrorists and gangsters.

author: VishalsinhZala-8
title: This is what cinema should be RAW & REAL
text:
Dhurandhar is a film that stands apart from most modern spy thrillers because of one simple reason - its rawness. Unlike the glossy, over-stylized, over-dramatic movies like Pathaan or Tiger 3, this film doesn't try to sell fantasy. It doesn't hide behind unnecessary glamour, childish heroism, or diplomatic sugar-coating. Instead, Dhurandhar presents a world that feels brutally real, emotionally heavy, and disturbingly close to what an actual covert operation might look like.

What I appreciated the most is how the movie handles the portrayal of geopolitical tension. It doesn't pretend that everything is rosy between neighbouring nations. It doesn't create fake friendship arcs or forcefully show the enemy country as "good" just to make the plot politically correct. Instead, it shows the harsh mindset, hostility, and underground operations that exist in the world of intelligence. The movie doesn't generalize people - it targets the systems, organizations, and power structures that fuel conflict. And in that sense, the film hits with a level of truthfulness that mainstream spy films usually avoid.

Ranveer Singh's performance adds a layer of intensity that makes you feel the danger and brutality of espionage. His character isn't a superhero - he bleeds, breaks, doubts, and still fights. The film's atmosphere remains dark, realistic, and grounded from start to end, without jumping into unrealistic stunts or cringe dialogues seen in many commercial spy movies.

The biggest strength of Dhurandhar is its commitment to authenticity. The cinematography, locations, interrogations, military operations, and emotional stakes are all built with a sense of reality, not Bollywood-style exaggeration. It creates tension that feels earned and situations that feel possible.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a gripping, unapologetically real spy thriller that refuses to compromise its truth for entertainment. If you prefer grounded storytelling over flashy nonsense, this movie is absolutely worth watching.

author: AARYANT-11

The pacing in the first half can feel stretched, but once the story locks in, it becomes a compelling and immersive ride. Overall, Dhurandhar is an ambitious and stylish espionage drama that rewards patient viewers with powerful moments, strong performances, and a rich narrative world.

title: A Bold Mix of Stars and Intense Drama

author: abhisheksingh-27708
title: Perfect movie
text:
Perfect for me and for me aditya dhar had done great job and Akshay khanna had done a Here is a "Dhurandhar" (powerful/impactful) review of the recent blockbuster "Animal" (assuming you are looking for a review of a high-impact, intense film).

Animal: A Visceral, Unapologetic Beast Sandeep Reddy Vanga's "Animal" is not just a film; it is a seismic event in Indian cinema. It is a "Dhurandhar" entry in the genre of crime dramas-bold, bloody, and brutally intense. At its core, the movie is a twisted father-son saga, but wrapped in layers of hyperbolic violence and toxic masculinity that refuse to apologize for their existence.

Ranbir Kapoor delivers the performance of a lifetime. As Ranvijay, he is terrifyingly calm yet explosively violent, shedding his chocolate-boy image for something far darker. His transformation from a neglected son to an obsessive protector is chilling. Anil Kapoor brings a weary gravity to the role of the father, while Bobby Deol, despite limited screen time, leaves a haunting impact as the mute antagonist.

The background score is thunderous, elevating the action sequences into operatic chaos. However, the film is not without flaws. The runtime is punishing, and the screenplay occasionally drags under its own weight. Critics may argue the morality is questionable, but as a piece of cinema, it is undeniable. "Animal" is a wild, untamed beast that roars loud enough to shake the foundations of Bollywood.

Would you like me to write a review for a different specific movie or in a specific style (e.g., funny, critical)?

author: Mangesh303
title: A Star-Packed Saga with Explosive Twists
text: The film's initial sequences introduce viewers to a tense, layered universe where loyalty and betrayal intersect. Ranveer Singh's performance is magnetic-his subtle glances and controlled expressions in the early intelligence-gathering scenes communicate more than dialogue ever could. Sanjay Dutt brings a formidable presence, making scenes of confrontation electric with authority. Akshaye Khanna's sharp timing and R Madhavan's nuanced expressions enrich the ensemble, providing depth to each interaction. Arjun Rampal's menace is understated but palpable, and Sara Arjun's emotional vulnerability heightens the stakes. Aditya Dhar orchestrates a perfect balance of narrative tension, strategy, and action sequences, from close-quarters fights to sprawling chase sequences. Cinematography captures the dichotomy of violent chaos and intimate personal drama, while the soundtrack amplifies suspense. The second half escalates with relentless intensity, delivering emotional and adrenaline-fueled payoffs in equal measure.

author: nikhilkainturae
title: Omg whaatt a movie
text:
If you are tired of watching spies flying in cars, romancing enemy agents, and defying physics while saving the world, Dhurandhar is the wake-up call you've been waiting for. This isn't just a movie; it is a raw, gritty, and unapologetic documentation of what actual intelligence work looks like.

You hit the nail on the head compared to the glossed over narratives we've been fed by the likes of the "Spy Universe," this film is a brutal reality check. Unlike other films that try to balance the narrative by showing "good people on both sides" or romanticizing the enemy for the sake of diplomacy, Dhurandhar has the guts to call a spade a spade. It doesn't sugarcoat the enemy's intent. There is no forced romance track diverting from the mission. Ranveer's character, Hamza, isn't there to sing songs, he is there to dismantle a terror network from the inside. Instead of gravity defying bike jumps, we get actual tradecraft infiltration, encryption, silence, and the suffocating pressure of being undercover in Karachi. The tension in the 26/11 sequences is more heart pounding than any CGI explosion. The film dares to show the detailed planning and infrastructure of terror across the border without filtering it for "mass appeal." It shows the ugliness of the threat India faces, which is the "reality" many are too afraid to accept.

Dhurandhar exposes the "candy-floss espionage" of YRF for what it is entertainment divorced from reality. This film respects the audience's intelligence and the sacrifices of our actual unsung heroes.

It's not just a must watch; it's a history lesson wrapped in a thriller. If you care about the truth, you watch Dhurandhar. The rest can keep watching their cartoons.

text:

Living among gangsters, criminals, and power-hungry leaders, Hamza must carefully earn their trust while secretly working to stop a rising terror operation. What makes Dhurandhar truly stand out is the way it presents this world with such authenticity. The violence, the politics, and the emotional pressure Hamza faces all feel real and intense. The action scenes are extraordinary yet believable, and the performances bring a strong emotional weight to the narrative.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a powerful, fast-paced thriller that delivers both heart and heavy realism-an absolutely compelling watch.

author: monikaprasadroy
title: Heavy, Haunting, and Impossible to Ignore
text:
You know a film is compelling - truly a banger meant for an intelligent audience - when the experience inside the theatre itself becomes a statement.

When people are already seated well before the film begins, not because they were early, but because they didn't want to miss a second. When not a single phone rings, no screens light up, no restless scrolling - just collective stillness. When no one gets up, not even once, not for water, not for comfort, not for distraction - even as legs go numb and time stretches. When there's no cross-talk, no commentary, no casual reactions, because everyone is too absorbed to speak. You know it's working when the only sounds in the theatre are sharp gasps, involuntary screams, and silence so heavy it presses on your chest - especially during those brutal scenes where it almost feels like the audience itself is enduring the pain on screen.

That's what Dhurandhar does.

From the very first shot, the film doesn't ease you in - it pulls you under. There's no warm-up, no cushioning. You're submerged immediately, watching continuously, without blinking, without relief. Time becomes irrelevant. Three and a half hours pass, your body protests, your legs go numb - and yet you don't flinch for even a second, because the screen refuses to loosen its grip.

The background score and songs are absolute bangers - not decorative, not loud for effect, but perfectly timed, one after the other, amplifying tension, dread, rage, and inevitability. The music doesn't tell you what to feel - it locks you into it.

What's remarkable is how long it takes to realise what kind of film you're watching.

At some point - much later - it hits you: this is a villain-driven movie.

And even more unsettling - the villains are the main characters.

The film doesn't announce this. It lets you discover it slowly, uncomfortably, once you're already emotionally invested. That delayed realisation is part of its brilliance.

There are moments that don't just disturb - they linger physically.

Your blood boils.

Your throat tightens.

You unexpectedly shed a tear or two.

The Kandahar attack sequence - the neck slicing - is horrifying not because it's graphic, but because it's matter-of-fact, stripped of dramatics. The torture sequence involving Arjun Rampal isn't sensational - it's procedural, controlled, and therefore far more unsettling. And the 26/11 audio recordings playing against a red screen - that moment doesn't scream at you. It haunts you.

What makes Dhurandhar successful isn't just scale, performances, or technical finesse. It's the way it demands attention and then earns it completely. It trusts its audience to sit with discomfort, to process moral ambiguity, to endure silence, brutality, and restraint without spoon-feeding emotion.

This is not a film you casually watch.

It's a film you experience collectively, in a theatre, in silence, in tension, in shared unease.

And when the lights come back on, you don't walk out buzzing or cheering.

You walk out quieter. Heavier. Still processing.

That's how you know it worked.

author: theabhilove
title: Title: A Tense, Gritty Thriller Driven by Strong Performances
text:
Dhurandar is a gripping geopolitical thriller that blends high-stakes espionage with an emotionally charged narrative. Set against the backdrop of cross-border terrorism, the film follows an Indian intelligence operative who infiltrates hostile networks in Pakistan to stop a covert terror operation aimed at destabilizing India.

What works best in Dhurandar is its ability to maintain constant tension without resorting to unnecessary dramatization. The screenplay is tight, the pacing steady, and the atmosphere consistently intense. The film avoids simplistic patriotism and instead presents espionage as a world of moral ambiguity, personal sacrifice, and psychological pressure.

The lead actor delivers one of his finest performances-controlled, layered, and convincingly sharp as a field operative trained to think several steps ahead. The supporting cast, particularly the antagonist network's handler, adds depth and menace without feeling caricatured.

Technical execution is also commendable. The cinematography captures the covert world with muted tones and shadowy interiors, while the background score elevates moments of suspense without overpowering them. Action sequences are grounded and realistic, staying true to the genre.

If the film falters anywhere, it is in a few predictable story beats and an overlong second act. However, the final payoff is satisfying, with a climax that feels both thrilling and emotionally resonant.

Overall, Dhurandar stands out as an engaging spy thriller that combines geopolitical realism with cinematic flair. Fans of intelligence-driven stories like Baby, Raazi, or Special 26 will find plenty to appreciate here.

author: sanjubhat
title: A path breaking masterpiece .. unmissable!!
text:
Dhurandhar: An honest introspection.

Finally watched #dhurandhar .. pretty late compared to others who must've watched it in the first week itself . I was reading and watching the hype around the film , the talk abt Akshaye Khanna's Rehman Dacait overshadowing Ranveer Singh's Hamza and finally after a misadventure that i shall mention at the end , I finally managed to catch the film in the theatre.

My honest perspective... Film was fantastic .. a 3.5 hr film that keeps u hooked from start to end .. kuch toh hoga na .. Aditya Dhar .. hats off to u bro .. grt film indeed .. Quentin Tarantino ka chaap dikhayi deta hai isme, yet retaining its regional identity üëåüëå.

Abt the Akshaye vs Ranveer hype ... All bullshit according to me. Both actors have held their own and r brilliant in their own right!! üëåüëç .. each having their own space in the film with extremely well written characters. No one overshadows the other in any form. Sab bakwaas hai !!

The film is much more than just these 2 characters.. Rakesh Bedi as the devious politician, Sanjay Dutt as the encounter specialist cop , Arjun Rampal as the ISI chief whose hatred for India sends a shiver down ur spine, R Madhavans portrayal of Ajit Doval and Gaurav Gera as Ranveers handler in Pak - each and every one has given it their all to make it a memorable watch.

Now abt my misadventure.. going with the flow ,i had booked my tickets for 7th Dec and enthusiastically went to the cinema hall to watch it.

author: imdbfan-7529837661

author: imdbfan-8417256431
title: Every Frame Bursting With Passion
text: From start to finish, Dhurandhar exhibits storytelling at its finest. The lead's portrayal of a conflicted and determined character feels lived-in, striking a balance between intensity and vulnerability. The director's genius is evident in the way multiple storylines converge seamlessly, keeping the narrative coherent despite the intricate plot. The supporting cast shines in moments that could easily have been overlooked, proving that every character has significance. The film's action sequences are not just visually thrilling but narratively purposeful, while the background score heightens the tension without overshadowing the performances. Cinematic techniques like slow-motion, sharp cuts, and immersive camera angles create a dynamic yet grounded experience. The geopolitical and underworld backdrop adds realism and weight, making the stakes feel immediate and impactful. Every scene demonstrates the director's meticulous planning, ensuring that even subtle moments have lasting impact. Dhurandhar is a testament to what intelligent, performance-driven filmmaking can achieve.

author: sakshi-99681

Cinematography and score work hand-in-hand, creating a palpable atmosphere of tension. Secondary roles are compelling, adding depth to the narrative and highlighting the broader stakes. The story seamlessly blends political intrigue with personal drama, culminating in a second-half payoff that is both shocking and satisfying. This film showcases the perfect balance of intelligence, suspense, and visceral thrill, leaving a lasting impression on viewers.

author: Bhavya-970
title: Show me a better movie and we will debate about it!
text:
Ranveer Singh in Dhurandhar feels like pure controlled chaos in the best way. There's an intensity to him that doesn't scream for attention but still dominates every frame. After a while, you stop seeing "Ranveer the star" and start seeing a man who looks dangerous, unpredictable, and mentally ten steps ahead of everyone else. His eyes do half the acting - cold, sharp, and unsettling - and that's what makes the character stick.

The hype isn't just about action or scale; it's about how restrained yet explosive he feels. When he finally snaps, it hits harder because of the calm he carries before it. This role reminds people why Ranveer is considered one of the most fearless performers of his generation - he doesn't play safe, he commits fully. Dhurandhar feels less like a comeback and more like a statement: Ranveer Singh is back, and he's not here to be comfortable, he's here to be unforgettable üî•

author: reddygeetha14
title: Courageous, Bold, Brilliant is what Aditya Dhar's Dhurandhar is
text:
A homage to all the unnamed men and women who have been risking more than just their lives while working every single moment for the country that they wish to protect and for the people that won't even know their names. The movie is supposed to be lengthy but when you're in the theatre watching the movie, you don't even realise when the 3.34 hours were up. The movie got the entire theatre whooping & cheering at the end. It tells you how crisp and perfect the direction & narration were. Some of the real life events that Dhar cleverly interwove with the story was honestly beautiful. It hits you hard. How much we have lost. How many lives were lost especially because of our own people. While the direction is clearly the star of the movie, the actors are not far behind. Ranveer Singh proved yet again why he's the most versatile actor of his generation. He proved yet again how he is an actor with a calibre no other current generation or his can come close to. Especially in the first half, the character needs subtlety & patience. He delivers so well. You only see Hamsa on the screen throughout. Madhavan, Akshay & Arjun were each terrific in the respective roles that they play. Each of their characters get an arc and a story that they don't feel like side characters which is also something Aditya did well. The movie does so well to not just tell the story & sacrifice behind every single brave heart that sacrifice everything for the country but he does it in a way that keeps the audience engaged & invested. He ensured we leave the theatres feeling extremely proud yet also a little ashamed that we weren't aware of things that had before transpired or contributed to the silence that once was part of India's response to anything Terror related.

There is one sentence that actually is powerful.

"Pakistan has always been India's second biggest problem, it's first problem are the very people that it tries to protect"

The movie has references to the governments lack or response or wanting a government that's brave to respond to the terrorists in their own language but if you want to call it nationalism or anti Pakistan or pro-BJP that's you trying to run away from the truth. Propaganda is when you sell lies, not when you speak the truth.

author: aakashderia
title: Truth That Triggered the Noise
text:
When the first trailer dropped, I was set on watching Dhurandhar first day, first show.. the music itself was enough to pull me in. Circumstances delayed that, in the meantime I came across reviews from a couple of entitled commentators who chose distortion over honesty. Still, I went in with an open mind and I'm glad I did.

The film lands because it dares to show a truth that many prefer not to see. Yes, it's dramatized , because it's cinema, not a courtroom document.. but the core is unmistakably clear. And let's be honest: the Indian audience isn't na√Øve. Public hai, sab jaanti hai.

What's ironic is how the movie stayed in the crosshairs of so-called "intellectual" reviewers and even a certain loud German Shepherd from YouTube only for their outrage to backfire spectacularly. The noise pushed more people into theatres, and the result speaks for itself ..a 1000-crore film.

I watched Dhurandhar again..not out of spite, but appreciation. This is proof that truth, even when inconvenient, finds its audience .. And no amount of barking can change that.

author: raja-mishra7
title: A gripping, grounded Espionage Masterpiece that finally lets its spies blend in, its villains feel real.
text:
Dhurandhar is built on a genre I care about deeply: the serious spy thriller - closer to Body of Lies or The Departed than to the usual glossy "RAW loves ISI anti-hero" template that Hindi cinema keeps recycling.

For years, our films have been oddly shy about showing Pakistan's deep-state ecosystem for what it is.

We either romanticise it, or soften key players into "good at heart but misguided" figures at the very top of a security apparatus that, in reality, has been repeatedly linked to terror networks. Dhurandhar, very deliberately, refuses that soft focus. It treats the Pakistani establishment and its proxies with a cold, clinical lens, while still keeping the story accessible to a mainstream audience. That alone makes it feel like a generational correction.

Is it perfect? No. At three and a half hours, the film is long on runtime but still feels rushed in parts, as if it's constantly jumping from frame to frame rather than letting some moments breathe. There is enough material here for three films instead of two, and you can sense that density in how quickly some arcs are wrapped.

Where it really shines is in the writing. The core script and screenplay are sharply structured: real-life antagonists and events are woven with fictional protagonists in a way that feels disturbingly plausible. The Lyari gang wars give the film its spine. We see just enough of that brutality to understand the stakes and the moral rot, but the director stops short of Game of Thrones level gore. That restraint is not timidity; it's craft.

The direction, overall, is of genuinely international standard. Compressing a brutal, politically loaded reality into one contained narrative, keeping the context clear and the emotional throughline intact across such a long film, is no small feat. The filmmaker has already proved himself with Uri, and this only underlines that he is a craftsperson to track very closely.

The casting is interesting, and uneven.

R. Madhavan is superb as Sanyal, clearly inspired by someone the whole nation really admires. It's technically a cameo, but he walks in with such quiet authority that the character feels much larger than his screen time.

Ranveer Singh's work here is more complicated to talk about. On the surface, he doesn't "stand out" - and that is exactly why he works as a spy. If your undercover operative is constantly dancing, showing off, and drawing attention, he's failing at the job. Dhurandhar does something almost embarrassingly obvious yet rarely done in our cinema: it remembers that spies are meant to disappear into the crowd, not turn espionage into a spectacle. Ranveer leans into that idea. When he is in the backdrop, thinking more than speaking, you get a glimpse of a credible field operative who relies on brain over brute force or CGI heroics. At the same time, his innate screen presence is undeniable; it's rare among current "stars," and he remains, purely on craft and range, one of the finest actors of his generation. The jarring contrast, of course, is between that disciplined performance and his often chaotic, attention-seeking public persona - but on screen, in this film, the work holds.

Sara Arjun is competent and does what the part asks, but the romantic or emotional chemistry with Ranveer never fully catches fire. It's not bad - just oddly flat for what the story could have supported and you will sense that it is not the age-gap that has caused the lapse.

Sanjay Dutt, for me, is the weak link. He physically resembles the real-world figure he's based on, which helps, but the performance feels undercooked. You keep wishing someone like Kumud Mishra had been cast instead; he could have brought the same menace with far more nuance.

Arjun Rampal and Rakesh Bedi are both on point. Rampal has an ominous, slow-burn presence that clearly sets him up for a larger role in the sequel. Bedi does lecherous and morally greasy exactly the way the part demands, without drifting into caricature.

Danish Pandor is convincing in the limited time he gets. The casting for the Uzair Baloch counterpart is smart: you can see the foundation being laid for a much heavier load in the next film, and he seems ready to carry it.

The show-stealer, though, is Akshaye Khanna. This is his second standout villain turn in the same year, and Dhurandhar cements his comeback. If you don't know the real man he's playing, you could believe Khanna is that person. If you do know the reference, you're still likely to feel he rocked in the role. With very few lines, and a performance built almost entirely on body language, gaze, and timing, he reminds you just how refined an actor of the previous generation he really is.

The craft around the performances is equally solid. The songs and background score are excellent, and the BGM in particular does heavy lifting in tension and mood. Production design is both era-appropriate and class-appropriate - a chronic weakness in many Hindi films. The rich have the kind of high-end gadgets they would plausibly own; street-level characters use basic, believable devices. Nothing feels randomly "fancy" for the sake of it.

The film leaves a lot unsaid and unexplained. Some of that is clearly by design, to hold material back for the next instalment. Some of it feels like a casualty of the already massive runtime.

And then there are the "usual" accusations that get thrown at any unapologetically pro-India narrative.

Is Dhurandhar jingoistic? Not really. If anything, it is far more restrained than the label suggests. There are no chest-thumping speeches, barely any melodramatic breakdowns. The patriotism is mostly in the choices characters make, not in slogans shouted at the camera.

Does it show "too much" Pakistan and "not enough" India? The story is literally about an Indian spy infiltrating a Pakistani gang in one of Karachi's most notorious spaces. Of course most of the visual canvas is Pakistan. Expecting equal visual time for India here is like complaining that a submarine film shows too much water. If you want pretty postcards of Indian cities, that's what travel videos are for. This film is about the underbelly across the border.

Is it "anti-secular" because it portrays a mostly Muslim gang in Pakistan as violent and regressive? That criticism skips the basic context: this is not a random community portrait. It's about gangsters who, in the real world, have been tied to multiple terror incidents. Sanitising them into misunderstood soft anti-heroes would be far more dishonest than showing them as dangerous.

Is it "too violent"? By most expert accounts of Lyari and similar spaces, what's on screen is perhaps a fraction of the real brutality. Dhurandhar shows enough to disturb, but not enough to numb. That is a conscious artistic choice.

Finally, the film refuses the usual commercial distractions: there are no item numbers parachuted into the plot, no bikini songs on foreign beaches that pause the story for choreography. Real operatives in the field usually live hard, compromised lives; they are not pausing mid-mission for a music video. Dhurandhar respects that reality and, in doing so, respects the audience's intelligence.

By the end of the year, taken together with Chaava, this stands as one of the strongest Hindi films in the mainstream space - and it's no coincidence that Akshaye Khanna is central to both. Dhurandhar may be imperfect and occasionally overstuffed, but it does one simple, essential thing that our cinema has been avoiding for years: it uses common sense about what spies are supposed to do - blend in, not perform - and builds a gripping, politically clear story around that truth.

author: anirban-sarkar84
title: Dhurandhar is not just a movie; it is atonement for nearly 40 years of Bollywood's sins.
text: Dhurandhar is not just a movie; it is atonement for nearly 40 years of Bollywood's sins. The Hollywood industry has always worked to project the American narrative, and Bollywood has finally learned it now. Decades of Bollywood's propaganda are now fading. The roaring success of Dhurandhar proves that India's mindset has changed and the industry has finally acknowledged it.

author: divineflame06
title: Dhurandhar is a beast of a theatrical experience
text:
Dhurandhar is raw, ruthless, and absolutely unflinching.

Aditya Dhar has put together a full-blown big-screen assault - the world-building is so immersive and detailed that you feel every shadow, every scream, every drop of blood. Yes, the film is long... very long at 212 minutes. But those 212 minutes are pure madness.

The writing is top-tier, even if the pacing wobbles occasionally. What really surprised me is that Dhar refuses to take the usual espionage-thriller route. There's no cheap "what's next?" tension-building. Instead, he goes for a gritty, documentary-style tone ; dark, heavy, and brutally honest. The colour palette is gloomy, the lighting is fascinating, and the cinematography is just wild. Sashwat's music lifts the film several notches. And the violence? At times, it's genuinely hard to watch. This is brutality at its peak.

The characters are written with real weight. Akshay Khanna as Rahmat Dakait owns this film. What a performance. Ranveer isn't far behind either. Maddy, Rampal, Dutt... everyone is rock solid and brings something memorable. Special mention to Rakesh Bedi.

The final stretch sets up Part 2 beautifully; darker, deadlier, and ready to dive deep into Ranveer's past and whatever chaos comes next.

Dhurandhar is a beast of a theatrical experience. Miss it at your own risk.

author: mohitpandey-26179
title: Great experience
text: Dhurandhar is a powerful and ambitious spy thriller that makes for a great big-screen experience. It is a solid entertainer, driven by the sheer intensity of its central performances (especially Singh and Khanna) and raw, well-executed action. For fans of the patriotic spy genre and intense character-driven dramas, it's considered a must-watch.

author: ChandanP-991
title: A cinematic powerhouse pulsing with unstoppable momentum
text: Every narrative thread is carefully interwoven, building a sense of foreboding that never lets up. Ranveer Singh's performance anchors the story, balancing vulnerability with relentless determination. The ensemble cast, including unexpected standouts in smaller roles, brings additional layers to the story's tension. Director Dhar masterfully fuses action, strategy, and emotional depth, ensuring that spectacle never overshadows character development. The cinematography captures both the grit of urban danger and the intimacy of personal stakes, while the editing maintains a taut rhythm. By the climax, the stakes feel monumental, and the resolution is both shocking and satisfying.

author: SamkitJ-1
title: Dhurandhar review
text:
Dhurandhar is one of those rare Bollywood films where the craft genuinely rises above everything else. What impressed me most is that the movie is not carried by just one performance. Akshaye, Rampal, Sanjay, Ranveer - everyone comes in with the presence of a lead, and together they hold the film with remarkable balance. Ranveer plays his part exactly the way it should be played, without overshadowing the world the film is trying to create.

The real achievement, though, is how the film rises beyond individual actors. It reminds me of how Pacino in The Godfather or De Niro in Casino and Goodfellas are remembered not just because of their acting but because they were part of films that were masterpieces in themselves. When a movie reaches that level, the film and the performances become inseparable.

Aditya Dhar manages to achieve that with Dhurandhar. The film feels meticulously built, confident in what it wants to say, and bold in how it says it. It shows what happens when Bollywood actually takes risks instead of following formulas. The result is something powerful, memorable and genuinely cinematic.

author: deepanshushandilya
title: Awesome
text:
Amazing. Dhurandhar is a bold and gripping spy thriller that blends political intrigue, smart world-building, and intense performances. Ranveer Singh delivers one of his most controlled and layered roles, bringing both vulnerability and fire to his character. Akshaye Khanna is outstanding as the unpredictable antagonist, adding depth and tension whenever he appears on screen.

The film's scale is huge - packed with gritty action, strong cinematography, and a soundtrack that elevates the atmosphere. The pacing in the first half can feel stretched, but once the story locks in, it becomes a compelling and immersive ride. By the end, the film sets up its sequel with a strong cliffhanger that leaves you wanting more.

Overall, Dhurandhar is an ambitious and stylish espionage drama that rewards patient viewers with powerful moments, strong performances, and a rich narrative world.

I enjoyed watching dhunrander in theatre I recommend it if you're watching it on big screens.

author: kaskau
title: Must Watch
text:
Dhurandhar is a masterclass in suspense and action, weaving a complex narrative that keeps you on the edge of your seat. Ranveer Singh shines as the deep-cover RAW agent, bringing depth and nuance to his character. The supporting cast, including Akshaye Khanna and R. Madhavan, deliver standout performances.

Unlike some recent releases in the spy genre with delusional plot, Dhurandhar doesn't rely on gimmicks or over-the-top action sequences. Instead, it focuses on crafting a believable story with well-developed characters. The film's pacing is well-balanced, moving seamlessly from intense action scenes to emotional moments.

One of the standout aspects of Dhurandhar is its thoughtful direction. Aditya Dhar's vision brings a sense of realism to the film, making it feel more grounded than some of its counterparts in the genre.

author: saligujjar
title: Blockbuster
text:
Dhurandhar is one of those Bollywood thrillers that pulls you in from the very first frame and doesn't let go until the end. The film delivers a powerful mix of drama, suspense, and stylish storytelling, supported by outstanding performances from its lead cast.

Akshaye Khanna once again proves why he is one of Bollywood's most underrated powerhouses. His calm intensity, sharp expressions, and effortless command over emotional scenes make his character unforgettable. Every moment he appears on screen adds weight to the narrative.

Sanjay Dutt is equally impressive, bringing a raw, rugged charm that only he can deliver. His experience shows in every gesture. Whether he is delivering a threatening dialogue or portraying a moment of vulnerability, he keeps the audience glued to his journey.

Ranveer Kapoor gives one of his best performances in recent years. He brings depth, energy, and emotional complexity to his role. His transitions between subtle emotions and explosive moments are handled with remarkable skill. This is the Ranveer audiences love , committed, expressive, and completely immersed in the character.

The music of Dhurandhar is another strong point. The background score is thrilling and adds tremendous tension to the chase sequences and emotional scenes. The songs blend well with the story instead of feeling forced, which is rare in commercial cinema today.

The direction deserves special praise. The filmmaker balances excitement, mystery, and human emotion in a smooth, gripping flow. The visual style, the pacing, and the use of sound effects all contribute to a high-quality cinematic experience. The thrilling effects elevate the movie and make the action scenes feel real and impactful.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a well-crafted entertainer with top-notch acting, great music, and excellent direction. It is a must-watch for fans of intense Bollywood thrillers and for anyone who appreciates strong performances by Akshaye Khanna, Sanjay Dutt, and Ranveer Kapoor.

author: adi-11705
title: Good screen play
text:
Summary, then delve into key aspects like character depth, acting, visuals, music, and themes, explaining why things worked or didn't, and conclude with your overall recommendation, all while staying focused and providing specific examples to support your opinions, as seen in this sample review of The Empire, directed by is a thrilling corporate drama that plunges audiences into the high-stakes world of finance as young Jake inherits his father's empire. Starring Lead Actor's Name, this film promises intrigue, power struggles, and a fight for legacy, setting the stage for a fast-paced ride.

The narrative quickly establishes Jake's overwhelming challenge: navigating cutthroat politics and protecting his inheritance from vultures. While the plot is packed with twists, keeping you engaged, it's the nuanced portrayal of Jake's internal conflict-balancing duty with morality-that truly shines. The supporting cast, particularly the cunning antagonists, adds layers of complexity, making every interaction feel vital.

Visually, the film is stunning, with sleek cinematography and grand production design that perfectly captures the opulent yet cold world of high finance. The score effectively builds tension, driving home the dramatic weight of pivotal scenes. Thematically, The Empire explores ambition, betrayal, and the corrupting nature of wealth, suggesting that power often demands sacrifice. Director irectors Name expertly balances spectacle with character study, avoiding typical action movie cliches by rooting the drama in believable human motivations, despite the grand scale.

While some might find the corporate jargon dense, The Empire delivers a genuinely gripping and well-crafted experience. It's more than just a business thriller; it's a compelling character study wrapped in a visually impressive package. I highly recommend it for fans of intricate plots and strong performances, proving that dramas about money can be truly electrifying and keep you on the edge of your seat.

author: anandkumarrs
title: A well made, engaging spy story
text:
Anand Kumar R. S My Flash Review: Dhurandhar is scripted, directed, and produced by Aditya Dhar, whose earlier directorial outing was Uri: The Surgical Strike. If the "Josh levels" were high in that film, Dhar takes them even higher in Dhurandhar. Although the film opens with a long disclaimer stating it is purely a work of fiction, most viewers can tell that it is largely based on real events, accounts, and people. For those closely following current affairs, the events depicted in the film are easy to relate to and therefore engaging.

Any commentary on the film is difficult without mentioning its length. The film runs for 3.5 hours, and this is only Part 1. A sequel is scheduled for release by March 2026. With such a lengthy film, it is a significant challenge for the creators to keep viewers engaged throughout, and in this regard, I would say it is a mixed bag. The screenplay mostly keeps us engaged, but there are moments when it struggles to hold our attention, only to regain it later. The ability to stage a comeback when the film begins to lag is one of the film's strong points.

Dhurandhar clearly belongs to the spy thriller genre, but is entirely different from the 'Pathan, War, Ek Tha Tiger' types of spy thrillers. Because it is based on real events, it is more intense, with a raw storytelling style. The film is structured as chapters, and in the first chapter itself, the director sets the context: Pakistan-backed terrorists are repeatedly involved in attacks in India, such as the IC 814 hijack and the Parliament attack. Yet, India is unable to stop these through dialogue or Aman ki Asha efforts and therefore decides to resort to covert operations. This decision follows an impactful scene inside the hijacked aircraft at Kandahar when the IB Chief shouts Bharat Mata ki, but meets with an eerie silence.

Ranveer Singh plays Hamza, an undercover operative planted in Pakistan to gather intelligence on its terror plans. He joins a powerful mafia gang, and until the interval, we are immersed in intergang rivalry, the politician-mafia nexus, and the ISI's scheming. These parts are quite different and feel very realistic. The first half of the film runs for two hours, and the director tries to fit too much into it. As a result, the watch feels somewhat tiring, but the second half becomes sleeker and more engaging.

The film scores very high on craft and making. It is, to a large extent, an action film, and the action set pieces are brilliantly executed. For example, the action sequence in the climax inside a moving car, I thought, was very well shot. Vikash Nowlakha is the cinematographer, and his work is top-notch. It seems that, except for the long shots or the drone shots, the entire film has been shot on multiple steady cams, which gives an edgy feel not just to the action sequences but even to conversational scenes. Dhar has put a lot of thought into framing of the scenes, and that shows in how the screenplay on paper has been translated to the big screen. There is a scene reminiscent of Iruvar, in which Mohanlal makes an entry into a public meeting while Prakash Raj is speaking on the dias. Here, Akshay Khanna makes that entry when Rakesh Bedi speaks, and this showcases Dhar's skills in staging an important scene.

Apart from the direction and technique, the other aspect that works strongly for the film is the cast. Ranveer Singh as Hamsa plays his role with a highly intense yet restrained intensity that suits the character. He has a commanding screen presence and, when necessary, emotes in a controlled way to express the pain and agony his character endures when he cannot control certain situations. The other standout performer is Akshay Khanna. He maintains a mean, menacing look throughout. In his entry scene, he appears even more menacing and gives Ranveer a tough fight in terms of presence. The supporting cast of Sanjay Dutt, Arjun Rampal, Gaurav Gera, and Rakesh Bedi all perform their roles quite competently. Madhavan appears in only a few scenes, but as the Intelligence chief playing Ajit Doval, he matches his look and persona very well. There is a love-interest thread introduced between Ranveer and Sara Arjun that seems forced, but the screenplay makes intelligent use of it later.

The editing could have been sharper for sure. The transitions were sometimes jagged, such as when moving from Chapter 2 to Chapter 3. Additionally, the director could have cut some of the lengthy sequences that felt a bit indulgent and risked undermining the film's pacy tone. The action sequences are excessively loud and gory. This isn't a film for the faint-hearted. The trailer clearly indicated this, so viewers should be prepared for it. However, this level of violence and noise will likely deter those who dislike seeing excessive blood on screen.

The film's narrative clearly reveals the makers' politics. It appeals to the hypernationalistic section of the audience and doesn't attempt any monkey-balancing in the narrative. There are scenes that are propagandistic, aimed at winning over supporters of the current regime. The film goes all out to trigger a rage against Pakistan among viewers with a detailed portrayal of the country's hatred towards India. The putting out of portions of the actual audio transcripts during the 26/11 attacks is testimony to this.

It would have made sense to make this subject into a web series. However, the audacious ambition and scale of the project make it unviable to release solely on OTT. It required a successful theatrical run followed by OTT and satellite releases to sustain the budget. Notwithstanding the length and excessive violence, Durandhar keeps us engaged with the proceedings. If you are a fan of the spy thriller genre, Durandhar is a good watch. The film has certainly piqued interest in the sequel.

author: MahiraS-89
title: Stars Elevate Every Moment of This Ride
text: This film is a thrilling exploration of ambition, loyalty, and moral compromise. Ranveer Singh anchors the story with a performance that is as physically intense as it is emotionally resonant. Sanjay Dutt adds layers of authority and menace, while Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan make every dialogue-driven moment count, giving the narrative additional complexity. Arjun Rampal's controlled intensity and Sara Arjun's heartbreaking innocence make the stakes feel immediate and real. Aditya Dhar's direction showcases a careful command of pacing and tone, blending suspenseful tension with cinematic spectacle. The action scenes are smartly choreographed and shot, emphasizing realism and consequence over flamboyance. The soundscape and editing further enhance immersion, ensuring viewers are constantly on edge. By the second half, the film escalates into a gripping crescendo, combining strategic plotting with raw emotional power, leaving a lingering impact.

author: ayushsinha-38625
title: Dhurandar Review
text:
Dhundandar is a Brilliant Movie that stands tall as a powerful example of what thoughtful cinema can achieve when every department works in perfect harmony. From the very first frame, the film pulls you into its world with confidence, intent, and an unmistakable cinematic voice. It doesn't rely on shortcuts or noise; instead, it trusts its story and its craft.

One of the strongest pillars of Dhundandar is its great casting. Every actor feels perfectly chosen for their role, delivering performances that are natural, layered, and deeply engaging. No character feels forced or out of place, and even the smallest roles leave a lasting impression. The chemistry between the cast elevates the emotional depth of the narrative and keeps the audience invested throughout.

The writing deserves special praise. The screenplay is sharp, meaningful, and well-paced, balancing emotion and intensity without ever feeling heavy-handed. The dialogues feel real and purposeful, adding weight to the story rather than distracting from it. Complimenting this is the direction, which is confident and mature. The director's vision is clear in every scene, allowing moments to breathe while maintaining a steady grip on the film's rhythm.

Visually, the filmography is stunning. Each frame is carefully composed, using light, shadow, and movement to enhance the mood of the story. The visuals don't just look beautiful; they serve the narrative. Adding to this richness, the background music was perfect, subtly amplifying emotions and tension without overpowering the scenes.

Overall, Dhundandar delivers an allover cinematic experience was great, making it a film that stays with you long after the credits roll. It is immersive, impactful, and truly memorable-a must-watch for anyone who appreciates quality cinema.

title: This is how a Spy movie is made!
text:
Dhurandhar is a triumphant reminder of what powerful cinema looks like when anchored by exceptional performances and fearless storytelling. The film unfolds with gripping intensity, yet every moment feels purposeful and controlled. It is the kind of work that pulls you in completely and refuses to let go.

Akshaye Khanna delivers one of the finest performances of his career. His screen presence is magnetic. His emotional precision is astonishing. He brings a rare blend of restraint and fire that elevates every scene he appears in. Watching him inhabit this role feels like witnessing an actor at the peak of his craft.

Rakesh Bedi is a revelation. Known for his comic timing, he takes an unexpected turn here and delivers a performance that is both grounded and quietly devastating. His contribution adds depth and texture, proving once again that he is one of the industry's most versatile talents.

The film's writing is sharp, the direction assured, and the visual language striking. Cinematography and music work in perfect harmony, amplifying the emotional force of the narrative.

Dhurandhar is more than a film. It is an experience. A gripping, beautifully executed piece of cinema that needs to be experienced in theatres.

author: ashishkeshari567
title: Must watch
text:
One of the best movies I've watched in recent times.

Dhurandhar stands out for its raw honesty and courage to break away from the false narratives often portrayed in Bollywood. For years, mainstream cinema has tried to present a softened, unrealistic image of India-Pakistan relations, sometimes even showing Pakistan's ISI in a sympathetic or friendly light. This film does the exact opposite-and that's where its strength lies.

Dhurandhar presents a hard-hitting and realistic portrayal of ground realities, exposing the truth without unnecessary dramatization or sugarcoating. The storytelling is gripping, the performances feel authentic, and the narrative keeps you engaged from start to finish.

What makes this movie truly impactful is its commitment to realism and its refusal to dilute facts for commercial comfort. It doesn't try to please everyone-it tells the story as it is, and that honesty is refreshing.

A must-watch for anyone who appreciates meaningful cinema, strong storytelling, and films that dare to challenge long-standing misconceptions.

author: gituchora-52205
title: Entertaining throughout, no shortness of excitement
text:
The mammoth runtime holding actioners, Animal (2023) and now the most awaited movie of 2025 Dhurandhar, prove that even as attention spans have nosedived to a fleeting 3 seconds, powerful content can still hold sway for more than 3 hours. While Animal may have had a few cringe moments or story sagging sub plots, Dhurandhar has none. It is rich on patriotic sentiment, rooted in real events, entertaining and gripping throughout, and full of memorable action that never goes overboard. The performances are sharp, the tone is assured and the film knows exactly what it wants to be.

Aditya Dhar, director and co producer, has a history of creating riveting action political entertainers. He has hit the nail on the head with this one. Locations, action sequences, background research, casting, the zippy pace, the fine editing, all add up to make it a must watch as the year ends.

If you are even slightly aware of India's geopolitics, Dhurandhar will strike a chord.

Ranveer Singh is on top of his game here, and credit goes to the director again for shaping and controlling the energy that Ranveer brings. That said, what Ranveer recently did to Rishabh Shetty was unnecessary, misinformed and disrespectful of a belief that millions hold sacred. It had nothing to do with the craft on display in Dhurandhar and only distracted from the good work he has delivered on screen.

author: mr-satyam-dey
title: Raw. Relentless. Real.
text:
Finally, Bollywood has found its spine.

After decades of soft-focus RAW-ISI bromance fed to us through glossy YRF-style storytelling, Dhurandhar finally gives us a raw, uncomfortable, and realistic look at espionage. At almost 3.5 hours long, the film never drags - not for a single moment.

A major strength lies in its casting: when the supporting actors are chosen for talent and not because the film industry functions like a rojgar yojna, the result is authenticity. Every character feels lived-in, layered, and believable.

Ranveer delivers one of his finest performances - intense, grounded, and controlled. If only he applied the same restraint to his off-screen persona, his craft would shine even brighter.

From the hauntingly amazing background score to the realistic production design and unpolished action sequences free from flashy VFX, everything pulls you straight into the gritty underbelly of Pakistan.

Yes, there are a few lines sprinkled in to flatter the current ruling government - but they are sparse and don't disrupt the rhythm or credibility of the narrative.

This is the kind of cinema we should be supporting - especially after collectively committing a crime against logic by turning Pushpa 2 and Pathaan into blockbusters.

A word of caution: do not take kids or anyone uncomfortable with raw brutality. The violence here isn't senseless or stylized - unlike Marco, it exists to serve the story.

In the end, Dhurandhar stands tall as a compelling, intelligent, and unapologetically real film - a striking balance of fact and fiction, executed with rare conviction.

author: Aaryaman-2
title: Dhurandhar A Must Watch
text:
The movie delves straight into the plot. The screenplay is tight, and even though some dialogues are dramatic, they do not feel cringeworthy.

Ranveer Singh is easily one of the best things to happen to Bollywood. He completely transforms for the role and feels perfect in it.

This movie feels like an Akshay Khanna aura project. Everyone knew he would deliver great acting, but looking this good was unexpected.

Arjun Rampal has a comparatively short role, but his menacing presence genuinely makes certain scenes intimidating.

Madhavan is noticeably underutilised.

Sara looks beautiful and, for a newcomer, performs well. Her chemistry with Ranveer is not weird, but it is not very strong either.

You will feel the long runtime, but there is not a single scene that feels unnecessary or worth removing.

The action scenes are gory, but the overall violence is less than expected. I personally wanted to see more of action hero Ranveer.

The story is not a typical spy thriller. The way certain dialogues and situations are presented adds a strong dramatic impact.

The background music is powerful, and when the title track plays, the theatre energy rises instantly.

The final five minutes, which set up the next part, are genuinely exciting and elevate the overall experience.

author: aashishgundewar
title: Must Watch - Cultish Spy Universe!!
text:
'Dhurandhar' Movie Review: This is the Spy Universe We Deserve!

This is how Bollywood should make the spy-universe. Not that RAW + ISI love affair ultra boring story should be directed. Dhurandhar is a fresh breather as far as covert ops is concerned. What a movie, everybody has played their part with utmost sincerity.

From the gritty, unfiltered world-building to the calculated, non-stop tension, director Aditya Dhar delivers a sprawling, muscular espionage thriller that stays firmly rooted in the mechanics of a black-ops mission. Unlike predecessors that relied on over-the-top glamour, Dhurandhar pulls you into a dangerously believable underworld that feels textured and real.

Stellar Performances That Electrify

The film belongs not just to its lead, but to a powerful ensemble where every key player is a masterstroke:

Akshaye Khanna - as Rehman Dakait was splendid! His performance is a sheer masterclass in simmering intensity. His silences scream, and his presence is so magnetic that he arguably steals every scene he's in.

Arjun Rampal - as Major Iqbal was magnificent! He adds steel and authenticity to his role, delivering a performance that is both commanding and deeply convincing.

Sanjay Dutt - As SP Ch Aslam was stupendous! Dutt brings a necessary weight and gravitas to the proceedings, rounding out the high-stakes political drama.

Rakesh Bedi - as Nabeel Gabol was refreshing! He's a revelation, breezing in with unexpected humor and a performance nobody saw coming, proving his versatility.

Ranveer Singh - RAW Spy was super calm/composed! This is Ranveer in a new, layered, and restrained avatar, playing the character Hamza with a focus and conviction that is truly impressive.

Music, Screenplay, Story, Cinematography is Top Class.

author: spjek
title: A Brutal, Realistic, Gripping Genre Redefining Spy Action Thriller
text:
In the current era of the faltering, synthetic flavored Spy Universes where style matters more than substance, Dhurandhar injects a much needed dose of grittyness and realism enhanced by a strong story, nuanced characters and powerful performances. The movie is indeed Brutal in parts, full of expletives and not an easy watch but thats what makes it real. Do note that a lot of the gore and action from the teaser and trailer are not in this part of the saga. Aditya Dhar has done a great job creating an authentic spy world which is based on real life characters and incidents and sprinkled it with heavy dose of masala to augment the flavors and experience. He gets it right by focusing on things that matter for good cinema - start with a good relatable story, then add well written characters with strong arcs, cast the right actors, give them the reins to bring their characters to life and then take no short cuts to deliver the vision.

Dhar starts with a premise that we have all seen and experienced over the last few decades and makes it relatable for his target audience by splicing in images and videos of the real life attacks that lead to the inception of the Dhurandhar project. He very smartly breaks the movie into multiple tightly written and executed chapters which is one of the reasons the movie even at a really really long run time of 3 and a half hours is highly engaging and entertaining. Almost every scene, character, dialog is an essential part of the screenplay and important in taking the story forward and making the long run time gripping without losing its target audience. The real star of Dhurandhar is Aditya Dhar for creating and delivering on his vision.

Then comes the characters and the actors who inhabit them on the screen. The movie's main protagonist -Hamza Ali Mazari AKA Jaskirat Singh Rangi played brilliantly by Ranveer Singh is the Indian Agent infiltrating the underworld of Lyari area in Karachi which Dhar created in a real location in Thailand instead of in a studio or infont of green screens. Ranveer may have invoked the character of Hamza in part from Gully Boy's Murad and in part from Padmaavat's Khilji but the final result is an effective character of a troubled, skilled, smart, dangerous patriot on a mission. The force behind the creation of Dhurandhar's spy is Ajay Sanyal, the director of the Intelligence Bureau, a character that has truly been inhabited and brought to life by an exceptional Madhavan.

If a story's protagonist is as good as the antagonist then we are heading in for a treat to the other side with a buffet of well writen and enacted group of adversaries with real depth and character. The brightest of them all is Rehman Dakait, a role in which Akshaye Khanna literally becomes the much feared and notorious real life gangster. Akshaye Khanna gives such depth to the character that one can see both the human and the devil that resides within. Akshaye's Rehman Dakait is one of the highlights of Dhurandhar's first part and one of the main reasons to go on this 3 and a half hour journey through the streets of Lyari. Arjun Rampal's Major Iqbal takes evil and brutality to a completely new level and with the limited screen time in this part, he is only warming up. In this part, Rampal has shown the potential to create a villain for the ages, so hoping that with Part 2 he can unleash the real devil.

A special mention to Rakesh Bedi who has done a great job in creating the slimy and evil politician Jameel Jamali in what is not only his longest role in a mainstream movie but one that not only parallels but far exceeds his funny supporting roles of Chashme Buddoor and Yeh Jo Hai Zindagi. Sanjay Dutt as SP Chaudhary Aslam is good but is missing the edge, intensity and cut throatedness that one would expect from a character with the nickname, "The Jinn". Rest of the cast is good in their respective roles with Danish Pandor as Uzair Baloch and Naveen Kaushik as Donga standing out as Rehman Dakait's faithful gang members. Sara Arjun is decent in a small role which has been set up appropriately, lesser as a romantic interest and more as an important step in the mission.

The real location, the gritty action sequences, the gut wrenching visceral beatings and torture scenes are further augmented by its eclectic background score. The movie doesnt get distracted much by unnecessary songs. Arijit's Gehra Hua is a pleasant break from the movie's ever growing tension. Shararat is a bit of a sub-par song that was not needed in the movie but it is easily forgiven because of the spectacular background songs like Hanumankind's title track and Ez-Ez along with the multiple old Bollywood classics splattered through the movie.

If you were looking forward to watch the movie after experiencing its hyperviolent and gory teaser and trailer, then you are its target audience and will not be disappointed. Overall the movie is extremely gripping and well made with brilliant performances and very good direction. It is long but not boring. It is brutal and gory but not at the level expected. It is not an easy watch but almost a must watch. Overall it is highly entertaining. I really enjoyed it and cant wait for Part 2 on March 19th when the real action will get unleashed, the true evil of some the characters will come forth, a peak will get provided into the protagonist's troubled past, a big character reveal may take the tension to the next level and real chaos will descend on the world of Dhurandhar. 8/10.

author: knewyxxy
title: A Thunderstorm of Action and Emotion

author: sachanutkarsh
title: This is new INDIA cinema.
text:
Ruly a fantastic spy movie, this film stands out as an authentic and realistic portrayal of the espionage world. Unlike many mainstream Bollywood spy thrillers that depend on glamour, exaggerated action, or unnecessary romantic subplots, this movie stays focused on the true nature of intelligence operations. It presents espionage as a world of strategy, risk, and discipline rather than flashy heroics.

What makes this film rare and refreshing is its commitment to realism. The story highlights intelligence gathering, surveillance, covert planning, and the psychological pressure faced by operatives. The characters feel grounded and believable, driven by duty and national interest instead of personal drama. This realism adds depth and credibility, making the narrative more engaging.

Another strong point is the absence of forced romance. The film avoids the typical Bollywood formula where a love story distracts from the core plot. This allows the storyline to remain tight and impactful. It also refrains from romanticizing geopolitics, particularly the portrayal of Pakistan, which is often softened or idealized in many films. Instead, the movie maintains a pragmatic and serious tone, reflecting the harsh realities of international intelligence and national security.

The direction and screenplay are crisp, with sharp dialogues and well-paced scenes that sustain tension throughout. Performances are restrained and effective, enhancing the authenticity of the story. Overall, this film is a rare and commendable Bollywood spy movie that respects the intelligence of its audience and delivers a grounded, mature, and honest depiction of the spy world.

author: DeepanshuS-05
title: About movie
text:
Dhorander is a surprisingly refreshing and engaging film that blends emotion, intensity, and strong storytelling in a way that keeps you hooked from beginning to end. What truly stands out is the gripping narrative, which slowly pulls you into the world of the characters and makes you genuinely care about what happens to them.

The performances are excellent-each actor brings authenticity and depth to their role. The lead delivers a powerful portrayal, effortlessly balancing emotional vulnerability with inner strength. Supporting actors also shine, adding realism and texture to every scene.

author: ArjunN-00
title: Dhurandhar - My take
text:
Just walked out of Dhurandhar and honestly... what a ride.

Went in expecting a loud mass entertainer and got a solid adrenaline rush instead. The film keeps a tight grip from the start, with moments that genuinely get your pulse going, even if a few stretches feel familiar.

The lead cast absolutely commit - performances feel intense without going overboard, and the supporting actors pull their weight well. You can tell the director knew exactly what tone they were chasing, and for the most part, the execution lands. Action blocks are punchy, well-shot, and staged with confidence, while the background score does a lot of heavy lifting in elevating key scenes.

That said, the film doesn't try to reinvent the wheel. A couple of plot beats are predictable, and some emotional moments could've breathed a bit more. Still, the overall experience stays engaging, and the pacing rarely drops enough to lose you.

Bottom line: Dhurandhar is a crowd-pleasing, high-energy watch that delivers on intensity and performance. Not perfect, but definitely worth the ticket if you're in the mood for a proper big-screen rush.

author: PareshD-85
title: "Where Real Events Meet Cinematic Greatness: Dhurandhar Review"
text:
Dhurandhar is easily the finest film of 2025 - no second thoughts about it. From the opening frame to the final moment, the story holds you in a tight grip and never lets go. The lead characters are written with remarkable depth, and each actor delivers a powerhouse performance that elevates the entire experience. Even the supporting cast shines, contributing meaningfully to every twist and turn.

The action sequences are intense, sharply choreographed, and executed with precision. What makes the film even more compelling is its ambitious storyline, rooted in real geopolitical events across the Indian subcontinent from 1999 to 2010. The way the movie blends actual news footage and historical moments into its narrative is seamless and impressive.

Despite the heavy themes, the screenplay knows exactly when to breathe - sprinkling smart, well-placed humour that lightens the mood after stretches of intense action and complex political and underworld drama.

Dhurandhar is not just a film - it's an experience. A definite must-watch.

author: aatishagarwal
title: Unapologetic, Unfiltered, Unforgettable
text: Dhurandhar is not just a mind-gripping cinematic experience; it is also a path-breaker in the narrative set by earlier films of this genre. While many movies have put Pakistan in the spotlight for exporting terrorism to India, they often end on a soft, terror-sympathizing, pseudo-secular note. This film breaks that long-cast spell on Indian viewers and presents the brutal truth about Pakistan's nature and its intention to "bleed India with a thousand cuts," without any sugar-coating. There is no artificial icing in the name of fake calls for peace and humanity when the other side continues to hurt us. The film makes it clear that there is no grey area in war, and this reality is portrayed unapologetically. It serves as a wake-up call for all Indians to understand their enemy better - Shatru Bodh. Aditya Dhar has delivered before with Uri, but Dhurandhar is on a different level. It is a masterpiece. Every character does complete justice to their role. The movie keeps you glued to your seat for 3.5 hours, and even then, you're left wanting more !!
