author: AJReelNotes
title: Unapologetic, Gripping, and Necessary
text:
Watched Dhurandhar the second time.

I can't remember the last time I watched a film twice in a theatre, or the last time I wrote about a movie.

Its is a rare cinematic achievement. Despite its long runtime, it never loosens its grip. There isn't a single dull moment.

It offers a grounded look at how spies really work quietly, patiently, far from the spotlight. And it's completely unapologetic about fighting terrorism tooth and claw.

Aditya Dhar has balances realism, violence, romance, true events, subplots, & nationalism with remarkable control. The BGM & cinematography really elevates the movie. Then performances are exceptional, with Akshaye Khanna and Ranveer Singh as clear standouts.

author: dhyansharma
title: A Bold, Uncompromising Triumph - Dhurhandar is a Rare Masterpiece
text:
Dhurhandar is one of those films that reminds you why cinema exists in the first place. It doesn't just tell a story - it pulls you into a world that is raw, unpredictable, emotionally charged, and brilliantly crafted. From the first frame to the last, the film maintains a level of intensity and artistic confidence that very few Indian films even attempt.

The direction is razor-sharp, the writing is layered and intelligent, and every character feels alive with purpose. The performances are nothing short of extraordinary - subtle when they need to be, explosive when the story demands it. The cinematography elevates the narrative, blending grit and elegance in a way that feels both grounded and mythic.

What truly sets Dhurhandar apart is its refusal to spoon-feed or simplify. It trusts the viewer. It challenges you. It rewards your attention with depth, symbolism, and emotional weight that lingers long after the credits roll.

For me, this is not just a great film - it's a benchmark. A shining example of what modern Indian storytelling can achieve when ambition meets craft.

Highly recommended. Easily one of the best films I've seen in years.

author: webervishal
title: Dhurandhar : A Riveting Three and a Half Hour Epic
text:
Aditya Dhar has long shown a penchant for ambitious filmmaking, but with Dhurandhar he delivers something that feels both grand in scale and meticulously controlled. Clocking in at around three and a half hours, the film could easily have felt bloated or indulgent, but Dhar's confident direction and a taut screenplay ensure that not a minute drifts without purpose. This is a movie that wears its epic intentions proudly yet remains intimate in its emotional core.

The story revolves around a fraught period in contemporary India, where individual destinies collide with larger political and social forces. Dhar crafts a layered narrative that combines a politically charged central plot with quieter, more personal subplots. This duality is one of the film's greatest strengths: it gives the film the sweep of a socio-political thriller while anchoring it in human stakes. The pacing-remarkable for such a long runtime-allows characters and their relationships to breathe, developing arcs that pay off richly by the film's final act.

Performances across the board are uniformly excellent. The lead-commanding, nuanced, and always in control-carries the film's moral ambiguities with a rare mix of charisma and restraint. Supporting actors deliver standout moments that add texture and depth; comic relief is earned rather than tacked on, and emotional beats land because these characters feel lived-in. The ensemble works together like a finely tuned machine: every glance, every silence, contributes to the film's atmosphere.

Visually, Dhurandhar is a triumph. The cinematography is both painterly and precise, using long takes and carefully composed frames to build tension and underscore character psychology. Action sequences are choreographed with clarity-each punch, chase, and confrontation serves a narrative purpose rather than merely showcasing spectacle. Production design and costumes ground the film in a believable world, while the sound design amplifies suspense and keeps the viewer invested during quieter passages.

A major achievement here is the screenplay's refusal to simplify. Dhar and his writers avoid easy answers, embracing moral complexity. Themes of power, loyalty, and ideology are interrogated rather than preached, and the film trusts its audience to follow layered arguments and conflicting motivations. Dialogues are sharp, occasionally theatrical in moments of high stakes, yet often quiet and revealing in one-on-one scenes.

If the film has flaws, they are minor. A subplot or two could have been tightened, and some viewers might find the runtime demanding-there are stretches that require patience and careful attention. But for those willing to commit, the rewards are ample: an emotionally satisfying payoff, striking set pieces, and a closing sequence that lingers long after the credits roll.

Ultimately, Dhurandhar is a testament to what ambitious mainstream cinema can achieve. It's a film made with conviction, technical mastery, and a deep respect for character-driven storytelling. Aditya Dhar proves himself not just as an action director but as a filmmaker capable of handling complex themes and long-form narrative without losing grip. In a cinematic landscape where brevity often reigns, Dhurandhar is a bold, engrossing epic that keeps you riveted for its entire runtime. Highly recommended for viewers who appreciate layered storytelling, strong performances, and cinema that thinks as it thrills.

author: nipunvats-30976
title: Substance Over Stars: Why Dhurandhar is the Exception to the Rule
text:
While I typically avoid mainstream Bollywood-where budgets often favor star salaries over substance-Dhurandhar stands as a striking exception. Despite its daunting 3.5-hour runtime, the pacing is relentless; every sequence feels essential to the soul of the film. The violence is undeniably visceral and heavy on gore, yet it never feels gratuitous; instead, it is a narrative-driven necessity that underscores the stakes of the story.

What truly distinguishes the film is its political maturity. While it exercises creative freedom to offer subtle critiques of specific Indian political dynamics, it successfully avoids the "propaganda" label by grounding itself in universal truths about power. Rather than fueling cross-border animosity, the script exposes a grim reality: how those in power manufacture external threats to distract the public from internal failures.

Refreshingly empathetic, the film refuses to lean on tired anti-Muslim tropes and even sheds light on the often-ignored plight of the Baloch people. Ultimately, Dhurandhar is a sobering look at the cost of conflict, illustrating how the masses pay the price of blind loyalty while the elite reap the rewards.

Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan provide subtle, layered performances, complementing the lead with intelligence and nuance. Arjun Rampal's quiet menace enhances suspense, and Sara Arjun's emotionally charged scenes provide a poignant human counterbalance. Aditya Dhar's direction blends suspense, strategic plotting, and action sequences seamlessly. Cinematography captures the underworld's chaotic beauty and intimate human moments alike, while the score punctuates tension and emotion. By the climax, the film delivers an adrenaline-charged and emotionally satisfying finale.

author: adityajat-04152
title: A Crowd-Pleaser with Heart, Humor, and Heroics
text:
Dhurandhar plants itself squarely in that satisfying zone where a film knows exactly what it wants to be: energetic, emotional, and larger than life. The story leans into familiar archetypes, but the execution is lively enough that the familiar becomes fun rather than predictable.

The film orbits around Dhurandhar, the kind of protagonist who seems carved out of the same rock as classic folk heroes. He is equal parts stubborn, clever, and tender-hearted. His defining trait is an odd mix of bravado and vulnerability; he charges into trouble like a bull but quietly wrestles with doubts when it comes to the people he loves. The film wisely lets these contradictions breathe, giving the audience someone who feels human rather than mythic.

Opposite him is Gauri, a sharp-tongued, free-thinking character whose presence adds both emotional depth and comedic combustion. Her role isn't limited to being a romantic foil; she is a catalyst who pushes Dhurandhar to examine his own values. Their chemistry works not because they are perfect for each other but because they genuinely irritate, challenge, and inspire one another.

Then there's Mama Saheb, the antagonist who steals more scenes than he deserves. He's crafty instead of cartoonish, and his schemes give the film its momentum. His dynamic with Dhurandhar becomes a playful chess match-a recurring tension between brute improvisation and polished manipulation.

The film's most popular moments tend to be the ones where its tone snaps into high gear. Audiences keep talking about the chaotic marketplace showdown, where Dhurandhar turns a simple argument into a hilariously escalating spectacle, complete with improvised weapons, brilliant one-liners, and a sense of physical comedy that never tips into slapstick. Another scene that struck a chord is the quiet nighttime conversation between Dhurandhar and Gauri on the village bridge, where the film lets its emotional spine show without melodrama. It's the kind of moment that softens everything around it.

The soundtrack works like narrative seasoning-each song sharpens the film's flavor. "Sher Maza Zindabad" became the defacto anthem of Dhurandhar's swagger, a rhythmic, percussion-heavy piece that urges the audience to thump along. "Manaachi Gani" is the heart's counterweight to the heroics; it blends folk instrumentation with mellow vocals, turning Gauri's inner world into something audible. The festival number "Rang Bari Dhurandhar" is pure spectacle: color, choreography, and a jubilant crowd sequence that's practically engineered for repeat viewing.

In short, Dhurandhar doesn't reinvent the cinematic wheel, yet it rolls with such gusto that resisting its charm becomes difficult. It's a film that swings between mischief and sincerity and manages to carry the audience along for the ride. The characters are memorable not because they're flawless, but because they stumble and roar and blunder with the kind of energy that keeps the story alive well after the credits.

Exploring how modern regional cinema blends classic folk-hero storytelling with contemporary tone offers fertile ground for further discussion.

author: kunuiam
title: High-Octane Scenes You'll Remember
text: Every moment of the film feels deliberate and charged with meaning, offering a blend of thrilling action and nuanced storytelling. Ranveer Singh delivers an electrifying performance, embodying both intensity and emotional depth, while the supporting actors provide rich, layered portrayals. Director Dhar masterfully navigates complex themes of loyalty, power, and morality, crafting a narrative that is both gripping and reflective. Action sequences are executed with breathtaking precision, while cinematography captures both grandeur and subtle emotional beats with elegance. Editing ensures that tension is sustained without overwhelming the viewer, and the musical score underlines the drama and suspense with subtlety. author: Arvinds-196
title: A Casting Thought on Dhurandhar: Why Sidharth Malhotra Feels Like a Natural Fit
text:
Dhurandhar is a film that carries the weight of bravery, sacrifice, and realism on its shoulders. Everything about the narrative, the treatment, and the emotional core works well, yet one aspect that invites personal reflection is the casting choice for the character of Major Mohit Sharma. While Ranveer Singh is undeniably a powerful performer, there is a lingering thought that Sidharth Malhotra might have been a more fitting choice for this role.

The resemblance between Sidharth Malhotra and Major Mohit Sharma is striking. Beyond physical similarity, there is a quiet intensity in Sidharth's screen presence that aligns naturally with the disciplined, grounded aura of an Indian Army officer. Major Mohit Sharma was known for his calm courage, sharp focus, and restrained strength qualities that demand subtlety more than flamboyance. This is where Sidharth Malhotra excels.

His performance in Shershaah stands as strong evidence. As Captain Vikram Batra, Sidharth portrayed bravery not through loud heroism, but through emotional control, sincerity, and inner fire. He understood the silence behind the uniform-the weight of duty, the personal cost of service, and the unspoken fear that coexists with courage. That same emotional maturity would have translated beautifully into the character of Major Mohit Sharma in Dhurandhar.

Ranveer Singh brings immense energy and transformative dedication to his roles, but his style often leans toward expressive intensity. For a character rooted in realism and tactical intelligence, a more understated approach might have enhanced authenticity. Sidharth's restrained performance style could have allowed the story to breathe, keeping the focus firmly on the mission, the man, and the meaning of sacrifice.

Ultimately, Dhurandhar remains impactful, but imagining Sidharth Malhotra in the role of Major Mohit Sharma opens an interesting discussion on casting, realism, and emotional alignment-one that highlights how sometimes, quiet strength speaks louder than dramatic flair.

author: reshmark-62200
title: Indian Cinema at Its Finest
text:
I just watched Dhurandhar, and I'm truly blown away. The film is spectacular in every sense. Bow down to the director. Every single frame felt like something Bollywood hasn't delivered before. At this point, it doesn't even feel right to compare Indian cinema to Hollywood; our films are already operating on their own level. But Dhurandhar stands out even within that; its filmmaking is top-tier.

Despite being 3 hours and 30 minutes long, the movie never once felt stretched. The pacing was tight, the editing was crisp, and the colour grading was stunning. Every frame was crafted with intention. Every frame was classy and impactful. The music was beautiful, and the BGM in the second half was especially outstanding.

Akshaye Khanna.. what a beautiful actor. His style, his presence, his impact... impeccable. Every time he appeared on screen, he elevated the moment. He deserves a bow.

And then there's Ranveer Singh. The way he commanded the screen, even in silence, was extraordinary. He continues to prove his versatility film after film: Padmaavat, Gully Boy, Rocky Aur Rani Ki Beti, Bajirao Mastani, Ram-Leela, Dil Dhadakne Do, 83, and now Dhurandhar. Truly spectacular. At this point, I'm not sure if he can even be compared to any actor of his generation. He is in his own league. People can say whatever they want, but they cannot take away the fact that Ranveer Singh is a brilliant, versatile, audacious performer. He absolutely nailed this role and cannot wait for part 2.

The rest of the cast- R. Madhavan, Arjun Rampal, Sanjay Dutt, Rakesh Bedi, Sara Arjun and others were all powerful contributors to this cinematic experience. Each of them delivered exactly what the film needed. What a casting.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a masterclass in filmmaking, performance, and storytelling..

Take a bow, team.

author: Shweta-971
title: Cinema with courage- A story india needed to Hear
text:
Dhurandhar is an emotionally shattering masterpiece that exposes the painful sacrifices our spies make to protect our nation. This is not a YRF film, and making a film like this is definitely not their cup of tea - it needs a fearless creator with courage and conviction.

Aditya Dhar, you absolutely nailed it. The film honestly reveals uncomfortable truths and highlights how political negligence and poor leadership in the past led to losses and suffering for our brave heroes. It powerfully portrays how the system failed them and how the country paid the price.

There are strong moments that show how decisions taken during earlier governments affected national security, and how our soldiers and spies were left to bear the consequences. It opens the eyes of the public to realities that were hidden or ignored.

The storytelling shakes your soul - raw, real and unforgettable.

This is not just a movie - it's a tribute to the unsung warriors of India.

A must-watch for every Indian. Salute to our real heroes. üáÆüá≥

author: piyushpatelpp-04377

author: Mihirb-55
title: DHURANDHAR: A Roar of the Nation's Conscience
text:
DHURANDHAR is not merely a film-it is a declaration. Rooted in the spirit of the soil and driven by an unflinching sense of duty, the movie channels a powerful nationalist fervor that resonates long after the screen fades to black. It speaks in the language of sacrifice, resolve, and unwavering belief in the idea of the nation.

At its core, DHURANDHAR celebrates the strength of character that defines true patriotism. The narrative moves with intensity, portraying individuals who rise above personal comfort to answer a larger call-one that demands courage, discipline, and moral clarity. Without resorting to hollow slogans, the film builds its nationalism through actions, choices, and consequences. This grounded approach makes the emotion feel earned and deeply authentic.

Visually, the film reinforces its message with strong compositions and an earthy palette that anchors the story in lived reality. The background score complements the mood, elevating moments of tension and pride without overpowering the narrative. Dialogues are sharp and purposeful, carrying the weight of conviction rather than theatrics.

What makes DHURANDHAR stand out is its refusal to romanticize nationalism superficially. Instead, it portrays patriotism as responsibility-towards land, people, and values. The characters are not flawless heroes; they are determined citizens shaped by struggle, loss, and an unbreakable sense of belonging. This human depth lends credibility to the film's ideological stance.

In a time when national identity is often reduced to noise, DHURANDHAR reminds us that the nation is built by silent perseverance and fearless action. It urges viewers to reflect on their own role within the collective, making the experience both stirring and introspective.

DHURANDHAR is a bold cinematic statement-raw, resolute, and deeply Indian. It stands tall as a film that doesn't just entertain, but ignites pride and responsibility in equal measure.

author: hd-89290

Ultimately, Dhurandhar is a "paisa vasool" theatrical experience that rewards patient viewers with a sophisticated, textured look at the cost of espionage. It sets a massive stage for its sequel, Revenge, slated for March 19, 2026, leaving audiences both exhausted and eager for more. For fans of grounded, high-stakes cinema, it is an absolute must-watch.

author: nitinjaiswal06
title: Aditya dhar backupd by yami as house wife for mental peace to give masterpiece
text:
The Verdict: A Masterclass in Espionage Dhurandhar is a gritty, high-stakes thriller that proves Indian cinema can deliver a world-class spy epic without relying on over-the-top stunts. Director Aditya Dhar swaps flashy heroics for raw realism, focusing on the psychological tension of undercover operations.

* The Cast: Ranveer Singh delivers a career-defining, restrained performance, while Akshaye Khanna is terrifyingly brilliant as the antagonist.

* The Action: Intense, visceral, and grounded. Every sequence feels earned and high-stakes.

* The Vibe: Dark, immersive, and fast-paced. It's a cerebral cat-and-mouse game that keeps you on the edge of your seat.

Bottom Line: A massive achievement for Bollywood. It's not just a movie; it's an experience that sets a new gold standard for the genre.

author: ankityadav-90051
title: A Masterpiece of Patriotism and Espionage
text:
Yet again, Aditya Dhar has delivered an absolute masterpiece. With this film, the director is undeniably on a roll, establishing himself as one of the most daring and purposeful filmmakers in contemporary Indian cinema. While many of his peers continue to churn out frivolous romantic comedies and predictable love stories, Dhar remains committed to telling the untold, brave tales of real heroes-stories that deserve to be on the big screen. And he nails it perfectly.

I'm not typically a huge fan of Ranveer Singh, but credit where it's due: under Aditya Dhar's direction, Singh delivers a performance that does full justice to his complex character. One can't help but wonder if another actor might have brought an equally powerful interpretation to the role, yet Bollywood's infamous networking game seems to have prevailed once more. That said, Singh rises to the occasion, and the result is compelling.

A massive thank you to Aditya Dhar for finally giving us a sensible, gripping Indian spy thriller that honors its subject with authenticity and intensity. Hats off to the casting team as well-they've pulled off a coup by assembling an ensemble of absolute juggernauts, creating on-screen magic that's rare to witness.

This is the kind of cinema India needs more of. I'm already counting the days until the second part. Highly recommended-don't miss it !!!!

Ranveer Singh's portrayal is nuanced, embodying both vulnerability and tactical brilliance. Sanjay Dutt brings authority and intimidation to every scene, while Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan elevate supporting sequences with subtle performances. Arjun Rampal's quiet menace permeates multiple pivotal moments, and Sara Arjun's emotional authenticity provides a humanizing counterpoint. Aditya Dhar's direction balances layered storytelling with adrenaline-driven sequences. Cinematography captures the scale of the underworld alongside intimate character moments, and the score enhances tension and emotional resonance. By the climax, every narrative thread converges in a finale that is thrilling, shocking, and deeply satisfying.

author: framebyrahul
title: A Monument in Indian Cinema - I'm Still Thinking About It
text:
It has been weeks since I first saw Dhurandhar and the more I reflect on it the more I realize we have just witnessed a massive shift in storytelling. Aditya Dhar has not just made a thriller. He has built a sprawling eight chapter epic that feels more like a prestige series than a standard movie.

The decision to divide the film into eight distinct movements is a stroke of genius. It forces you to sit with the consequences of every scene. One specific chapter set in the streets of Lyari is a masterclass in world building. We were not just watching a mission. We were breathing the air of that world. It is rare to see a director trust his audience enough to let the plot simmer for over three hours but here every minute is earned.

If there is any justice the cinematography should sweep every award this year. It is sculpted in the truest sense. Instead of the usual bright action movie look it uses a dark shadow heavy style that makes the screen feel alive. The way the camera frames Ranveer's character often in half shadow perfectly mirrors a man losing his identity to his cover. The red screen moment during the intercepts felt genuinely new for a mainstream film.

The music score is the secret weapon here. It does not just underline the action. It drives it. The synth heavy sound in the climax gave me chills. The way the score transitions from traditional textures into cold mechanical sounds mirrors the lead character's descent from a man of mission to a machine of war.

While some may complain about the long runtime it is necessary. This film respects patience and craft. It shows the waiting and the mental weight of being undercover. Ranveer's performance is built on what he does not say and Akshaye Khanna is terrifying because of how human and polite he is.

Dhurandhar is a technical marvel that refuses to simplify itself for the masses. It is gritty long and unapologetically intelligent. This is a film that will be studied for years as the moment Indian cinema finally grew up. Absolute ten out of ten.

author: SrinathR-83
title: This is must watch Theatrical Experience
text:
Went into Dhurandhar expecting a hard-hitting spy thriller, and on many counts, the film delivers. Director Aditya Dhar builds a violent, morally charged world inspired by real-life events, giving the story solid weight. The performances are the film's biggest strength-Ranveer Singh brings fierce intensity and carries the narrative whenever the stakes rise, while Akshaye Khanna and R. Madhavan add depth and gravitas to the drama. Visually, the gritty cinematography, realistic action, and strong background score make it a compelling big-screen experience.

That said, the film isn't without flaws. Its lengthy 3h 32m runtime leads to slower stretches, especially in the middle, which may test the patience of viewers expecting a tighter thriller. While the ambitious eight-chapter structure mostly works, a sharper edit could have elevated the impact. Overall, Dhurandhar is a bold and intense watch that largely hits its mark-imperfect, but worth experiencing for fans of hard-edged spy thrillers.

author: Mishy101
title: Probably the most realistic Indian spy thriller, simply loved it.
text:
This isn't merely a movie, it feels like a gut punch of truth, a long overdue cinematic wake up call for India, from the moment the film begins.

Movie starts with the infamous hijacking of IC-814 which was taken to Kandhar Afganistan and follows up with the terror attack on the Indian Parliament, it makes you feel how incompetent we were and what's the mindset of these terrorists, and then from there on it grabs you by the collar and drags you deep into the world of covert terror networks the kind that operate across the border, lurking in the shadows, pulling strings from Pakistan. The brutality, the cold calculation, the lies it paints a chillingly realistic portrait of how these terrorists operate.

This film doesn't do the old Bollywood fireworks, it doesn't lean on exaggerated jingoism. Instead, it opts for gritty realism. The depiction of terror operations feels raw.

What made my jaw drop was the film's most explosive strand, when it's revealed that a minister and his son (movie hinted towards P Chidambaram) being linked to schemes that enabled fake currency to flood the country. The way the movie lays out this charge, the quiet transfers, the paper trails, the calculated betrayals. Watching it, I felt a cold morphological shift from disbelief to outraged clarity, the film insists we can't compartmentalize national security from the corridors of power.

Performances are electrifying, villains are frighteningly human and bureaucratic, amazing background score and themes for different characters, quite cool overall.

I feel if cinema is meant to provoke and make us look at uncomfortable truths, Dhurandhar succeeds spectacularly.

Controversial? Absolutely.

Brave? Undeniably.

Movie being of 3hrs 35mins doesn't feel long surprisingly. It's the kind of film that will be argued about for years, a cinematic blow that asks us not just to watch, but to reckon.

Eagerly waiting for the next part.

author: z3dverse
title: A Masterpiece
text: Dhurandhar completely blew me away - and I actually did a bit of reading about the film beforehand so I wasn't just guessing: it's clearly rooted in real covert operations and inspired by real figures and events, which gives everything a heavier, more grounded feel than your usual glossy actioner, and I loved that about it; the movie doesn't chase a single over-the-top climax so much as it carefully unfolds - a relentless, realistic sequence of intelligence work, consequences, and human costs - and that slow-burn, documentary-ish weight made the whole thing feel way more authentic and intense to me. The cast is insane: everyone brings it - the leads and the smaller players - no weak links, and their chemistry and conviction kept me locked in even during the quieter stretches. Direction and production design make the world feel lived-in and dangerous, not stylised for show, and the score and camerawork ramp up tension without ever feeling manipulative. I came out of the theatre buzzing not because of a single jaw-dropping finale but because the film left me thinking about the moral grey areas it digs into and the real people it nods to; that's rarer than you'd expect in a big film. If you're after authentic spycraft framed like a human story more than a superhero spectacle, this is your movie - powerful, thoughtful, and properly acted. I genuinely enjoyed every minute and I'm already keen for whatever comes in the next sequel.

author: Mr-Gahlot
title: Dhurandhar: Undercover Fury in the Heart of Karachi's Chaos
text:
What a rollercoaster! Aditya Dhar has outdone himself with Dhurandhar, crafting a spy thriller that's equal parts gritty gangster saga and high-octane espionage drama. Ranveer Singh as Hamza is a revelation-fierce, vulnerable, and utterly magnetic as the undercover Indian agent infiltrating Karachi's shadowy Lyari gang. His transformation from a mysterious drifter to a force tearing apart the ISI-underworld nexus feels raw and real, blending intense action sequences with those quiet moments of moral ambiguity that hit you hard.

The ensemble steals the show too: Akshaye Khanna oozes menacing charisma as Rehman Dakait, Sanjay Dutt brings that timeless gravitas in his limited but pivotal role, and R. Madhavan's Ajay Sanyal adds layers of strategic depth. Arjun Rampal and Sara Arjun round out the cast with solid support, keeping the emotional stakes sky-high. At 3+ hours, you'd think it'd drag, but the pacing is razor-sharp-every twist in the political intrigue and brutal fight scenes (those goosebump-inducing chases through Karachi's underbelly!) keeps you glued. The BGM, with clever nods to classic Bollywood tracks, amps up the immersion without overdoing it.

Sure, a few subplots feel a tad overstuffed, and the gore might turn off the faint-hearted, but this is bold, unapologetic cinema that resonates with real-world edge. A must-watch for thriller fans-leaves you craving that sequel tease at the end. Kudos to the tech team; the cinematography captures the chaos perfectly. One of 2025's best!

author: svetank-chaudhary
title: A Raging Storm
text: I walked out of the theater carrying the kind of quiet that follows a storm-the hush that comes after a film has shaken something loose inside you. Dhurandhar is that rare, unflinching work: a brave story told with the steadiness of someone who has seen the truth up close and refuses to look away. What makes it so gripping is its realism-not just in tone, but in texture. You feel the grit of the streets, the weight of decisions, the tension of rooms where history is being nudged, ever so forcefully, into focus. The story, inspired by real events, does not merely borrow from reality; it honors it. The integration of real footage is seamless and purposeful, never a gimmick or a shortcut. It acts like a spine running through the narrative, giving the film a raw nerve and undeniable authenticity. And yet, for all its documentary-like sincerity, the movie doesn't forget to breathe. It entertains-smartly, fiercely-drawing you in with craft and pacing, then challenging you with consequence. The acting is, simply, fabulous. Performances here aren't just "strong"-they are lived-in. You see it in the eyes before a word is spoken, in the small hesitations, in the way a hand grips a table edge when the weight of a choice becomes too heavy to carry. The lead turns in a performance that feels both heroic and human, while the supporting cast adds a chorus of voices that make the world of the film feel startlingly alive. Some critics, especially those viewing the film through a rigid ideological lens, seem to miss its core. This isn't a polemic; it's a portrait-of moral courage, of the costs paid by those who insist that truth be seen in the clear light of day. The film does not demand you agree with every choice its characters make; it asks only that you witness. And in witnessing, you feel. By the time the credits roll, Dhurandhar has done something rare: it leaves you stirred, not by spectacle alone, but by conviction. It's the kind of film that reminds you why stories matter-why we revisit painful histories, why we celebrate defiance, why we keep pushing for clarity in a world that so often rewards the fog. Watch it. Sit with it. Let it argue with you. And then, maybe, let it change you a little.

title: Go For It !!!
text:
I would like to Start with the Real Life elements used in the Film , Like 1999 Kandahar Hijack , 2001 Parliament Attack and 2008 Mumbai Attacks.

Along with The Real life Currency Scam which was done by then Finance Minister who's name is as we all know sounds like P Bambambram !

The Story' Hits you hard as your Blood boils thinking how incapable and corrupt politicians has ruled over this Nation without any true sense of Nationalism and Patriotism.

Now as per Movie's Story. It sets in Pakistan's Lyari Town area in Karachi which is even now famous for it's Lawlessness and Gangland wars The Characters used in the film , Rahman Dakait , Arshad Pappu , Babu Dakait , Uzair Baloch , Jameel Sahab ( Based on Nabil Habol) , Asif Ali Zardaris close connection with these Gangsters , SSP Chaudhary Aslam , these are all Legendary status guys in Karachi's Gang history. Their Crimes n Corruption is talked about even to this date.

My suggestion is do watch some documentary or Videos on Lyari Gangwar before watching this movie. Then you will truly appreciate and enjoy the story even more.

Character of Ranveer is fictional and he is amalgamation of all Unknown Gunmens we all hear and are proud of who are living and bumping off India's enemies within Pakistan on daily basis.

The Story involving Ranveers Character is totally fictional and cleverly set up and mixed with the real life people and their lives. It's a very Smart mix of Reality and Fiction and Aditya Dhar has done it outstandingly.

The movie is 3 hour's 30 minutes but am not complaining, it's very well paced and each n every character is given enough time , so as audience we understand their Nature , motivation. Nothing feels rushed or underperforming.

A big and Special Shout out to Akshay Khanna Sahab, what an Acting. It seems he didn't act but was possessed by Soul of Rahman Dakait in entire film. When you watch him you will feel that this is how Rahman Dakait must have walked , talked , smiled, behaved , that's how Good Akshay Khanna is.

R madhavan is unrecognisable. He has done impeccable job as Ajit Doval ( name changed in movie) And Arjun Rampal, bhaisahab he is so Raw , intense that watching him in every scene gives you Literal Chills. He is surely gonna be the Big Bad Villain in 2nd Part. Yes there is a Second Part too.

And let me tell you the Last Scene , and the Voice of Sonu Nigam hits you different.

The film is dedicated to all the Unknown Gunmens who have sacrificed their entire life, without any form of Reward or Recognition so that we people can live safely . Salute to them , watch it for them atleast.

Just imagine we would never ever know even Names of those People.

Also the BGM is awesome, hits perfect cords at perfect Scenes.

Sanjay Dutt as SP Chaudhary Aslam plays his part well , and he does look exactly like the Real guy he is portraying.

The film is surely giving Burns to lot of Pakistan loving , Aman ki asha kind of Liberals but it's a Good Thing. They should feel the burn as the real Truth should be Known to all.

Final Verdict - Just go for it. Book your tickets and Watch it.

author: BinaG-98
title: Best movie for India against pakistan
text:
Dhurandhar is one of the boldest and most ambitious action thrillers Bollywood has delivered in recent years. Directed by Aditya Dhar and starring Ranveer Singh, Sanjay Dutt, Akshaye Khanna, R. Madhavan, Arjun Rampal, and Sara Arjun, the film plunges audiences into a gritty underworld saga inspired by real historical events and covert operations. At its core, the story follows Hamza (Ranveer Singh), a mysterious Indian agent who infiltrates Karachi's mafia and terror networks to dismantle them from within.

From the outset, Dhurandhar grabs attention with its intense world-building and meticulous attention to detail. The cinematography and background score elevate the film's atmosphere - weaving classic sounds with modern pulse - creating an immersive landscape that feels both cinematic and raw. The narrative unfolds over several chapters, and while the nearly 3.5-hour runtime may test some viewers' patience, many feel it never drags thanks to tight storytelling and dramatic momentum.

Performances are a standout strength. Ranveer Singh delivers a restrained yet powerful central performance, anchoring the film's emotional and action beats with confidence. Akshaye Khanna, in particular, has been widely praised for his role, bringing depth and charismatic menace to his character. The ensemble cast contributes to a textured experience - every actor adds weight, making the film feel both large in scope and detailed in execution.

That said, Dhurandhar isn't without its flaws. The extended second half and occasional narrative excesses may feel overindulgent, and some scenes lean on familiar tropes instead of fresh storytelling. But for fans of high-stakes espionage, layered character work, and powerhouse performances, Dhurandhar delivers a visceral, engaging experience that's worth watching on the big screen.

author: siddbhatt-237-624447
title: A stunning feat
text: I don't usually write reviews for movies but this was such a special movie that I felt the need to express my appreciation. This is a movie of rare brilliance and intensity, and one that holds your attention fully for 3.5 hours. The movie is technically brilliant, the casting is great and the script is taut with realistic dialogue. The performances are uniformly brilliant - no one puts a foot wrong and the background score elevates the viewing experience throughout. One rare thing about this movie is the number of unforgettable sequences it has - scenes that stay with you long after leaving the theatre. Watching this makes me wonder why everyone doesn't make movies in this manner, instead of making slop like Animal with its awful script and cringeworthy dialogue. Perhaps it comes down to the man who put all of it together - the Director Aditya Dhar. He is clearly in a different league to his peers and as he himself said - he wants to make films, not complete a 'project'. Can't wait for part 2 and everything else Aditya Dhar will do for the rest of his career. And yes, I will be going back to the theatre to watch it at least one more time.

author: traikhy
title: Espionage thriller, one of the best in india
text:
Dhurandhar is an engaging watch driven by strong performances-particularly from Madhavan and Akshaye Khanna-and an impressive musical backbone.

The film still offers enough substance to make it a worthwhile espionage thriller, one of the best in india.

Ranveer Singh delivers a strong and committed performance as Hamza, bringing physicality and emotional urgency to the role. His screen presence keeps the narrative engaging, especially during high-stakes action sequences.

R. Madhavan, as Ajay Sanyal-the Chief of the Intelligence Bureau-truly stands out. This is classic Madhavan method acting: restrained, intelligent, and layered.

Akshaye Khanna is exceptional as Rehman Dakait. His portrayal is chilling, especially in the brutally raw action sequences that are designed to make the audience uncomfortable-and they succeed. Once again, Akshaye completely dissolves into his character, reinforcing why he remains one of the most underrated actors in the Hindi film industry.

Arjun Rampal is convincingly menacing as Major Iqbal, while Rakesh Bedi does full justice to his role as a scheming politician, adding subtle menace and realism. Sanjay Dutt, as SP Chaudhary Aslam, feels routine and visually similar to several of his recent performances, offering little novelty.

The music is another major highlight. Composer Shashwat Sachdev smartly integrates classic Pakistani tracks like Hawa Hawa, ghazals such as Chupke Chupke, and qawwalis like Afreen Afreen, alongside Indian retro bangers like Piya Tu Ab To Aaja and Rambha Ho. These choices flow organically with the narrative rather than feeling forced.

The film's jukebox boasts several standout tracks, including the powerful title song, the reimagined Karvan qawwali, and Ez-Ez, all worth a listen.

The background score effectively amplifies tension and delivers the adrenaline rush needed to elevate the action-heavy moments.

author: rinkudaxini
title: Aditya Dhar's Unflinching Vision: A Landmark Film for Indian Filmmaking
text:
The film's unflinching honesty is its greatest asset. It lays bare the critical issues on both sides of the border with skillful neutrality, never stooping to name-calling. The overall direction, writing, and marvelous ensemble performances deserve every bit of the praise they receive.

Mr. Dhar's boldness is commendable-he chose to relay the bare truth, and his execution was superb, pulling phenomenal, career-best performances from the entire cast. While I won't be surprised if the film is unfortunately overlooked in the Best Director and Best Actor awards due to clear ideological bias, its quality remains undeniable.

This movie is a watershed moment for Indian filmmaking. I'm already certain Part 2 is going to be an even bigger hit.

author: Appleabhishekshukla
title: A Relentless, Gritty Spy Thriller
text:
That Raises the Bar for Bollywood.

Dhurandhar is a gripping, no-nonsense spy thriller that proves Bollywood can deliver world-class espionage cinema without relying on clich√©s or unnecessary fluff. From the very first frame, the film pulls you into a dark, tense world of intelligence operations, moral ambiguity, and high-stakes patriotism.

Ranveer Singh delivers one of his most controlled and intense performances to date. Gone are the flamboyant quirks - here he is raw, focused, and completely convincing as a man shaped by secrets, loss, and duty. The supporting cast is equally strong, with every actor bringing weight and credibility to their roles, especially in the confrontational and dialogue-heavy scenes.

What truly stands out is the writing and direction. The screenplay respects the audience's intelligence, avoiding spoon-feeding and trusting viewers to follow the layered narrative. The pacing is deliberate - sometimes slow, but always purposeful - allowing tension to build naturally. Action sequences feel grounded and brutal rather than stylized, which adds to the realism.

Technically, the film is top-notch. Cinematography captures a moody, international spy-film aesthetic, the background score enhances tension without overpowering scenes, and the sound design during action moments is particularly impactful.

Dhurandhar isn't a typical masala entertainer - it's serious, intense, and occasionally uncomfortable. But that's exactly its strength. It asks questions about loyalty, sacrifice, and the cost of living in the shadows.

Final Verdict: A bold, mature, and ambitious spy thriller that marks a significant step forward for the genre in Hindi cinema. Not for those looking for light entertainment, but a must-watch for fans of intelligent, hard-hitting storytelling.

author: samarthdesai-01565
title: Next Level Experience
text:
If cinema is meant to be an immersive experience, Dhurandhar is the new gold standard. From the very first frame to the rolling credits, this film does not just entertain; it engulfs you. It is a cinematic triumph that proudly wears its identity on its sleeve-unapologetically Indian, fiercely intense, and technically flawless.

What truly sets Dhurandhar apart is the technical wizardry on display, specifically the synchronization of the background score (BGM) with the visuals. The editors and sound designers deserve a standing ovation. The music doesn't just accompany the scene; it dictates the heartbeat of the film. Every punch, every chase sequence, and every dramatic pause is mathematically timed to the score, creating a "next-level experience" that feels less like a movie and more like a sensory event. The BGM acts as an adrenaline pump, elevating the tension to a fever pitch.

Narratively, the film manages a difficult balancing act. It is undeniably a hero-focused movie, with the protagonist carrying the weight of the mission and the emotional arc. However, the screenplay is generous and intelligent enough to ensure that it isn't a one-man show. The film features a heavyweight ensemble cast, and every major actor is given equal importance. There are no wasted characters here; each performance adds a crucial layer to the storytelling, making the stakes feel real and the camaraderie authentic.

But the soul of Dhurandhar lies in its spirit. In an era of globalized content, this film stands tall as a rooted, "Hindustani" movie. It captures the grit, the emotion, and the ethos of India without resorting to empty clich√©s. It connects with the audience on a visceral level, evoking a sense of pride and belonging that resonates long after the lights come up.

Verdict: Dhurandhar is a masterclass in modern commercial cinema. With stellar performances, a thumping score that syncs perfectly with the action, and a story that beats with an Indian heart, it is a must-watch. It is big, bold, and brilliantly executed. Don't miss it.

author: mainakoddar
title: One of the best spy movie
text:
Dhurandar is a fast-paced, engaging entertainer that blends action, emotion, and sharp storytelling. From the very first scene, the film sets a strong tone with its stylish visuals and gripping background score. The director deserves credit for keeping the narrative tight and making sure the audience remains hooked throughout.

The lead actor delivers one of his most powerful performances-balancing intensity, humour, and vulnerability with ease. His screen presence lifts every scene, especially the high-voltage action sequences which are choreographed with great precision. The supporting cast also performs convincingly and adds depth to the story.

One of the strongest aspects of Dhurandar is its screenplay. The twists are well-placed, the dialogues are memorable, and the emotional moments feel genuine rather than forced. The cinematography is visually impressive, and the music complements the mood of the film beautifully.

While the film has a few predictable moments, they never take away from the overall experience. Instead, the energy, pace, and performances make Dhurandar a solid mass entertainer that keeps the audience satisfied till the end.

Overall, Dhurandar is a well-crafted, highly engaging film that delivers exactly what it promises-thrill, emotion, and entertainment. A must-watch for fans of high-impact commercial cinema.

author: visualverse25
title: Raw, Riveting and a Benchmark in the making
text:
This movie has 'aura' written all over it. I had heard the praise and was sceptical about the runtime, the flow, and the pacing, but Aditya Dhar quashes all of that, delivering something that truly deserves to be experienced on the big screen. There's really no other way to put it.

This is gonna be the benchmark for the future films of this genre. It's exhilarating, raw, and doesn't shy away from showing uncomfortable truths.

Coming to the performances, everyone delivers near perfection. Ranveer Singh, the obvious hero of the movie has given a phenomenal performance. The sketch and portrayal of Ajay Sanyal, played by Madhavan, felt so real and stylish.

The actor who plays the character of Uzair Baloch may not be named by many but delivers a strong performance throughout the movie. Very crucial to the plot and he acted so natural. And Sanjay Dutt played Sanjay Dutt, that works sometimes, sometimes that doesn't. Akshaye Khanna acted with brilliance from the very first scene which was exceptionally well acted. But I felt tired of seeing one dimensional expression throughout the movie.

The real hero of this movie is the soundtrack and bgm. They are well placed and on point, a mixture of modern and retro music. Nothing felt out of place.

While I didn't find the chemistry between the lead pair very convincing, I guess that was the intention (I may be wrong).

This movie demands to be experienced on the big screen. This is made for the big screen. Deserves all the hype it is getting. Part 2 can't come soon enough.

author: docvsa
title: Dhurandhar too violent but unavoidable
text:
*Review of Dhurandhar*

Pratham grasse makshita pata means the first bite itself tells you everything.

Let me state this at the very beginning: do not watch this movie if you are soft-hearted.

The level of violence is deeply disturbing and can get on your nerves. Despite being a doctor who has seen extreme brutality during post-mortems, I found certain scenes almost impossible to digest. It is disgusting - though undeniably real.

That said, the film is based on actual events, and because it confronts uncomfortable truths, one cannot simply avoid it as mere escapism. It is therefore not surprising that the film has been banned in six Arab countries and in Pakistan.

The movie exposes The Banker, The General, and The Gangster - the Pakistani Trinity that bled India. (Details are widely available online.)

The viral blockbuster *Dhurandhar brings this chilling reality to the big screen.* Along with the narrative, several shocking revelations emerge. Perhaps the most disturbing is the alleged involvement of an Indian UPA minister, who reportedly sold Indian currency printing plates to Pakistan - the same individual infamously known for "growing cauliflowers on his balcony." This so-called Cauliflower Man, his son, and former RAW Secretary A. S. Dulat are portrayed as being deeply entangled in the racket, allegedly receiving kickbacks.

On the Pakistani side, the Trinity included some of the most notorious figures: Ilyas Kashmiri and Sajid Mir (masterminds of the 26/11 attacks), Javed Khanani, the Karachi-based fake currency king, Gangster Rehman Dakait, and SP Aslam Chaudhary of Lyari.

These individuals are portrayed with remarkable accuracy in the film.

Set against major terror milestones - the IC-814 Kandahar hijacking (1999), the Indian Parliament attack (2001), and the 26/11 Mumbai attacks (2008) - the film follows Intelligence Bureau Chief Ajay Sanyal (brilliantly portrayed by R. Madhavan), codenamed Dhurandhar and based on Ajit Doval.

The convergence of the Trinity during the 2008 Mumbai attacks represents the film's most chilling moment - the perfect storm of the Banker, the General, and the Gangster.

A particularly telling dialogue comes when Ajay Sanyal says: "Kabhi koi sarkar aayegi, jisko desh ki chinta hogi; tab kuch karenge." (You know exactly whom this refers to.)

Dhurandhar is a stark reminder that modern warfare no longer requires tanks crossing borders. A nation can be destabilized by eroding trust in its own currency and economy.

The film depicts all this powerfully though I strongly feel that the makers could have avoided excessive, graphic violence, even if it was realistic.

That said, the story, dialogues, casting, direction, and performances are all of the highest caliber. The music of the 1970s and 80s adds a layer of nostalgia, and despite its 214-minute runtime, the film remains so gripping that time almost disappears.

An extension of Uri's iconic sentiment - *"Yeh naya India hai; yeh ghar mein ghusega bhi aur maarega bhi"* has propelled this film into blockbuster territory.

One can only hope that the next parts narrate the truth with the same intensity, but with less direct violence and greater restraint.

By *Dr. Vijay Athalye (2025)*

author: tb-sapgrc
title: Amazing espionage film with a strong message
text: Dhurander is a bold and uncompromising film that cuts through the distorted narratives often pushed in mainstream Bollywood. Instead of glorifying the Pakistani military or portraying them as unwilling participants, this movie presents the raw and unfiltered truth with remarkable clarity. It stands apart for its honesty, courage, and commitment to reality. The makers have delivered an important piece of cinema that deserves widespread appreciation. Viewers should wholeheartedly support and promote films like this, as they play a crucial role in bringing authenticity back to storytelling.

author: naman42237
title: Emotion-Heavy Moments Meet Power-Packed Scenes
text: Every scene is meticulously constructed, creating a world where danger feels omnipresent. Ranveer Singh's performance fluctuates between moral conflict and raw determination, whether in his calculated infiltration of criminal networks or quiet moments of reflection. Sanjay Dutt commands every interaction, his presence an anchor amid chaos. Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan offer subtle performances, making each exchange weighty and impactful. Arjun Rampal's controlled menace keeps tension taut, while Sara Arjun's poignant scenes remind viewers of the human cost of the narrative. Director Aditya Dhar ensures that the pacing, suspense, and action coexist perfectly. Cinematography frames both expansive urban chaos and intimate character moments with skill. The score heightens tension, especially during climactic confrontations, leading to a finale that is both shocking and emotionally satisfying.

author: mohitmohit-32080
title: A Thrilling Ride with Epic Performances
text: Every frame is charged with tension, drama, and intricate storytelling. Ranveer Singh delivers a multi-layered performance, Sanjay Dutt brings commanding authority, and Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan's roles add narrative depth. Arjun Rampal's menace contrasts with Sara Arjun's vulnerability, heightening stakes. Aditya Dhar directs with precision, blending suspense, strategy, and thrilling action sequences. Cinematography highlights both urban sprawl and intimate character moments, while the score accentuates tension. By the end, the film's combination of adrenaline, emotional resonance, and strong performances leaves viewers deeply impressed.

author: sameersoni-26858
title: Full of Action, Drama, and Emotion
text: Each sequence of the film is carefully constructed to heighten suspense, emotion, and realism. Ranveer Singh dominates with a performance that is both physically commanding and emotionally nuanced, embodying the moral complexity of his character. Sanjay Dutt adds gravitas, presence, and menace, making every interaction feel impactful. Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan provide intelligent, restrained performances that enrich the narrative, while Arjun Rampal's understated threat maintains constant tension. Sara Arjun's emotionally charged scenes anchor the story, giving depth to the stakes. Director Aditya Dhar ensures that every action sequence, dialogue-heavy scene, and character arc contributes to a cohesive, gripping narrative. Cinematography captures the chaos of urban environments and the intimacy of personal interactions, while the score accentuates suspense, drama, and emotion. The finale delivers a masterful blend of adrenaline, strategy, and emotional payoff.

author: Priyansh-83

author: Jayeshb-905
title: A Taut, Gripping Espionage Saga That Excels on Pure Grit
text: A powerful testament to the fact that an Indian spy thriller can be simultaneously high-voltage and deeply grounded in realism. Dhar sheds the typical "super-spy" tropes to deliver a gritty, authentic look at the immense personal sacrifices made behind enemy lines. An ambitious film, while undeniably long, rewards patient viewers with a meticulously crafted world, stellar performances, and a narrative urgency that rarely lets up.

author: RenukaA-63
title: Dhurandhar - A Bold, Emotionally Charged Thriller With Heart.
text:
Dhurandhar is one of those rare films that manages to be both massively entertaining and surprisingly thoughtful. The story grips you from the opening scene and refuses to let go, weaving together mystery, emotion, and social commentary in a way that feels fresh and impactful.

Ranveer Singh delivers one of his most layered performances, effortlessly switching between charm, vulnerability, and intensity. His character has real depth, and the film takes the time to explore his backstory in a way that adds weight to every twist. Akshaye Khanna is brilliant as always-calm, sharp, and quietly menacing when needed. His screen presence elevates every frame he appears in.

The direction deserves special mention: The pacing is tight without feeling rushed.

The cinematography captures both the grit and the beauty of the world the film is set in.

The background score enhances the tension perfectly, especially during the later emotional and psychological scenes (the smoking scene with Akshaye Khanna is masterfully done).

Beneath the thrills lies a very human story-one that touches on identity, morality, and the idea that people are far more complex than the labels society puts on them.

By the time the film ends, you're left with a sense of satisfaction and a lot to think about. It's the kind of movie that sparks conversation long after the credits roll.

Highly recommended if you enjoy intelligent thrillers, standout performances, and cinema that respects the audience's intelligence.

author: bronzereload
title: Powerful Cast and Captivating Storytelling
text: Indian cinema and TV have seen many action packed espionage and crime thrillers lately, but this one definitely hits it out of the park. It's raw, unhinged, and packed with energy from the begging till the very end. Ranveer Singh did great as the lead, but Akshaye Khanna, R. Madhavan, Sanjay Dutt, Gaurav Gera, Arjun Rampal and Rakesh Bedi all carried the movie with as much (or even more) zeal and energy. This is a perfect example of casting done right. The movie is among the longest in recent times, but split beautifully into chapters, woven together in seamless storytelling, with glimpses of real incidents that connect (and stir emotions) with the audiences, that at no point does it feel like it's dragging on. The set designing was on point, although more easily identifiable locations like the Rose Garden underpass, could have been substituted with lesser known public infrastructure that would pass for the actual locations in the story. Keeping that aside, no matter how gritty, gory, violent, and to some extent disturbing, some of the scenes might be, this is one of those movies that would make me go for seconds.

author: sujeetjeet
title: Dhurandhar (2025) - A Gripping Spy Thriller Based on the Reality of Indian Undercover Missions That Delivers on Every Front!
text:
Dhurandhar (2025) - A Gripping Spy Thriller Based on the Reality of Indian Undercover Missions That Delivers on Every Front!

Aditya Dhar's Dhurandhar is an absolute powerhouse of a film - a bold, ambitious spy action thriller that reminds us why we fell in love with Bollywood's big-scale storytelling. From the moment it starts, you're pulled into a gritty, high-stakes world of espionage, betrayal, and patriotism that's inspired by real events, and it never lets go.

Ranveer Singh is phenomenal as the undercover operative Hamza - restrained yet explosive, delivering one of his career-best performances with subtle intensity that builds to an unforgettable climax. But this is truly an ensemble triumph: Akshaye Khanna steals every scene as the menacing Rehman Dakait, oozing charisma and menace, while R. Madhavan, Sanjay Dutt, and Arjun Rampal bring incredible depth and presence to their roles. No one feels like a side character; everyone shines.

Hats off to director-writer Aditya Dhar (@AdityaDharFilms) for crafting a dense, meticulously researched universe with atmospheric world-building that's unlike anything we've seen in recent Indian cinema - special credit to journalist Aditya Raj Kaul (@AdityaRajKaul) as research consultant, whose expertise lends that authentic, reportage-level edge to the geopolitics, Karachi underworld details, and covert operations. What makes it truly powerful is how it portrays the harsh reality of Indian undercover missions - the sacrifices, moral dilemmas, and sheer courage our unsung heroes endure.

The cinematography is stunning, the action sequences are raw and visceral, and the background score thunders through the theater, elevating every twist and turn. It's politically sharp, emotionally charged, and packed with Shakespearean betrayals that keep you on the edge of your seat.

Dhurandhar is paisa vasool entertainment - a muscular, patriotic saga that's thrilling, thought-provoking, and brilliantly executed. Ranveer is back in top form, and this feels like the start of a new benchmark for Bollywood spy thrillers. Highly recommended - catch it on the big screen! #Dhurandhar.

author: mo_reviews_mo_vies
title: Dhurandhar Part 1: A Fiction Forged from Brutal and Painful Reality
text:
Dhurandhar truly is a breath of fresh air in the otherwise formulaic, predictable and endlessly unmemorable list of Bollywood movies that have come out in 2025. This movie has the potential to change Bollywood and its attitude on film making, prioritizing story, characters, cinematography over style (which this movie also has an abundance off).

The genius of the movie lies in its ability to hold the attention of viewers for a full 3.5 hours through meticulous world building of the infamous Lyari Town (based in Karachi) during the late 2000's. The movie does a great job of showing how the gangs in small Pakistani Towns are linked to global terrorist events.

The movie is a technical masterpiece with great cinematography, tight editing and a unique use of background score and old Bollywood songs. The acting and casting are top notch with outstanding performances from all the supporting cast as well. Starting with the gang members, they have been given opportunities to show their own unique personalities. Sara Arjun has also played a convincing character of a young daughter of an MP who has been stifled from enjoying her life at her age and is a perfect candidate for honey potting for Ranveer Singh's character. Rakesh Bedi as the MP of Lyari Town is as conniving and sketchy as the leaders of the gangs so much so that he uses his daughter as a pawn in order to maintain his political control over Karachi.

As for the main cast, each actor has truly metamorphized into their respective roles. R Madhavan is unrecognizable as the sharp, morally unshakeable and simmering underneath with anger Indian Intelligence Bureau Chief Ajay Sanyal. Arjun Rampal plays the cunning, vile and evil ISI Major Iqbal (although he has a short stint in this movie, the sequel might have a larger focus on him as the main antagonist). Sanjay Dutt was the perfect pick to play the frank, foul mouthed and strong-willed SP Aslam Chaudhary. His resemblance to the real-life character is uncanny.

However, Akshay Khanna takes the cake when it comes to playing the barbaric, ambitious and family loving gang leader Rehman Baloch (aka Rehman Dakait). His screen presence is magnetic and he takes the centre stage of any scene he is in. Last but by no means the least, Ranveer Singh has a perfectly played the role of an undercover spy who is trying to make his name in the Karachi Gang syndicate to uncover the people responsible for committing the terrorist atrocities on India. His understated performance (quiet contrary to his bombastic and extrovert real life personality) shows the man's versatility and ability to shape shift into any role given to him. Dhurandhar might very well be the turning point in his career giving him the much-needed impetus to go onto possibly become the future king of Bollywood.

As a cinephile, I can't be more excited to recommend this movie to everyone. The movie truly has the potential to break the old hero centric mould of Bollywood movies and usher in a new age of story and character centric movies. This however can only be possible if we as the audience show our support by watching this movie in the theatres and make it a financial success.

author: Adityam-165
title: Pure Cinema without any propaganda
text:
This film feels like pure cinema in the truest sense of the word. It avoids cheap tricks, unnecessary noise, and exaggerated storytelling, and instead focuses on presenting a grounded, immersive experience that feels honest and real. There is no forceful messaging, no agenda-driven narrative, and no misleading or fabricated information. What you get is a film that respects the intelligence of its audience and trusts them to feel, think, and experience the story in their own way.

The storytelling is tight and meaningful, carefully balancing emotion, realism, and cinematic beauty. Every scene feels purposeful, and every moment adds weight to the overall journey. The film doesn't rely on over-the-top drama or unrealistic heroism. Instead, it shows human struggle, silence, tension, and resilience in a way that feels authentic. The world it creates feels lived-in, familiar, and believable, as if you are not just watching a story but stepping into real moments of real lives.

Performances are powerful yet restrained. The actors don't "perform" their roles; they live them. Their expressions, silences, and body language speak more than loud dialogues ever could. The direction is confident and mature, allowing scenes to breathe rather than rushing through emotions. The cinematography captures rawness and beauty in equal measure, making even the quietest frames feel impactful and meaningful.

What makes this film truly special is its honesty. It doesn't manipulate emotions, it earns them. It doesn't sell fantasy; it presents reality through a cinematic lens that feels respectful and sincere. This is not just a movie for entertainment; it is an experience that stays with you long after the screen fades to black.

This is cinema at its purest - simple, truthful, and deeply powerful.

author: prajjwalsingh-96797
title: Dhurandhar - When Indian Spy Cinema Learns the Art of Silence and Substance
text:
Dhurandhar is not just another spy film-it feels like a quiet reset button for the Indian spy universe. What instantly stands out is the filmmaking style: restrained, confident, and deeply immersive. The film doesn't rely on loud nationalism or overdone spectacle; instead, it trusts its storytelling, visuals, and characters to do the heavy lifting.

Aditya Dhar's approach to character-building deserves special mention. Every character feels intentional, layered, and grounded in reality. You can sense the time spent in shaping their motivations, silences, and moral conflicts. Nothing feels rushed or decorative-each arc serves the larger narrative. Dhar proves once again that he understands how to make patriotism feel earned rather than announced.

The performances across the board are exceptional. There isn't a single weak link-each actor brings depth and authenticity, making the world of Dhurandhar feel lived-in and believable. The acting doesn't scream for attention; it pulls you in subtly, which makes the impact even stronger.

What truly sets Dhurandhar apart is how it redefines the Indian spy universe. It chooses intelligence over noise, tension over theatrics, and realism over formula. The film respects the audience's intelligence and rewards patience, leaving a lasting impression long after the credits roll.

In essence, Dhurandhar is a masterclass in controlled storytelling-bold in vision, refined in execution, and refreshing in its intent. This is the kind of cinema that doesn't just entertain; it elevates the genre.

title: Fantastic
text:
Dhurandhar, the legendary cartoonist! I just can't get enough of his incredible work! His cartoons are like a breath of fresh air, always hitting the nail on the head with wit and humor. The way he captures the essence of Indian society and politics is simply amazing!

His creations like "Garam Chai" and "Gayabari Gopinath" are iconic, and his ability to poke fun at everyday situations is unparalleled. His art is simple yet powerful, making us laugh and think at the same time. It's no wonder he's considered one of India's greatest cartoonists!

What I love about Dhurandhar's work is how relatable it is. His cartoons are like a mirror to our society, reflecting our quirks and flaws in a way that's both entertaining and thought-provoking. He's a true master of his craft, and I'm a huge fan!

If you're not familiar with Dhurandhar's work, do yourself a favor and check him out. Trust me, you won't be disappointed! His cartoons will make you smile, nod in agreement, and maybe even make you think twice about the world around you. A true legend in Indian cartooning!

author: rameshlaad-33871
title: Stars, Action, and Pure Entertainment
text: The film immerses viewers in a dangerous, morally complex world where every decision carries life-altering consequences. Ranveer Singh delivers an extraordinary performance, seamlessly balancing emotional vulnerability, intellectual strategy, and physical intensity. Sanjay Dutt brings commanding presence and gravitas, while Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan provide cerebral support that enriches the story. Arjun Rampal's quiet menace heightens suspense, and Sara Arjun's emotional authenticity offers a human perspective on the stakes. Aditya Dhar's direction blends suspense, action, and psychological tension perfectly. Cinematography captures sprawling urban chaos and intimate character moments, while the score accentuates tension, drama, and action. The second half escalates with explosive revelations and confrontations, culminating in a finale that is both thrilling and emotionally resonant.

author: imdbfan-4531838808
title: Cinematic Excellence Unleashed
text: A cinematic achievement that combines intelligence, intensity, and style, the movie demands attention from start to finish. Ranveer Singh's portrayal is layered and immersive, anchoring the story's emotional core. Dhar's direction balances high-stakes action with introspective character moments, giving every scene purpose. Supporting performances are memorable, each adding texture to the world of intrigue. Visual storytelling and sound design amplify tension, resulting in a film that is as gripping intellectually as it is viscerally thrilling.

author: vs-83042
title: Dhurandhar: I believe it's a truth
text:
Dhurandhar is an absolute triumph of intense, uncompromising filmmaking that deserves every bit of praise it is receiving. Directed by Aditya Dhar, this isn't the usual Bollywood spy spectacle; it's a raw, visceral, and creeping journey into the dangerous heart of international espionage and the global syndicate of terror. The film's greatness lies in its unflinching commitment to realism and its deliberate, slow-burn tension.

From the moment Ranveer Singh's character, Hamza, infiltrates the Karachi underworld of Lyari, the movie establishes a palpable sense of danger and moral murkiness. It is a dense, detailed world of gang wars and political machinations, all inspired by and woven around real-life geopolitical conflicts. The plot meticulously details the cold, calculating nature of covert operations, making the audience feel the weight of every difficult decision and the true cost of operating outside the lines.

The movie succeeds brilliantly in showing the truth of this gritty, unforgiving world. It is unapologetic, grounded, and focused on the emotional and physical toll on the operatives. The action is not glorified but presented as brutal, necessary, and realistic, especially the hand-to-hand combat sequences.

Ranveer Singh delivers one of his most powerful and restrained performances, carrying the weight of his mission with intense, brooding subtlety-a true beast on screen. However, it is Akshaye Khanna, as the menacing kingpin Rehman Dakait, who truly commands the film with his chilling, controlled presence. The entire ensemble cast is stellar, giving the massive 3.5-hour runtime a gripping, propulsive quality that prevents it from ever feeling slow. Backed by a phenomenal, goosebump-inducing background score, Dhurandhar is a masterclass in storytelling and technical craft. It is a must-watch film that offers both high-stakes action and a deep, thoughtful narrative, proving that Bollywood can deliver a world-class, great cinematic thriller.

author: shubhamshuuu
title: Drama That Keeps You on the Edge
text: Every element of this film-from performance to direction to technical execution-works in concert to create a gripping, unforgettable experience. Ranveer Singh's portrayal is layered and compelling, making the audience invest in his character's journey from the first scene. Action sequences are meticulously choreographed, blending tension, realism, and cinematic flair. Supporting actors provide depth, each scene reinforcing the stakes and motivations. The director's vision ensures a delicate balance between character development and plot progression. Cinematography captures both intimate moments and epic scale with equal artistry, while the score punctuates tension and emotion seamlessly. The finale delivers a powerful conclusion, leaving viewers in awe of the cinematic craftsmanship.

author: ankurvaid-38758
title: 10/10 Haven't seen better movies than this
text:
10/10 - A Cinematic Masterpiece That Transcends Time

Dhurandar is not just a film; it is a profound, soul-stirring experience that etches itself permanently into the viewer's consciousness. From the very first frame to the hauntingly beautiful final shot, this movie is a flawless symphony of impeccable storytelling, breathtaking visuals, and powerhouse performances.

The narrative is a masterclass in emotional depth and complexity, weaving a tale that is both intimately personal and grandly universal. It navigates the rugged terrain of human relationships, ambition, and sacrifice with a sensitivity and intelligence that is rare in cinema today. The screenplay is taut, layered, and rich with symbolism, demanding and rewarding the viewer's complete attention.

Every performance is a revelation, with the lead actors delivering career-defining work. Their portrayals are so raw, so authentic, that you forget you are watching a performance and instead feel you are witnessing real life unfold. The supporting cast is equally magnificent, adding layers of texture and authenticity to the world of the film.

Visually, Dhurandar is a canvas painted with light and shadow. The cinematography is nothing short of spectacular, using the Maharashtrian landscape not merely as a backdrop but as a vital, breathing character in the story. Each composition is a work of art, enhancing the film's emotional gravity. The music score seamlessly blends with the narrative, rising and falling with the characters' journeys, amplifying every moment of joy, tension, and heartbreak.

Director Ravi Jadhav has crafted his magnum opus. His vision is clear, confident, and uncompromising, guiding this epic with a steady hand and a poetic heart. The film's pacing is perfect, allowing the story to breathe and the characters to grow, culminating in a climax that is both devastating and spiritually uplifting.

In an era of fleeting entertainment, Dhurandar stands as a monumental achievement-a film of immense beauty, intelligence, and heart. It is a powerful, moving, and unforgettable journey that deserves not just to be seen, but to be felt and contemplated. This is Indian cinema at its absolute finest. A perfect 10. An undisputed classic.

author: akshayyr
title: The Movie Is A Blast
text: Most of the negative reviews around Dhurandhar feel forced and barely genuine. I watched the film with my friends a few days ago, and honestly, this is exactly what I want Bollywood to move towards. The film delivers solid action without turning mindless, performances that feel committed rather than lazy, and direction that knows what it wants to say. The pacing keeps you engaged, the atmosphere is gritty, and the execution feels confident. It doesn't insult the audience's intelligence and doesn't rely on unnecessary gimmicks. Overall, Dhurandhar is a well-made, engaging film that proves Bollywood can still deliver strong cinema when intent and craft come together.

author: imdbfan-5473096648
title: A Bold Story Fueled by Passion and Power
text: The story's gradual buildup makes each revelation and action set piece feel earned and impactful. Ranveer Singh anchors the narrative with a powerful performance, portraying both vulnerability and steely resolve. Sanjay Dutt's presence adds weight to the narrative, while Akshaye Khanna, R Madhavan, and Arjun Rampal create a dynamic ensemble whose interactions feel authentic and layered. Sara Arjun's performance brings emotional clarity amidst the chaos. Under Aditya Dhar's direction, suspense, political tension, and raw action coexist seamlessly. The cinematography captures the underworld's harshness, while the soundtrack complements both quiet and explosive sequences. By the second half, the tension and emotional stakes reach a peak that makes the film both thrilling and deeply affecting.

author: upamaroy2007
title: This film is a masterpiece. All low ratings are unwarranted & propagated.
text:
While the film runs well over three and a half hours, I still found myself wanting more even after the credits finished rolling.

Every actor delivers their role with absolute precision, the director brings brilliance to every frame, the cinematography is pure chef's kiss, and the music feels both refreshing and nostalgic. Pure perfection. An absolute masterpiece.

It is disappointing to see a smear campaign surrounding this movie, and I do not agree with people calling it "toxic," "masculine," or "violent." The subject matter demands rawness, grit, gore, violence and a certain kind of masculinity because of the characters and world it portrays. I wish more people would actually watch the film, understand its plot points, and see the vision behind delivering an espionage spy thriller, something truly new for Indian cinema.

I cannot wait for 19 March 2026!!
