author: Saurav-30
title: Dhurandhar
text:
Dhurandhar" is the kind of movie that surprises you in the best way. I went in without big expectations, but the film pulled me in almost immediately. It has that rare mix of fun, excitement, and emotion that keeps you watching without ever checking the time. What I liked most is how natural everything feels - the story doesn't try too hard, the humour doesn't feel forced, and the emotional moments actually hit.

The lead actor carries the movie really well. He has this easy screen presence that makes you connect with him instantly, and you actually care about what happens to his character. The supporting cast also does a solid job. Even the smaller roles feel important, and everyone gets at least one moment that stays with you. Their chemistry makes the movie feel grounded and real.

The visual style is another big plus. The movie looks clean, colourful, and well-shot. The timing of the cuts, the way scenes are framed, and even the simple moments all feel thoughtfully done. The music also plays a big part - the background score lifts the energy, and some scenes feel more impactful because of it.

What I appreciated most is the heart of the movie. Behind all the fun and entertainment, "Dhurandhar" has something to say about loyalty, courage, and believing in yourself. It's not preachy, but the message lands naturally through the characters and their choices. That's what makes the film stick with you even after it ends.

Overall, "Dhurandhar" is a refreshing watch - entertaining, meaningful, and memorable. It's one of those movies that make you feel good, make you think a little, and leave you satisfied. Definitely worth appreciating.

author: dharmesh-53
title: A Surprisingly Engaging Thriller with Strong Performances
text:
I didn't expect Dhurandhar to hit this hard. The story is raw, the emotions feel real, and the film builds tension in a way that keeps you thinking long after it ends. The lead's performance is honest and relatable. A few scenes are slow, but the payoff is strong.

Highly recommended for anyone who loves meaningful cinema.

author: Manoj-4086
title: Great movie
text:
Dhurandhar is one of those movies that doesn't try to be overly stylish or preachy - it just tells its story in a raw, honest way. From the very first scene, you can feel the dusty town vibe, the tension in the streets, and the constant push-and-pull between power and survival. It feels real, like something you could actually witness in any small town where politics and personal ego clash every day.

The first half moves really well. Characters are introduced smoothly, and you actually start caring about them without even realising it. The lead actor carries the film with a mix of calm intensity and emotion that feels natural, not forced. The action scenes are not over-the-top; they look like real fights, messy and unpredictable, which makes them way more engaging.

The score heightens suspense, and by the finale, the narrative delivers both emotional and adrenaline-fueled satisfaction.

author: sonianujmohit
title: Undoubtedly! most realistic spy-thriller movie
text:
Why its a must-watch: 1. Extremely well paced, you won't feel the time throughout the movie, only time I felt bored was during ad breaks in PVR.

2. IMAX movies are always pleasing to eyes, do take middle seats and scenes and bass will give you chills.

3. It shows true colors of pakistan, not just a hindu-muslim concept, but gangs/politicians working for money and power.

4. Top notch acting by Ranveer Singh, Akshay Khanna, Sanjay Dutt, R. Madhvan, Arjun Rampal. Even actress and side actors were brilliant.

5. Amazing screenplay, you will start to belive you are in Pakistan, and many times feel sad for the nation.

6. Build-up and explaination was amazing, from the beginning they made us understand requirment for the plan Dhurandar.

Not so good aspects: 1. Too many dialogues to convey hatered for current government(i.e Congress) and a build-up for the new government(i.e Modi Govt.) 2. Not many wow/claps/hooting moments, theatre was almost silent 3. Too much Gore, somewhat was required to show brutality, but making it a Final Destination death was not needed.

4. Just one dialogue that should have been corrected, terrorist says, "Hindu darpok kom hai", should have said "Bhartiya darpok log hai". This may make some communal tensions, other that this scene/dialogue no other, not even single scene shows hindu-muslim divide.

author: Abhishek-7134
title: Reality Check-In Into the Espionage world
text:
Skip Dhurandhar if you're craving YRF's glossy spy fantasies. No sleek cars, no bikini-clad bombshells, no cheesy RAW-ISI romance crap. Dhurandhar slams you with the brutal, blood-soaked reality of espionage. It's a kickass beast that doesn't pull punches.

Clocking in at a massive 3 hours 30 minutes, it still flies by without a single dull second. The relentless pace hooks you and keeps you glued to the edge of your seat. That background score? Pure adrenaline fuel that ramps up the chaos. Some scenes are so raw and visceral that they twist your insides. And those 26/11 audio clips? They ignite a firestorm of fury you will never forget.

author: amartyapandey
title: Redefines Bollywood
text: Dhurandhar delivers a pulse-pounding spy thriller that redefines Bollywood action with raw intensity and a stellar ensemble. Ranveer Singh transforms into the undercover operative Hamza, blending vulnerability with volcanic fury in a career-best performance. Director Aditya Dhar crafts a labyrinth of gang wars, terror networks, and geopolitical intrigue inspired by real RAW operations. Standout Performances Akshaye Khanna rules as the sly antagonist Rehman Dacait, stealing scenes with understated menace. Sanjay Dutt brings gravelly authority, Arjun Rampal delivers chills, and R. Madhavan adds sharp intellect. Technical Brilliance The nearly 3.5-hour runtime flies by with panoramic cinematography capturing gritty Karachi streets and a score remixing classics into adrenaline anthems. Action sequences erupt with strategic choreography, from chases to brutal combat. Why It's a Must-WatchThis Part 1 masterpiece balances drama, edge, and tension, leaving you hungry for the sequel. Despite minor pacing hiccups, its epic scope earns a 9.5/10-catch it in theaters.

author: monybatra
title: Star-Studded Cast Brings Action Alive
text: From the opening shot, the film immerses audiences into a meticulously constructed underworld where danger lurks in every shadow. Ranveer Singh delivers a career-defining performance, embodying both moral conflict and raw determination, his expressions and body language conveying the internal struggles of a man navigating treachery and loyalty. Sanjay Dutt dominates every scene with commanding authority, his presence alone heightening tension and credibility. Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan add layers of intelligence and subtlety, delivering dialogue and emotional beats that give the narrative depth. Arjun Rampal's quiet menace keeps viewers constantly on edge, while Sara Arjun's innocent, heartfelt moments add emotional stakes, grounding the story in humanity. Director Aditya Dhar's vision is impeccable, orchestrating suspense, strategy, and large-scale action sequences with precision. Cinematography captures Karachi's urban chaos and intimate, character-driven moments with equal flair, while the score punctuates every beat of tension, making even quiet scenes feel charged. The second half escalates into a breathtaking mix of revelations, confrontations, and emotional catharsis, culminating in a finale that is both thrilling and deeply satisfying.

author: rohitprabhu-83707
title: Dhurandhar: An Adrenaline-Pumping, Flawless Masterpiece!
text:
Verdict: A landmark patriotic thriller that Indian cinema desperately needed! Director Aditya Dhar delivers a staggering film that is, simply put, mind-blowing from start to finish.

Dhurandhar is not just a movie; it is a meticulously crafted, emotionally resonant, and relentlessly paced cinematic event. The sheer brilliance of the direction by Aditya Dhar is the film's backbone. Following his previous work, Dhar once again proves he is a master of the genre, tackling a sensitive patriotic subject with maturity, grit, and a spectacular vision. The scale and execution of this project are truly top-notch.

One of the film's most remarkable achievements is its narrative grip. At a colossal runtime of 3 and a half hours, it doesn't feel stretched for a single second. The screenplay is so taut and the pacing so dynamic that you remain glued to your seat, completely immersed in the covert operations and intense geopolitical drama.

The technical and performance aspects are equally flawless: BGM (Background Music): The score is an absolute character in itself-hard-hitting, visceral, and perfectly timed to amplify the tension and the emotional stakes. It gives you goosebumps during every action beat.

Acting: The ensemble cast is flawless. Every actor, regardless of screen time, delivers a knockout performance, bringing conviction and raw intensity to their respective roles.

Patriotic Tone: This is the kind of patriotic film that is the much-needed hour for Indian cinema. It is grounded, real, and carries its nationalistic message with dignity and impact, avoiding melodrama.

A special, towering mention must go to Aditya Dhar for taking on such an ambitious and amazing project and executing it in a breathtaking way. His vision, dedication, and ability to command such a massive canvas are truly commendable. Dhurandhar sets a new benchmark for the Indian spy thriller genre. A must-watch big-screen experience!

author: amitabhp-32296
title: A Powerhouse Blend of Drama and High Action
text: Intelligence and ambition define this film, which balances high-stakes action with emotional resonance. Ranveer Singh's portrayal is magnetic, conveying both charm and moral ambiguity, ensuring audiences are invested in his character's choices. Director Dhar orchestrates a rich narrative, blending suspenseful plotting with moments of quiet reflection that deepen the story. Action sequences are crafted with precision, often escalating tension through inventive choreography rather than sheer spectacle. Each supporting actor delivers memorable performances, with layered motivations that make the underworld feel vivid and dangerous. The cinematography captures a spectrum of moods, from claustrophobic intensity to wide, cinematic tension, while the sound design intensifies every heartbeat of the narrative. The screenplay's intricate pacing ensures that even the quieter moments are charged with significance. By the climax, the film achieves a rare synthesis of adrenaline, emotion, and narrative satisfaction.

author: rnraoin-43966
title: Record Breaking
text:
Personally, Dhurandhar broke more records for me than it did at the box office.

I've never liked a movie enough to watch it twice in the theater within two weeks - until Dhurandhar. I had never done that before. Usually, with OTT releases just a month or two away, there's little reason to revisit a film on the big screen. But this one was different. Its characters quietly move into your mind and refuse to leave. Even after leaving the theater, you keep discovering more about them through reels, interviews, and behind-the-scenes stories - which only deepen the connection.

I've always dismissed remixes as unoriginal, a lazy excuse to repackage old hits. But Dhurandhar's music turned that belief on its head. Its tracks sound as fresh and stirring as the originals - sometimes even more so. I've been looping the album nonstop, and every listen makes me want to experience the film again on the big screen. The absence of official music videos only adds to the intrigue, making the imagination do the heavy lifting.

What Dhurandhar has really done is redefine my movie-watching experience. I've always appreciated nationalistic and patriotic films, but most fail to deliver artistically. Audiences don't pay for sentiment alone - they pay for quality. Dhurandhar succeeds because it's an exceptional piece of filmmaking first, and a patriotic story second. Its commercial success proves that excellence resonates across ideologies, unlike Ikkis or other "peace narrative" films that have struggled to find an audience.

Perhaps the most surprising record it broke was personal - I never imagined watching a Ranveer Singh film in theaters, let alone twice. Though undoubtedly talented, I often found his performances excessive. The last Hindi film I watched in a theater was Chup. Since then, nothing - no actor, no story - felt worth the ticket. Films like Su From So or Kantara seemed more deserving of that big-screen experience... until Dhurandhar came along.

Many have compared it to Satya - RGV's finest work - calling Dhurandhar "the Satya of Lyari." I couldn't agree more. Every few years, a film comes along that resets the standard and redefines cinema's possibilities. Dhurandhar is one of those rare milestones.

author: GambhireP
title: There is still hope from Bollywood
text:
Watched Dhurandhar yesterday, and it genuinely left an impression on me. The film may not be your typical masala entertainer, but it has its own intensity that slowly pulls you in.

The story builds up with a mix of mystery, emotion, and a slight old-school flavor, which I actually enjoyed. What stood out the most for me was Akshaye Khanna's performance, he completely owns every frame he's in. There's something about his calm yet commanding presence that makes even the simplest dialogue hit harder. He brings depth to his character without going overboard, and that's what makes him so good. You can sense the maturity and nuance he adds; it's one of those performances that remind you why he's still among the most underrated actors in Bollywood.

The supporting cast did fairly well too, though some scenes could've had tighter editing. The background score added a nice touch to the tension, especially in the second half. But honestly, it's Akshaye who carries the film on his shoulders.

Overall, Dhurandhar is not just another thriller, it's a performance-driven film with substance. If you're someone who appreciates strong acting and layered storytelling, it's definitely worth watching once.

author: Kmanav
title: Dhurandar: Style, Substance and Stunning Performances
text:
The film opens with a confidence that is immediately disarming. Dhurandar doesn't rush. It watches, listens, and slowly allows its world to unfold with a kind of swagger that comes only from total conviction in writing and craft. Within minutes, you realise you aren't merely watching a film-you're entering a vibrant ecosystem of personalities, egos, secrets and ambitions.

The narrative breathes. Every scene feels measured, yet alive. Dialogues crackle with wit, the dramatic beats never overreach, and the emotional undercurrents are surprisingly tender. There is a tonal balance here - satire, sentiment, and sharp observation - handled with the sort of maturity Hindi cinema rarely attempts today.

Performances are the engine, and what an engine.

Rakesh Bedi, the "yesterday's young comedian" who has seen decades of stage and screen, brings a touch of genius. His rhythm is impeccable. He does not try to be funny - he is funny. Even when silent, the eyes comment, the body responds, and the scene wakes up. He steals moments with the ease of a veteran who knows timing is everything.

Akshay Khanna gives a performance that is both brittle and charismatic. There is a wryness in his smile, a melancholy in his gaze, and a razor hidden behind almost every word. He moves through the film like a man who has seen too much and trusted too little, and the audience senses the fragility beneath the surface. His restraint is thrilling.

And then there is Ranbir Singh. Physically, visually, energetically - he looks like he has walked out of a polished Hollywood frame. The grooming, the attitude, the sinewy precision of his movement, the camera loves him. More importantly, he delivers not only glamour but gravitas. His presence lifts the film. There is a quiet command in his performance, the kind that makes every scene feel more expensive, more international, more stylish.

What stays long after the lights come up is the feeling of pleasure - the pleasure of watching actors who know their craft, a director who respects the story, and a film that never underestimates its audience. Dhurandar is witty without being flippant, emotional without being sentimental, and entertaining without ever becoming hollow.

A rare achievement in contemporary cinema.

A film worth applauding.

author: RumanaA-44

author: Vaibhavs-043
title: A change for good
text:
An absolute spectacle Great acting and direction and to say nothing about the music A must watch.

Dhurandhar is a film that knows exactly what it wants to be-and more importantly, it commits to it with conviction. From its opening moments, the film establishes a strong sense of mood and intent, pulling the audience into a world that feels gritty, intense, and unapologetically rooted in its narrative core. It doesn't rush to impress; instead, it builds its strength steadily, scene by scene.

The performances are one of the film's biggest assets. The lead delivers a commanding portrayal, balancing raw intensity with restraint, making the character both formidable and believable. Supporting performances add depth rather than distraction, ensuring the story never loses focus. There's a grounded realism in the acting that makes even the heightened moments feel earned.

Technically, Dhurandhar stands tall. The cinematography complements the tone beautifully, using light, shadow, and framing to enhance the film's emotional weight. Action sequences are well-staged and impactful, avoiding unnecessary excess and focusing instead on clarity and consequence. The background score deserves special mention-it elevates key moments without overpowering them, reinforcing tension and drama organically.

What truly sets Dhurandhar apart is its confidence in storytelling. It respects the audience's intelligence, allowing silences, expressions, and visual cues to speak as loudly as dialogue. The film doesn't rely on gimmicks; it relies on craft.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a strong, assured cinematic experience-one that blends performance, technique, and narrative discipline into a compelling whole. It's a film that stays with you not because it shouts, but because it knows when to speak softly and hit hard.

author: meet-01
title: üé¨ A Truth-Opener That Dares to Go Beneath the Surface
text:
This film is not just another story - it is a raw, layered truth-opener that exposes how crime, intelligence, and survival quietly intersect beneath society's visible order.

Following a tightly woven network of criminals, informants, and covert operatives, the movie reveals a world where every alliance is fragile, every secret is currency, and every decision has consequences. What makes it stand out is its refusal to glorify crime. Instead, it humanizes the players, showing how desperation, ambition, fear, and loyalty drive people into morally grey territories.

Why this movie deserves to be watched

Interconnected storytelling Multiple lives intersect seamlessly, creating a gripping web of cause and effect.

Realistic espionage tone The covert operations feel grounded and believable, not exaggerated or cinematic fantasy.

Sharp look at betrayal Trust is shown as the most dangerous weapon - once broken, nothing remains the same.

Truth over glamour The film peels away the myth of power, exposing the psychological cost of living in shadows.

Intelligent writing Dialogues carry weight, silences speak loudly, and every move feels intentional.

This is a movie that opens your eyes to how information is traded, how loyalties shift, and how invisible wars are fought without headlines. It respects the audience's intelligence and invites them to think, connect, and question.

If you appreciate serious cinema, layered narratives, and stories that reflect uncomfortable truths, this film is a must-watch. It doesn't shout - it reveals.

Watch it not for spectacle, but for the reality it dares to show.

author: Sidd01
title: A Genre-Defining Masterpiece!
text:
Dhurandhar is a riveting cinematic experience that utterly resets the benchmark for spy-action thrillers. It completely breaks away from tired Bollywood/Pakistan tropes, offering a nuanced, authentic story set against stunningly realized, top-notch sets.

The film is anchored by a collective masterclass in acting; Ranveer Singh is fierce, and Akshaye Khanna delivers one of the best villain performances in years. The narrative is utterly engaging, a perfect cocktail of intense action, thrilling suspense, and genuinely funny light-hearted moments.

The dialogues are awesome-crisp and serving the plot. Adding to the tension is the awesome music and background score by Shashwat Sachdev, which acts as the film's heartbeat.

It is rare to find a film that is technically brilliant, powerfully acted, and deeply engrossing.

author: AmolP-41
title: High-Energy Action and Emotion
text: From its first act, the film establishes a high-stakes, morally complex narrative. Ranveer Singh delivers an immersive performance, seamlessly switching between strategic calculation and emotional intensity. Sanjay Dutt's commanding presence adds weight and menace, while Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan provide nuanced support. Arjun Rampal's understated menace keeps tension taut, and Sara Arjun adds an emotionally resonant presence. Aditya Dhar's direction blends suspense, action, and character development masterfully. Cinematography captures both sprawling urban chaos and intimate character moments, while the score accentuates dramatic tension. The second half escalates into a breathtaking finale of emotion and spectacle.

author: RahulP-419

Action sequences are sharp, realistic, and strategically placed to maintain tension, while cinematography emphasizes mood and scale, enhancing the film's immersive experience. By the final act, every thread converges into a climax that delivers emotional and narrative satisfaction, leaving the audience fully absorbed and reflective on the moral complexities presented.

author: manishadhar
title: A Cinematic Masterpiece - Dhurandhar Shines Bright
text:
Dhurandhar is nothing short of a triumph. It's bold, gripping, and beautifully realized. From the very first frame, the film grips you with its powerful storytelling and refuses to let go. Aditya Dhar proves once again that he is in a league of his own; his direction is nothing short of extraordinary, blending intensity, emotion, and scale with flawless precision.

The cast delivers performances that elevate the film to another level. Akshay Khanna is brilliant and magnetic, bringing nuance and depth to every scene he appears in. Ranveer Singh is electric as always, delivering an energetic and emotionally rich performance.

The script and storytelling are exceptionally tight, engaging, and layered, keeping you invested throughout. The background score deserves special mention; it intensifies the emotional beats and elevates every action sequence, making the film feel grand and immersive.

Dhurandhar is a rare blend of stellar acting, masterful direction, and brilliant writing. An absolute must-watch for anyone who loves impactful cinema.

author: jketankumar83
title: A Masterclass from Aditya Dhar - Gripping, Powerful, and Shockingly Real
text:
A Masterclass from Aditya Dhar - Gripping, Powerful, and Shockingly Real

Aditya Dhar delivers an absolute knockout. This isn't just another action-packed thriller-it's a razor-sharp political spy drama crafted with astonishing technical finesse. The moment it starts, you realize you're watching something rare. Even though it's labeled "inspired by real events," it feels uncannily real, almost like the filmmakers lifted an actual classified operation and put it on screen.

The casting is flawless by Mukesh Chhabra.

Rakesh Bedi, Sanjay Dutt, Akshaye Khanna, Sara Arjun and Many more are in blazing form-commanding, intense, unforgettable. And Ranveer Singh reminds us yet again why he's one of the most powerful actors of this generation. Every scene he's in hits with impact.

The music and background score by Shaswat Sachdev is a beautiful surprise. The use of timeless melodies and perfectly timed songs elevates the emotion without ever slowing the pacing.

Special applause for the editing team. Cutting a long, story-heavy film into something this engaging is a triumph. The interval placement-subtle, without a forced "shock moment"-is exactly how mature filmmaking should be done.

Yes, the film leans into strong contemporary political ideologies, and the story isn't fully complete yet. But honestly? It's still one of the most gripping, well-made spy dramas to come out of Indian cinema in years. A must-watch. 10/10.

Do watch it its rare to see this in bollywood.

author: PrimeX-6
title: Brutality With Purpose
text:
Dhurandar is a relentless, hard-hitting thriller that doesn't flinch from the cost of violence and duty. The film grips you tighter as it moves forward, culminating in a final act so intense and brutal that looking away feels impossible. Performances are raw and convincing, the action is grounded and unsensationalized, and the emotional weight - clearly inspired by real-world counter-terror realities - hits deep. Rather than glorifying heroism, Dhurandar forces the audience to sit with its consequences.

Verdict: Dark, uncompromising, and unforgettable - Dhurandar earns its intensity and leaves a lasting impact.

author: Sharad-210
title: Realistic, Grounded, Killer Casting and Acting
text:
Dhurandhar is a gripping and emotionally charged drama that stands out for its powerful storytelling and strong cinematic identity. From the very first frame, the film immerses the audience in a world where ambition, morality, and inner conflict collide, creating a narrative that is as entertaining as it is thought-provoking.

What truly elevates Dhurandhar is its character-driven narrative. The protagonist is written with remarkable depth-flawed, determined, vulnerable, and relentless. His journey is not just a linear progression but a layered transformation, marked by moments of triumph, introspection, and intense struggle. The supporting cast also delivers equally compelling performances, ensuring that every emotional beat lands with authenticity.

The direction is tight and confident, with each scene crafted to serve the story. The pacing is steady and engaging, balancing high-tension moments with quieter, reflective sequences that give the audience space to breathe. The writing is sharp, filled with dialogues that resonate long after the credits roll. It avoids clich√©s and instead presents a fresh, grounded perspective on themes like loyalty, identity, and personal redemption.

Visually, the film is stunning. The cinematography perfectly captures the mood-whether it's the intensity of confrontational scenes or the subtle beauty of character-driven moments. The music and background score complement the narrative beautifully, enhancing emotions without overpowering them.

What makes Dhurandhar truly impactful is its ability to maintain emotional honesty. It is not just a story; it is an experience-one that leaves the viewer thinking about the choices we make and the consequences we face.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a must-watch for audiences who appreciate meaningful cinema with strong performances, engaging drama, and a story that stays with you. It is bold, heartfelt, and brilliantly executed.

A must see!!

title: Full of Action, Drama, and Star Energy

author: kaushikaditya-89632

text:
Dhurandhar is a full paisa-vasool movie that keeps you hooked from start to end. The story is strong, emotional, and has that raw desi feel which connects directly with the audience.

author: SanskarK-97
title: A Relentless Thriller Revealing the Hidden Threats Behind India's Security Challenges
text:
Dhurandhar is a gripping and unapologetic political thriller that dives straight into the uncomfortable truths the film wants to highlight. The narrative boldly portrays how, within the movie's storyline, Pakistan as a country along with its government and sections of the Pakistan Army is shown to actively support terrorism. The film makes this theme central, illustrating how extremist outfits are funded, sheltered, and encouraged to operate against India. Groups inspired by ISIS and other terror organizations are shown receiving systematic backing, creating a chilling picture of state-linked destabilization.

Another striking layer of Dhurandhar is its portrayal of India's internal political decisions. The film does not hesitate to suggest that during the UPA government era, several crucial national security concerns were overlooked. It showcases how intelligence warnings, terror-related indicators, and sensitive geopolitical signals were, according to the film's viewpoint, ignored or sidelined, leading to gaps that compromised India's internal security framework.

Despite dealing with complex political themes, Dhurandhar never loses its cinematic grip. The screenplay is sharp, the pacing intense, and the tension is sustained throughout. The lead performances add weight and credibility, capturing the struggle of intelligence officers fighting not only hostile forces across the border but also bureaucratic hesitation and political missteps at home.

Overall, Dhurandhar is a bold, thought-provoking film that raises difficult questions about governance, terrorism, and the unseen pressures shaping India's stability. It is a must-watch for anyone who appreciates powerful, politically charged storytelling that resonates long after the credits roll.

author: dubeyhritwika

It is a massive, must-see spectacle that ignites national pride and confirms Aditya Dhar as a master storyteller of courage and justice.

author: JOY02kDAS
title: December, 2025 turns into Dhurandhar 2025!!
text:
For years, Bollywood espionage was a landscape of secularly balanced sugarcoating and safe narratives. But Aditya Dhar-the captain of URI-has dismantled that blueprint. With 'Dhurandhar,' he delivers a masterclass in 'unapologetic nationalism' that is as technically brilliant as it is emotionally devastating. By dividing the film into chapters, Dhar gives the audience breathing space in a narrative that moves with the speed of a galloping local, meticulously building the 'Why' before diving into the high-octane 'How' of the mission. The intermediate chapters plunge the viewer into the chaotic belly of Lyari, where the film transcends traditional action-drama. It is here that we see the mission evolve from a strategy on a map to a desperate fight for survival. Dhar's mastery lies in his ability to reveal character through conflict-every bullet fired and every silent stare tells us exactly what these men are fighting for.

The soul of the film, however, lies in its most haunting sequence: the moment the screen is bathed in red. In those few minutes, as a conversation pierces the silence, the theater transforms. It isn't just cinema anymore; it is a visceral encounter with a national scar that shatters the soul to its core. Every countryman of Bharat felt a pain beyond words-a moment of collective grief that serves as the fuel for the fire that follows.

The performances are, without question, the heartbeat of this project:

Ranveer Singh delivers his most disciplined performance yet-cold, calculated, and stripped of all flamboyance.

Akshaye Khanna, the "aura farmer," commands the screen with a gravitational pull that only a veteran of his caliber could provide.

R. Madhavan, as the "Silent Signal" Sanyal, is the film's moral and intellectual anchor, proving that sometimes the loudest impact is made in total silence.

Arjun Rampal brings an intimidating physicality that injects a much needed sense of menace in his character. While Sanjay Dutt's intense performance adds a layer of seasoned wisdom. Newcomer Sara Arjun is a cheerful revelation, filling her shoes with a maturity that anchors the emotional stakes.

The technical craft is the final piece of this perfect puzzle. Shashwat Sachdev's score isn't just background music; it is the film's pulse, pounding in sync with the audience's heartbeat.

The cinematography captures the grit of Lyari and the vastness of the mission's scope with a visual language that is both poetic and brutal.

Aditya Dhar has doubled his efforts, proving that Uri was no fluke. Every frame of Dhurandhar feels organic, masterfully crafted, and earned. It is a project that doesn't just meet expectations-it Clinches cinematic brilliance and redefines nationalism for a new era.

Dhurandhar hasn't just arrived; it has conquered. So much so that it has turned December 2025 into DHURANDHAR 2025!!

author: getkenny
title: You too Brutus??
text:
Every once in a while, a film comes along that reminds you why you fell in love with cinema in the first place. Dhurandar is that film.

From the opening scene, you're swept into a masterclass in storytelling. Aditya Dhar weaves a sprawling, 3.5-hour epic that somehow does not feel long. The entire theater sat in silence-glued to their seats, breathless. The film's clever chapter-by-chapter structure is pure genius. Each segment builds like a well-paced novel, and one stunning chapter even draws bold inspiration from Shakespeare's Julius Caesar.

The music is rocket fuel for this film. It doesn't just sit in the background; it drives scenes forward, lifts emotions, and pushes the story to its full potential, like powering a high-performance engine.

When it comes to action and visual effects, Dhurandar delivers something rare in Bollywood: raw, brutal & unfiltered. Here, the action feels real, gritty, and visceral-reminding me of the savage intensity of Mad Max. It's honest and utterly thrilling.

But the true magic lies in the performances. Ranveer Singh transforms completely -a sher amongst lions like Scar from The Lion King.

Akshaye Khanna delivers a performance for the ages. His character is so deeply felt, so unforgettable, it will echo in film history-much like his Sid in iconic Dil Chahta Hai.

Rakesh Bedi, meanwhile, slips into the skin of a spineless politician with such precision it feels like a tailor-made glove. And then there's Madhavan and Arjun Rampal: both radiating menace, but standing on opposite ends of the spectrum.

Yes, Dhurandar touches on real-world politics. And why shouldn't it? Cinema has always been a mirror to society-a place where we confront hard truths, celebrate our struggles, and imagine a better world. To dismiss a film because it dares to address issues threatening our nation's freedom is to miss the point of art entirely.

Dhurandar isn't just a movie; it's a celebration of everything great about cinema. If you love film, see this. It will remind you why you do.

Ps: I am also glad the next part comes sooner than later.

text: From the opening scene, Dhurandhar grabs your attention and never lets go. Ranveer Singh is phenomenal, full of energy and emotion. author: mk-48750
title: Forget flying cars. Dhurandhar brings raw, bone-crunching hand-to-hand combat that feels dangerously real. This is action with consequences.
text:
Aditya Dhar has done it again. Moving past the high-josh of Uri, Dhurandhar dives deep into the gritty, shadowy world of covert ops, and the result is spectacular. This isn't a polished, stylish spy fest; it is a raw, bloody, and intense slow-burn that keeps you on edge for nearly nearly 3.5 hours.

Ranveer Singh delivers a career-defining performance as Hamza, stripping away his usual energy for a simmering, intense portrayal of a spy living on a knife's edge. But the surprise package is Akshaye Khanna-his portrayal of Rehman Dakait is chilling, understated, and absolutely magnetic.

The film's 'chapter' structure gives it a novel-like depth, and the action sequences are grounded in realism rather than gravity-defying stunts. While the runtime is long, the payoff in the final act (and that cliffhanger!) makes every minute worth it.

Verdict: A brutal, brilliant, and brave piece of cinema. Don't wait for OTT-experience the sound design and tension in a theater.

author: ashrut-jain
title: When the time comes nothing can stop an actor.
text:

author: SapnaK-68
title: üáÆüá≥üé¨ Dhurandhar - Review (No Spoilers)
text:
Dhurandhar is not just a film - it feels like an experience that stays with you even after you leave the theatre. The storytelling is strong and smooth, and at no point does it feel forced. The narrative pulls you in quietly and keeps you emotionally connected till the end.

What truly stands out is how real and believable everything feels. Every actor has performed with honesty - no overacting, no unnecessary drama. The emotions, dialogues, and reactions feel natural, making the characters feel like real people rather than reel heroes.

This film carries a deep sense of respect for India and its true fighters - especially the Army and the countless unknown soldiers whose sacrifices often go unnoticed. The emotions are subtle but powerful, and they hit you at the right moments without being loud.

The direction is mature, the background score supports the mood beautifully, and the film gives space to silence where needed - which makes the impact even stronger. It's the kind of cinema that makes you feel proud, emotional, and reflective at the same time.

Everyone who truly loves India, respects our soldiers, and believes in the sacrifices of our brave men and women should watch this film at least once in theatres. Some stories deserve to be experienced on the big screen.

‚≠ê Highly recommended.

author: vijayaryan-26216
title: My Salute
text:
Finally, something good from Bollywood after so long! Or maybe I should say it was almost perfect-just take out the Ajit Doval scenes. I know they were a necessary part of the story, but they didn't quite fit the flow. Other than that, my god, the film was on absolute steroids, especially in the chaotically beautiful second half.

It was full of an amazing cast and sets that made me feel like I was living in dirty 2000s Karachi. The action was some of-if not the-greatest in any Bollywood film. Some scenes were so jaw-dropping that I forgot to breathe while my jaw kept dropping lower and lower.

And finally, the boldness to portray the story in its truest form. Salute to all those unknown gunmen who do such things, living in these harsh conditions for years without seeing their families, where danger lurks around every corner and you could die at any second. Why do they do it? I am sure they aren't going to have immense wealth or a dream of a happy, nice life afterward. Is it only the love for our nation (which is imperfect in so many ways) that makes them carry out these tasks? Maybe these great men have hope that someday this country will thrive. No matter how many corrupt politicians, selfish businessmen, or 'sar tan se juda' gangs persist, Hindustan has never knelt, and it won't in the future.

author: imdbfan-4644583677
title: High-Octane Action with a Stellar Cast
text: The narrative slowly tightens its grip, immersing audiences in a world of danger, loyalty, and moral conflict. Ranveer Singh anchors the story with precision, Sanjay Dutt commands presence, and Akshaye Khanna and R Madhavan add complexity. Arjun Rampal's menace and Sara Arjun's emotional performance raise the stakes. Aditya Dhar's direction integrates suspense, strategy, and action seamlessly. Cinematography captures both vast chaos and intimate moments, and the sound design accentuates tension. By the climax, the film delivers an unforgettable cinematic experience.

author: samyachatterjee
title: Best spy movie I have watched in recent years
text:
I finally caught Dhurandhar in theaters this weekend, and honestly, I'm still recovering. If you're on the fence about committing to a 3.5 Hour runtime, just go for it this isn't your typical polished spy thriller; it's a gritty, violent, and absolutely relentless beast of a film.

The Vibe: Director Aditya Dhar (of Uri fame) has completely flipped the script here. Instead of glossy locations, we get dropped straight into the claustrophobic, chaotic alleyways of Lyari, Karachi. The atmosphere is suffocating in the best way possible. You can practically feel the dust and tension. It feels less like a standard Bollywood actioner and more like a raw crime saga think Gangs of Wasseypur meets intense espionage.

The Performances: Ranveer Singh is, expectedly, a powerhouse. Playing Hamza Ali Mazari (an undercover Indian spy), he sheds his usual flamboyant energy for something much darker and more feral. There are moments where he doesn't even speak, just conveys sheer panic and resolve with his eyes.

But-and I can't believe I'm saying this-Akshaye Khanna steals the show. As the gangster Rehman Dakait, he is terrifyingly calm and charismatic. Every time he's on screen, the tension spikes. The dynamic between him and Ranveer is the heartbeat of the movie. Also, seeing Arjun Rampal back as the menacing ISI agent Major Iqbal and R. Madhavan as the intelligence chief brings such a solid weight to the cast.

The Music & Action The background score by Shashwat Sachdev is pulsating and heavy, perfectly matching the on-screen violence. Speaking of violence-be warned, this is a hard "A" rated film. The action is brutal, messy, and looks painfully real.

The Verdict: Is it perfect? Maybe not. It's long, and the political undertones might be heavy for some. But as a piece of cinema, it's a massive achievement. The cliffhanger ending sets up the sequel perfectly.

Bottom Line: Don't wait for OTT. This is a theatrical experience. Watch it for the scale, the insane performances, and the fact that Bollywood finally made a spy film that feels dangerous.

title: Worst
text:
Dhurandar - Movie Review

Dhurandar is a completely bakwas movie and a total waste of time. The story is weak and confusing, with no proper flow or purpose. Scenes feel random, and there is nothing in the film that keeps the audience engaged.

The acting is poor and looks forced. Dialogues are boring and sometimes cringe-worthy, making serious scenes unintentionally funny. Direction and editing are also very bad-the movie feels unnecessarily long and slow, with many useless scenes.

author: northwest21
title: Loved this movie but with one evident flaw
text:
No doubt this is a masterpiece. This movie has the potential to redefine Indian cinema like Satya. Everyone was perfect for their role. But I found one serious flaw which almost killed my interest.

At the end, in the car, Rehman picks a blade to fight Hamza. But when SP Chaudary shoots at Rehman, Rehman and Donga had every type of gun to defend themselves. They had every opportunity to kill Hamza with all the guns they had but instead use a blade.

Instead, the guns should've been in the trunk and when SP attacks them, breaking the back windshield from the back seat and taking the guns would've been more convincing.

author: AyushS-8972
title: Good
text:
Dhurandar is a lively, crowd-pleasing entertainer that blends action, comedy, and emotional drama with surprising finesse. At its core, the film is driven by its charismatic lead, whose performance anchors the story even when the plot occasionally leans on familiar tropes. What makes Dhurandar engaging is not just its hero-centric narrative, but the way it uses humor and heartfelt moments to maintain an energetic rhythm from start to finish.

The story follows Dhurandar, a street-smart problem solver with a knack for turning chaotic situations into opportunities. When he becomes entangled in a local political conspiracy, the film shifts gears from light comedy to a more layered drama, revealing the vulnerabilities beneath his swagger. The screenplay balances these tonal shifts well, giving the character a satisfying arc that extends beyond the usual "larger-than-life" persona.

Supporting characters add color and depth, particularly the comic sidekick and the sharp, grounded female lead who often steals scenes with her wit. The villain, though somewhat formulaic, delivers enough menace to keep the stakes high. The dialogue is punchy and clever, offering plenty of memorable lines without feeling forced.

Technically, Dhurandar shines with its vibrant cinematography and energetic action sequences. The music is catchy and well-placed, enhancing both the emotional beats and the high-octane moments. A few pacing issues appear in the second half, where the plot dips into predictable territory, but the film quickly recovers with a strong, satisfying finale.

Overall, Dhurandar is an enjoyable, well-crafted entertainer that knows exactly what it wants to be. It delivers humor, heart, and heroism in equal measure-making it a worthy watch for fans of commercial cinema.

If you'd like, I can also write a negative review, spoiler-filled analysis, or shorter/longer versions.

author: IAmStacey69
title: A Bold and Unfiltered Political Thriller
text:
Dhurandhar is the kind of film that doesn't try to play safe. It directly points out how weak and confused the UP government looks when it comes to handling serious threats. The movie also doesn't hesitate to show Pakistan as a state that openly shelters and supports terrorism, and that bluntness actually gives the story a lot of weight.

What stands out is how real the frustration feels. The pacing is tight, the tension keeps building, and the political commentary hits hard without getting preachy. Whether someone agrees with its viewpoint or not, the movie stays confident in what it wants to say.

Overall, Dhurandhar works because it's bold, gritty, and not afraid to call out the things we usually tiptoe around. If you enjoy politically charged stories that mirror real-world messiness, this one delivers.

author: invincible-virus
title: Commercial movie with misleading content
text:
The movie is good as long as audience know that they are watching fiction for the purpose of entertainment. However, there are mentions about real incidences and real footage has been show at few places; this misleads the audience into thinking that they are watching dramatization of actual events.

No real spy can survive as per the script of the movie and some turns of the story can only happen in fantasy - like daughter of a politician going against her father for a henchman and a politician who is too stupid and weak.

author: Aditya_Bhattacharyya
title: Dhurandhar: A Brutal, Unflinching Spy Thriller That Raises the Bar
text:
Mind-blowing and absolutely gripping, Dhurandhar is easily one of the most realistic spy films to come out of India. In tone and intent, it reminded me of Munich-but with far more relentless, hard-hitting action. Not for a single second does the film lose momentum; there is no filler, no boredom, only constant tension.

What truly sets Dhurandhar apart is its courage. It is unapologetic and brutally honest in its worldview, calling a spade a spade. It dares to call out the real enemies of India, clearly showing that the most dangerous threats to the country often come from within India itself, while Pakistan comes next. This clarity is rare in Bollywood, especially in a genre usually diluted with fantasy and politically safe storytelling.

The inner struggle of an Indian spy is portrayed with depth and realism-lonely, morally complex, and emotionally exhausting. The action sequences are raw and savage, and the Parliament attack footage, along with the chilling audio clips between cross-border hostile operatives and their handlers, sends shivers down the spine. These elements give the film a dark, haunting, and unforgettable vibe.

The music deserves special mention-totally energetic and operating at a different level altogether. The fusion of rap with Punjabi and qawwali elements creates powerful vibes and elevates the tension and intensity of the film brilliantly.

The set design is shockingly realistic. The recreation of Lyari Town in Bangkok is so authentic that you never once feel it was shot outside its actual location. It is a masterclass in immersive production design.

Casting and performances are excellent across the board. Ranveer is restrained, precise, and deeply impactful. Akshay delivers the character and performance of a lifetime. Arjun Rampal and Madhavan bring the same level of gravitas and conviction, while Rakesh Bedi leaves a strong impression as well. Every actor feels perfectly placed.

Editing and cinematography are top-notch, maintaining relentless pace while capturing the grit, brutality, and emotional weight of the story with precision.

This film single-handedly dismantles the glossy, shallow spy universes with trash storylines. Eagerly waiting for Part 2 in March 2026.

author: sharmamanan-39149
title: Another gem from Aditya Dhar üíé
text:
Movie Review üé¨ - Dhurandhar Runtime: 3h 34m Public Rating: 3.75/5 Personal Rating:4.5/5 + Spectacular cinematography & performances from all characters, each getting equal screen time + The first half offers an engaging setup of characters & gang-war politics + The second half stays closer to reality - many moments are inspired by real events + Raw action sequences + The love story is short & subtle + R. Madhavan's acting & dialogues + Exposes ISI & terrorist networks in Pakistan

  • Some viewers may find the film lengthy (but for me, it was engaging)
  • Contains lots of abusive language, which could've been muted for family audiences, as there is no nudity in the film, and these days family audiences are fine with R-rated violent action & bloodshed
  • I don't like films that become overly dramatic just to portray patriotism, but Dhurandhar doesn't even try to evoke a sense of patriotism in us - something Uri: The Surgical Strike did successfully


My PUBLIC RATING for the movie is 3.75, but my PERSONAL RATING is 4.5.

I never felt the runtime was too long - in fact, it was necessary; otherwise, the story would have felt confusing.

I don't mind that the movie isn't fully family-friendly because of the abusive language. Families with kids usually tolerate violence but avoid films with abuses or nudity. That's why I'm a bit disappointed, a film made in the national interest should have been suitable for kids & young ones.
